PART 1  9 
SHORT TIT LE, CONSTRUCTION AND  GENERAL PROVISIONS  10 
§1-101.  Short title  11 
This Title may be known and cited as "the Maine Uniform Probate Code."  12 
§1-102.  Purposes; rule of construction  13 
1.  Liberal construction.  This Code must be liberally construed and applied to 14 
prom ote its underlying purposes and policies.  15 
2.  Purposes and policies.  The underlying purposes and policies of this Code are to:  16 
A.  Simplify and clarify the law concerning the affairs of decedents, missing persons, 17 
protected persons, minors and incapacitat ed persons;  18 
B.  Discover and make effective the intent of a decedent in the distribution of the 19 
decedent's property;  20 
C.  Promote a speedy and efficient system for liquidating the estate of the decedent 21 
and making distribution to the decedent's successors;  22 
D.  Facilitate use and enforcement of certain trusts; and  23 
E.  Make uniform the law among the various jurisdictions.  24 
§1-103.  Supplementary general principles of law applicable  25 
Unless displaced by the provisions of this Code, the principles of law and equit y 26 
supplement its provisions.  27 
 
 Page 2 - 128LR0452(01) -1 
 §1-104.  Construction against implied repeal  1 
This Code is a general act intended to provide unified coverage of its subject matter 2 
and no part of it may be considered impliedly repealed by subsequent legislation if it can 3 
reaso nably be avoided.  4 
§1-105.  Effect of fraud and evasion  5 
Whenever fraud has been perpetrated in connection with any proceeding or in any 6 
statement filed under this Code or if fraud is used to avoid or circumvent the provisions 7 
or purposes of this Code, any p erson injured by the fraud may obtain appropriate relief 8 
against the perpetrator of the fraud or restitution from any person, other than a bona fide 9 
purchaser, benefiting from the fraud, whether innocent or not.  A proceeding must be 10 
commenced within 2 yea rs after the discovery of the fraud, but a proceeding may not be 11 
brought against a person who is not a perpetrator of the fraud later than 6 years after the 12 
time of commission of the fraud.  This section has no bearing on remedies relating to 13 
fraud practic ed on a decedent during the decedent's lifetime that affects the succession of 14 
the decedent's estate.  15 
§1-106.  Evidence as to death or status  16 
In proceedings under this Code, the rules of evidence in courts of general jurisdiction, 17 
including any relating to  simultaneous deaths, are applicable unless specifically displaced 18 
by the Code or by rules adopted under section 1 -304.  In addition, notwithstanding Title 19 
22, section 2707, the following provisions relating to determination of death and status 20 
are applica ble. 21 
1.  Application of Uniform Determination of Death Act.  Death occurs when an 22 
individual is determined to be dead under the Uniform Determination of Death Act.  23 
2.  Death certificate as prima facie evidence.  A certified or authenticated copy of a 24 
death  certificate purporting to be issued by an official or agency of the place where the 25 
death purportedly occurred is prima facie evidence of the fact, place, date and time of 26 
death and the identity of the decedent.  27 
3.  Government record as prima facie eviden ce.  A certified or authenticated copy 28 
of any record or report of a governmental agency, domestic or foreign, asserting that a 29 
person is missing, detained, dead or alive is prima facie evidence of the status and of the 30 
dates, circumstances and places discl osed by the record or report.  31 
4.  Absence of record; clear and convincing evidence required.  In the absence of 32 
prima facie evidence of death under subsection 2 or 3, the fact of death may be 33 
established by clear and convincing evidence, including circumst antial evidence.  34 
5.  Presumption of death after 5 -year absence.  An individual whose death is not 35 
established under subsections 1 to 4, who is absent for a continuous period of 5 years, 36 
during which the individual has not been heard from, and whose absence  is not 37 
satisfactorily explained after diligent search or inquiry is presumed to be dead.  Death is 38 
presumed to have occurred at the end of the period unless there is sufficient evidence for 39 
determining that death occurred earlier.  40 
 
 Page 3 - 128LR0452(01) -1 
 6.  Document as evidence  of time of death.  In the absence of evidence disputing 1 
the time of death stated on a document described in subsection 2 or 3, a document 2 
described in subsection 2 or 3 that states a time of death 120 hours or more after the time 3 
of death of another indiv idual, however the time of death of the other individual is 4 
determined, establishes by clear and convincing evidence that the individual survived the 5 
other individual by 120 hours.  6 
§1-107.  Acts by holder of general power  7 
For the purpose of granting consen t or approval with regard to the acts or accounts of 8 
a personal representative or trustee, including relief from liability or penalty for failure to 9 
post bond or to perform other duties, and for purposes of consenting to modification or 10 
termination of a tr ust or to deviation from its terms, the sole holder or all co -holders of a 11 
presently exercisable general power of appointment, including one in the form of a power 12 
of amendment or revocation, are deemed to act for beneficiaries to the extent their 13 
interest s, as objects, takers in default or otherwise, are subject to the power.  14 
§1-108.  Cost -of-living adjustment of certain dollar amounts  15 
1.  Definitions.  As used in this section, unless the context otherwise indicates, the 16 
following terms have the following meanings.  17 
A.  "Consumer Price Index" means the Consumer Price Index, Annual Average, for 18 
All Urban Consumers, CPI -U: U.S. City Average, All items, reported by the United 19 
States Department of Labor, Bureau of Labor Statistics, or its successor or, if the 20 
index is discontinued, an equivalent index reported by a federal authority or, if no 21 
such index is reported, "Consumer Price Index" means a comparable index chosen by 22 
the Bureau of Labor Statistics.  23 
B.  "Reference base index" means the Consumer Price Index f or calendar year 2017.  24 
2.  Automatic adjustment of amounts for inflation.  The dollar amounts stated in 25 
sections 2 -102, 2 -402, 2 -403 and 2 -405 apply to the estate of a decedent who died in or 26 
after 2017, but for the estate of a decedent who died after 2018 , these dollar amounts 27 
must be increased or decreased if the Consumer Price Index for the calendar year 28 
immediately preceding the year of death exceeds or is less than the reference base index.  29 
The amount of any increase or decrease is computed by multipl ying each dollar amount 30 
by the percentage by which the Consumer Price Index for the calendar year immediately 31 
preceding the year of death exceeds or is less than the reference base index.  If any 32 
increase or decrease produced by the computation is not a mu ltiple of $100, the increase 33 
or decrease is rounded down, if an increase, or up, if a decrease, to the next multiple of 34 
$100, but for the purpose of section 2 -405, the periodic installment amount is the lump - 35 
sum amount divided by 12.  If the Consumer Price  Index for 2018 is changed by the 36 
United States Department of Labor, Bureau of Labor Statistics, the reference base index 37 
must be revised using the rebasing factor reported by the Bureau of Labor Statistics or 38 
other comparable data if a rebasing factor is not reported.  39 
 
 Page 4 - 128LR0452(01) -1 
 §1-109.  Transfer for value  1 
Any recorded instrument described in this Code on which the register of deeds notes 2 
by an appropriate stamp "Maine Real Estate Transfer Tax Paid" is prima facie evidence 3 
that the transfer was made for value.  4 
§1-110.  Powers of fiduciaries relating to compliance with environmental laws  5 
1.  Fiduciary powers to comply with environmental law.  From the inception of 6 
the trust or estate, a fiduciary has the following powers, without court authorization, 7 
which the fiduciar y may use in the fiduciary's sole discretion to comply with 8 
environmental law:  9 
A.  To inspect and monitor property held by the fiduciary, including interests in sole 10 
proprietorships, partnerships or corporations and any assets owned by any such 11 
business en terprise, for the purpose of determining compliance with environmental 12 
law affecting the property and to respond to any actual or threatened violation of any 13 
environmental law affecting the property held by the fiduciary;  14 
B.  To take, on behalf of the trus t or estate, any action necessary to prevent, abate or 15 
otherwise remedy any actual or threatened violation of any environmental law 16 
affecting property held by the fiduciary, either before or after the initiation of an 17 
enforcement action by any governmental  body;  18 
C.  To refuse to accept property if the fiduciary determines that any property to be 19 
donated to the trust or estate either is contaminated by any hazardous substance or is 20 
being used or has been used for any activity directly or indirectly involving  any 21 
hazardous substance that could result in liability to the trust or estate or otherwise 22 
impair the value of the assets held in the trust or estate.  This paragraph does not 23 
apply to property in the trust or estate at its inception;  24 
D.  To settle or com promise at any time any claims against the trust or estate that may 25 
be asserted by any governmental body or private party involving the alleged violation 26 
of any environmental law affecting property held in trust or in an estate;  27 
E.  To disclaim any power g ranted by any document, statute or rule of law that, in the 28 
sole discretion of the fiduciary, may cause the fiduciary to incur personal liability 29 
under any environmental law; and  30 
F.  To decline to serve or to resign as a fiduciary if the fiduciary reasonab ly believes 31 
that there is or may be a conflict of interest between the fiduciary's fiduciary capacity 32 
and the fiduciary's individual capacity because of potential claims or liabilities that 33 
may be asserted against the fiduciary on behalf of the trust or es tate because of the 34 
type or condition of assets held in the trust or estate.  35 
2.  Definitions.  For purposes of this section, "environmental law" means any federal, 36 
state or local law, rule, regulation or ordinance relating to protection of the environment 37 
or human health.  For purposes of this section, "hazardous substance" has the meaning set 38 
forth in Title 38, section 1362, subsection 1.  39 
3.  Costs assessed to trust or estate.  The fiduciary may charge the cost of any 40 
inspection, review, abatement, respons e, cleanup or remedial action authorized in this 41 
 
 Page 5 - 128LR0452(01) -1 
 section against the income or principal of the trust or estate.  A fiduciary is not personally 1 
liable to any beneficiary or other party for any decrease in value of assets in trust or in an 2 
estate by reason of the fiduciary's compliance with any environmental law, specifically 3 
including any reporting requirement under the law.  Neither the acceptance by the 4 
fiduciary of property nor a failure by the fiduciary to inspect property creates an inference 5 
as to whe ther there is or may be any liability under any environmental law with respect to 6 
the property.  7 
4.  Compliance with environmental law not a conflict of interest.  The exercise by 8 
a fiduciary of any of the powers granted in this section does not constitute a transaction 9 
that is affected by a substantial conflict of interest on the part of the fiduciary.  10 
5.  Application and effective date.  This section applies to all trusts and estates in 11 
existence on and created after July 1, 1994.  12 
§1-111.  Guardian ad lite m 13 
1.  Appointment order.  In any proceeding under this Code for which the court may 14 
appoint a guardian ad litem for a child involved in the proceeding, at the time of the 15 
appointment, the court shall specify the guardian ad litem's length of appointment, d uties 16 
and fee arrangements.  17 
2.  Qualifications.  A guardian ad litem appointed on or after October 1, 2005 must 18 
meet the qualifications established by the Supreme Judicial Court.  19 
3.  Release of information and access to child.  If, in order to perform the guardian 20 
ad litem's duties, the guardian ad litem needs information concerning the child or parents, 21 
the court may order the parents to sign an authorization form allowing the release of the 22 
necessary information.  The guardian ad litem must be allowed acc ess to the child by 23 
caretakers of the child, whether the caretakers are individuals, authorized agencies or 24 
child care providers.  25 
4.  Best interest of the child.  The guardian ad litem shall use the standard of the best 26 
interest of the child as set forth i n Title 19 -A, section 1653, subsection 3.  The guardian 27 
ad litem shall make the wishes of the child known to the court if the child has expressed 28 
them, regardless of the recommendation of the guardian ad litem.  29 
5.  Written report; admissibility.  If requir ed by the court, the guardian ad litem 30 
shall make a final written report to the parties and the court reasonably in advance of a 31 
hearing.  The report is admissible as evidence and subject to cross -examination and 32 
rebuttal, whether or not objected to by a p arty. 33 
6.  Quasi -judicial immunity.  A person appointed by the court as a guardian ad litem 34 
acts as the court's agent and is entitled to quasi -judicial immunity for acts performed 35 
within the scope of the duties of the guardian ad litem.  36 
7.  Notice of other proceedings.  A guardian ad litem must be given notice of all 37 
civil or criminal hearings and proceedings, including, but not limited to, grand juries, in 38 
which the child is a party or a witness.  The guardian ad litem shall protect the best 39 
 
 Page 6 - 128LR0452(01) -1 
 interest of the  child in those hearings and proceedings, unless otherwise ordered by the 1 
court.  2 
PART 2  3 
DEFINITIONS  4 
§1-201.  Definitions  5 
As used in this Code, unless the context otherwise indicates, the following terms have 6 
the following meanings.  7 
1.  Agent.  "Agent" incl udes an attorney -in-fact under a durable or nondurable power 8 
of attorney, an individual authorized to make decisions concerning another's health care 9 
and an individual authorized to make decisions for another under the Uniform Health 10 
Care Decisions Act.  11 
2.  Application.  "Application" means a written request to the register for an order of 12 
informal probate or appointment under Article 3, Part 3.  13 
3.  Beneficiary.  "Beneficiary," as it relates to a trust beneficiary, includes a person 14 
who has any present or f uture interest, vested or contingent, and also includes the owner 15 
of an interest by assignment or other transfer; as it relates to a charitable trust, includes 16 
any person entitled to enforce the trust; as it relates to a beneficiary of a beneficiary 17 
design ation, refers to a beneficiary of an insurance or annuity policy, of an account with 18 
POD designation, of a security registered in beneficiary form, TOD, or of a pension, 19 
profit -sharing, retirement or similar benefit plan or other nonprobate transfer at dea th; 20 
and, as it relates to a beneficiary designated in a governing instrument, includes a grantee 21 
of a deed, a devisee, a trust beneficiary, a beneficiary of a beneficiary designation, a 22 
donee, appointee or taker in default of a power of appointment and a p erson in whose 23 
favor a power of attorney or a power held in any individual, fiduciary or representative 24 
capacity is exercised.  25 
4.  Beneficiary designation.  "Beneficiary designation" means a governing 26 
instrument naming a beneficiary of an insurance or annu ity policy, of an account with 27 
POD designation, of a security registered in beneficiary form, TOD, or of a pension, 28 
profit -sharing, retirement or similar benefit plan or other nonprobate transfer at death.  29 
5.  Child.  "Child" includes any individual entitl ed to take as a child under this Code 30 
by intestate succession from the parent whose relationship is involved and excludes any 31 
person who has no other relationship to the parent than as a stepchild, a foster child, a 32 
grandchild or any more remote descendant . 33 
6.  Claims.  "Claims," in respect to estates of decedents and protected persons, 34 
includes liabilities of the decedent or protected person whether arising in contract, in tort 35 
or otherwise, and liabilities of the estate that arise at or after the death of  the decedent or 36 
after the appointment of a conservator, including funeral expenses and expenses of 37 
administration.  "Claims" does not include estate or inheritance taxes, or demands or 38 
disputes regarding title of a decedent or protected person to specific  assets alleged to be 39 
included in the estate.  40 
 
 Page 7 - 128LR0452(01) -1 
 7.  Conservator.  "Conservator" means a person who is appointed by a court to 1 
manage the estate of a protected person.  "Conservator" includes a limited conservator.  2 
8.  Court.  "Court" means any one of the sev eral courts of probate of this State 3 
established as provided in Title 4, sections 201 and 202.  4 
9.  Descendant.  "Descendant," as it relates to an individual, means all of the 5 
individual's descendants of all generations.  The relationship of parent and chil d at each 6 
generation is determined by the definition of "parent" and "child" contained in this Code.  7 
10.  Devise.  "Devise" when used as a noun means a testamentary disposition of real 8 
or personal property and when used as a verb means to dispose of real o r personal 9 
property by will.  10 
11.  Devisee.  "Devisee" means any person designated in a will to receive a devise.  11 
For the purposes of Article 3, in the case of a devise to an existing trust or trustee, or to a 12 
trustee or trust described by will, "devisee" includes the trust or trustee but not the 13 
beneficiaries.  14 
12.  Disability.  "Disability" means cause for a protective order as described by 15 
section 5 -401. 16 
13.  Distributee.  "Distributee" means any person who has received property of a 17 
decedent from the per sonal representative other than as creditor or purchaser.  A 18 
testamentary trustee is a distributee only to the extent of the distributed assets or 19 
increment of distributed assets remaining in the trustee's possession.  A beneficiary of a 20 
testamentary trust  to whom the trustee has distributed property received from a personal 21 
representative is a distributee of the personal representative.  For purposes of this 22 
provision, "testamentary trustee" includes a trustee to whom assets are transferred by will, 23 
to the  extent of the devised assets.  24 
14.  Domestic partner.  "Domestic partner" means one of 2 unmarried adults who 25 
are domiciled together under long -term arrangements that evidence a commitment to 26 
remain responsible indefinitely for each other's welfare.  27 
15.  Estate.  "Estate" includes the property of the decedent, trust or other person 28 
whose affairs are subject to this Code as originally constituted and as it exists from time 29 
to time during administration.  30 
16.  Exempt property.  "Exempt property" means that pro perty of a decedent's estate 31 
that is described in section 2 -403. 32 
17.  Fiduciary.  "Fiduciary" includes a personal representative, guardian, conservator 33 
and trustee.  34 
18.  Foreign personal representative.  "Foreign personal representative" means a 35 
personal r epresentative appointed by another jurisdiction.  36 
 
 Page 8 - 128LR0452(01) -1 
 19.  Formal proceedings.  "Formal proceedings" means proceedings within the 1 
exclusive jurisdiction of the court conducted before a judge with notice to interested 2 
persons.  3 
20.  General personal representativ e.  "General personal representative" means a 4 
personal representative other than a special administrator.  5 
21.  Governing instrument.  "Governing instrument" means a deed, will, trust or 6 
insurance or annuity policy; account with POD designation; security re gistered in 7 
beneficiary form, TOD; transfer on death deed, TOD; pension, profit -sharing, retirement 8 
or similar benefit plan; instrument creating or exercising a power of appointment or a 9 
power of attorney; or dispositive, appointive or nominative instrumen t of any similar 10 
type.  11 
22.  Guardian.  "Guardian" means a person who has qualified as a guardian of a 12 
minor or incapacitated person pursuant to appointment by a parent or spouse or by the 13 
court.  "Guardian" includes a limited, an emergency and a temporary substitute guardian 14 
but not a guardian ad litem.  15 
23.  Heirs.  "Heirs," except as provided in section 2 -711, means those persons, 16 
including the surviving spouse, who are entitled under the statutes of intestate succession 17 
to the property of a decedent.  18 
24.  Incapacitated person.  "Incapacitated person" means an individual who, for 19 
reasons other than being a minor, is unable to receive and evaluate information or make 20 
or communicate informed decisions to such an extent that the individual lacks the ability 21 
to meet essential requirements for physical health, safety or self -care, even with 22 
reasonably available appropriate technological assistance.  23 
25.  Informal proceedings.  "Informal proceedings" means proceedings conducted 24 
without notice to interested persons by an officer of the Court acting as a register for 25 
probate of a will or appointment of a personal representative.  26 
26.  Interested person.  "Interested person" includes heirs, devisees, children, 27 
spouses, domestic partners, creditors, beneficiaries and any  others having a property right 28 
in or claim against a trust estate or the estate of a decedent, ward or protected person.  29 
"Interested person" also includes persons having priority for appointment as personal 30 
representative and other fiduciaries representi ng interested persons.  In any proceeding or 31 
hearing under Article 5 affecting a trust estate or estate, when the ward or protected 32 
person has received benefits from the United States Department of Veterans Affairs 33 
within 3 years, "interested person" inclu des the Secretary of Veterans Affairs.  The 34 
definition of "interested person" as it relates to particular persons may vary from time to 35 
time and must be determined according to the particular purposes of, and matter involved 36 
in, any proceeding.  37 
27.  Issue.   "Issue," as it relates to a person, means a descendant of that person.  38 
28.  Joint tenants with the right of survivorship.  "Joint tenants with the right of 39 
survivorship" includes co -owners of property held under circumstances that entitle one or 40 
 
 Page 9 - 128LR0452(01) -1 
 more to the whole of the property on the death of the other or others, but excludes forms 1 
of co -ownership registration in which the underlying ownership of each party is in 2 
proportion to that party's contribution.  3 
29.  Judge.  "Judge" means the judge of a court.  4 
30.  Lease.  "Lease" includes an oil, gas or other mineral lease.  5 
31.  Letters.  "Letters" includes letters of authority, letters testamentary, letters of 6 
guardianship, letters of administration and letters of conservatorship.  7 
32.  Minor.  "Minor" means an unemancipated individual who has not attained 18 8 
years of age.  9 
33.  Mortgage.  "Mortgage" means any conveyance, agreement or arrangement in 10 
which property is encumbered or used as security.  11 
34.  Nonresident decedent.  "Nonresident decedent" means a deceden t who was 12 
domiciled in another jurisdiction at the time of death.  13 
35.  Oath.  "Oath" means an oath or affirmation.  14 
36.  Organization.  "Organization" includes a corporation, government or 15 
governmental subdivision or agency, business trust, estate, trust, p artnership, joint 16 
venture, association or any other legal or commercial entity.  17 
37.  Parent.  "Parent" includes any person entitled to take, or who would be entitled 18 
to take if a child died without a will, as a parent under this Code by intestate successio n 19 
from the child whose relationship is in question and excludes any person who has no 20 
other relationship to the child than as a stepparent, foster parent or grandparent.  21 
38.  Payor.  "Payor" means a trustee, insurer, business entity, employer, government, 22 
governmental agency or subdivision or any other person authorized or obligated by law 23 
or a governing instrument to make payments.  24 
39.  Person.  "Person" means an individual or an organization.  25 
40.  Personal representative.  "Personal representative" includ es an executor, 26 
administrator, successor personal representative, special administrator and a person who 27 
performs substantially the same function under the appropriate governing law.  28 
41.  Petition.  "Petition" means a written request to the court for an or der after notice.  29 
42.  POD designation.  "POD designation" has the same meaning as in section 30 
6-201, subsection 8.  31 
43.  Proceeding.  "Proceeding" includes any civil action in any court of competent 32 
jurisdiction.  33 
44.  Property.  "Property" means anything th at may be the subject of ownership and 34 
includes both real and personal property or any interest therein.  35 
 
 Page 10 - 128LR0452(01) -1 
 45.  Protected person.  "Protected person" means a minor or other individual for 1 
whom a conservator has been appointed or other protective order has be en made.  2 
46.  Protective proceeding.  "Protective proceeding" means a proceeding under 3 
Article 5, Part 5.  4 
47.  Record.  "Record" means information that is inscribed on a tangible medium or 5 
that is stored in an electronic or other medium and is retrievable in perceivable form.  6 
48.  Register.  "Register" means the official of the court elected or appointed as 7 
provided in section 1 -501 or any other person performing the functions of register as 8 
provided in Part 5.  9 
49.  Registered domestic partners.  "Registere d domestic partners" means domestic 10 
partners who are registered in accordance with Title 22, section 2710.  11 
50.  Security.  "Security" includes any note, stock, treasury stock, bond, debenture, 12 
evidence of indebtedness, certificate of interest or participat ion in an oil, gas or mining 13 
title or lease or in payments out of production under such a title or lease, collateral trust 14 
certificate, transferable share, voting trust certificate or, in general, any interest or 15 
instrument commonly known as a security, or  any certificate of interest or participation, 16 
any temporary or interim certificate, receipt or certificate of deposit for, or any warrant or 17 
right to subscribe to or purchase, any such security.  18 
51.  Settlement.  "Settlement," in reference to a decedent's  estate, includes the full 19 
process of administration, distribution and closing.  20 
52.  Sign.  "Sign" means with present intent to authenticate or adopt a record other 21 
than a will:  22 
A.  To execute or adopt a tangible symbol; or  23 
B.  To attach to or logically as sociate with the record an electronic symbol, sound or 24 
process.  25 
53.  Special administrator.  "Special administrator" means a personal representative 26 
as described by sections 3 -614 to 3 -618. 27 
54.  Spouse.  "Spouse" means an individual who is lawfully married  and includes 28 
registered domestic partners and individuals who are in a legal union that was validly 29 
formed in any state or jurisdiction and that provides substantially the same rights, benefits 30 
and responsibilities as a marriage.  31 
55.  State.  "State" mean s a state of the United States, the District of Columbia, the 32 
Commonwealth of Puerto Rico or any territory or insular possession subject to the 33 
jurisdiction of the United States.  34 
56.  Successor personal representative.  "Successor personal representative" means 35 
a personal representative, other than a special administrator, who is appointed to succeed 36 
a previously appointed personal representative.  37 
 
 Page 11 - 128LR0452(01) -1 
 57.  Successors.  "Successors" means those persons, other than creditors, who are 1 
entitled to property of a dec edent under the decedent's will or this Code.  2 
58.  Supervised administration.  "Supervised administration" refers to the 3 
proceedings described in Article 3, Part 5.  4 
59.  Survive.  "Survive," as it relates to an individual, means to neither predecease an 5 
event, including the death of another individual, nor be deemed to have predeceased an 6 
event under section 2 -104 or 2 -702.  "Survive" includes its derivatives, such as 7 
"survives," "survived," "survivor" and "surviving."  8 
60.  Testacy proceeding.  "Testacy pro ceeding" means a proceeding to establish a 9 
will or determine intestacy.  10 
61.  Testator.  "Testator" means an individual of either sex who has executed a will.  11 
62.  TOD designation.  "TOD designation" means the designation of a security 12 
registered in benefic iary form to provide that the security be transferred on the death of 13 
the owner.  14 
63.  Trust.  "Trust" includes any express trust, private or charitable, with additions 15 
thereto, wherever and however created.  "Trust" also includes a trust created or 16 
determi ned by judgment or decree under which the trust is to be administered in the 17 
manner of an express trust.  "Trust" excludes other constructive trusts and excludes 18 
resulting trusts, conservatorships, personal representatives, trust accounts as defined in 19 
Article 6, custodial arrangements pursuant to the Maine Uniform Transfers to Minors 20 
Act, business trusts provided for certificates to be issued to beneficiaries, common trust 21 
funds, voting trusts, security arrangements, liquidation trusts and trusts for the p rimary 22 
purpose of paying debts, dividends, interest, salaries, wages, profits, pensions or 23 
employee benefits of any kind, and excludes any arrangement under which a person is 24 
nominee or escrowee for another person.  25 
64.  Trustee.  "Trustee" includes an orig inal, additional or successor trustee, whether 26 
or not appointed or confirmed by a court.  27 
65.  Ward.  "Ward" means an individual for whom a guardian has been appointed.  28 
66.  Will.  "Will" includes a codicil and any testamentary instrument that only 29 
appoints  an executor, revokes or revises another will, nominates a guardian or expressly 30 
excludes or limits the right of an individual or class to succeed to property of the decedent 31 
passing by intestate succession.  32

SCOPE, JURISDICTION AND COURTS  34 
§1-301.  T erritorial application  35 
Except as otherwise provided in this Code, this Code applies to the following:  36 
 
 Page 12 - 128LR0452(01) -1 
 1.  Domiciled in the State.  The affairs and estates of decedents, missing persons and 1 
persons to be protected who are domiciled in this State;  2 
2.  Nonres idents.  The property of nonresidents located in this State or property 3 
coming into the control of a fiduciary who is subject to the laws of this State;  4 
3.  Persons without capacity.  Incapacitated persons and minors in this State;  5 
4.  Survivorship.  Survi vorship and related accounts in this State; and  6 
5.  Trusts.  Trusts subject to administration in this State.  7 
§1-302.  Subject matter jurisdiction  8 
1.  Subject matter jurisdiction.  To the full extent permitted by the laws of the State, 9 
the court has jurisdi ction over all subject matter relating to:  10 
A.  The estates of decedents, including the construction of wills and determination of 11 
heirs and successors of decedents, and estates of protected persons;  12 
B.  The protection of minors and incapacitated persons; a nd 13 
C.  Trusts.  14 
2.  Court authority.  The court has full power to make orders, judgments and 15 
decrees and take all other action necessary and proper to administer justice in the matters 16 
that come before it.  17 
3.  Protective and guardianship proceedings.  The c ourt has jurisdiction over 18 
protective proceedings and guardianship proceedings.  19 
4.  Consolidation.  If both guardianship and protective proceedings as to the same 20 
person are commenced or pending in the same court, the proceedings may be 21 
consolidated.  22 
§1-303.  Venue; multiple proceedings; transfer  23 
1.  Court where proceeding first commenced.   If a proceeding under this Code 24 
could be maintained in more than one court in this State, the court in which the 25 
proceeding is first commenced has the exclusive right t o proceed.  26 
2.  Multiple proceedings.  If proceedings concerning the same estate, protected 27 
person, ward or trust are commenced in more than one court of this State, the court in 28 
which the proceeding was first commenced shall continue to hear the matter, an d the 29 
other courts shall hold the matter in abeyance until the question of venue is decided.  If 30 
the ruling court determines that venue is properly in another court, it shall transfer the 31 
proceeding to the other court.  32 
3.  Transfer in the interest of justi ce.  If a court finds that in the interest of justice a 33 
proceeding or a file should be located in another court of this State, the court making the 34 
finding may transfer the proceeding or file to the other court.  35 
 
 Page 13 - 128LR0452(01) -1 
 §1-304.  Rule -making power  1 
1.  Rules.  The S upreme Judicial Court may prescribe by general rules the forms, 2 
practice and procedure, including rules of evidence, to be followed in all proceedings 3 
under this Code and all appeals from such proceedings.  The rules must be consistent with 4 
the provisions of this Code and may not abridge, enlarge or modify any substantive right.  5 
2.  Laws inconsistent with rules.  After the effective date of the rules adopted or 6 
amended under subsection 1, all laws in conflict with those rules are of no further force or 7 
effect, except that in the event of a conflict with a provision of this Code, the Code 8 
provision prevails.  9 
§1-305.  Records and certified copies; judicial supervision  10 
The register shall maintain records and files and provide copies of documents as 11 
provided in sections 1 -501 to 1 -511 and further records and copies as the Supreme 12 
Judicial Court may by rule provide.  The register is subject to the supervision and 13 
authority of the judge of the court in which the register serves.  14 
§1-306.  No jury trial; removal  15 
1.  No jury trial.  In any proceeding under this Code, the court shall sit without a 16 
jury. 17 
2.  Removal to Superior Court for jury trial.  Upon timely demand by any party, 18 
any proceeding not within the exclusive jurisdiction of the court may be removed for tria l 19 
to the Superior Court under the procedures the Supreme Judicial Court provides by rule.  20 
§1-307.  Register; powers  21 
The register has the power to probate wills, appoint personal representatives as 22 
provided in sections 3 -302 and 3 -307 and perform other duti es set out in this Code.  The 23 
acts and orders that may be performed by the register under this Code may also be 24 
performed by a judge of the court or by a deputy register appointed under the provisions 25 
of section 1 -506. 26 
§1-308.  Appeals  27 
Appeals from all fin al judgments, orders and decrees of the court may be taken to the 28 
Supreme Judicial Court, sitting as the law court, as in other civil actions.  29 
§1-309.  Judges  30 
A judge of the court must be chosen and shall serve as provided in Title 4, sections 31 
301 to 312.  32 
§1-310.  Oath or affirmation on filed documents  33 
Except as otherwise specifically provided in this Code or by rule, every document 34 
filed with the court under this Code, including applications, petitions and demands for 35 
notice, is deemed to include an oath, affirmation or statement to the effect that its 36 
 
 Page 14 - 128LR0452(01) -1 
 representations are true as far as the person executing or filing it knows or is informed.  1 
Deliberate falsification may subject the person executing or filing the document to 2 
penalties for perjury.  3 
PART 4  4 
NOTICE, PARTIES AND RE PRESENTATION IN ESTA TE LITIGATION AND 5 
OTHER MATTERS  6 
§1-401.  Notice  7 
Whenever notice of any proceeding or any hearing is required under this Code, it 8 
must be given to any interested person in the manner the Supreme Judicial Court provide s 9 
by rule.  Each notice must include notification of any right to contest or appeal and may 10 
be proved by the filing of an affidavit of notice.  11 
§1-402.  Notice; waiver  12 
A person, including a guardian ad litem, conservator or other fiduciary, may waive 13 
notice  in the manner the Supreme Judicial Court provides by rule.  14 
§1-403.  Pleadings; when parties bound by others; notice  15 
In formal proceedings involving trusts or estates of decedents, minors, protected 16 
persons or incapacitated persons, and in judicially super vised settlements, the following 17 
provisions apply.  18 
1.  Pleadings.  Interests to be affected must be described in pleadings that give 19 
reasonable information to owners by name or class, by reference to the instrument 20 
creating the interests or in some other a ppropriate manner.  21 
2.  Orders binding another person.  A person is bound by an order binding another 22 
person in the following cases.  23 
A.  An order binding the sole holder or all coholders of a power of revocation or a 24 
presently exercisable general power of a ppointment, including one in the form of a 25 
power of amendment, binds other persons to the extent their interests, as objects or 26 
takers in default or otherwise, are subject to the power.  27 
B.  To the extent there is no conflict of interest between them or amo ng persons 28 
represented:  29 
(1)  An order binding a conservator binds the person whose estate the conservator 30 
controls;  31 
(2)  An order binding a guardian binds the ward if no conservator of the ward's 32 
estate has been appointed;  33 
(3)  An order binding a trustee b inds beneficiaries of the trust in proceedings to 34 
probate a will establishing or adding to a trust, in proceedings to review the acts 35 
or accounts of a prior fiduciary and in proceedings involving creditors or other 36 
3rd parties;  37 
 
 Page 15 - 128LR0452(01) -1 
 (4)  An order binding a pers onal representative binds persons interested in the 1 
undistributed assets of a decedent's estate in actions or proceedings by or against 2 
the estate; and  3 
(5)  An order binding a sole holder or all coholders of a general testamentary 4 
power of appointment bind s other persons to the extent their interests, as objects 5 
or takers in default or otherwise, are subject to the power.  6 
C.  Unless otherwise represented, a minor, an incapacitated person or an unborn or 7 
unascertained person is bound by an order to the exten t the person's interest is 8 
adequately represented by another party having a substantially identical interest in the 9 
proceeding.  10 
3.  Representation of minors.  If a conservator or guardian has not been appointed, a 11 
parent may represent a minor.  12 
4.  Notice.  Notice is required as follows:  13 
A.  Notice as prescribed by section 1 -401 must be given to every interested person or 14 
to a person who may bind an interested person as described in subsection 2, 15 
paragraph A or B.  Notice may be given both to a person and to  another person who 16 
may bind the person; and  17 
B.  Notice must be given to unborn or unascertained persons who are not represented 18 
under subsection 2, paragraph A or B by giving notice to all known persons whose 19 
interests in the proceedings are substantially  identical to those of the unborn or 20 
unascertained persons.  21 
5.  Appointment of guardian ad litem.  At any point in a proceeding, a court may 22 
appoint a guardian ad litem to represent the interest of a minor, an incapacitated person or 23 
an unborn or unascerta ined person if the court determines that representation of the 24 
interest otherwise would be inadequate.  If not precluded by a conflict of interest, a 25 
guardian ad litem may be appointed to represent several persons or interests.  The court 26 
shall set out its  reasons for appointing a guardian ad litem as a part of the record or the 27 
proceeding.  28 
PART 5  29 
REGISTERS OF PROBATE  30 
§1-501.  Election; bond; vacancies; salaries; copies  31 
1.  Election.  Registers of probate are elected or appointed as provided in the 32 
Constitu tion of Maine.  A register's election is effected and determined as is provided for 33 
county commissioners by Title 30 -A, chapter 1, subchapter 2, and a register's term 34 
commences on the first day of January following the register's election, except that the 35 
term of a register appointed to fill a vacancy commences immediately.  36 
2.  Bond.  A register, before acting, shall give bond to the treasurer of the register's 37 
county with sufficient sureties in the sum of $2,500, except that this sum must be $10,000 38 
for Cu mberland County.  A register, having executed the bond, shall file the bond in the 39 
office of the county commissioners of the register's county, to be presented to the county 40 
 
 Page 16 - 128LR0452(01) -1 
 commissioners at the next meeting for approval.  After the bond is approved, the c ounty 1 
commissioners shall retain a copy of the bond and deliver the original bond to the 2 
register, who shall deliver the original bond to the treasurer of the county within 10 days 3 
after the bond's approval.  Surety and fidelity insurance coverage provided  by a public 4 
sector self -funded risk pool organized pursuant to Title 30 -A, section 2253 in the sum 5 
ordered by the commissioners is deemed to comply with the requirements of this section.  6 
3.  Vacancies.  Vacancies caused by death, resignation, removal from  the county, 7 
permanent incapacity as defined in Title 30 -A, section 1, subsection 2 -A or any other 8 
reason must be filled as provided in the Constitution of Maine.  In the case of a vacancy 9 
in the term of a register who was nominated by primary election bef ore the general 10 
election, the register appointed by the Governor to fill the vacancy until a successor is 11 
chosen at election must be enrolled in the same political party as the register whose term 12 
is vacant.  In making the appointment, the Governor shall c hoose from any 13 
recommendations submitted to the Governor by the county committee of the political 14 
party from which the appointment is to be made.  15 
4.  Salary.  A register is entitled to receive an annual salary as established by the 16 
register's county pursua nt to Title 30 -A, chapter 3.  The salary of the register must be in 17 
full compensation for the performance of all duties required of the register.  18 
5.  Copies and fees.  Registers may make copies of wills, accounts, inventories, 19 
petitions and decrees and fur nish the copies to the persons requesting the copies and may 20 
charge a reasonable fee for that service, which is considered a fee for the use of the 21 
county.  Fees for exemplified copies of the records of the probate of wills and the 22 
granting of administrati ons, guardianships and conservatorships; fees for copies of 23 
petitions and orders of notice for personal service; fees for appeal copies; and the 24 
statutory fees for abstracts and copies of the waivers of wills and other copies required to 25 
be recorded in the  registry of deeds are considered official fees for the use of the county.  26 
This subsection may not be construed to change or repeal any provisions of law requiring 27 
the furnishing of certain copies without charge.  28 
§1-502.  Condition of bond  29 
A register's bo nd is conditioned on the register's accounting, according to law, for all 30 
fees received by or payable to the register by virtue of the office and the register's paying 31 
the fees to the county treasurer by the 15th day of each month following the month in 32 
which the fees were collected, as provided by law; the register's keeping, seasonably and 33 
in good order, the records of the court; the register's making and keeping correct and 34 
convenient indices of the records; and the register's faithfully discharging all other duties 35 
of the office.  If a register forfeits the register's bond, the register is disqualified from 36 
holding office.  The register's failure to complete the register's records for more than 6 37 
months at any time, except in cases of sickness or extraor dinary casualty, constitutes a 38 
forfeiture.  39 
§1-503.  Duties; records; binding of papers; facsimile signature  40 
1.  Duties.  Registers are responsible for the care and custody of all files, papers and 41 
books belonging to the probate office and shall duly record  all wills probated formally or 42 
 
 Page 17 - 128LR0452(01) -1 
 informally, letters of authority of a personal representative, guardianships or 1 
conservatorships issued, bonds approved, accounts filed or allowed, all informal 2 
applications and findings, all petitions, decrees, orders or ju dgments of the judge, 3 
including all petitions, decrees or orders relating to adoptions and changes of names and 4 
other matters, as the judge directs.  5 
2.  Records.  Registers shall keep a docket of all probate cases and, under the 6 
appropriate heading of each  case, make entries of each motion, order, decree and 7 
proceeding so that at all times the docket shows the exact condition of each case.  A 8 
register may act as an auditor of accounts when requested to do so by the judge, and the 9 
judge's decision is final u nless appealed in the same manner as other probate appeals.  10 
The records may be attested by the volume, and it is considered to be a sufficient 11 
attestation of those records when each volume bears the attest with the written signature 12 
of the register or oth er person authorized by law to attest those records.  13 
3.  Binding of papers.  A register may bind in volumes of convenient size original 14 
inventories and accounts filed in the register's office and, when bound and indexed, those 15 
inventories and accounts are deemed to be recorded in all cases in which the law requires 16 
a record to be made and no further record is required.  17 
4.  Facsimile signature.  A facsimile of the signature of the register or deputy 18 
register imprinted at the register's or deputy register's d irection upon any instrument, 19 
certification or copy that is customarily certified by the register or deputy register or 20 
recorded in the probate office has the same validity as the register's or deputy register's 21 
signature.  22 
§1-504.  Certification of wills; appointments of personal representatives; elective 23 
share petitions involving real estate  24 
1.  Duty of register.  The register shall prepare and submit a certification in 25 
accordance with subsection 2 within 30 days after the date on which:  26 
A.  A will has bee n proved or allowed;  27 
B.  An appointment of a personal representative has been made upon an assumption 28 
of intestate status and the petition for appointment indicates that the decedent owned 29 
real estate; or  30 
C.  A petition for an elective share has been filed  and the will or the petition upon 31 
which the appointment of a personal representative was granted indicates that the 32 
decedent owned real estate.  33 
2.  Certification.  When required by subsection 1, the register shall certify to the 34 
register of deeds in the c ounty where any affected real estate is situated a true copy of the 35 
portion of the will that devises the real estate, an abstract of the appointment of the 36 
personal representative or a true copy or abstract of the petition for an elective share.  37 
Each cert ification must also include:  38 
A.  A description of the real estate derived from the probated will or the petition upon 39 
which the appointment of the personal representative was made;  40 
 
 Page 18 - 128LR0452(01) -1 
 B.  The name of the decedent;  1 
C.  The name or names of the devisees or heir s; and  2 
D.  In the case of a will, the date of allowance of the will and an indication whether 3 
the will was probated formally or informally.  4 
3.  Additional certification if will previously probated informally.  If a will was 5 
informally probated and subseque ntly formally probated or denied probate in formal 6 
proceedings, the register shall certify the formal probate or formal denial of probate to the 7 
register of deeds to which the prior informally probated will was certified, setting forth 8 
the date of the form al probate or denial.  A register of deeds that receives a certification 9 
pursuant to this subsection shall indicate on the certification the time of receipt and record 10 
the certification in the same manner as a deed of real estate.  11 
§1-505.  Notice to benefi ciaries; furnishing of copies  12 
A register shall, within 30 days after a will is probated, notify by mail all 13 
beneficiaries under the will that devises have been made to them, stating the name of the 14 
testator and the name of the personal representative, if a  personal representative has been 15 
appointed at the time this notification is sent.  Beneficiaries in a will may, upon 16 
application to the register, be furnished with a copy of the probated will upon payment of 17 
a fee of $1 per page.  18 
§1-506.  Deputy register of probate  19 
A register may appoint a deputy register for the county, subject to the requirements of 20 
Title 30 -A, section 501.  The deputy register may perform any of the duties prescribed by 21 
law to be performed by the register.  The signature of the deputy r egister has the same 22 
force and effect as the signature of the register.  The deputy register shall give bond to the 23 
county for the faithful discharge of the deputy register's duties in the same sum and in the 24 
same manner as the register.  The deputy regist er shall act as register in the event of a 25 
vacancy or absence of the register, until the register resumes the register's duties or 26 
another person is qualified as register.  The deputy register is entitled to receive an annual 27 
salary established by the regi ster and approved by the county commissioners.  28 
In the case of an absence of the register in a county where a deputy register has not 29 
been appointed or in the case of a vacancy in the office of register due to death, 30 
resignation or any other cause, the judg e shall appoint a suitable person to act as register 31 
pro tempore until the register resumes the duties of office or another person is qualified as 32 
register.  A register pro tempore must be sworn and, if the judge requires it, shall give 33 
bond as in the case  of the register.  34 
§1-507.  Inspection of register's conduct of office  35 
A judge shall constantly inspect the conduct of the register with respect to the 36 
register's records and duties and give information in writing of any breach of the register's 37 
bond to the  treasurer of the county, who shall bring a civil action.  Any funds recovered 38 
in the civil action must be applied toward the expenses of completing the records of the 39 
register under the direction of the judge and the surplus, if any, must inure to the cou nty.  40 
 
 Page 19 - 128LR0452(01) -1 
 If the funds are insufficient, the treasurer may recover the deficiency from the register in 1 
a civil action.  2 
§1-508.  Register incapable or neglects duties  3 
When a register is unable to perform or neglects the duties of the office, the judge 4 
shall cer tify the register's inability or neglect to the county treasurer, the time of the 5 
commencement and termination of the inability or neglect and the name of the person 6 
who has performed the duties for that time period.  The treasurer shall pay the person 7 
named by the judge a salary in proportion to the time that the person has performed the 8 
duties of the register and the amount must be deducted from the register's salary.  9 
§1-509.  Records in case of vacancy  10 
When there is a vacancy in the office of register an d the office's records are 11 
incomplete, the records may be completed and certified by the person appointed to act as 12 
register or by the register's successor.  13 
§1-510.  Register or court employee; prohibited activities  14 
1.  Prohibited activities.   A register m ay not:  15 
A.  Be an attorney or counselor in or out of court in an action or matter pending in the 16 
court of which the register is register or in an appeal in such action or matter;  17 
B.  Be an administrator, guardian, commissioner of insolvency, appraiser or d ivider 18 
of an estate, in a case within the jurisdiction of the court of which the register is 19 
register, except as provided in Title 4, section 307, or be in any manner interested in 20 
the fees and emoluments arising from such an estate in that capacity; or  21 
C.  In violation of this section, commence or conduct, either personally or by agent or 22 
clerk, any matter, petition, process or proceeding in the court of which the register is 23 
register.  24 
2.  Assistance in drafting.   Except as otherwise provided in this secti on, a register 25 
may not draft or aid in drafting documents or paper that the register is by law required to 26 
record in full or in part.  A register may aid in drafting applications in informal 27 
proceedings, petitions or sworn statements relating to the closin g of decedents' estates 28 
that have not been contested prior to closing, applications for change of name and 29 
petitions for guardians of minors.  A register or an employee of a court may not charge 30 
fees or accept anything of value for assisting in the draftin g of documents to be used or 31 
filed in the court of which the person is the register or an employee.  32 
3.  Penalties.   The following penalties apply to violations of this section.  33 
A.  A register who violates subsection 1 commits a Class E crime.  Violation of  34 
subsection 1 is a strict liability crime as defined in Title 17 -A, section 34, subsection 35 
4-A. 36 
B.  A register or employee of a court who violates subsection 2 is subject to a civil 37 
penalty of not more than $100, to be recovered by a complainant in a civil  action for 38 
the complainant's benefit or by civil action for the benefit of the county.  39 
 
 Page 20 - 128LR0452(01) -1 
 §1-511.  Fees for approved blanks and forms  1 
For all approved blanks, forms or schedule paper required in court proceedings, the 2 
register shall charge fees, which must b e set by the register and approved by the county 3 
commissioners, so as to avoid incurring a loss to the county for such services.  The 4 
register shall pay such fees to the county treasurer for the use and benefit of the county.  5 
PART 6  6 
COSTS AND FEES  7 
§1-601.  Costs in contested cases  8 
In contested probate cases and appeals, costs may be allowed to either party, 9 
including reasonable witness fees, costs of depositions, hospital records or medical 10 
reports and attorney's fees, to be paid to either or both parties o ut of the estate in 11 
controversy, as justice requires.  In cases in which a will is contested on the grounds of 12 
undue influence or mental capacity, attorney's fees and costs may not be allowed to a 13 
party who unsuccessfully contests the will.  14 
§1-602.  Filing  and certification fees  15 
The person making the request shall pay the register the following fees for filing or 16 
certifying documents.  17 
1.  Certification.  For making and certifying to the register of deeds copies of devises 18 
of real estate, abstracts of petiti ons for appointment of a personal representative or for an 19 
elective share and any other document for which certification is required, the fee is $15 20 
plus the fee for recording as provided by Title 33, section 751, except as otherwise 21 
expressly provided by law.  The fee must be paid by the personal representative, 22 
petitioner or other person filing the document to be certified when the copy of the devise, 23 
abstract, petition for elective share or other document for which certification is required is 24 
requested.   The register of probate shall deliver the certified document to the register of 25 
deeds together with the fee for recording as provided by Title 33, section 751.  26 
2.  Filing.  For receiving and entering each petition or application for all estates, 27 
testate and intestate, including foreign estates, and the filing of a notice by a domiciliary 28 
foreign personal representative, except for the filing of a successor personal 29 
representative, when the value of the estate is:  30 
A.  $10,000 and under, the fee is $20;  31 
B.  $10,001 to $20,000, the fee is $40;  32 
C.  $20,001 to $30,000, the fee is $60;  33 
D.  $30,001 to $40,000, the fee is $75;  34 
E.  $40,001 to $50,000, the fee is $95;  35 
F.  $50,001 to $75,000, the fee is $125;  36 
G.  $75,001 to $100,000, the fee is $190;  37

 H.  $100,001 to $150,000, the fee is $250;  1 
I.  $150,001 to $200,000, the fee is $325;  2 
J.  $200,001 to $250,000, the fee is $375;  3 
K.  $250,001 to $300,000, the fee is $450;  4 
L.  $300,001 to $400,000, the fee is $500;  5 
M.  $400,001 to $500,000, the fee is $575;  6 
N.  $500,001 t o $750,000, the fee is $625;  7 
O.  $750,001 to $1,000,000, the fee is $700;  8 
P.  $1,000,001 to $1,500,000, the fee is $750;  9 
Q.  $1,500,001 to $2,000,000, the fee is $875; or  10 
R.  More than $2,000,000, the fee is $950, and continuing in steps of $100 for every 11 
increase in value of $500,000 or part thereof above $2,500,000.  12 
For filing a will for no probate, there is no charge.  13 
For filing a will to be probated and without an appointment, the fee is $15.  14 
3.  Copies of court records.  For making copies from the reco rds of the court, the fee 15 
is $1 for each page.  16 
4.  Certificate of appointment.  For each certificate, under seal of the court, of the 17

6.  Application for involuntary hospitalization.  For filing an application for 22

7.  Petition for guardian and conservator.  For filing a joined petition for guardian 24

of conservator, the fee is $50.  27 
9.  Petition for elective share.  For filing a petition for elective share, the fee is $120.  28 
10.  Subsequent informal appointments.  For all other subsequent informal 29 
appointments, the fee is $25.  30 
11.  Other formal proceeding.  For filing any other formal procee ding, the fee is 31 
$25. 32

 §1-603.  Registers to account monthly for fees  1 
A register shall account for each calendar month under oath to the county treasurer 2 
for all fees received by the register or payable to the register by virtue of the office, 3 
specifying th e items, and shall pay the whole amount for each calendar month to the 4 
treasurer of the county not later than the 15th day of the following month.  5 
§1-604.  Expenses of partition  6 
When a partition of real estate is made by order of a judge, the interested pa rties shall 7 
pay the expenses in proportion to their interests.  When expenses accrue prior to the 8 
closing order or statement of the personal representative of the deceased owner of such 9 
real estate, the personal representative may pay the expenses from the  personal 10 
representative's account.  In case of neglect or refusal to pay of any person liable to pay 11 
such expenses, the judge may issue a warrant of distress against that person for the 12 
amount due and costs of process.  13 
§1-605.  Compensation of court repor ters 14 
Court reporters appointed under Title 4, sections 751 to 756 shall, if a transcript is 15 
requested by the court or a party, file the original transcript with the court and receive the 16 
same compensation as provided by law for temporary court reporters as  well as mileage 17 
at the rate of 10¢ a mile.  18 
Transcripts furnished for the files of the court must be paid for by the county in 19 
which the court or examination is held at the rate prescribed by the Supreme Judicial 20 
Court, after the reporter's bill has been a llowed by the judge of the court in which the 21 
services were rendered.  In probate matters, the personal representative, conservator or 22 
guardian shall, in each case out of the estate handled by that personal representative, 23 
conservator or guardian, pay to t he register for the county the amount of the reporter's 24 
fees, giving the fees the same priority as provided in section 3 -815 for other costs and 25 
expenses of administration, or as otherwise provided for in the case of insolvent estates.  26 
If the estate asset s are not sufficient, the court may order payment by the county.  27 
§1-606.  Court reporters to furnish copies  28 
Court reporters shall furnish correct typewritten copies of the oral testimony taken at 29 
any hearing or examination upon request by any person and pa yment of transcript rates 30 
prescribed by the Supreme Judicial Court.  31 
§1-607.  Surcharge for restoration, storage and preservation of records  32 
1.  Surcharge.  In addition to any other fees required by law, a register shall collect a 33 
surcharge of $10 per petit ion, application or complaint, except for name changes, filed in 34 
the court.  35 
2.  Nonlapsing account.  The surcharge imposed in subsection 1 must be transferred 36 
to the county treasurer, who shall deposit it in a separate, nonlapsing account within 30 37 
days of  receipt.  Money in the account is not available for use as general revenue of the 38 
county.  Interest earned on the account must be credited to the account.  39 
 
 Page 23 - 128LR0452(01) -1 
 3.  Use of account funds.  The money in the account established in subsection 2 must 1 
be used for the  restoration, storage and preservation of the records filed in the office of 2 
the register and in the court.  No withdrawals from this account may be made without the 3 
express written request or approval of the register.  4 
4.  Waiver of surcharge.  The judge m ay waive the surcharge in subsection 1 if the 5 
judge believes that it will prove a hardship for the individual filing the petition, 6 
application or complaint.  7 
§1-608.  Fees not established in statute  8 
Unless otherwise specifically stated in statute or in the Rules of Probate Procedure 9 
published by the Supreme Judicial Court, the Probate Court shall charge the same fee 10 
charged by the District Court or the Superior Court for similar procedures.  11 
PART 7  12 
CHANGE OF NAME  13 
§1-701.  Petition to change name  14 
1.  Petition;  where filed.  If a person desires to have that person's name changed, the 15 
person may petition the judge in the county where the person resides.  If the person is a 16 
minor, the person's legal custodian may petition on the person's behalf.  If there is a 17 
proceeding involving custody or other parental rights with respect to the minor pending in 18 
the District Court, the petition must be filed in the District Court.  19 
2.  Notice and name change.  Upon receipt of a petition filed under subsection 1, the 20 
judge, after  due notice, may change the name of the person.  To protect the person's 21 
safety, the judge may limit the notice required if the person shows by a preponderance of 22 
the evidence that:  23 
A.  The person is a victim of abuse; and  24 
B.  The person is currently in re asonable fear of the person's safety.  25 
3.  Record.  The judge shall make and preserve a record of a name change.  If the 26 
judge limited the notice required under subsection 2, the judge may seal the record of the 27 
name change.  28 
4.  Filing fee.  The fee for fil ing a name change petition is $40.  29 
5.  Background checks.  The judge may require a person seeking a name change to 30 
undergo one or more of the following background checks:  a criminal history record 31 
check; a motor vehicle record check; or a credit check.  T he judge may require the person 32 
to pay the cost of each background check required.  33 
6.  Denial of petition brought for improper purpose.  The judge may not change 34 
the name of a person if the judge has reason to believe that the person is seeking the name 35 
change for purposes of defrauding another person or entity or for purposes otherwise 36 
contrary to the public interest.  37 
 
 Page 24 - 128LR0452(01) -1 
 PART 8  1 
PROBATE AND TRUST LA W ADVISORY COMMISSIO N 2 
§1-801.  Commission established  3 
The Probate and Trust Law Advisory Commission, established in Title 5, section 4 
12004 -I, subsection 73 -B and referred to in this Part as "the commission," is created for 5 
the purpose of conducting a continuing study of the probate and trust laws of the State.  6 
1.  Membership.   The commission is composed of 10 members  who have experience 7 
in practicing probate and trust law or are knowledgeable about probate and trust law.  The 8 
membership of the commission must include:  9 
A.  Two Probate Court Judges, appointed by the Chief Justice of the Supreme 10 
Judicial Court;  11 
B.  One S uperior Court Justice, appointed by the Chief Justice of the Supreme 12 
Judicial Court;  13 
C.  Five members of the trusts and estates law section of the Maine State Bar 14 
Association, appointed by the Chief Justice of the Supreme Judicial Court;  15 
D.  One member rep resenting the interests of older people, appointed by the 16 
Governor; and  17 
E.  The Attorney General or the Attorney General's designee.  18 
2.  Terms.   A member is appointed for a term of 3 years and may be reappointed.  19 
3.  Vacancies.   In the event of the death o r resignation of a member, the appointing 20 
authority under subsection 1 shall appoint a qualified person for the remainder of the 21 
term.  22 
§1-802.  Consultants; experts  23 
Whenever it considers appropriate, the commission may seek the advice of 24 
consultants or exp erts, including representatives of the legislative and executive branches, 25 
in fields related to the commission's duties.  26 
§1-803.  Duties  27 
1.  Examine, evaluate and recommend.   The commission shall:  28 
A.  Examine this Title and Title 18 -B and draft amendments that the commission 29 
considers advisable;  30 
B.  Evaluate the operation of this Title and Title 18 -B and recommend amendments 31 
based on the evaluation;  32 
C.  Examine current laws pertaining to probate and trust laws and recommend 33 
changes based on the examination;  and 34 
 
 Page 25 - 128LR0452(01) -1 
 D.  Examine any other aspects of the State's probate and trust laws, including 1 
substantive, procedural and administrative matters, that the commission considers 2 
relevant.  3 
2.  Propose changes.   The commission may propose to the Legislature, at the star t of 4 
each session, changes in the probate and trust laws and in related provisions that the 5 
commission considers appropriate.  6 
§1-804.  Organization  7 
The Chief Justice of the Supreme Judicial Court shall notify all members of the 8 
commission of the time and p lace of the first meeting of the commission.  At that time the 9 
commission shall organize, elect a chair, vice -chair and secretary -treasurer from its 10 
membership and adopt rules governing the administration of the commission and its 11 
affairs.  The commission shall maintain financial records as required by the State Auditor.  12 
§1-805.  Federal funds  13 
The commission may accept federal funds on behalf of the State.  14
