ARTICLE 2  14 
INTESTACY, WILLS AND  DONATIVE TRANSFERS  15 
PART 1  16 
INTES TATE SUCCESSION  17 
SUBPART 1  18 
GENERAL PROVISIONS  19 
§2-101.  Intestate estate  20 
1.  Intestate succession.  Any part of a decedent’s estate not effectively disposed of 21 
by will passes by intestate succession to the decedent’s heirs as prescribed in this Code, 22 
except as modified by the decedent’s will.  23 
2.  Will expressly excludes or limits.  A decedent by will may expressly exclude or 24 
limit the right of an individual or class to succeed to property of the decedent passing by 25 
intestate succession.  If that individual or  a member of that class survives the decedent, 26 
the share of the decedent’s intestate estate to which that individual or class would have 27 
succeeded passes as if that individual or each member of that class had disclaimed the 28 
individual’s or member’s intesta te share.  29 
 
 Page 27 - 128LR0452(01) -1 
 §2-102.  Share of spouse  1 
The intestate share of a decedent’s surviving spouse is:  2 
1.  No descendant or parent.  The entire intestate estate if:  3 
A.  No descendant or parent of the decedent survives the decedent; or  4 
B.  All of the decedent’s surviv ing descendants are also descendants of the surviving 5 
spouse and there is no other descendant of the surviving spouse who survives the 6 
decedent;  7 
2.  No descendant but parent survives.  The first $300,000, plus 3/4 of any balance 8 
of the intestate estate, if  no descendant of the decedent survives the decedent, but a parent 9 
of the decedent survives the decedent;  10 
3.  Descendants of both decedent and spouse, just spouse.  The first $100,000, plus 11 
1/2 of any balance of the intestate estate, if all of the decedent ’s surviving descendants are 12 
also descendants of the surviving spouse and the surviving spouse has one or more 13 
surviving descendants who are not descendants of the decedent; and  14 
4.  Descendants of decedent, not spouse.  One-half of the intestate estate, if  there 15 
are surviving descendants one or more of whom are not descendants of the surviving 16 
spouse.  17 
§2-103.  Share of heirs other than surviving spouse  18 
1.  Share of heirs other than surviving spouse; order.  Any part of the intestate 19 
estate not passing to a decedent’s surviving spouse under section 2 -102, or the entire 20 
intestate estate if there is no surviving spouse, passes in the following order to the 21 
individuals who survive the decedent:  22 
A.  To the decedent’s descendants per capita at each generation;  23 
B.  If there is no surviving descendant, to the decedent’s parents equally if both 24 
survive or to the surviving parent if only one survives;  25 
C.  If there is no surviving descendant or parent, to the descendants of the decedent’s 26 
parents or either of them per c apita at each generation;  27 
D.  If there is no surviving descendant, parent or descendant of a parent, but the 28 
decedent is survived on both the paternal and maternal sides by one or more 29 
grandparents or descendants of grandparents:  30 
(1)  Half to the decedent’ s paternal grandparents equally if both survive, to the 31 
surviving paternal grandparent if only one survives or to the descendants of the 32 
decedent’s paternal grandparents or either of them if both are deceased, to be 33 
distributed to the descendants per capit a at each generation; and  34 
(2)  Half to the decedent’s maternal grandparents equally if both survive, to the 35 
surviving maternal grandparent if only one survives or to the descendants of the 36 
decedent’s maternal grandparents or either of them if both are dece ased, to be 37 
distributed to the descendants per capita at each generation;  38 
 
 Page 28 - 128LR0452(01) -1 
 E.  If there is no surviving descendant, parent or descendant of a parent, but the 1 
decedent is survived by one or more grandparents or descendants of grandparents on 2 
the paternal but  not the maternal side, or on the maternal but not the paternal side, to 3 
the decedent’s relatives on the side with one or more surviving members in the 4 
manner described in paragraph D; and  5 
F.  If there is no surviving descendant, parent or descendant of a parent, grandparent 6 
or descendant of a grandparent, but the decedent is survived by one or more great - 7 
grandparents or descendants of great -grandparents, half of the estate passes to the 8 
paternal great -grandparents who survive, or to the descendants of the paternal great - 9 
grandparents if all are deceased, to be distributed per capita at each generation as 10 
described in section 2 -106; and the other half passes to the maternal relatives in the 11 
same manner, but if there is no surviving great -grandparent or descen dant of a great - 12 
grandparent on either the paternal or maternal side, the entire estate passes to the 13 
relatives on the other side in the same manner as the half.  14 
2.  No takers under subsection 1.  If there is no taker under subsection 1, but the 15 
decedent ha s: 16 
A.  One deceased spouse who has one or more descendants who survive the decedent, 17 
the estate or part thereof passes to that spouse’s descendants per capita at each 18 
generation; or  19 
B.  More than one deceased spouse who has one or more descendants who surv ive 20 
the decedent, an equal share of the estate or part thereof passes to each set of 21 
descendants per capita at each generation.  22 
§2-104.  Requirement of survival by 120 hours; individual in gestation  23 
1.  Applicable provisions.  For purposes of intestate suc cession, homestead 24 
allowance and exempt property, and except as otherwise provided in subsection 2, the 25 
provisions of this subsection apply.  26 
A.  An individual born before a decedent’s death who fails to survive the decedent by 27 
120 hours is deemed to have p redeceased the decedent.  If it is not established by 28 
clear and convincing evidence that an individual born before the decedent’s death 29 
survived the decedent by 120 hours, the individual is deemed to have failed to survive 30 
for the required period.  31 
B.  An i ndividual in gestation at a decedent’s death is deemed to be living at the 32 
decedent’s death if the individual lives 120 hours after birth.  If it is not established 33 
by clear and convincing evidence that an individual in gestation at the decedent’s 34 
death li ved 120 hours after birth, the individual is deemed to have failed to survive 35 
for the required period.  36 
2.  Not applicable if results in escheat.  This section does not apply if its application 37 
would cause the estate to pass to the State under section 2 -105. 38 
§2-105.  No taker  39 
If there is no taker under the provisions of this Article, the intestate estate passes to 40 
the State, except that an amount of funds included in the estate up to the total amount of 41 
 
 Page 29 - 128LR0452(01) -1 
 restitution paid to the decedent pursuant to a court or der for a crime of which the 1 
decedent was the victim passes to the Elder Victims Restitution Fund established in Title 2 
34-A, section 1214 -A. 3 
§2-106.  Per capita at each generation  4 
1.  Definitions.  As used in this section, unless the context otherwise indi cates, the 5 
following terms have the following meanings.  6 
A.  "Deceased descendant," "deceased parent" or "deceased grandparent" means a 7 
descendant, parent or grandparent, respectively, who either predeceased the decedent 8 
or is deemed to have predeceased the  decedent under section 2 -104. 9 
B.  "Surviving descendant" means a descendant who neither predeceased the 10 
decedent nor is deemed to have predeceased the decedent under section 2 -104. 11 
2.  Per capita at each generation; decedent's descendants.  If, under sect ion 2 -103, 12 
subsection 1, paragraph A, a decedent's intestate estate or a part thereof passes per capita 13 
at each generation to the decedent's descendants, the estate or part thereof is divided into 14 
as many equal shares as there are:  15 
A.  Surviving descendant s in the generation nearest to the decedent that contains one 16 
or more surviving descendants; and  17 
B.  Deceased descendants in the same generation identified in paragraph A who left 18 
surviving descendants, if any.  19 
Each surviving descendant in the nearest gene ration is allocated one share.  The 20 
remaining shares, if any, are combined and then divided in the same manner among the 21 
surviving descendants of the deceased descendants as if the surviving descendants who 22 
were allocated a share and their surviving descen dants had predeceased the decedent.  23 
3.  Per capita at each generation; descendants of decedent's parents, 24 
grandparents.  If, under section 2 -103, subsection 1, paragraph C or D, a decedent's 25 
intestate estate or a part thereof passes per capita at each gene ration to the descendants of 26 
the decedent's deceased parents or either of them or to the descendants of the decedent's 27 
deceased paternal or maternal grandparents or either of them, the estate or part thereof is 28 
divided into as many equal shares as there ar e: 29 
A.  Surviving descendants in the generation nearest the deceased parents or either of 30 
them, or the deceased grandparents or either of them, that contains one or more 31 
surviving descendants; and  32 
B.  Deceased descendants in the same generation identified i n paragraph A who left 33 
surviving descendants, if any.  34 
Each surviving descendant in the nearest generation is allocated one share.  The 35 
remaining shares, if any, are combined and then divided in the same manner among the 36 
surviving descendants of the decease d descendants as if the surviving descendants who 37 
were allocated a share and their surviving descendants had predeceased the decedent.  38 
 
 Page 30 - 128LR0452(01) -1 
 §2-107.  Kindred of half blood  1 
Relatives of the half blood inherit the same share they would inherit if they were of 2 
the whole blood.  3 
§2-108.  Advancements  4 
1.  Gifts treated as advancements.  If an individual dies intestate as to all or a 5 
portion of that individual’s estate, property the decedent gave during the decedent’s 6 
lifetime to an individual who, at the decedent’s dea th, is an heir is treated as an 7 
advancement against the heir’s intestate share only if:  8 
A.  The decedent declared in a contemporaneous writing or the heir acknowledged in 9 
writing that the gift is an advancement; or  10 
B.  The decedent’s contemporaneous writin g or the heir’s written acknowledgment 11 
otherwise indicates that the gift is to be taken into account in computing the division 12 
and distribution of the decedent’s intestate estate.  13 
2.  Valuation of advanced property.  For purposes of subsection 1, property 14 
advanced is valued as of the time the heir came into possession or enjoyment of the 15 
property or as of the time of the decedent’s death, whichever first occurs.  16 
3.  Recipient's failure to survive decedent.  If the recipient of the property under 17 
subsection 1 fails to survive the decedent, the property is not taken into account in 18 
computing the division and distribution of the decedent’s intestate estate, unless the 19 
decedent’s contemporaneous writing provides otherwise.  20 
§2-109.  Debts to decedent  21 
A debt owed to the decedent is not charged against the intestate share of any 22 
individual except the debtor.  If the debtor fails to survive the decedent, the debt is not 23 
taken into account in computing the intestate share of the debtor's descendants.  24 
§2-110.  Alienage  25 
An individual is not disqualified to take as an heir because the individual or an 26 
individual through whom the individual claims is or has been an alien.  27 
§2-111.  Dower and curtesy abolished  28 
The estates of dower and curtesy are abolished.  29 
§2-112.  Individu als related to decedent through 2 lines  30 
An individual who is related to the decedent through 2 lines of relationship is entitled 31 
to only a single share based on the relationship that would entitle the individual to the 32 
larger share.  In cases where such an  heir would take equal shares, the individual is 33 
entitled to the equivalent of a single share.  The court shall equitably apportion the 34 
amount equivalent in value to the share denied such heir by the provisions of this section.  35 
 
 Page 31 - 128LR0452(01) -1 
 §2-113.  Parent barred from inheriting  1 
1.  Parent barred from inheriting though child.  A parent is barred from inheriting 2 
from or through a child of the parent if:  3 
A.  The parent’s parental rights were terminated and the parent -child relationship was 4 
not judicially reestablished; or  5 
B.  The child died before reaching 18 years of age and there is clear and convincing 6 
evidence that immediately before the child’s death the parental rights of the parent 7 
could have been terminated under the laws of this State other than Articles 1 to 8 on  8 
the basis of nonsupport, abandonment, abuse, neglect or other actions or inactions of 9 
the parent toward the child.  10 
2.  Treated as predeceased child.  For the purpose of intestate succession from or 11 
through a deceased child, a parent who is barred from inh eriting under this section is 12 
treated as if the parent predeceased the child.  13 
SUBPART 2  14 
PARENT -CHILD RELATIONSHIP  15 
§2-115.  Definitions  16 
As used in this subpart, unless the context otherwise indicates, the following terms 17 
have the following meanings.  18 
1.  Adoptee.  "Adoptee" means an individual who is adopted.  19 
2.  Assisted reproduction.  "Assisted reproduction" means a method of causing 20 
pregnancy other than sexual intercourse.  21 
3.  Divorce.  "Divorce" includes an annulment, dissolution and declaration of 22 
invali dity of a marriage.  23 
4.  Function as a parent of the child.  "Function as a parent of the child" means to 24 
behave toward a child in a manner consistent with being the child's parent and to perform 25 
functions that are customarily performed by a parent, includi ng fulfilling parental 26 
responsibilities toward the child, recognizing or holding out the child as the individual's 27 
child, materially participating in the child's upbringing and residing with the child in the 28 
same household as a regular member of that house hold.  29 
5.  Genetic father.  "Genetic father" means the man whose sperm fertilized the egg 30 
of a child's genetic mother.  If the father -child relationship is established under the 31 
presumption of paternity under Title 19 -A, chapter 61, "genetic father" means o nly the 32 
man for whom that relationship is established.  33 
6.  Genetic mother.  "Genetic mother" means the woman whose egg was fertilized 34 
by the sperm of a child's genetic father.  35 
 
 Page 32 - 128LR0452(01) -1 
 7.  Genetic parent.  "Genetic parent" means a child's genetic father or genetic 1 
mother.  2 
8.  Incapacity.  "Incapacity" means the inability of an individual to function as a 3 
parent of a child because of the individual's physical or mental condition.  4 
9.  Relative.  "Relative" means a grandparent or a descendant of a grandparent.  5 
§2-116.  Effect of parent -child relationship  6 
Except as otherwise provided in section 2 -119, subsections 2 to 5, if a parent -child 7 
relationship exists or is established under this subpart or under Title 19 -A, chapter 61, the 8 
parent is a parent of the child and the child is a child of the parent for the purpose of 9 
intestate succession.  10 
§2-117.  No distinction based on marital status  11 
Except as otherwise provided in sections 2 -113, 2 -119, 2 -120 and 2 -121, a parent - 12 
child relationship exists between a child and the child 's genetic parents, regardless of the 13 
parents' marital status.  14 
§2-118.  Adoptee and adoptee's adoptive parent or parents  15 
1.  Parent -child relationship.  A parent -child relationship exists between an adoptee 16 
and the adoptee's adoptive parent or parents.  17 
2.  Treated as adopted.  For purposes of subsection 1:  18 
A.  An individual who is in the process of being adopted by a married couple when 19 
one of the spouses dies is treated as adopted by the deceased spouse if the adoption is 20 
subsequently granted to the decede nt's surviving spouse; and  21 
B.  A child of a genetic parent who is in the process of being adopted by a genetic 22 
parent's spouse when the spouse dies is treated as adopted by the deceased spouse if 23 
the genetic parent survives the deceased spouse by 120 hours . 24 
3.  Adoption by spouse.  If, after a parent -child relationship is established between a 25 
child of assisted reproduction and a parent under section 2 -120 or between a gestational 26 
child and a parent under section 2 -121, the child is in the process of being adopted by the 27 
parent's spouse when that spouse dies, the child is treated as adopted by the deceased 28 
spouse for the purpose of subsection 2, paragraph B.  29 
§2-119.  Adoptee and adoptee's genetic parents  30 
1.  No parent -child relationship.  Except as otherwise  provided in subsections 2 to 31 
5, a parent -child relationship does not exist between an adoptee and the adoptee's genetic 32 
parents.  33 
2.  Adopted by spouse of genetic parent.  A parent -child relationship exists between 34 
an individual who is adopted by the spous e of either genetic parent and:  35 
A.  The genetic parent whose spouse adopted the individual; and  36 
 
 Page 33 - 128LR0452(01) -1 
 B.  The other genetic parent, but only for the purpose of the right of the adoptee or a 1 
descendant of the adoptee to inherit from or through the other genetic p arent.  2 
3.  Adopted by relative of genetic parent.  A parent -child relationship exists 3 
between both genetic parents and an individual who is adopted by a relative of a genetic 4 
parent, or by the spouse or surviving spouse of a relative of a genetic parent, b ut only for 5 
the purpose of the right of the adoptee or a descendant of the adoptee to inherit from or 6 
through either genetic parent.  7 
4.  Adoption after death of genetic parents.  A parent -child relationship exists 8 
between both genetic parents and an indivi dual who is adopted after the death of both 9 
genetic parents, but only for the purpose of the right of the adoptee or a descendant of the 10 
adoptee to inherit through either genetic parent.  11 
5.  Child of assisted reproduction or gestational agreement.  If, aft er a parent - 12 
child relationship is established between a child of assisted reproduction and a parent or 13 
parents under section 2 -120 or between a gestational child and a parent or parents under 14 
section 2 -121, the child is adopted by another or others, the ch ild's parent or parents under 15 
section 2 -120 or 2 -121 are treated as the child's genetic parent or parents for the purpose 16 
of this section.  17 
6.  Inheritance in adoption decree.  Regardless of whether a parent -child 18 
relationship is established or not, an adop tee inherits from the adoptee's genetic parents if 19 
so provided in the adoption decree.  20 
§2-120.  Child conceived by assisted reproduction other than child born to 21 
gestational carrier or child born to surrogate  22 
1.  Definitions.  As used in this section, unle ss the context otherwise indicates, the 23 
following terms have the following meanings.  24 
A.  "Birth mother" means a woman, other than a gestational carrier or a surrogate 25 
under section 2 -121, who gives birth to a child of assisted reproduction.  "Birth 26 
mother"  is not limited to a woman who is the child's genetic mother.  27 
B.  "Child of assisted reproduction" means a child conceived by means of assisted 28 
reproduction by a woman other than a gestational carrier or surrogate under section 29 
2-121. 30 
C.  "Third -party dono r" means an individual who produces eggs or sperm used for 31 
assisted reproduction, whether or not for consideration.  "Third -party donor" does not 32 
include:  33 
(1)  A husband who provides sperm, or a wife who provides eggs, that are used 34 
for assisted reproducti on by the wife;  35 
(2)  The birth mother; or  36 
(3)  An individual who has been determined under subsection 5 or 6 to have a 37 
parent -child relationship with a child of assisted reproduction.  38 
 
 Page 34 - 128LR0452(01) -1 
 2.  Child of assisted reproduction and 3rd -party donor.  A parent -child 1 
relationship does not exist between a child of assisted reproduction and a 3rd -party donor.  2 
3.  Child of assisted reproduction and birth mother.  A parent -child relationship 3 
exists between a child of assisted reproduction and the child's birth mother.  4 
4.  Child of assisted reproduction and husband of birth mother.  Except as 5 
otherwise provided in subsections 1 and 11, a parent -child relationship exists between a 6 
child of assisted reproduction and the husband of the child's birth mother if the husband 7 
provid ed the sperm that the birth mother used during his lifetime for assisted 8 
reproduction.  9 
5.  Birth certificate presumptively establishes relationship.  A birth certificate 10 
identifying an individual other than the birth mother as the other parent of a child o f 11 
assisted reproduction presumptively establishes a parent -child relationship between the 12 
child and that individual.  13 
6.  Child of assisted reproduction and intended parent.  Except as otherwise 14 
provided in subsections 8, 10 and 11, and unless a parent -child relationship is established 15 
under subsection 4 or 5, a parent -child relationship exists between a child of assisted 16 
reproduction and an individual other than the birth mother who consented to assisted 17 
reproduction by the birth mother with intent to be tr eated as the other parent of the child.  18 
Consent to assisted reproduction by the birth mother with intent to be treated as the other 19 
parent of the child is established if the individual:  20 
A.  Before or after the child's birth, signed a record that, consider ing all the facts and 21 
circumstances, evidences the individual's consent; or  22 
B.  In the absence of a signed record under paragraph A:  23 
(1)  Functioned as a parent of the child no later than 2 years after the child's birth;  24 
(2)  Intended to function as a pare nt of the child no later than 2 years after the 25 
child's birth but was prevented from carrying out that intent by death, incapacity 26 
or other circumstances; or  27 
(3)  Intended to be treated as a parent of a posthumously conceived child, if that 28 
intent is estab lished by clear and convincing evidence.  29 
7.  Relationship conclusively established by court order.  A parent -child 30 
relationship is conclusively established by a court order designating the parent or parents 31 
of a child of assisted reproduction.  32 
8.  No inher itance if record more than 2 years after birth; exception.  For the 33 
purpose of subsection 6, paragraph A, neither an individual who signed a record more 34 
than 2 years after the birth of the child nor a relative of that individual who is not also a 35 
relative of the birth mother inherits from or through the child unless the individual 36 
functioned as a parent of the child before the child reached 18 years of age.  37 
9.  Spouse of birth mother.  For the purpose of subsection 6, paragraph B, the 38 
provisions of this sub section apply.  39

 A.  If the birth mother is married and no divorce proceeding is pending, in the 1

§2-121.  Child born to gestational carrier  23 
1.  Definitions.  As used in this section, unless the context otherwise indicates, the 24 
following terms have the following meanings.  25 
A.  "Gestatio nal agreement" means an enforceable or unenforceable agreement for 26 
assisted reproduction in which a woman agrees to carry a child to birth for an 27 
intended parent, intended parents or an individual described in subsection 6.  28 
B.  "Gestational carrier" means a woman who gives birth to a child under a 29 
gestational agreement and who:  30 
(1)  Has no genetic connection to the child; and  31 
(2)  Is not an intended parent.  32 
C.  "Gestational child" means a child born to a gestational carrier or surrogate under a 33 
gestational agreement.  34 
D.  "Intended parent" means an individual who entered into a gestational agreement 35 
providing that the individual will be the parent of a child born to a gestational carrier 36 
or surrogate by means of assisted reproduction.  "Intended parent" is no t limited to an 37 
individual who has a genetic relationship with the child.  38 
 
 Page 36 - 128LR0452(01) -1 
 E.  "Surrogate" means a woman who gives birth to a child under a gestational 1 
agreement and who:  2 
(1)  Has a genetic connection to the child; and  3 
(2)  Is not an intended parent.  4 
2.  Relationship conclusively established by court order.  A parent -child 5 
relationship is conclusively established by a court order designating the parent or parents 6 
of a gestational child.  7 
3.  Gestational child and gestational carrier.  A parent -child relations hip between a 8 
gestational child and the child's gestational carrier does not exist unless the gestational 9 
carrier is designated as a parent of the child in a court order described in subsection 2.  10 
4.  Gestational child and surrogate.  A parent -child relati onship between a 11 
gestational child and the child's surrogate does not exist unless the surrogate is:  12 
A.  Designated as a parent of the child in a court order described in subsection 2; or  13 
B.  The child's genetic mother and a parent -child relationship does not exist under this 14 
section with an individual other than the surrogate.  15 
5.  Gestational child and intended parent.  In the absence of a court order under 16 
subsection 2, a parent -child relationship exists between a gestational child and an 17 
intended parent who:  18 
A.  Functioned as a parent of the child no later than 2 years after the child's birth; or  19 
B.  Died while the gestational carrier or surrogate was pregnant if:  20 
(1)  There were 2 intended parents and the other intended parent functioned as a 21 
parent of t he child no later than 2 years after the child's birth;  22 
(2)  There were 2 intended parents, the other intended parent also died while the 23 
gestational carrier or surrogate was pregnant and a relative of either deceased 24 
intended parent or the spouse or survi ving spouse of a relative of either deceased 25 
intended parent functioned as a parent of the child no later than 2 years after the 26 
child's birth; or  27 
(3)  There was no other intended parent and a relative of or the spouse or 28 
surviving spouse of a relative of the deceased intended parent functioned as a 29 
parent of the child no later than 2 years after the child's birth.  30 
6.  Gestational child and provider of sperm or eggs after death or incapacity; 31 
intent.  In the absence of a court order under subsection 2, a pa rent-child relationship 32 
exists between a gestational child and an individual whose sperm or eggs were used after 33 
the individual's death or incapacity to conceive a child under a gestational agreement 34 
entered into after the individual's death or incapacity if the individual intended to be 35 
treated as the parent of the child.  The individual's intent may be shown by:  36 
A.  A record signed by the individual that considering all the facts and circumstances 37 
evidences the individual's intent; or  38 
 
 Page 37 - 128LR0452(01) -1 
 B.  Other facts and circumstances establishing the individual's intent by clear and 1 
convincing evidence.  2 
7.  Individual's presumed intent.  Except as otherwise provided in subsection 8, and 3 
unless there is clear and convincing evidence of a contrary intent, an individual is 4 
presumed to have intended to be treated as the parent of a gestational child for purposes 5 
of subsection 6, paragraph B if:  6 
A.  The individual, before death or incapacity, deposited the sperm or eggs that were 7 
used to conceive the child;  8 
B.  When the individ ual deposited the sperm or eggs, the individual was married and 9 
no divorce proceeding was pending; and  10 
C.  The individual's spouse or surviving spouse functioned as a parent of the child no 11 
later than 2 years after the child's birth.  12 
8.  Exception to presu mption.  The presumption under subsection 7 does not apply 13 
if there is:  14 
A.  A court order under subsection 2; or  15 
B.  A signed record that satisfies subsection 6, paragraph A.  16 
9.  Treated as in gestation.  If, under this section, an individual is a parent o f a 17 
gestational child who is conceived after the individual's death, the child is treated as in 18 
gestation at the individual's death for purposes of section 2 -104, subsection 1, paragraph 19 
B if the child is:  20 
A.  In utero not later than 36 months after the in dividual's death; or  21 
B.  Born not later than 45 months after the individual's death.  22 
10.  No effect on gestational agreement.  This section does not affect law of this 23 
State other than this Code regarding the enforceability or validity of a gestational 24 
agreement.  25 
PART 2  26 
ELECTIVE SHARE OF SU RVIVING SPOUSE  27 
§2-201.  Definitions  28 
As used in this Part, unless the context otherwise indicates, the following terms have 29 
the following meanings.  30 
1.  Decedent's nonprobate transfers to others.  As used in sections other than 31 
section 2 -205, "decedent's nonprobate transfers to others" means the amounts that are 32 
included in the augmented estate under section 2 -205. 33 
2.  Fractional interest in property held in joint tenancy with the right of 34 
survivorship.  "Fractional interest  in property held in joint tenancy with the right of 35 
survivorship," whether the fractional interest is unilaterally severable or not, means a 36 
 
 Page 38 - 128LR0452(01) -1 
 fraction, the numerator of which is one and the denominator of which, if the decedent was 1 
a joint tenant, is one p lus the number of joint tenants who survive the decedent or, if the 2 
decedent was not a joint tenant, is the number of joint tenants.  3 
3.  Marriage.  "Marriage," as it relates to a transfer by the decedent during marriage, 4 
means any marriage of the decedent to the decedent's surviving spouse.  5 
4.  Nonadverse party.  "Nonadverse party" means a person who does not have a 6 
substantial beneficial interest in the trust or other property arrangement that would be 7 
adversely affected by the exercise or nonexercise of t he power that the person possesses 8 
respecting the trust or other property arrangement.  A person having a general power of 9 
appointment over property is deemed to have a beneficial interest in the property.  10 
5.  Power; power of appointment.  "Power" or "powe r of appointment" includes a 11 
power to designate the beneficiary of a beneficiary designation.  12 
6.  Presently exercisable general power of appointment.  "Presently exercisable 13 
general power of appointment" means a power of appointment under which, at the tim e in 14 
question, the decedent, whether or not the decedent then had the capacity to exercise the 15 
power, held a power to create a present or future interest in the decedent, the decedent's 16 
creditors, the decedent's estate or creditors of the decedent's estate , and includes a power 17 
to revoke or invade the principal of a trust or other property arrangement.  18 
7.  Property.  "Property" includes values subject to a beneficiary designation.  19 
8.  Right to income.  "Right to income" includes a right to payments under a 20 
commercial or private annuity, an annuity trust, a unitrust or a similar arrangement.  21 
9.  Transfer.  "Transfer," as it relates to a transfer by or of the decedent, includes:  22 
A.  An exercise or release of a presently exercisable general power of appointment  23 
held by the decedent;  24 
B.  A lapse at death of a presently exercisable general power of appointment held by 25 
the decedent; and  26 
C.  An exercise, release or lapse of a general power of appointment that the decedent 27 
created in the decedent and of a power descr ibed in section 2 -205, subsection 2, 28 
paragraph B that the decedent conferred on a nonadverse party.  29 
§2-202.  Elective share  30 
1.  Elective -share amount.  The surviving spouse of a decedent who dies domiciled 31 
in this State has a right of election, under the l imitations and conditions stated in this Part, 32 
to take an elective -share amount equal to 50% of the value of the marital -property portion 33 
of the augmented estate.  34 
2.  Effect of election on statutory benefits.  If the right of election is exercised by or 35 
on behalf of the surviving spouse, the surviving spouse’s homestead allowance, exempt 36 
property and family allowance, if any, are not charged against but are in addition to the 37 
elective share.  38 
 
 Page 39 - 128LR0452(01) -1 
 3.  Nondomiciliary.  The right, if any, of the surviving spouse of  a decedent who dies 1 
domiciled outside this State to take an elective share in property in this State is governed 2 
by the law of the decedent’s domicile at death.  3 
§2-203.  Composition of the augmented estate; marital -property portion  4 
1.  Value of augmented estate.  Subject to section 2 -208, the value of the augmented 5 
estate, to the extent provided in sections 2 -204, 2 -205, 2 -206 and 2 -207, consists of the 6 
sum of the values of all property, whether real or personal, movable or immovable, 7 
tangible or intangibl e, wherever situated, that constitute:  8 
A.  The decedent’s net probate estate;  9 
B.  The decedent’s nonprobate transfers to others;  10 
C.  The decedent’s nonprobate transfers to the surviving spouse; and  11 
D.  The surviving spouse’s property and nonprobate transfe rs to others.  12 
2.  Value of marital -property portion.  The value of the marital -property portion of 13 
the augmented estate consists of the sum of the values of the 4 components of the 14 
augmented estate as determined under subsection 1 multiplied by a percentag e as follows.  15 
If the decedent and the spouse were married to each other:  16 
A.  Less than one year, the percentage is 3%;  17 
B.  One year but less than 2 years, the percentage is 6%;  18 
C.  Two years but less than 3 years, the percentage is 12%;  19 
D.  Three years but  less than 4 years, the percentage is 18%;  20 
E.  Four years but less than 5 years, the percentage is 24%;  21 
F.  Five years but less than 6 years, the percentage is 30%;  22 
G.  Six years but less than 7 years, the percentage is 36%;  23 
H.  Seven years but less than 8  years, the percentage is 42%;  24 
I.  Eight years but less than 9 years, the percentage is 48%;  25 
J.  Nine years but less than 10 years, the percentage is 54%;  26 
K.  Ten years but less than 11 years, the percentage is 60%;  27 
L.  Eleven years but less than 12 years,  the percentage is 68%;  28 
M.  Twelve years but less than 13 years, the percentage is 76%;  29 
N.  Thirteen years but less than 14 years, the percentage is 84%;  30 
O.  Fourteen years but less than 15 years, the percentage is 92%; and  31 
P.  Fifteen years or more, the p ercentage is 100%.  32 
 
 Page 40 - 128LR0452(01) -1 
 §2-204.  Decedent’s net probate estate  1 
The value of the augmented estate includes the value of the decedent’s probate estate 2 
reduced by funeral and administration expenses, homestead allowance, family 3 
allowances, exempt property and enfo rceable claims.  4 
§2-205.  Decedent’s nonprobate transfers to others  5 
The value of the augmented estate includes the value of the decedent’s nonprobate 6 
transfers to others, not included under section 2 -204, of any of the following types, in the 7 
amount provide d respectively for each type of transfer:  8 
1.  Passed outside probate at death.  Property owned or owned in substance by the 9 
decedent immediately before death that passed outside probate at the decedent’s death.  10 
Property is included under this category onl y if it consists of any of the following types:  11 
A.  Property over which the decedent alone, immediately before death, held a 12 
presently exercisable general power of appointment.  The amount included is the 13 
value of the property subject to the power, to the extent the property passed at the 14 
decedent’s death, by exercise, release, lapse, in default or otherwise, to or for the 15 
benefit of any person other than the decedent’s estate or surviving spouse;  16 
B.  The decedent’s fractional interest in property held in j oint tenancy with the right 17 
of survivorship.  The amount included is the value of the decedent’s fractional 18 
interest, to the extent the fractional interest passed by right of survivorship at the 19 
decedent’s death to a surviving joint tenant other than the d ecedent’s surviving 20 
spouse;  21 
C.  The decedent’s ownership interest in property or accounts held in POD, TOD or 22 
co-ownership registration with the right of survivorship.  The amount included is the 23 
value of the decedent’s ownership interest, to the extent th e decedent’s ownership 24 
interest passed at the decedent’s death to or for the benefit of any person other than 25 
the decedent’s estate or surviving spouse; or  26 
D.  Proceeds of insurance, including accidental death benefits, on the life of the 27 
decedent, if the decedent owned the insurance policy immediately before death or if 28 
and to the extent the decedent alone and immediately before death held a presently 29 
exercisable general power of appointment over the policy or its proceeds.  The 30 
amount included is the valu e of the proceeds, to the extent they were payable at the 31 
decedent’s death to or for the benefit of any person other than the decedent’s estate or 32 
surviving spouse;  33 
2.  Transferred during marriage.  Property transferred in any of the following 34 
forms by the  decedent during marriage:  35 
A.  Any irrevocable transfer in which the decedent retained the right to the possession 36 
or enjoyment of, or to the income from, the property if and to the extent the 37 
decedent’s right terminated at or continued beyond the decedent ’s death.  The amount 38 
included is the value of the fraction of the property to which the decedent’s right 39 
related, to the extent the fraction of the property passed outside probate to or for the 40 
benefit of any person other than the decedent’s estate or sur viving spouse; or  41 
 
 Page 41 - 128LR0452(01) -1 
 B.  Any transfer in which the decedent created a power over income or property, 1 
exercisable by the decedent alone or in conjunction with any other person, or 2 
exercisable by a nonadverse party, to or for the benefit of the decedent, credit ors of 3 
the decedent, the decedent’s estate or creditors of the decedent’s estate.  The amount 4 
included with respect to a power over property is the value of the property subject to 5 
the power, and the amount included with respect to a power over income is t he value 6 
of the property that produces or produced the income, to the extent the power in 7 
either case was exercisable at the decedent’s death to or for the benefit of any person 8 
other than the decedent’s surviving spouse or to the extent the property passe d at the 9 
decedent’s death, by exercise, release, lapse, in default or otherwise, to or for the 10 
benefit of any person other than the decedent’s estate or surviving spouse.  If the 11 
power is a power over both income and property and the preceding sentence pro duces 12 
different amounts, the amount included is the greater amount; and  13 
3.  Passed during marriage within 2 years before death.  Property that passed 14 
during marriage and during the 2 -year period next preceding the decedent’s death as a 15 
result of a transfer  by the decedent if the transfer was of any of the following types:  16 
A.  Any property that passed as a result of the termination of a right or interest in, or 17 
power over, property that would have been included in the augmented estate under 18 
subsection 1, par agraph A, B or C, or under subsection 2, if the right, interest or 19 
power had not terminated until the decedent’s death.  The amount included is the 20 
value of the property that would have been included under those paragraphs if the 21 
property were valued at th e time the right, interest or power terminated, and is 22 
included only to the extent the property passed upon termination to or for the benefit 23 
of any person other than the decedent or the decedent’s estate, spouse or surviving 24 
spouse.  For purposes of this paragraph, termination, with respect to a right or interest 25 
in property, occurs when the right or interest terminated by the terms of the governing 26 
instrument or the decedent transferred or relinquished the right or interest, and, with 27 
respect to a power o ver property, occurs when the power terminated by exercise, 28 
release, lapse, default or otherwise, but, with respect to a power described in 29 
subsection 1, paragraph A, termination occurs when the power terminated by exercise 30 
or release, but not otherwise;  31 
B.  Any transfer of or relating to an insurance policy on the life of the decedent if the 32 
proceeds would have been included in the augmented estate under subsection 1, 33 
paragraph D had the transfer not occurred.  The amount included is the value of the 34 
insur ance proceeds to the extent the proceeds were payable at the decedent’s death to 35 
or for the benefit of any person other than the decedent’s estate or surviving spouse; 36 
or 37 
C.  Any transfer of property, to the extent not otherwise included in the augmented 38 
estate, made to or for the benefit of a person other than the decedent’s surviving 39 
spouse.  The amount included is the value of the transferred property to the extent the 40 
transfers to any one donee in either of the 2 years exceeded 50% of the amount 41 
excluda ble from taxable gifts under 26 United States Code, Section 2503(b) or its 42 
successor on the date next preceding the date of the decedent’s death.  43 
 
 Page 42 - 128LR0452(01) -1 
 §2-206.  Decedent's nonprobate transfers to the surviving spouse  1 
Excluding property passing to the surviving s pouse under the federal Social Security 2 
system, the value of the augmented estate includes the value of the decedent’s nonprobate 3 
transfers to the decedent’s surviving spouse, which consist of all property that passed 4 
outside probate at the decedent’s deat h from the decedent to the surviving spouse by 5 
reason of the decedent’s death, including:  6 
1.  Joint tenancy.  The decedent's fractional interest in property held in joint tenancy 7 
with the right of survivorship, to the extent that the decedent's fractional interest passed to 8 
the surviving spouse as surviving joint tenant;  9 
2.  Co-ownership registration.  The decedent's ownership interest in property or 10 
accounts held in co -ownership registration with the right of survivorship, to the extent the 11 
decedent's owne rship interest passed to the surviving spouse as surviving co -owner; and  12 
3.  Other nonprobate transfers.  All other property that would have been included 13 
in the augmented estate under section 2 -205, subsection 1 or 2 had it passed to or for the 14 
benefit of  a person other than the decedent's spouse, surviving spouse, the decedent or the 15 
decedent's creditors, estate or estate creditors.  16 
§2-207.  Surviving spouse's property and nonprobate transfers to others  17 
1.  Included property.  Except to the extent include d in the augmented estate under 18 
section 2 -204 or 2 -206, the value of the augmented estate includes the value of:  19

(1)  The surviving spouse's fractional inter est in property held in joint tenancy 22 
with the right of survivorship;  23 
(2)  The surviving spouse's ownership interest in property or accounts held in co - 24 
ownership registration with the right of survivorship; and  25 
(3)  Property that passed to the surviving sp ouse by reason of the decedent's 26 
death, but not including the spouse's right to homestead allowance, family 27 
allowance, exempt property or payments under the federal Social Security 28 
system; and  29 
B.  Property that would have been included in the surviving spo use's nonprobate 30 
transfers to others, other than the spouse's fractional and ownership interests included 31 
under subsection 1, paragraph A, subparagraph (1) or (2), had the spouse been the 32 
decedent.  33 
2.  Time of valuation.  Property included under this secti on is valued at the 34 
decedent's death, taking the fact that the decedent predeceased the spouse into account, 35 
but, for purposes of subsection 1, paragraph A, subparagraphs (1) and (2), the values of 36 
the spouse's fractional and ownership interests are determ ined immediately before the 37 
decedent's death if the decedent was then a joint tenant or a co -owner of the property or 38 
accounts.  For purposes of subsection 1, paragraph B, proceeds of insurance that would 39 
 
 Page 43 - 128LR0452(01) -1 
 have been included in the spouse's nonprobate trans fers to others under section 2 -205, 1 
subsection 1, paragraph D are not valued as if the spouse were deceased.  2 
3.  Reduction for enforceable claims.  The value of property included under this 3 
section is reduced by enforceable claims against the surviving spo use. 4 
§2-208.  Exclusions, valuation and overlapping application  5 
1.  Exclusions.  The value of any property is excluded from the decedent's 6 
nonprobate transfers to others:  7 
A.  To the extent the decedent received adequate and full consideration in money or 8 
money's worth for a transfer of the property; or  9 
B.  If the property was transferred with the written joinder of, or if the transfer was 10 
consented to in writing before or after the transfer by, the surviving spouse.  11 
2.  Valuation.  The value of property is  determined as follows.  12 
A.  The value of property included in the augmented estate under section 2 -205, 13 
2-206 or 2 -207 is reduced in each category by enforceable claims against the included 14 
property.  15 
B.  The value of property includes the commuted value of  any present or future 16 
interest and the commuted value of amounts payable under any trust, life insurance 17 
settlement option, annuity contract, public or private pension, disability 18 
compensation, death benefit or retirement plan or any similar arrangement, exclusive 19 
of the federal Social Security system.  20 
3.  Overlapping application; no double exclusion.  In case of overlapping 21 
application to the same property of the provisions of section 2 -205, 2 -206 or 2 -207, the 22 
property is included in the augmented estate  under the provision yielding the greatest 23 
value, and under only one overlapping provision if they all yield the same value.  24 
§2-209.  Sources from which elective share payable  25 
1.  Elective -share amount only.  In a proceeding for an elective share, the foll owing 26 
are applied first to satisfy the elective -share amount and to reduce or eliminate any 27 
contributions due from the decedent's probate estate and recipients of the decedent's 28 
nonprobate transfers to others:  29 
A.  Amounts included in the augmented estate u nder section 2 -204 that pass or have 30 
passed to the surviving spouse by testate or intestate succession and amounts 31 
included in the augmented estate under section 2 -206; and  32 
B.  The marital -property portion of amounts included in the augmented estate under 33 
section 2 -207. 34 
2.  Marital -property portion.  The marital -property portion under subsection 1, 35 
paragraph B is computed by multiplying the value of the amounts included in the 36 
augmented estate under section 2 -207 by the percentage of the augmented estate se t forth 37 
 
 Page 44 - 128LR0452(01) -1 
 in the schedule in section 2 -203, subsection 2 appropriate to the length of time the spouse 1 
and the decedent were married to each other.  2 
3.  Unsatisfied balance of elective -share amount; net probate estate.  If, after the 3 
application of subsection 1, the elective -share amount is not fully satisfied, or the 4 
surviving spouse is entitled to a supplemental elective -share amount, amounts included in 5 
the decedent's net probate estate, other than assets passing to the surviving spouse by 6 
testate or intesta te succession, and in the decedent's nonprobate transfers to others under 7 
section 2 -205, subsections 1 and 2 and section 2 -205, subsection 3, paragraph B are 8 
applied first to satisfy the unsatisfied balance of the elective -share amount or the 9 
supplemental elective -share amount.  The decedent's net probate estate and that portion of 10 
the decedent's nonprobate transfers to others are applied so that liability for the 11 
unsatisfied balance of the elective -share amount or for the supplemental elective -share 12 
amount  is apportioned among the recipients of the decedent's net probate estate and of 13 
that portion of the decedent's nonprobate transfers to others in proportion to the value of 14 
their interests therein.  15 
4.  Unsatisfied balance of elective share; nonprobate tran sfers.  If, after the 16 
application of subsections 1 and 2, the elective -share or supplemental elective -share 17 
amount is not fully satisfied, the remaining portion of the decedent's nonprobate transfers 18 
to others is applied so that liability for the unsatisfi ed balance of the elective -share or 19 
supplemental elective -share amount is apportioned among the recipients of the remaining 20 
portion of the decedent's nonprobate transfers to others in proportion to the value of their 21 
interests therein.  22 
5.  Unsatisfied bala nce treated as general pecuniary devise.  The unsatisfied 23 
balance of the elective -share or supplemental elective -share amount as determined under 24 
subsection 3 or 4 is treated as a general pecuniary devise for purposes of section 3 -904. 25 
§2-210.  Personal li ability of recipients  26 
1.  Original recipients; satisfaction of elective -share amount.  Only original 27 
recipients of the decedent's nonprobate transfers to others, and the donees of the 28 
recipients of the decedent's nonprobate transfers to others to the exten t the donees have 29 
the property or its proceeds, are liable to make a proportional contribution toward 30 
satisfaction of the surviving spouse's elective -share amount.  A person liable to make a 31 
contribution may choose to give up the proportional part of the d ecedent's nonprobate 32 
transfers to that person or to pay the value of the amount for which that person is liable.  33 
2.  Preemption; obligated and personally liable.  If any section or part of any 34 
section of this Part is preempted by federal law with respect t o a payment, an item of 35 
property or any other benefit included in the decedent's nonprobate transfers to others, a 36 
person who, not for value, receives the payment, item of property or any other benefit is 37 
obligated to return the payment, item of property o r benefit or is personally liable for the 38 
amount of the payment or the value of that item of property or benefit, as provided in 39 
section 2 -209, to the person who would have been entitled to it were that section or part 40 
of that section not preempted.  41 
 
 Page 45 - 128LR0452(01) -1 
 §2-211.  Proceeding for elective share; time limit  1 
1.  Time of election.  Except as provided in subsection 2, the surviving spouse or the 2 
surviving spouse's conservator or agent under authority of a power of attorney must make 3 
the election by filing in the court  and mailing or delivering to the personal representative, 4 
if any, a petition for the elective share within 9 months after the date of the decedent's 5 
death or within 6 months after the probate of the decedent's will, whichever limitation 6 
later expires.  No tice of the time and place set for the hearing must be given to persons 7 
interested in the estate and to the distributees and recipients of portions of the augmented 8 
estate whose interests will be adversely affected by the taking of the elective share.  9 
Except as provided in subsection 2, the decedent's nonprobate transfers to others are not 10 
included within the augmented estate for the purpose of computing the elective share if 11 
the petition is filed more than 9 months after the decedent's death.  12 
2.  Extensio n.  Within 9 months after the decedent's death, a petition for an extension 13 
of time for making an election may be filed by the surviving spouse or the surviving 14 
spouse's conservator or agent under authority of a power of attorney.  If, within 9 months 15 
after the decedent's death, notice is given of the petition to all persons interested in the 16 
decedent's nonprobate transfers to others, the court for cause shown may extend the time 17 
for election.  If the court grants the petition for an extension, the decedent 's nonprobate 18 
transfers to others are not excluded from the augmented estate for the purpose of 19 
computing the elective -share amount, if the election is made by filing in the court and 20 
mailing or delivering to the personal representative, if any, a petition  for the elective 21 
share within the time allowed by the extension.  22 
3.  Withdrawal of demand.  A demand for an elective share may be withdrawn at 23 
any time before entry of a final determination by the court.  24 
4.  Court determination.  After notice and hearing,  the court shall determine the 25 
elective -share amount, and shall order its payment from the assets of the augmented 26 
estate or by contribution as appears appropriate under sections 2 -209 and 2 -210.  If it 27 
appears that a fund or property included in the augme nted estate has not come into the 28 
possession of the personal representative, or has been distributed by the personal 29 
representative, the court nevertheless shall fix the liability of any person who has any 30 
interest in the fund or property or who has posses sion thereof, whether as trustee or 31 
otherwise.  The proceeding may be maintained against fewer than all persons against 32 
whom relief could be sought, but a person is not subject to contribution in any greater 33 
amount than the person would have been under sec tions 2 -209 and 2 -210 had relief been 34 
secured against all persons subject to contribution.  35 
5.  Enforcement.  An order or judgment of the court may be enforced as necessary in 36 
suit for contribution or payment in other courts of this State or other jurisdict ions.  37 
§2-212.  Right of election personal to surviving spouse  38 
The right of election may be exercised only by a surviving spouse who is living when 39 
the petition for the elective share is filed in the court under section 2 -211, subsection 1.  If 40 
the election  is not exercised by the surviving spouse personally, it may be exercised on 41 
 
 Page 46 - 128LR0452(01) -1 
 the surviving spouse's behalf by the surviving spouse's conservator or agent under 1 
authority of a power of attorney.  2 
§2-213.  Waiver of right to elect and of other rights  3 
1.  Waiv er of election and statutory benefits.  The right of election of a surviving 4 
spouse and the rights of the surviving spouse to homestead allowance, exempt property 5 
and family allowance may be waived, wholly or partially, before or after marriage, by a 6 
writt en contract, agreement or waiver signed by the surviving spouse.  7 
2.  Waiver not enforceable.  A surviving spouse's waiver is not enforceable if the 8 
surviving spouse proves that:  9 
A.  The surviving spouse did not execute the waiver voluntarily; or  10 
B.  The w aiver was unconscionable when it was executed and, before execution of 11 
the waiver, the surviving spouse:  12 
(1)  Was not provided a fair and reasonable disclosure of the property or financial 13 
obligations of the decedent;  14 
(2)  Did not voluntarily and expressly  waive, in writing, any right to disclosure of 15 
the property or financial obligations of the decedent beyond the disclosure 16 
provided; and  17 
(3)  Did not have, or reasonably could not have had, an adequate knowledge of 18 
the property or financial obligations of the decedent.  19 
3.  Unconscionability.  An issue of unconscionability of a waiver is for decision by 20 
the court as a matter of law.  21 
4.  Waiver of "all rights."  Unless it provides to the contrary, a waiver of "all 22 
rights," or equivalent language, in the prope rty or estate of a present or prospective 23 
spouse or a complete property settlement entered into after or in anticipation of separation 24 
or divorce is a waiver of all rights of elective share, homestead allowance, exempt 25 
property and family allowance by each  spouse in the property of the other and a 26 
renunciation by each of all benefits that would otherwise pass to the spouse from the 27 
other by intestate succession or by virtue of any will executed before the waiver or 28 
property settlement.  29 
§2-214.  Protection o f payors and other 3rd parties  30 
1.  Liability of payors and other 3rd parties.  Although under section 2 -205 a 31 
payment, item of property or other benefit is included in the decedent's nonprobate 32 
transfers to others, a payor or other 3rd party is not liable for having made a payment or 33 
transferred an item of property or other benefit to a beneficiary designated in a governing 34 
instrument, or for having taken any other action in good faith reliance on the validity of a 35 
governing instrument, upon request and sat isfactory proof of the decedent's death, before 36 
the payor or other 3rd party received written notice from the surviving spouse or spouse's 37 
representative of an intention to file a petition for the elective share or that a petition for 38 
the elective share ha s been filed.  A payor or other 3rd party is liable for payments made 39 
 
 Page 47 - 128LR0452(01) -1 
 or other actions taken after the payor or other 3rd party received written notice that a 1 
petition for the elective share has been filed.  2 
2.  Notice to payors and other 3rd parties.  A wr itten notice of intention to file a 3 
petition for the elective share or that a petition for the elective share has been filed must 4 
be mailed to the payor's or other 3rd party's main office or home by registered or certified 5 
mail, return receipt requested, o r served upon the payor or other 3rd party in the same 6 
manner as a summons in a civil action.  Upon receipt of written notice of intention to file 7 
a petition for the elective share or that a petition for the elective share has been filed, a 8 
payor or other 3rd party may pay any amount owed or transfer or deposit any item of 9 
property held by it to or with the court having jurisdiction of the probate proceedings 10 
relating to the decedent's estate or, if no proceedings have been commenced, to or with 11 
the court h aving jurisdiction of probate proceedings relating to decedents' estates located 12 
in the county of the decedent's residence.  The court shall hold the funds or item of 13 
property and, upon its determination under section 2 -211, subsection 4, shall order 14 
disbu rsement in accordance with the determination.  If no petition is filed in the court 15 
within the specified time under section 2 -211, subsection 1 or, if filed, the demand for an 16 
elective share is withdrawn under section 2 -211, subsection 3, the court shall o rder 17 
disbursement to the designated beneficiary.  Payments or transfers to the court or deposits 18 
made into court discharge the payor or other 3rd party from all claims for amounts so 19 
paid or the value of property so transferred or deposited.  20 
3.  Petition b y beneficiary; court order.  Upon petition to the court by the 21 
beneficiary designated in a governing instrument, the court may order that all or part of 22 
the property be paid to the beneficiary in an amount and subject to conditions consistent 23 
with this Par t. 24 
PART 3  25 
SPOUSE AND CHILDREN UNPROVIDED FOR IN WI LLS 26 
§2-301.  Entitlement of spouse; premarital will  27 
1.  Entitlement of spouse.  If a testator's surviving spouse married the testator after 28 
the testator executed a will, the surviving spouse is entitled to receive, as an intestate 29 
share, no less than the value of the share of the estate the surviving spouse would have 30 
received if the testator had died intestate as to that portion of the testator's estate, if any, 31 
that neither is devised to a child of the tes tator who was born before the testator married 32 
the surviving spouse and who is not a child of the surviving spouse nor is devised to a 33 
descendant of such a child or passes under section 2 -603 or 2 -604 to such a child or to a 34 
descendant of such a child, unl ess: 35 
A.  It appears from the will or other evidence that the will was made in contemplation 36 
of the testator's marriage to the surviving spouse;  37 
B.  The will expresses the intention that it is to be effective notwithstanding any 38 
subsequent marriage; or  39 
 
 Page 48 - 128LR0452(01) -1 
 C.  The testator provided for the spouse by transfer outside the will and the intent that 1 
the transfer be in lieu of a testamentary provision is shown by the testator's statements 2 
or is reasonably inferred from the amount of the transfer or other evidence.  3 
2.  Devises by will to spouse; others abate.  In satisfying the share provided by this 4 
section, devises made by the will to the testator's surviving spouse, if any, are applied 5 
first, and other devises, other than a devise to a child of the testator who was b orn before 6 
the testator married the surviving spouse and who is not a child of the surviving spouse or 7 
a devise or substitute gift under section 2 -603 or 2 -604 to a descendant of such a child, 8 
abate as provided in section 3 -902. 9 
§2-302.  Omitted children  10 
1.  Omitted children shares.  Except as provided in subsection 2, if a testator fails to 11 
provide in the testator's will for any of the testator's children born or adopted after the 12 
execution of the will, the omitted after -born or after -adopted child receive s a share in the 13 
estate as follows:  14 
A.  If a testator had no child living when the testator executed the will, an omitted 15 
after-born or after -adopted child receives a share in the estate equal in value to that 16 
which the child would have received had the te stator died intestate, unless the will 17 
devised all or substantially all of the estate to the other parent of the omitted child and 18 
that other parent survives the testator and is entitled to take under the will.  19 
B.  If a testator had one or more children li ving when the testator executed the will, 20 
and the will devised property or an interest in property to one or more of the then - 21 
living children, an omitted after -born or after -adopted child is entitled to share in the 22 
testator's estate as follows:  23 
(1)  The p ortion of the testator's estate in which the omitted after -born or after - 24 
adopted child is entitled to share is limited to devises made to the testator's then - 25 
living children under the will;  26 
(2)  The omitted after -born or after -adopted child is entitled to receive the share 27 
of the testator's estate, as limited in subparagraph (1), that the child would have 28 
received had the testator included all omitted after -born and after -adopted 29 
children with the children to whom devises were made under the will and had 30 
given an equal share of the estate to each child;  31 
(3)  To the extent feasible, the interest granted an omitted after -born or after - 32 
adopted child under this paragraph must be of the same character, whether 33 
equitable or legal, present or future, as that devise d to the testator's then -living 34 
children under the will; and  35 
(4)  In satisfying a share provided by this paragraph, devises to the testator's 36 
children who were living when the will was executed abate ratably.  In abating 37 
the devises of the then -living chil dren, the court shall preserve to the maximum 38 
extent possible the character of the testamentary plan adopted by the testator.  39 
2.  No shares for omitted children.  Neither subsection 1, paragraph A nor 40 
subsection 1, paragraph B applies if:  41 
 
 Page 49 - 128LR0452(01) -1 
 A.  It appears fr om the will that the omission was intentional; or  1 
B.  The testator provided for the omitted after -born or after -adopted child by transfer 2 
outside the will and the intent that the transfer be in lieu of a testamentary provision 3 
is shown by the testator's st atements or is reasonably inferred from the amount of the 4 
transfer or other evidence.  5 
3.  Child believed to be dead.  If at the time of execution of the will the testator fails 6 
to provide in the testator's will for a living child solely because the testato r believes the 7 
child to be dead, the child is entitled to share in the estate as if the child were an omitted 8 
after-born or after -adopted child.  9 
4.  Shares abate.  In satisfying a share provided by subsection 1, paragraph A, 10 
devises made by the will abate under section 3 -902. 11 
PART 4  12 
EXEMPT PROPERTY AND ALLOWANCES  13 
§2-401.  Applicable law  14 
This Part applies to the estate of the decedent who dies domiciled in this State.  15 
Rights to homestead allowance, exempt property and family allowance for a decedent 16 
who die s not domiciled in this State are governed by the law of the decedent's domicile at 17 
death.  18 
§2-402.  Homestead allowance  19 
A decedent's surviving spouse is entitled to a homestead allowance of $22,500.  If 20 
there is no surviving spouse, each minor child and ea ch dependent child of the decedent is 21 
entitled to a homestead allowance amounting to $22,500 divided by the number of minor 22 
and dependent children of the decedent.  The homestead allowance is exempt from and 23 
has priority over all claims against the estate.   Homestead allowance is in addition to any 24 
share passing to the surviving spouse or minor or dependent child by the decedent's will 25 
unless otherwise provided by intestate succession or by way of elective share.  26 
§2-403.  Exempt property  27 
In addition to the homestead allowance, the decedent's surviving spouse is entitled 28 
from the estate to a value, not exceeding $15,000 in excess of any security interests in the 29 
estate, in household furniture, automobiles, furnishings, appliances and personal effects.  30 
If the re is no surviving spouse, children of the decedent are entitled jointly to the same 31 
value; however, the decedent, by will, may exclude one or more adult children from the 32 
receipt of exempt property.  If encumbered chattels are selected and the value in ex cess of 33 
security interests, plus that of other exempt property, is less than $15,000, or if there is 34 
not $15,000 worth of exempt property in the estate, the spouse or children are entitled to 35 
other assets of the estate, if any, to the extent necessary to m ake up the $15,000 value.  36 
Rights to exempt property and assets needed to make up a deficiency of exempt property 37 
have priority over all claims against the estate, except that the right to any assets to make 38 
up a deficiency of exempt property abates as nec essary to permit earlier payment of 39 
 
 Page 50 - 128LR0452(01) -1 
 homestead allowance and family allowance.  These rights are in addition to any benefit or 1 
share passing to the surviving spouse or children by the decedent's will unless otherwise 2 
provided by intestate succession or by w ay of elective share.  3 
§2-404.  Family allowance  4 
1.  Family allowance during administration.  In addition to the right to homestead 5 
allowance and exempt property, the decedent's surviving spouse and minor children 6 
whom the decedent was obligated to support and children who were in fact being 7 
supported by the decedent are entitled to a reasonable allowance in money out of the 8 
estate for their maintenance during the period of administration, which allowance may 9 
not continue for longer than one year if the esta te is inadequate to discharge allowed 10 
claims.  The allowance may be paid as a lump sum or in periodic installments.  It is 11 
payable to the surviving spouse, if living, for the use of the surviving spouse and minor 12 
and dependent children; otherwise to the ch ildren, or persons having their care and 13 
custody.  If a minor child or dependent child is not living with the surviving spouse, the 14 
allowance may be made partially to the child or the child's guardian or other person 15 
having the child's care and custody, an d partially to the spouse, as their needs may appear.  16 
The family allowance is exempt from and has priority over all claims but not over the 17 
homestead allowance.  18 
2.  Not chargeable against benefit or share; right terminates on death.  The 19 
family allowance is not chargeable against any benefit or share passing to the surviving 20 
spouse or children by the decedent's will unless otherwise provided by intestate 21 
succession or by way of elective share.  The death of any person entitled to family 22 
allowance terminate s that person's right to allowance not yet paid.  23 
§2-405.  Source, determination and documentation  24 
If the estate is otherwise sufficient, property specifically devised may not be used to 25 
satisfy rights to homestead and exempt property.  Subject to this rest riction, the surviving 26 
spouse, the guardians of minor children or children who are adults may select property of 27 
the estate as homestead allowance and exempt property.  The personal representative may 28 
make these selections if the surviving spouse, the chil dren or the guardians of the minor 29 
children are unable or fail to do so within a reasonable time or there is no guardian of a 30 
minor child.  The personal representative may execute an instrument or deed of 31 
distribution to establish the ownership of property  taken as homestead allowance or 32 
exempt property.  The personal representative may determine the family allowance in a 33 
lump sum not exceeding $27,000 or periodic installments not exceeding $2,250 per 34 
month for one year, and may disburse funds of the estate  in payment of the family 35 
allowance and any part of the homestead allowance payable in cash.  The personal 36 
representative or any interested person aggrieved by any selection, determination, 37 
payment, proposed payment or failure to act under this section may  petition the court for 38 
appropriate relief, which relief may include a family allowance other than that which the 39 
personal representative determined or could have determined.  40 
PART 5  41 
WILLS  42

 §2-501.  Who may make a will  1 
An individual of sound mind who is 18 o r more years of age or a legally emancipated 2 
minor may make a will.  3 
§2-502.  Execution; holographic wills  4 
1.  Witnessed wills.  Except as otherwise provided in subsection 2 and in sections 5 
2-505 and 2 -512, a will must be:  6 
A.  In writing;  7 
B.  Signed by the testator or in the testator's name by some other individual in the 8 
testator's conscious presence and by the testator's direction; and  9 
C.  Signed by at least 2 individuals, each of whom signed within a reasonable time 10 
after the individual witnessed either t he signing of the will as described in paragraph 11 
B or the testator's acknowledgment of that signature or acknowledgment of the will.  12 
2.  Holographic wills.  A will that does not comply with subsection 1 is valid as a 13 
holographic will, whether or not witnes sed, if the signature and material portions of the 14 
document are in the testator's handwriting.  15 
3.  Extrinsic evidence.  Intent that a document constitute the testator's will may be 16 
established by extrinsic evidence, including, for holographic wills, portio ns of the 17 
document that are not in the testator's handwriting.  18 
§2-503.  Self -proved will  19 
1.  Self-proved at execution.  Any will may be simultaneously executed, attested and 20 
made self -proved by acknowledgment thereof by the testator and affidavits of the 21 
witnesses, each made before an officer authorized to administer oaths under the laws of 22 
the state where execution occurs and evidenced by the officer's certificate in substantially 23 
the following form:  24

duly sworn, do hereby declare to the undersigned authority that I sign and execute this 26 
instrument as my last will and that I sign it willingly (or willingly direct another to sign 27 
for me), as my fr ee and voluntary act and that I am eighteen years of age or older or am a 28 
legally emancipated minor, of sound mind, and under no constraint or undue influence.  29
