3.  Affidavit sufficient.  A signature affixed to a self -proving affidavit attached to a 7 
will is considered a signature affixed to the will, if necessary to  prove the will's due 8 
execution.  9 
§2-504.  Who may witness a will  10 
1.  Witness.  An individual generally competent to be a witness may act as a witness 11 
to a will.  12 
2.  Interested witness.  The signing of a will by an interested witness does not 13 
invalidate the  will or any portion of it.  14 
§2-505.  Choice of law as to execution  15 
A written will is valid if executed in compliance with section 2 -502 or if its execution 16 
complies with the law at the time of execution of the place where the will is executed, or 17 
of the la w of the place where at the time of execution or at the time of death the testator is 18 
domiciled, has a place of abode or is a national or if executed in compliance with 10 19 
United States Code, Section 1044d.  20 
§2-506.  Revocation by writing or by act  21 
1.  Revo cation.  A will or any part thereof is revoked:  22 
A.  By the execution of a subsequent will that revokes the previous will or part 23 
expressly or by inconsistency; or  24 
B.  By the performance of a revocatory act on the will, if the testator performs the act 25 
with the intent and for the purpose of revoking the will or part or if another individual 26 
performs the act in the testator's conscious presence and by the testator's direction.  27 
For purposes of this paragraph, "revocatory act on the will" includes burning, tea ring, 28 
canceling, obliterating or destroying the will or any part of it.  A burning, tearing or 29 
canceling is a revocatory act on the will, whether or not the burn, tear or cancellation 30 
touched any of the words on the will.  31 
2.  Intent to replace previous wil l.  If a subsequent will does not expressly revoke a 32 
previous will, the execution of the subsequent will wholly revokes the previous will by 33  (Signed) ..........................................................  
 ...................................................................  
 (Official capacity of officer)  
 
 Page 54 - 128LR0452(01) -1 
 inconsistency if the testator intended the subsequent will to replace rather than 1 
supplement the previous will.  2 
3.  Presumption of intent to replace.  The testator is presumed to have intended a 3 
subsequent will to replace rather than supplement a previous will if the subsequent will 4 
makes a complete disposition of the testator's estate.  If this presumption arises and is not 5 
rebutted by clear and convincing evidence, the previous will is revoked; only the 6 
subsequent will is operative on the testator's death.  7 
4.  Presumption of intent to supplement.  The testator is presumed to have intended 8 
a subsequent will to suppleme nt rather than replace a previous will if the subsequent will 9 
does not make a complete disposition of the testator's estate.  If this presumption arises 10 
and is not rebutted by clear and convincing evidence, the subsequent will revokes the 11 
previous will onl y to the extent the subsequent will is inconsistent with the previous will; 12 
each will is fully operative on the testator's death to the extent they are not inconsistent.  13 
§2-507.  Revocation by change of circumstances  14 
Except as provided in sections 2 -802, 2 -803 and 2 -804, a change of circumstances 15 
does not revoke a will or any part of it.  16 
§2-508.  Revival of revoked will  17 
1.  Subsequent will revoked by revocatory act; wholly revoked previous will.  If a 18 
subsequent will that wholly revoked a previous will is t hereafter revoked by a revocatory 19 
act under section 2 -506, subsection 1, paragraph B, the previous will remains revoked 20 
unless it is revived.  The previous will is revived if it is evident from the circumstances of 21 
the revocation of the subsequent will or from the testator's contemporary or subsequent 22 
declarations that the testator intended the previous will to take effect as executed.  23 
2.  Subsequent will revoked by revocatory act; partly revoked previous will.  If a 24 
subsequent will that partly revoked a pr evious will is thereafter revoked by a revocatory 25 
act under section 2 -506, subsection 1, paragraph B, a revoked part of the previous will is 26 
revived unless it is evident from the circumstances of the revocation of the subsequent 27 
will or from the testator's  contemporary or subsequent declarations that the testator did 28 
not intend the revoked part to take effect as executed.  29 
3.  Subsequent will revoked by later will.  If a subsequent will that revoked a 30 
previous will in whole or in part is thereafter revoked b y another, later will, the previous 31 
will remains revoked in whole or in part, unless it or its revoked part is revived.  The 32 
previous will or its revoked part is revived to the extent it appears from the terms of the 33 
later will that the testator intended t he previous will to take effect.  34 
§2-509.  Incorporation by reference  35 
Any writing in existence when a will is executed may be incorporated by reference if 36 
the language of the will manifests this intent and describes the writing sufficiently to 37 
permit its id entification.  38 
 
 Page 55 - 128LR0452(01) -1 
 §2-510.  Uniform Testamentary Additions to Trusts Act  1 
1.  Devise to a trust.  A will may validly devise property to the trustee of a trust 2 
established or to be established:  3 
A.  During the testator's lifetime by the testator, by the testator a nd some other person 4 
or by some other person, including a funded or unfunded life insurance trust, 5 
although the settlor has reserved any or all rights of ownership of the insurance 6 
contracts; or  7 
B.  At the testator's death by the testator's devise to the t rustee, if the trust is identified 8 
in the testator's will and its terms are set forth in a written instrument, other than a 9 
will, executed before, concurrently with or after the execution of the testator's will or 10 
in another individual's will if that other  individual has predeceased the testator, 11 
regardless of the existence, size or character of the corpus of the trust.  12 
The devise is not invalid because the trust is amendable or revocable or because the trust 13 
was amended after the execution of the will or t he testator's death.  14 
2.  Not held under testamentary trust.  Unless the testator's will provides 15 
otherwise, property devised to a trust described in subsection 1 is not held under a 16 
testamentary trust of the testator but becomes a part of the trust to whic h it is devised and 17 
must be administered and disposed of in accordance with the provisions of the governing 18 
instrument setting forth the terms of the trust, including any amendments thereto made 19 
before or after the testator's death.  20 
3.  Revocation or termi nation before death.  Unless the testator's will provides 21 
otherwise, a revocation or termination of the trust before the testator's death causes the 22 
devise to lapse.  23 
§2-511.  Events of independent significance  24 
A will may dispose of property by reference to  acts and events that have significance 25 
apart from their effect upon the dispositions made by the will, whether they occur before 26 
or after the execution of the will or before or after the testator's death.  The execution or 27 
revocation of a will of another person is such an event.  28 
§2-512.  Separate writing identifying devise of certain types of tangible personal 29 
property  30 
Whether or not the provisions relating to holographic wills apply, a will may refer to 31 
a written statement or list to dispose of items of t angible personal property not otherwise 32 
specifically disposed of by the will, other than money.  To be admissible under this 33 
section as evidence of the intended disposition, the writing must be in the handwriting of 34 
the testator or be signed by the testato r and must describe the items and the devisees with 35 
reasonable certainty.  The writing may be referred to as one to be in existence at the time 36 
of the testator's death; it may be prepared before or after the execution of the will; it may 37 
be altered by the testator after its preparation; and it may be a writing that has no 38 
significance apart from its effect upon the dispositions made by the will.  39 
 
 Page 56 - 128LR0452(01) -1 
 §2-513.  Contracts concerning succession  1 
A contract to make a will or devise, or not to revoke a will or devise, or to die 2 
intestate, if executed after the effective date of this Act, can be established only by:  3 
1.  Material provisions.  Provisions of a will stating material provisions of the 4 
contract;  5 
2.  Express reference, extrinsic evidence.  An express reference in a will to a 6 
contract and extrinsic evidence proving the terms of the contract; or  7 
3.  Writing evidencing the contract.  A writing signed by the decedent evidencing 8 
the contract.  9 
The execution of a joint will or mutual wills does not create a presumption  of a 10 
contract not to revoke the will or wills.  11 
§2-514.  Disposition of will deposited with court  12 
A will deposited for safekeeping with the court in the office of the register before 13 
September 19, 1997 may be delivered only to the testator or to a person a uthorized in 14 
writing signed by the testator to receive the will.  A conservator may be allowed to 15 
examine a deposited will of a protected testator under procedures designed to maintain 16 
the confidential character of the document to the extent possible and t o ensure that it will 17 
be resealed and left on deposit after the examination.  Upon being informed of the 18 
testator's death, the court shall notify any person designated to receive the will and deliver 19 
it to that designated person on request; or the court ma y deliver the will to the appropriate 20 
court.  The court may not accept a will for safekeeping after September 19, 1997.  21 
§2-515.  Duty of custodian of will; liability  22 
After the death of a testator, a person having custody of a will of the testator shall 23 
deliver it with reasonable promptness to a person able to secure its probate or, if no such 24 
person is known, to an appropriate court for filing and recording until probate is sought.  25 
A person having custody of a will is not liable, to any person aggrieved, f or failure to 26 
learn of the death of the testator of that will and the failure, therefore, to deliver that will 27 
as required.  A person who willfully fails to deliver a will or who willfully defaces or 28 
destroys any will of a deceased person is liable to any person aggrieved for the damages 29 
that may be sustained by such failure to deliver or by such defacement or destruction.  A 30 
person who willfully refuses or fails to deliver a will, or who defaces or destroys it, after 31 
being ordered by the court in a proceed ing brought for the purpose of compelling delivery 32 
is subject to penalty for contempt of court.  33 
§2-516.  Penalty clause for contest  34 
A provision in a will purporting to penalize an interested person for contesting the 35 
will or instituting other proceedings r elating to the estate is unenforceable if probable 36 
cause exists for instituting proceedings.  37 
 
 Page 57 - 128LR0452(01) -1 
 §2-517.  Statutory wills  1 
1.  Form.  Any person may execute a will on the following form, and the will must 2 
be presumed to be reasonable.  This section does not lim it any spousal rights, rights to 3 
exempt property or other rights set forth elsewhere in this Code.  4

PART 6  3 
RULES OF CONSTRUCTIO N APPLICABLE ONLY TO  WILLS  4 
§2-601.  Scope  5 
In the absence of a finding of a contrary intention, the rules of construction in this 6 
Part control the construction of a will.  7 
§2-602.  Will may pass all property and after -acquired property  8 
A will may provide for the passage of all property the testator owns at death and all 9 
property acquired by the estate after the testator’s death.  10 
§2-603.  Antilapse; deceased devisee; class gifts  11 
1.  Definitions.  As used in this section, unless the context otherwise indicates, the 12 
following terms have the following meanings.  13 
A.  "Alternative devise" means a devise that is expressly created by a will and, under 14 
the terms of the will, ca n take effect instead of another devise on the happening of 15 
one or more events, including survival of the testator or failure to survive the testator, 16 
whether an event is expressed in condition -precedent, condition -subsequent or any 17 
other form.  A residuar y clause constitutes an alternative devise with respect to a 18 
nonresiduary devise only if the will specifically provides that, upon lapse or failure, 19 
the nonresiduary devise, or nonresiduary devises in general, pass under the residuary 20 
clause.  21 
B.  "Class me mber" includes an individual who fails to survive the testator but who 22 
would have taken under a devise in the form of a class gift had the individual 23 
survived the testator.  24 
C.  "Descendant of a grandparent" means an individual who qualifies as a descendant  25 
of a grandparent of the testator or of the donor of a power of appointment under the:  26 
(1)  Rules of construction applicable to a class gift created in the testator's will if 27 
the devise or exercise of the power is in the form of a class gift; or  28 
(2)  Rules  for intestate succession if the devise or exercise of the power is not in 29 
the form of a class gift.  30 
D.  "Devise" includes an alternative devise, a devise in the form of a class gift and an 31 
exercise of a power of appointment.  32 
E.  "Devisee" includes:  33 
(1)  A  class member if the devise is in the form of a class gift;  34 
(2)  An individual or class member who was deceased at the time the testator 35 
executed the testator's will as well as an individual or class member who was then 36 
living but who failed to survive th e testator; and  37 
 
 Page 64 - 128LR0452(01) -1 
 (3)  An appointee under a power of appointment exercised by the testator's will.  1 
F.  "Stepchild" means a child of the surviving, deceased or former spouse of the 2 
testator or of the donor of a power of appointment and not of the testator or donor.  3 
G.  "Surviving devisee" or "surviving descendant" means a devisee or descendant, 4 
respectively, who neither predeceased the testator nor is deemed to have predeceased 5 
the testator under section 2 -702. 6 
H.  "Testator" includes the donee of a power of a ppointment if the power is exercised 7 
in the testator's will.  8 
2.  Substitute gift.  If a devisee fails to survive the testator and is a grandparent, a 9 
descendant of a grandparent or a stepchild of either the testator or the donor of a power of 10 
appointment e xercised by the testator's will, the following apply.  11 
A.  Except as provided in paragraph D, if the devise is not in the form of a class gift 12 
and the deceased devisee leaves surviving descendants, a substitute gift is created in 13 
the devisee's surviving des cendants.  The surviving descendants take per capita at 14 
each generation the property to which the devisee would have been entitled had the 15 
devisee survived the testator.  16 
B.  Except as provided in paragraph D, if the devise is in the form of a class gift, 17 
other than a devise to "issue," "descendants," "heirs of the body," "heirs," "next of 18 
kin," "relatives" or "family," or a class described by language of similar import, a 19 
substitute gift is created in the surviving descendants of any deceased devisee.  The 20 
property to which the devisees would have been entitled had all of them survived the 21 
testator passes to the surviving devisees and the surviving descendants of the 22 
deceased devisees.  Each surviving devisee takes the share to which the devisee 23 
would have b een entitled had the deceased devisee survived the testator.  Each 24 
deceased devisee's surviving descendants who are substituted for the deceased 25 
devisee take per capita at each generation the share to which the deceased devisee 26 
would have been entitled had  the deceased devisee survived the testator.  For the 27 
purposes of this paragraph, "deceased devisee" means a class member who failed to 28 
survive the testator and left one or more surviving descendants.  29 
C.  For the purposes of section 2 -601, words of survivo rship, such as in a devise to an 30 
individual "if he survives me," or in a devise to "my surviving children," are, in the 31 
absence of additional evidence, a sufficient indication of an intent contrary to the 32 
application of this section.  33 
D.  If the will create s an alternative devise with respect to a devise for which a 34 
substitute gift is created by paragraph A or B, the substitute gift is superseded by the 35 
alternative devise if:  36 
(1)  The alternative devise is in the form of a class gift and one or more members 37 
of the class is entitled to take under the will; or  38 
(2)  The alternative devise is not in the form of a class gift and the expressly 39 
designated devisee of the alternative devise is entitled to take under the will.  40 
E.  Unless the language creating a power o f appointment expressly excludes the 41 
substitution of the descendants of an appointee for the appointee, a surviving 42 
 
 Page 65 - 128LR0452(01) -1 
 descendant of a deceased appointee of a power of appointment may be substituted for 1 
the appointee under this section, whether or not the des cendant is an object of the 2 
power.  3 
"Descendant," in the phrase "surviving descendant," used in reference to a deceased 4 
devisee or class member, means the descendant of a deceased devisee or class member in 5 
paragraphs A and B who would take under a class gi ft created in the testator's will.  6 
3.  More than one substitute gift; which one takes effect.  If, under subsection 2, 7 
substitute gifts are created and not superseded with respect to more than one devise and 8 
the devises are alternative devises, one to the other, the devised property passes under the 9 
primary substitute gift except that if there is a younger -generation devise, the devised 10 
property passes under the younger -generation substitute gift and not under the primary 11 
substitute gift.  12 
As used in this su bsection, unless the context otherwise indicates, the following terms 13 
have the following meanings.  14 
A.  "Primary devise" means the devise that would have taken effect had all the 15 
deceased devisees of the alternative devises who left surviving descendants su rvived 16 
the testator.  17 
B.  "Primary substitute gift" means the substitute gift created with respect to the 18 
primary devise.  19 
C.  "Younger -generation devise" means a devise that:  20 
(1)  Is to a descendant of a devisee of the primary devise;  21 
(2)  Is an alternative  devise with respect to the primary devise;  22 
(3)  Is a devise for which a substitute gift is created; and  23 
(4)  Would have taken effect had all the deceased devisees who left surviving 24 
descendants survived the testator except the deceased devisee or devisees  of the 25 
primary devise.  26 
D.  "Younger -generation substitute gift" means the substitute gift created with respect 27 
to the younger -generation devise.  28 
§2-604.  Failure of testamentary provision  29 
1.  Failed devise becomes part of residue.  Except as provided in s ection 2 -603, a 30 
devise, other than a residuary devise, that fails for any reason becomes a part of the 31 
residue.  32 
2.  Failed residuary devise passes in proportion.  Except as provided in section 33 
2-603, if the residue is devised to 2 or more persons, the shar e of a residuary devisee that 34 
fails for any reason passes to the other residuary devisee or to other residuary devisees in 35 
proportion to the interest of each in the remaining part of the residue.  36 
 
 Page 66 - 128LR0452(01) -1 
 §2-605.  Increase in securities; accessions  1 
1.  Additional s ecurities.  If a testator executes a will that devises securities and the 2 
testator then owned securities that meet the description in the will, the devise includes 3 
additional securities owned by the testator at death to the extent the additional securities  4 
were acquired by the testator after the will was executed as a result of the testator's 5 
ownership of the described securities and are securities of any of the following types:  6 
A.  Securities of the same organization acquired by reason of action initiated by the 7 
organization or any successor, related or acquiring organization, excluding any 8 
acquired by exercise of purchase options;  9 
B.  Securities of another organization acquired as a result of a merger, consolidation, 10 
reorganization or other distribution by  the organization or any successor, related or 11 
acquiring organization; or  12 
C.  Securities of the same organization acquired as a result of a plan of reinvestment.  13 
2.  Distributions in cash.  Distributions in cash before death with respect to a 14 
described sec urity are not part of the devise under subsection 1.  15 
§2-606.  Nonademption of specific devises; unpaid proceeds of sale, condemnation or 16 
insurance; sale by conservator or agent  17 
1.  Specifically devised property.  A specific devisee has a right to specifica lly 18 
devised property in the testator's estate at the testator's death and to:  19 
A.  Any balance of the purchase price, together with any security agreement, owed by 20 
a purchaser at the testator's death by reason of sale of the property;  21 
B.  Any amount of a co ndemnation award for the taking of the property unpaid at 22 
death;  23 
C.  Any proceeds unpaid at death on fire or casualty insurance on or other recovery 24 
for injury to the property;  25 
D.  Any property owned by the testator at death and acquired as a result of 26 
foreclosure, or obtained in lieu of foreclosure, of the security interest for a 27 
specifically devised obligation;  28 
E.  Any real property or tangible personal property owned by the testator at death that 29 
the testator acquired as a replacement for specifically de vised real property or 30 
tangible personal property; and  31 
F.  If not covered by paragraphs A to E, a pecuniary devise equal to the value as of its 32 
date of disposition of other specifically devised property disposed of during the 33 
testator's lifetime but only t o the extent it is established that ademption would be 34 
inconsistent with the testator's manifested plan of distribution or that at the time the 35 
will was made, the date of disposition or otherwise, the testator did not intend 36 
ademption of the devise.  37 
2.  General pecuniary devise from specifically devised property.  If specifically 38 
devised property is sold or mortgaged by a conservator or by an agent acting within the 39 
 
 Page 67 - 128LR0452(01) -1 
 authority of a durable power of attorney for an incapacitated principal, or a condemnation 1 
award, insurance proceeds or recovery for injury to the property is paid to a conservator 2 
or to an agent acting within the authority of a durable power of attorney for an 3 
incapacitated principal, the specific devisee has the right to a general pecuniary dev ise 4 
equal to the net sale price, the amount of the unpaid loan, the condemnation award, the 5 
insurance proceeds or the recovery.  6 
3.  Reduction of right to general pecuniary devise.  The right of a specific devisee 7 
under subsection 2 is reduced by any right the devisee has under subsection 1.  8 
4.  Survival of testator; incapacity ceased.  For the purposes of the references in 9 
subsection 2 to a conservator, subsection 2 does not apply if, after the sale, mortgage, 10 
condemnation, casualty or recovery, it was adju dicated that the testator's incapacity 11 
ceased and the testator survived the adjudication for at least one year.  12 
5.  Durable power of attorney.  For the purposes of the references in subsection 2 to 13 
an agent acting within the authority of a durable power of  attorney for an incapacitated 14 
principal:  15 
A.  "Incapacitated principal" means a principal who is an incapacitated person;  16 
B.  An adjudication of incapacity before death is not necessary; and  17 
C.  The acts of an agent within the authority of a durable power of attorney are 18 
presumed to be for an incapacitated principal.  19 
§2-607.  Nonexoneration  20 
A specific devise passes subject to any mortgage interest existing at the date of death 21 
without right of exoneration, regardless of a general directive in the will to pa y debts.  22 
§2-608.  Exercise power of appointment  23 
In the absence of a requirement that a power of appointment be exercised by a 24 
reference to the power or by an express or specific reference to the power, a general 25 
residuary clause in a will, or a will making  general disposition of all of the testator's 26 
property, expresses an intention to exercise a power of appointment held by the testator 27 
only if:  28 
1.  General power.  The power is a general power exercisable in favor of the 29 
powerholder's estate and the creati ng instrument does not contain an effective gift if the 30 
power is not exercised; or  31 
2.  Intention to include property subject to the power.  The testator's will 32 
manifests an intention to include the property subject to the power.  33 
§2-609.  Ademption by satis faction  34 
1.  Property given during testator's lifetime.  Property a testator gave in the 35 
testator's lifetime to a person is treated as a satisfaction of a devise in whole or in part 36 
only if:  37 
 
 Page 68 - 128LR0452(01) -1 
 A.  The will provides for deduction of the gift;  1 
B.  The testator declared in a contemporaneous writing that the gift is in satisfaction 2 
of the devise or that its value is to be deducted from the value of the devise; or  3 
C.  The devisee acknowledged in writing that the gift is in satisfaction of the devise 4 
or that its val ue is to be deducted from the value of the devise.  5 
2.  Partial satisfaction; value.  For purposes of partial satisfaction, property given 6 
during the testator's lifetime is valued as of the time the devisee came into possession or 7 
enjoyment of the property or at the testator's death, whichever occurs first.  8 
3.  Devisee fails to survive testator.  If the devisee fails to survive the testator, the 9 
gift described in subsection 1 is treated as a full or partial satisfaction of the devise, as 10 
appropriate, in appl ying sections 2 -603 and 2 -604, unless the testator's contemporaneous 11 
writing provides otherwise.  12 
PART 7  13 
RULES OF CONSTRUCTIO N APPLICABLE TO WILL S AND OTHER 14 
GOVERNING INSTRUMENT S 15 
§2-701.  Scope  16 
In the absence of a finding of a contrary intention, the rules of construction in this 17 
Part control the construction of a governing instrument.  The rules of construction in this 18 
Part apply to a governing instrument of any type, except as the application of a particular 19 
section is limited by its terms to a specific ty pe or types of provision or governing 20 
instrument.  21 
§2-702.  Requirement of survival by 120 hours  22 
1.  Requirement of survival by 120 hours under Code.  For the purposes of this 23 
Code, except as provided in subsection 4, an individual who has not been establis hed by 24 
clear and convincing evidence to have survived an event, including the death of another 25 
individual, by 120 hours is deemed to have predeceased the event.  26 
2.  Requirement of survival by 120 hours under governing instrument.  Except as 27 
provided in sub section 4, for purposes of a provision of a governing instrument that 28 
relates to an individual surviving an event, including the death of another individual, an 29 
individual who has not been established by clear and convincing evidence to have 30 
survived the e vent by 120 hours is deemed to have predeceased the event.  31 
3.  Co-owners with right of survivorship; requirement of survival by 120 hours.  32 
Except as provided in subsection 4, if:  33 
A.  It is not established by clear and convincing evidence that one of 2 co -owners 34 
with right of survivorship survived the other co -owner by 120 hours, 1/2 of the 35 
property passes as if one had survived by 120 hours and 1/2 as if the other had 36 
survived by 120 hours; or  37 
 
 Page 69 - 128LR0452(01) -1 
 B.  There are more than 2 co -owners with right of survivorship and it is not 1 
established by clear and convincing evidence that at least one of them survived the 2 
others by 120 hours, the property passes in the proportion that one bears to the whole 3 
number of co -owners.  4 
For the purposes of this subsection, "co -owners wi th right of survivorship" includes joint 5 
tenants, tenants by the entireties and other co -owners of property or accounts held under 6 
circumstances that entitle one or more to the whole of the property or account on the 7 
death of the other or others.  8 
4.  Excep tions.  Survival by 120 hours is not required if:  9 
A.  The governing instrument contains language dealing explicitly with simultaneous 10 
deaths or deaths in a common disaster and that language is operable under the facts of 11 
the case;  12 
B.  The governing instrum ent expressly indicates that an individual is not required to 13 
survive an event, including the death of another individual, by any specified period or 14 
expressly requires the individual to survive the event by a specified period. Survival 15 
of the event and th e specified period must be established by clear and convincing 16 
evidence;  17 
C.  The imposition of a 120 -hour requirement of survival would cause a nonvested 18 
property interest or a power of appointment to fail to qualify for validity under Title 19 
33, section 11 1, subsection 1, paragraph A, subsection 2, paragraph A or subsection 20 
3, paragraph A or to become invalid under Title 33, section 111, subsection 1, 21 
paragraph B, subsection 2, paragraph B or subsection 3, paragraph B. Survival must 22 
be established by clear and convincing evidence; or  23 
D.  The application of a 120 -hour requirement of survival to multiple governing 24 
instruments would result in an unintended failure or duplication of a disposition. 25 
Survival must be established by clear and convincing evidence.  26 
5.  Protection of payors and other 3rd parties.  This subsection governs liability of 27 
payors and other 3rd parties.  28 
A.  A payor or other 3rd party is not liable for having made a payment or transferred 29 
an item of property or any other benefit to a beneficiar y designated in a governing 30 
instrument who, under this section, is not entitled to the payment or item of property 31 
or for having taken any other action if that payment, transfer or other action is made 32 
in good faith reliance on the beneficiary's apparent e ntitlement under the terms of the 33 
governing instrument before the payor or other 3rd party received written notice of a 34 
claimed lack of entitlement under this section.  A payor or other 3rd party is liable for 35 
a payment or transfer made or other action tak en after the payor or other 3rd party 36 
received written notice of a claimed lack of entitlement under this section.  37 
B.  Written notice of a claimed lack of entitlement under paragraph A must be mailed 38 
to the payor's or other 3rd party's main office or home by registered or certified mail, 39 
return receipt requested, or served upon the payor or other 3rd party in the same 40 
manner as a summons in a civil action.  Upon receipt of written notice of a claimed 41 
lack of entitlement under this section, a payor or other 3rd party may pay any amount 42 
owed or transfer or deposit any item of property held by the payor or other 3rd party 43 
 
 Page 70 - 128LR0452(01) -1 
 to or with the court having jurisdiction of the probate proceedings relating to the 1 
decedent's estate or, if no proceedings have been commenc ed, to or with the court 2 
having jurisdiction of probate proceedings relating to decedents' estates located in the 3 
county of the decedent's residence.  The court shall hold the funds or item of property 4 
and, upon its determination under this section, shall order disbursement in accordance 5 
with the determination.  Payments, transfers or deposits made to or with the court 6 
discharge the payor or other 3rd party from all claims for the value of amounts paid 7 
to or items of property transferred to or deposited wit h the court.  8 
6.  Protection of bona fide purchaser; personal liability of recipient.  This 9 
subsection governs the liability of bona fide purchasers and other recipients.  10 
A.  A person who purchases property for value and without notice, or who receives a 11 
payment, and item of property or any other benefit in partial or full satisfaction of a 12 
legally enforceable obligation, is neither obligated under this section to return the 13 
payment, item of property or benefit nor liable under this section for the amount of  14 
the payment or the value of the item of property or benefit.  A person who, not for 15 
value, receives a payment, item of property or other benefit to which the person is not 16 
entitled under this section is obligated to return the payment, item of property or  17 
benefit, or is personally liable for the amount of the payment or the value of the item 18 
of property or benefit, to the person who is entitled to it under this section.  19 
B.  If this section or any part of this section is preempted by federal law with respec t 20 
to a payment, an item of property or any other benefit covered by this section, a 21 
person who, not for value, receives the payment, item of property or other benefit to 22 
which the person is not entitled under this section is obligated to return the payment , 23 
item of property or benefit, or is personally liable for the amount of the payment or 24 
the value of the item of property or benefit, to the person who would have been 25 
entitled to it were this section or part of this section not preempted.  26 
§2-703.  Choice of law as to meaning and effect of governing instrument  27 
The meaning and legal effect of a governing instrument is determined by the local 28 
law of the state selected in the governing instrument, unless the application of that law is 29 
contrary to the provision s relating to the elective share described in Part 2, the provisions 30 
relating to exempt property and allowances described in Part 4 or any other public policy 31 
of this State otherwise applicable to the disposition.  32 
§2-704.  Power of appointment; compliance with specific reference requirement  33 
A powerholder's substantial compliance with a formal requirement of appointment 34 
imposed in a governing instrument by the donor, including a requirement that the 35 
instrument exercising the power of appointment make referen ce or specific reference to 36 
the power, is sufficient if:  37 
1.  Knows of and intends to exercise power.  The powerholder knows of and 38 
intends to exercise the power; and  39 
2.  Does not impair a maternal purpose.  The powerholder's manner of attempted 40 
exercise do es not impair a material purpose of the donor in imposing the requirement.  41

 §2-705.  Class gifts construed to accord with intestate succession; exceptions  1 
1.  Definitions.  As used in this section, unless the context otherwise indicates, the 2 
following terms  have the following meanings.  3 
A.  "Adoptee" has the meaning set forth in section 2 -115. 4 
B.  "Child of assisted reproduction" has the meaning set forth in section 2 -120. 5 
C.  "Distribution date" means the date when an immediate or postponed class gift 6 
takes effect in possession or enjoyment.  7 
D.  "Function as a parent of the adoptee" has the meaning set forth in section 2 -115, 8 
substituting "adoptee" for "child" in that definition.  9 
E.  "Function as a parent of the child" has the meaning set forth in section 2 -115. 10 
F.  "Genetic parent" has the meaning set forth in section 2 -115. 11 
G.  "Gestational child" has the meaning set forth in section 2 -121. 12 
H.  "Relative" has the meaning set forth in section 2 -115. 13 
2.  Terms of relationship.  A class gift that uses a term of  relationship to identify the 14 
class members includes in the class a child of assisted reproduction, a gestational child 15 
and, except as otherwise provided in subsections 5 and 6, an adoptee and a child born to 16 
parents who are not married to each other, and their respective descendants if appropriate 17 
to the class, in accordance with the rules for intestate succession regarding parent -child 18 
relationships.  For the purpose of determining whether a contrary intention exists under 19 
section 2 -701, a provision in a governing instrument that relates to the inclusion or 20 
exclusion in a class gift of a child born to parents who are not married to each other but 21 
does not specifically refer to a child of assisted reproduction or a gestational child does 22 
not apply to a chil d of assisted reproduction or a gestational child.  23 
3.  Relatives by marriage.  Terms of relationship in a governing instrument that do 24 
not differentiate relationships by blood from those by marriage, such as uncles, aunts, 25 
nieces or nephews, are construed to exclude relatives by marriage, unless:  26 
A.  When the governing instrument was executed, the class was then and foreseeably 27 
would be empty; or  28 
B.  The language or circumstances otherwise establish that relatives by marriage were 29 
intended to be included.  30 
4.  Half -blood relatives.  Terms of relationship in a governing instrument that do not 31 
differentiate relationships by the half blood from those by the whole blood, such as 32 
brothers, sisters, nieces or nephews, are construed to include both types of relation ships.  33 
5.  Transferor not genetic parent.  In construing a dispositive provision of a 34 
transferor who is not the genetic parent, a child of a genetic parent is not considered the 35 
child of that genetic parent unless the genetic parent, a relative of the gene tic parent or the 36 
spouse or surviving spouse of the genetic parent or of a relative of the genetic parent 37 
functioned as a parent of the child before the child reached 18 years of age.  38 
 
 Page 72 - 128LR0452(01) -1 
 6.  Transferor not adoptive parent.  In construing a dispositive provisi on of a 1 
transferor who is not the adoptive parent, an adoptee is not considered the child of the 2 
adoptive parent unless:  3 
A.  The adoption took place before the adoptee reached 18 years of age;  4 
B.  The adoptive parent was the adoptee's stepparent or foster parent; or  5 
C.  The adoptive parent functioned as a parent of the adoptee before the adoptee 6 
reached 18 years of age.  7 
7.  Class -closing rules.  The following provisions apply for purposes of the class - 8 
closing rules.  9 
A.  A child in utero at a particular time  is treated as living at that time if the child 10 
lives 120 hours after birth.  11 
B.  If a child of assisted reproduction or a gestational child is conceived 12 
posthumously and the distribution date is the deceased parent's death, the child is 13 
treated as living o n the distribution date if the child lives 120 hours after birth and 14 
was in utero not later than 36 months after the deceased parent's death or born not 15 
later than 45 months after the deceased parent's death.  16 
C.  An individual who is in the process of bein g adopted when the class closes is 17 
treated as adopted when the class closes if the adoption is subsequently granted.  18 
§2-706.  Life insurance; retirement plan; account with POD designation; TOD 19 
designation; deceased beneficiary  20 
1.  Definitions.  As used in this section, unless the context otherwise indicates, the 21 
following terms have the following meanings.  22 
A.  "Alternative beneficiary designation" means a beneficiary designation that is 23 
expressly created by the governing instrument and, under the terms of t he governing 24 
instrument, can take effect instead of another designation on the happening of one or 25 
more events, including survival of the decedent or failure to survive the decedent, 26 
whether an event is expressed in condition -precedent, condition -subsequen t or any 27 
other form.  28 
B.  "Beneficiary" means the beneficiary of a beneficiary designation under which the 29 
beneficiary must survive the decedent and includes:  30 
(1)  A class member if the beneficiary designation is in the form of a class gift; 31 
and 32 
(2)  An ind ividual or class member who was deceased at the time the beneficiary 33 
designation was executed as well as an individual or class member who was then 34 
living but who failed to survive the decedent.  35 
"Beneficiary" excludes a joint tenant of a joint tenancy with  the right of survivorship 36 
and a party to a joint survivorship account.  37 
C.  "Beneficiary designation" includes an alternative beneficiary designation and a 38 
beneficiary designation in the form of a class gift.  39 
 
 Page 73 - 128LR0452(01) -1 
 D.  "Class member" includes an individual who f ails to survive the decedent but who 1 
would have taken under a beneficiary designation in the form of a class gift had the 2 
individual survived the decedent.  3 
E.  "Descendant of a grandparent" means an individual who qualifies as a descendant 4 
of a grandparent  of the decedent under the:  5 
(1)  Rules of construction applicable to a class gift created in the decedent's 6 
beneficiary designation if the beneficiary designation is in the form of a class 7 
gift; or  8 
(2)  Rules for intestate succession if the beneficiary des ignation is not in the form 9 
of a class gift.  10 
F.  "Stepchild" means a child of the decedent's surviving, deceased or former spouse 11 
and not of the decedent.  12 
G.  "Surviving beneficiaries" or "surviving descendants" means beneficiaries or 13 
descendants, respecti vely, who neither predeceased the decedent nor are deemed to 14 
have predeceased the decedent under section 2 -702. 15 
2.  Substitute gift.  If a beneficiary fails to survive the decedent and is a grandparent, 16 
a descendant of a grandparent or a stepchild of the d ecedent, the following apply.  17 
A.  Except as provided in paragraph D, if the beneficiary designation is not in the 18 
form of a class gift and the deceased beneficiary leaves surviving descendants, a 19 
substitute gift is created in the beneficiary's surviving de scendants.  The surviving 20 
descendants take per capita at each generation the property to which the beneficiary 21 
would have been entitled had the beneficiary survived the decedent.  22 
B.  Except as provided in paragraph D, if the beneficiary designation is in t he form of 23 
a class gift, other than a beneficiary designation to "issue," "descendants," "heirs of 24 
the body," "heirs," "next of kin," "relatives" or "family," or a class described by 25 
language of similar import, a substitute gift is created in the surviving  descendants of 26 
any deceased beneficiary.  The property to which the beneficiaries would have been 27 
entitled had all of them survived the decedent passes to the surviving beneficiaries 28 
and the surviving descendants of the deceased beneficiaries.  Each survi ving 29 
beneficiary takes the share to which that beneficiary would have been entitled had the 30 
deceased beneficiary survived the decedent.  Each deceased beneficiary's surviving 31 
descendants who are substituted for the deceased beneficiary take per capita at e ach 32 
generation the share to which the deceased beneficiary would have been entitled had 33 
the deceased beneficiary survived the decedent.  For the purposes of this paragraph, 34 
"deceased beneficiary" means a class member who failed to survive the decedent and 35 
left one or more surviving descendants.  36 
C.  For the purposes of section 2 -701, words of survivorship, such as in a beneficiary 37 
designation to an individual "if he survives me" or "if she survives me," or in a 38 
beneficiary designation to "my surviving childr en," are, in the absence of additional 39 
evidence, a sufficient indication of an intent contrary to the application of this 40 
section.  41 
 
 Page 74 - 128LR0452(01) -1 
 D.  If a governing instrument creates an alternative beneficiary designation with 1 
respect to a beneficiary designation for wh ich a substitute gift is created under 2 
paragraph A or B, the substitute gift is superseded by the alternative beneficiary 3 
designation if:  4 
(1)  The alternative beneficiary designation is in the form of a class gift and one 5 
or more members of the class is en titled to take; or  6 
(2)  The alternative beneficiary designation is not in the form of a class gift and 7 
the expressly designated beneficiary of the alternative beneficiary designation is 8 
entitled to take.  9 
"Descendants," in the phrase "surviving descendants, " used in reference to a deceased 10 
beneficiary or class member in paragraphs A and B, means the descendants of a deceased 11 
beneficiary or class member who would take under a class gift created in the beneficiary 12 
designation.  13 
3.  More than one substitute gift ; which one takes effect.  If, under subsection 2, 14 
substitute gifts are created and not superseded with respect to more than one beneficiary 15 
designation and the beneficiary designations are alternative beneficiary designations, one 16 
to the other, the proper ty passes under the primary substitute gift except that if there is a 17 
younger -generation beneficiary designation, the property passes under the younger - 18 
generation substitute gift and not under the primary substitute gift.  19 
As used in this subsection, unless  the context otherwise indicates, the following terms 20 
have the following meanings.  21 
A.  "Primary beneficiary designation" means the beneficiary designation that would 22 
have taken effect had all the deceased beneficiaries of the alternative beneficiary 23 
design ations who left surviving descendants survived the decedent.  24 
B.  "Primary substitute gift" means the substitute gift created with respect to the 25 
primary beneficiary designation.  26 
C.  "Younger -generation beneficiary designation" means a beneficiary designati on 27 
that: 28 
(1)  Is to a descendant of a beneficiary of the primary beneficiary designation;  29 
(2)  Is an alternative beneficiary designation with respect to the primary 30 
beneficiary designation;  31 
(3)  Is a beneficiary designation for which a substitute gift is c reated; and  32 
(4)  Would have taken effect had all the deceased beneficiaries who left surviving 33 
descendants survived the decedent except the deceased beneficiary or 34 
beneficiaries of the primary beneficiary designation.  35 
D.  "Younger -generation substitute gif t" means the substitute gift created with respect 36 
to the younger -generation beneficiary designation.  37 
4.  Protection of payors.  This subsection governs the liability of payors.  38 
A.  A payor is protected from liability in making payments under the terms of t he 39 
beneficiary designation until the payor has received written notice of a claim to a 40 
 
 Page 75 - 128LR0452(01) -1 
 substitute gift under this section.  Payment made before the receipt of written notice 1

payment received, whether or not written notice of the claim is given.  5

of the decedent's residence.  The court shall hold the funds and, upon its 13 
determination under this section, shall order disbursement in accordance with the 14 
determination.  Payment made to the court discharges the payor from all claims for 15 
the amounts paid.  16

§2-707.  Survivorship with respect to future interests under terms of trust; 35 
substitute takers  36 
1.  Definitions.  As used in this section, unless the context otherwise indicates, the 37 
following terms have the fo llowing meanings.  38 
A.  "Alternative future interest" means an expressly created future interest that can 39 
take effect in possession or enjoyment instead of another future interest on the 40 
happening of one or more events, including survival of an event or fail ure to survive 41 
an event, whether the event is expressed in condition -precedent, condition -subsequent 42 
or any other form.  A residuary clause in a will does not create an alternative future 43 
 
 Page 76 - 128LR0452(01) -1 
 interest with respect to a future interest created in a nonresiduary  devise in the will, 1 
whether or not the will specifically provides that lapsed or failed devises are to pass 2 
under the residuary clause.  3 
B.  "Beneficiary" means the beneficiary of a future interest and includes a class 4 
member if the future interest is in t he form of a class gift.  5 
C.  "Class member" includes an individual who fails to survive the distribution date 6 
but who would have taken under a future interest in the form of a class gift had the 7 
individual survived the distribution date.  8 
D.  "Distribution date," with respect to a future interest, means the time when the 9 
future interest is to take effect in possession or enjoyment.  The distribution date need 10 
not occur at the beginning or end of a calendar day, but can occur at a time during the 11 
course of a day. 12 
E.  "Future interest" includes an alternative future interest and a future interest in the 13 
form of a class gift.  14 
F.  "Future interest under the terms of a trust" means a future interest that was created 15 
by a transfer creating a trust or to an existing  trust or by an exercise of a power of 16

designating a beneficiary of an existing trust or creating a trust.  18 
G.  "Surviving beneficiaries" or "surviving descendants" means bene ficiaries or 19 
descendants, respectively, who neither predeceased the distribution date nor are 20 
deemed to have predeceased the distribution date under section 2 -702. 21 
2.  Survivorship required; substitute gift.  A future interest under the terms of a 22

following apply.  25

entitled had the beneficiary survived the distribution date.  30

"next of kin," "relatives" or "family," or a class described by language of similar 33 
import, a substitute gift is created in the surviving descendants of any deceased 34 
beneficiary.  The property to which the beneficiaries would have been entitled had all 35 
of them survived the distribution date passes to the surviving beneficiaries and the 36 
surviving descendants of the deceased beneficiaries.  Each surviving beneficiary 37 
takes the share to which that beneficiary would have been entitled had the decease d 38 
beneficiaries survived the distribution date.  Each deceased beneficiary's surviving 39 
descendants who are substituted for the deceased beneficiary take per capita at each 40 
generation the share to which the deceased beneficiary would have been entitled had 41 
the deceased beneficiary survived the distribution date.  For the purposes of this 42 
 
 Page 77 - 128LR0452(01) -1 
 paragraph, "deceased beneficiary" means a class member who failed to survive the 1 
distribution date and left one or more surviving descendants.  2 
C.  For the purposes of sectio n 2-701, words of survivorship attached to a future 3 
interest are, in the absence of additional evidence, a sufficient indication of an intent 4 
contrary to the application of this section.  As used in this paragraph, "words of 5 
survivorship" includes words of  survivorship that relate to the distribution date or to 6

 Page 78 - 128LR0452(01) -1 
 D.  "Younger -generation substitute gift" means the substitute gift create d with respect 1

§2-708.  Class gifts to "descendants," "issue" or "heirs of the body"; form of 22 
distribu tion if none specified  23 
If a class gift in favor of "descendants," "issue" or "heirs of the body" does not 24 
specify the manner in which the property is to be distributed among the class members, 25 
the property is distributed among the class members who are liv ing when the interest is to 26 
take effect in possession or enjoyment, in such shares as they would receive, under the 27 
applicable law of intestate succession, if the designated ancestor had then died intestate 28 
owning the subject matter of the class gift.  29 
§2-709.  Per capita at each generation; per stirpes or by representation  30 
1.  Definitions.  As used in this section, unless the context otherwise indicates, the 31 
following terms have the following meanings.  32 
A.  "Deceased child" or "deceased descendant" means a c hild or a descendant, 33 
respectively, who either predeceased the distribution date or is deemed to have 34 
predeceased the distribution date pursuant to section 2 -702. 35 
B.  "Distribution date," with respect to an interest, means the time when the interest is 36 
to take effect in possession or enjoyment.  The distribution date need not occur at the 37 
beginning or end of a calendar day, but can occur at a time during the course of a day.  38 
 
 Page 79 - 128LR0452(01) -1 
 C.  "Surviving ancestor," "surviving child" or "surviving descendant" means an 1 
ancestor, a child or a descendant, respectively, who neither predeceased the 2 
distribution date nor is deemed to have predeceased the distribution date pursuant to 3 
section 2 -702. 4 
2.  Per capita at each generation.  If an applicable statute or a governing instru ment 5 
calls for property to be distributed "per capita at each generation," the property is divided 6 
into as many equal shares as there are:  7 
A.  Surviving descendants in the generation nearest to the designated ancestor that 8 
contains one or more surviving de scendants; and  9 
B.  Deceased descendants in the same generation who left surviving descendants, if 10 
any. 11 
Each surviving descendant in the nearest generation is allocated one share.  The 12 
remaining shares, if any, are combined and then divided in the same mann er among the 13 
surviving descendants of the deceased descendants as if the surviving descendants who 14 
were allocated a share and their surviving descendants had predeceased the distribution 15 
date.  16 
3.  Per stirpes or by representation.  If a governing instrumen t calls for property to 17 
be distributed "per stirpes" or "by representation," the property is divided into as many 18 
equal shares as there are:  19 
A.  Surviving children of the designated ancestor; and  20 
B.  Deceased children who left surviving descendants.  21 
Each s urviving child, if any, is allocated one share.  The share of each deceased child 22 
with surviving descendants is divided in the same manner, with subdivision repeating at 23 
each succeeding generation until the property is fully allocated among surviving 24 
desce ndants.  25 
4.  Deceased descendant with no surviving descendant disregarded.  For the 26 
purposes of subsections 2 and 3, an individual who is deceased and left no surviving 27 
descendant is disregarded, and an individual who leaves a surviving ancestor who is a 28 
descendant of the designated ancestor is not entitled to a share.  29 
§2-710.  Worthier -title doctrine abolished  30 
The doctrine of worthier title is abolished as a rule of law and as a rule of 31 
construction.  Language in a governing instrument describing the benefi ciaries of a 32 
disposition as the transferor's "heirs," "heirs at law," "next of kin," "distributees," 33 
"relatives" or "family," or language of similar import, does not create or presumptively 34 
create a reversionary interest in the transferor.  35 
§2-711.  Interes ts in "heirs" and like  36 
If an applicable statute or a governing instrument calls for a present or future 37 
distribution to or creates a present or future interest in a designated individual's "heirs," 38 
"heirs at law," "next of kin," "relatives" or "family," or  language of similar import, the 39 
 
 Page 80 - 128LR0452(01) -1 
 property passes to those persons, including the State, and in such shares as would succeed 1 
to the designated individual's intestate estate under the intestate succession law of the 2 
designated individual's domicile if the de signated individual died when the disposition is 3 
to take effect in possession or enjoyment.  If the designated individual's surviving spouse 4 
is living but is remarried at the time the disposition is to take effect in possession or 5 
enjoyment, the surviving spouse is not an heir of the designated individual.  6 
PART 8  7 
GENERAL PROVISIONS C ONCERNING PROBATE AN D NONPROBATE 8 
TRANSFERS  9 
§2-801.  Effect of divorce, annulment and decree of separation  10 
1.  Divorce; annulment; separation.  An individual who is divorced from  the 11 
decedent or whose marriage to the decedent has been annulled is not a surviving spouse 12 
unless, by virtue of a subsequent marriage, the individual is married to the decedent at the 13 
time of death.  A decree of separation that does not terminate the stat us of spouses is not a 14 
divorce for purposes of this section.  15 
2.  Not a surviving spouse.  For purposes of Parts 1, 2, 3 and 4 and of section 3 -203, 16 
a surviving spouse does not include:  17 
A.  An individual who obtains or consents to a final decree or judgmen t of divorce 18 
from the decedent or an annulment of their marriage, if that decree or judgment is not 19 
recognized as valid in this State, unless they subsequently participate in a marriage 20 
ceremony purporting to marry each to the other, or subsequently live t ogether as 21 
spouses;  22 
B.  An individual who, following an invalid decree or judgment of divorce or 23 
annulment obtained by the decedent, participates in a marriage ceremony with a 3rd 24 
individual; or  25 
C.  An individual who was a party to a valid proceeding concl uded by an order 26 
purporting to terminate all marital property rights.  27 
§2-802.  Effect of homicide on intestate succession, wills, trusts, joint assets, life 28 
insurance and beneficiary designations  29 
1.  Definitions.  As used in this section, unless the contex t otherwise indicates, the 30 
following terms have the following meanings.  31 
A.  "Disposition or appointment of property" includes a transfer of an item of 32 
property or any other benefit to a beneficiary designated in a governing instrument.  33 
B.  "Governing instr ument" means a governing instrument executed by the decedent.  34 
C.  "Revocable," with respect to a disposition, appointment, provision or nomination, 35 
means one under which the decedent, at the time of or immediately before death, was 36 
alone empowered, by law or under the governing instrument, to cancel the 37 
designation in favor of the killer, whether or not the decedent was then empowered to 38 
 
 Page 81 - 128LR0452(01) -1 
 designate the decedent in place of the killer and whether or not the decedent then had 1 
capacity to exercise the power.  2 
2.  Forfeiture of statutory benefits.  An individual who feloniously and 3 
intentionally kills the decedent forfeits all benefits under this Article with respect to the 4 
decedent's estate, including an intestate share, an elective share, an omitted spouse's or 5 
child's share, a homestead allowance, exempt property and a family allowance.  If the 6 
decedent died intestate, the decedent's intestate estate passes as if the killer disclaimed the 7 
killer's intestate share.  8 
3.  Revocation of benefits under governing instr uments.  The felonious and 9 
intentional killing of the decedent:  10 
A.  Revokes any revocable:  11 
(1)  Disposition or appointment of property made by the decedent to the killer in 12 
a governing instrument;  13 
(2)  Provision in a governing instrument conferring a gener al or nongeneral 14 
power of appointment on the killer; and  15 
(3)  Nomination of the killer in a governing instrument nominating or appointing 16 
the killer to serve in any fiduciary or representative capacity, including as a 17 
personal representative, executor, tru stee or agent; and  18 
B.  Severs the interests of the decedent and killer in property held by them at the time 19 
of the killing as joint tenants with the right of survivorship, transforming the interests 20 
of the decedent and killer into equal tenancies in common . 21 
4.  Effect of severance.  A severance under subsection 3, paragraph B does not affect 22 
any 3rd -party interest in property acquired for value and in good faith reliance on an 23 
apparent title by survivorship in the killer unless a writing declaring the sever ance has 24 
been noted, registered, filed or recorded in records appropriate to the kind and location of 25 
the property that are relied upon, in the ordinary course of transactions involving such 26 
property, as evidence of ownership.  27 
5.  Effect of revocation.  Provisions of a governing instrument are given effect as if 28 
the killer disclaimed all provisions revoked by this section or, in the case of a revoked 29 
nomination in a fiduciary or representative capacity, as if the killer predeceased the 30 
decedent.  31 
6.  Wrongfu l acquisition of property.  A wrongful acquisition of property or 32 
interest by a killer not covered by this section must be treated in accordance with the 33 
principle that a killer may not profit from the killer's wrong.  34 
7.  Felonious and intentional killing;  how determined.  After all right to appeal has 35 
been exhausted, a judgment of conviction establishing criminal accountability for the 36 
felonious and intentional killing of the decedent conclusively establishes the convicted 37 
individual as the decedent's kill er for purposes of this section.  In the absence of a 38 
conviction, the court, upon the petition of an interested person, shall determine whether, 39 
under the preponderance of evidence standard, the individual would be found criminally 40 
accountable for the felo nious and intentional killing of the decedent.  If the court 41 
 
 Page 82 - 128LR0452(01) -1 
 determines that, under that standard, the individual would be found criminally 1 
accountable for the felonious and intentional killing of the decedent, the determination 2 
conclusively establishes th at individual as the decedent's killer for purposes of this 3 
section.  4 
8.  Protection of payors and other 3rd parties.  This subsection governs the 5 
liability of payors and other 3rd parties.  6 
A.  A payor or other 3rd party is not liable for having made a paym ent or transferred 7 
an item of property or any other benefit to a beneficiary designated in a governing 8 
instrument affected by an intentional and felonious killing or for having taken any 9 
other action if that payment, transfer or other action is made in goo d faith reliance on 10 
the validity of the governing instrument, upon request and satisfactory proof of the 11 
decedent's death, before the payor or other 3rd party received written notice of a 12 
claimed forfeiture or revocation under this section.  A payor or oth er 3rd party is 13 
liable for a payment or transfer made or other action taken after the payor or other 3rd 14 
party received written notice of a claimed forfeiture or revocation under this section.  15 
B.  Written notice of a claimed forfeiture or revocation under paragraph A must be 16 
mailed to the payor's or other 3rd party's main office or home by registered or 17 
certified mail, return receipt requested, or served upon the payor or other 3rd party in 18 
the same manner as a summons in a civil action.  Upon receipt of wr itten notice of a 19 
claimed forfeiture or revocation under this section, a payor or other 3rd party may 20 
pay any amount owed or transfer or deposit any item of property held by the payor or 21 
other 3rd party to or with the court having jurisdiction of the proba te proceedings 22 
relating to the decedent's estate or, if no proceedings have been commenced, to or 23 
with the court having jurisdiction of probate proceedings relating to decedents' estates 24 
located in the county of the decedent's residence.  The court shall h old the funds or 25 
item of property and, upon its determination under this section, shall order 26 
disbursement in accordance with the determination.  Payments, transfers or deposits 27 
made to or with the court discharge the payor or other 3rd party from all clai ms for 28 
the value of amounts paid to or items of property transferred to or deposited with the 29 
court.  30 
9.  Protection of bona fide purchaser; personal liability of recipient.  This 31 
subsection governs the liability of bona fide purchasers and other recipients . 32 
A.  A person who purchases property for value and without notice, or who receives a 33 
payment, an item of property or any other benefit in partial or full satisfaction of a 34 
legally enforceable obligation, is neither obligated under this section to return t he 35 
payment, item of property or benefit nor liable under this section for the amount of 36 
the payment or the value of the item of property or benefit.  A person who, not for 37 
value, receives a payment, item of property or other benefit to which the person is not 38 
entitled under this section is obligated to return the payment, item of property or 39 
benefit, or is personally liable for the amount of the payment or the value of the item 40 
of property or benefit, to the person who is entitled to it under this section.  41 
B.  If this section or any part of this section is preempted by federal law with respect 42 
to a payment, an item of property or any other benefit covered by this section, a 43 
person who, not for value, receives the payment, item of property or other benefit to  44 
 
 Page 83 - 128LR0452(01) -1 
 which the person is not entitled under this section is obligated to return the payment, 1 
item of property or benefit, or is personally liable for the amount of the payment or 2 
the value of the item of property or benefit, to the person who would have been 3 
entitled to it were this section or part of this section not preempted.  4 
§2-803.  Effect of criminal conviction on intestate succession, wills, joint assets, 5 
beneficiary designations and other property acquisition when restitution is 6 
owed to the decedent  7 
A person who has been convicted of a crime of which the decedent was a victim is 8 
not entitled to the following benefits to the extent that the benefits do not exceed the 9 
amount of restitution the person owes to the decedent as a result of the sentence for the  10 
crime:  11 
1.  Decedent's will or this Article.  Any benefits under the decedent's will or under 12 
this Article;  13 
2.  Jointly owned property.  Any property owned jointly with the decedent;  14 
3.  Bond, life insurance policy or other contractual arrangement.  Any be nefit as 15 
a beneficiary of a bond, life insurance policy or other contractual arrangement in which 16 
the principal obligee or the person upon whose life the policy is issued is the decedent; 17 
and 18 
4.  Acquisition of property.  Any benefit from any acquisition o f property in which 19 
the decedent had an interest.  20 
§2-804.  Revocation of probate and nonprobate transfers by divorce; no revocation 21 
by other changes of circumstances  22 
1.  Definitions.  As used in this section, unless the context otherwise indicates, the 23 
following terms have the following meanings.  24 
A.  "Disposition or appointment of property" includes a transfer of an item of 25 
property or any other benefit to a beneficiary designated in a governing instrument.  26 
B.  "Divorce or annulment" means any divorce or an nulment, or any dissolution or 27 
declaration of invalidity of a marriage, that would exclude the spouse as a surviving 28 
spouse within the meaning of section 2 -801.  A decree of separation that does not 29 
terminate the status of spouses is not a divorce for purp oses of this section.  30 
C.  "Divorced individual" includes an individual whose marriage has been annulled.  31 
D.  "Governing instrument" means a governing instrument executed by the divorced 32 
individual before the divorce or annulment of the individual's marriag e to the 33 
individual's former spouse.  34 
E.  "Relative of the divorced individual's former spouse" means an individual who is 35 
related to the divorced individual's former spouse by blood, adoption or affinity and 36 
who, after the divorce or annulment, is not rela ted to the divorced individual by 37 
blood, adoption or affinity.  38 
 
 Page 84 - 128LR0452(01) -1 
 F.  "Revocable," with respect to a disposition, appointment, provision or nomination, 1 
means one under which the divorced individual, at the time of the divorce or 2 
annulment, was alone empowered , by law or under the governing instrument, to 3 
cancel the designation in favor of the divorced individual's former spouse or relative 4 
of the divorced individual's former spouse, whether or not the divorced individual 5 
was then empowered to designate the div orced individual in place of the divorced 6 
individual's former spouse or in place of the relative of the divorced individual's 7 
former spouse and whether or not the divorced individual then had the capacity to 8

A.  Revokes any revocable:  14 
(1)  Disposition or appointment of property made by a divorced individual to the 15 
divorced individual's former spouse in a governing instrument and any 16

relative of the divorced individual's former spouse;  18 
(2)  Provision in a governing instrument conferring a general or nongeneral 19

of the divorced individual's f ormer spouse; and  21 
(3)  Nomination in a governing instrument nominating a divorced individual's 22 
former spouse or a relative of the divorced individual's former spouse to serve in 23 
any fiduciary or representative capacity, including as a personal representati ve, 24 
executor, trustee, conservator, agent or guardian; and  25 
B.  Severs the interests of the former spouses in property held by them at the time of 26 
the divorce or annulment as joint tenants with the right of survivorship, transforming 27 
the interests of the f ormer spouses into equal tenancies in common.  28 
3.  Effect of severance.  A severance under subsection 2, paragraph B does not affect 29 
any 3rd -party interest in property acquired for value and in good faith reliance on an 30 
apparent title by survivorship in the  survivor of the former spouses unless a writing 31 
declaring the severance has been noted, registered, filed or recorded in records 32 
appropriate to the kind and location of the property that are relied upon, in the ordinary 33 
course of transactions involving su ch property, as evidence of ownership.  34 
4.  Effect of revocation.  Provisions of a governing instrument are given effect as if 35 
the divorced individual's former spouse and relatives of the divorced individual's former 36 
spouse disclaimed all provisions revoked  by this section or, in the case of a revoked 37 
nomination in a fiduciary or representative capacity, as if the divorced individual's former 38

the divorce or annulment.  40 
 
 Page 85 - 128LR0452(01) -1 
 5.  Revival if divorce nullified.  Provisions revoked solely by this section are revived 1 
by the divorced individual's remarriage to the former spouse or by a nullification of the 2 
divorce or annulment.  3 
6.  No revocation for other change of circumstances.  A ch ange of circumstances 4 
other than as described in this section or in section 2 -802 does not effect a revocation 5 
pursuant to this section.  6

to or with the court having jurisdiction of the probate proceedings relat ing to the 24

and, upon its determination under this section, shall order disbursement or transfer in 28 
accordance with the determination.  Payments, transfers or deposits made to or with 29 
the court discharge the payor or other 3rd party from all claims for t he value of 30 
amounts paid to or items of property transferred to or deposited with the court.  31
