§2-805.  Reformatio n to correct mistakes  11 
The court may reform the terms of a governing instrument, even if unambiguous, to 12 
conform the terms to the transferor's intention if it is proved by clear and convincing 13 
evidence what the transferor's intention was and that the terms of the governing 14 
instrument were affected by a mistake of fact or law, whether in expression or 15 
inducement.  16 
§2-806.  Modification to achieve transferor's tax objectives  17 
To achieve the transferor's tax objectives, the court may modify the terms of a 18 
governi ng instrument in a manner that is not contrary to the transferor's probable 19 
intention.  The court may provide that the modification has retroactive effect.  20 
§2-807.  Actions for wrongful death  21 
1.  Liability notwithstanding death.  Whenever the death of a pe rson is caused by a 22 
wrongful act, neglect or default, and the act, neglect or default is such as would, if death 23 
had not ensued, have entitled the party injured to maintain an action and recover damages 24 
in respect thereof, then the person or the corporatio n that would have been liable if death 25 
had not ensued is liable for damages as provided in this section, notwithstanding the 26 
death of the person injured and although the death was caused under circumstances that 27 
amount to a felony.  28 
2.  Wrongful death actio n; damages; limitations.  Every wrongful death action 29 
must be brought by and in the name of the personal representative or special 30 
administrator of the deceased person, and is distributable, after payment for funeral 31 
expenses and the costs of recovery incl uding attorney's fees, directly to the decedent's 32 
heirs without becoming part of the probate estate, except as may be specifically provided 33 
in this subsection.  The amount recovered in every wrongful death action, except as 34 
specifically provided in this su bsection, is for the exclusive benefit of the deceased's heirs 35 
to be distributed to the individuals and in the proportions as provided in sections 2 -102 36 
and 2 -103.  The jury may give damages as it determines a fair and just compensation with 37 
reference to t he pecuniary injuries resulting from the death.  Damages are payable to the 38 
estate of the deceased person only if the jury specifically makes an award payable to the 39 
estate for reasonable expenses of medical, surgical and hospital care and treatment and 40 
for reasonable funeral expenses or, in the case of a settlement, the settlement documents 41 
specifically provide for such an allocation to the estate for the same.  In addition, the jury 42 
 
 Page 87 - 128LR0452(01) -1 
 may give damages not exceeding $500,000 for the loss of comfort, society and 1 
companionship of the deceased, including any damages for emotional distress arising 2 
from the same facts as those constituting the underlying claim, to the persons for whose 3 
benefit the action is brought.  The jury may also give punitive damages not exc eeding 4 
$250,000.  An action under this section must be commenced within 2 years after the 5 
decedent's death, except that if the decedent's death is caused by a homicide, the action 6 
may be commenced within 6 years of the date the personal representative or s pecial 7 
administrator of the decedent discovers that there is a just cause of action against the 8 
person who caused the homicide.  If a claim under this section is settled without an action 9 
having been commenced, the amount paid in settlement must be distrib uted as provided 10 
in this subsection.  A settlement on behalf of minor children is not valid unless approved 11 
by the court, as provided in Title 14, section 1605.  12 
3.  Damages for conscious suffering.  Whenever death ensues following a period of 13 
conscious suf fering, as a result of personal injuries due to the wrongful act, neglect or 14 
default of any person, the person who caused the personal injuries resulting in such 15 
conscious suffering and death is, in addition to the action at common law and damages 16 
recovera ble therein, liable in damages in a separate count in the same action for such 17 
death, brought, commenced and determined and subject to the same limitation as to the 18 
amount recoverable for such death and exclusively for the beneficiaries in the manner set 19 
forth in subsection 2, separately found, but in such cases there is only one recovery for 20 
the same injury.  21 
4.  Maine Tort Claims Act.  Any action under this section brought against a 22 
governmental entity under Title 14, sections 8101 to 8118 is limited as pr ovided in those 23 
sections.  24 
PART 9  25 
UNIFORM DISCLAIMER O F PROPERTY INTERESTS  ACT  26 
§2-901.  Short title  27 
This Part may be known and cited as "the Uniform Disclaimer of Property Interests 28 
Act."  29 
§2-902.  Definitions  30 
As used in this Part, unless the context otherwi se indicates, the following terms have 31 
the following meanings.  32 
1.  Disclaimant.  "Disclaimant" means the person to whom a disclaimed interest or 33 
power would have passed had the disclaimer not been made.  34 
2.  Disclaimed interest.  "Disclaimed interest" means  the interest that would have 35 
passed to the disclaimant had the disclaimer not been made.  36 
3.  Disclaimer.  "Disclaimer" means the refusal to accept an interest in or power over 37 
property.  38 
 
 Page 88 - 128LR0452(01) -1 
 4.  Fiduciary.  "Fiduciary" means a personal representative, trustee,  agent acting 1 
under a power of attorney or other person authorized to act as a fiduciary with respect to 2 
the property of another person.  3 
5.  Jointly held property.  "Jointly held property" means property held in the name 4 
of 2 or more persons under an arran gement in which all holders have concurrent interests 5 
and under which the last surviving holder is entitled to the whole of the property.  6 
6.  Person.  "Person" means an individual, corporation, business trust, estate, trust, 7 
partnership, limited liability company, association, joint venture, government, 8 
governmental subdivision, agency or instrumentality, public corporation or any other 9 
legal or commercial entity.  10 
7.  State.  "State" means a state of the United States, the District of Columbia, the 11 
Commonwe alth of Puerto Rico, the United States Virgin Islands or any territory or 12 
insular possession subject to the jurisdiction of the United States.  "State" includes an 13 
Indian tribe or band or Alaskan native village recognized by federal law or formally 14 
acknowl edged by a state.  15 
8.  Trust.  "Trust" means:  16 
A.  An express trust, charitable or noncharitable, with additions thereto, whenever 17 
and however created; and  18 
B.  A trust created pursuant to a statute, judgment or decree that requires the trust to 19 
be administer ed in the manner of an express trust.  20 
§2-903.  Scope  21 
This Part applies to disclaimers of any interest in or power over property, whenever 22 
created.  23 
§2-904.  Part supplemented by other law  24 
1.  Principles of law and equity.  Unless displaced by a provision of  this Part, the 25 
principles of law and equity supplement this Part.  26 
2.  Right to waive, release, disclaim or renounce property interest.  This Part does 27 
not limit any right of a person to waive, release, disclaim or renounce an interest in or 28 
power over pro perty under a law other than this Part.  29 
§2-905.  Power to disclaim; general requirements; when irrevocable  30 
1.  Power to disclaim.  A person may disclaim, in whole or part, any interest in or 31 
power over property, including a power of appointment.  A person may disclaim the 32 
interest or power even if its creator imposed a spendthrift provision or similar restriction 33 
on transfer or a restriction or limitation on the right to disclaim.  34 
2.  Fiduciary authority to disclaim.  Except to the extent a fiduciary's righ t to 35 
disclaim is expressly restricted or limited by another statute of this State or by the 36 
instrument creating the fiduciary relationship, a fiduciary may disclaim, in whole or part, 37 
 
 Page 89 - 128LR0452(01) -1 
 any interest in or power over property, including a power of appointment , whether acting 1 
in a personal or representative capacity.  A fiduciary may disclaim the interest or power 2 
even if its creator imposed a spendthrift provision or similar restriction on transfer or a 3 
restriction or limitation on the right to disclaim or an instrument other than the instrument 4 
that created the fiduciary relationship imposed a restriction or limitation on the right to 5 
disclaim.  6 
3.  General requirements.  To be effective, a disclaimer must be in a writing or 7 
other record, declare the disclaimer , describe the interest or power disclaimed, be signed 8 
by the person making the disclaimer and be delivered or filed in the manner provided in 9 
section 2 -912.  As used in this subsection, unless the context otherwise indicates, the 10 
following terms have the following meanings.  11 
A.  "Record" means information that is inscribed on a tangible medium or that is 12 
stored in an electronic or other medium and is retrievable in perceivable form.  13 
B.  "Sign" means, with present intent to authenticate or adopt a record, to : 14 
(1)  Execute or adopt a tangible symbol; or  15 
(2)  Attach to or logically associate with the record an electronic sound, symbol 16 
or process.  17 
4.  Partial disclaimer.  A partial disclaimer may be expressed as a fraction, 18 
percentage, monetary amount, term of y ears, limitation of a power or any other interest or 19 
estate in the property.  20 
5.  When irrevocable.  A disclaimer becomes irrevocable when it is delivered or 21 
filed pursuant to section 2 -912 or when it becomes effective as provided in sections 2 -906 22 
to 2-911, whichever occurs later.  23 
6.  Disclaimer not a transfer, assignment or release.  A disclaimer made under this 24 
Part is not a transfer, assignment or release.  25 
§2-906.  Disclaimer of interest in property  26 
1.  Definitions.  As used in this section, unless the c ontext otherwise indicates, the 27 
following terms have the following meanings.  28 
A.  "Future interest" means an interest that takes effect in possession or enjoyment, if 29 
at all, later than the time of its creation.  30 
B.  "Time of distribution" means the time whe n a disclaimed interest would have 31 
taken effect in possession or enjoyment.  32 
2.  General provisions governing disclaimers.  Except for a disclaimer governed by 33 
section 2 -907 or 2 -908, the following provisions apply to a disclaimer of an interest in 34 
property . 35 
A.  The disclaimer takes effect as of the time the instrument creating the interest 36 
becomes irrevocable or, if the interest arose under the law of intestate succession, as 37 
of the time of the intestate's death.  38 
 
 Page 90 - 128LR0452(01) -1 
 B.  The disclaimed interest passes according  to any provision in the instrument 1 
creating the interest providing for the disposition of the interest, should it be 2 
disclaimed, or of disclaimed interests in general.  3 
C.  If the instrument does not contain a provision described in paragraph B, the 4 
follow ing provisions apply.  5 
(1)  If the disclaimant is not an individual, the disclaimed interest passes as if the 6 
disclaimant did not exist.  7 
(2)  If the disclaimant is an individual, except as otherwise provided in 8 
subparagraphs (3) and (4), the disclaimed inte rest passes as if the disclaimant had 9 
died immediately before the time of distribution.  10 
(3)  If by law or under the instrument the descendants of the disclaimant would 11 
share in the disclaimed interest by any method of representation had the 12 
disclaimant die d before the time of distribution, the disclaimed interest passes 13 
only to the descendants of the disclaimant who survive the time of distribution.  14 
(4)  If the disclaimed interest would pass to the disclaimant's estate had the 15 
disclaimant died before the ti me of distribution, the disclaimed interest instead 16 
passes by representation to the descendants of the disclaimant who survive the 17 
time of distribution.  If no descendant of the disclaimant survives the time of 18 
distribution, the disclaimed interest passes to those persons, including the State 19 
but excluding the disclaimant, and in such shares as would succeed to the 20 
transferor's intestate estate under the intestate succession law of the transferor's 21 
domicile had the transferor died at the time of distributio n.  However, if the 22 
transferor's surviving spouse is living but is remarried at the time of distribution, 23 
the transferor is deemed to have died unmarried at the time of distribution.  24 
D.  Upon the disclaimer of a preceding interest, a future interest held b y a person 25 
other than the disclaimant takes effect as if the disclaimant had died or ceased to exist 26 
immediately before the time of distribution, but a future interest held by the 27 
disclaimant is not accelerated in possession or enjoyment.  28 
§2-907.  Disclaim er of rights of survivorship in jointly held property  29 
1.  Disclaimer by surviving holder of jointly held property.  Upon the death of a 30 
holder of jointly held property, a surviving holder may disclaim, in whole or part, the 31 
greater of:  32 
A.  A fractional sha re of the property determined by dividing the number one by the 33 
number of joint holders alive immediately before the death of the holder to whose 34 
death the disclaimer relates; and  35 
B.  All of the property except that part of the value of the entire interest  attributable to 36 
the contribution furnished by the disclaimant.  37 
2.  Effective date of disclaimer.  A disclaimer under subsection 1 takes effect as of 38 
the death of the holder of jointly held property to whose death the disclaimer relates.  39 
 
 Page 91 - 128LR0452(01) -1 
 3.  Disposition of  disclaimed property.  An interest in jointly held property 1 
disclaimed by a surviving holder of the property passes as if the disclaimant predeceased 2 
the holder to whose death the disclaimer relates.  3 
§2-908.  Disclaimer of interest by trustee  4 
If a trustee disclaims an interest in property that otherwise would have become trust 5 
property, the interest does not become trust property.  6 
§2-909.  Disclaimer of power of appointment or other power not held in fiduciary 7 
capacity  8 
If a holder disclaims a power of appoi ntment or other power not held in a fiduciary 9 
capacity, the following provisions apply.  10 
1.  Disclaimer of unexercised power.  If the holder has not exercised the power, the 11 
disclaimer takes effect as of the time the instrument creating the power becomes 12 
irrevocable.  13 
2.  Disclaimer of exercised power.   If the holder has exercised the power and the 14 
disclaimer is of a power other than a presently exercisable general power of appointment, 15 
the disclaimer takes effect immediately after the last exercise of the p ower.  16 
3.  Construction of instrument creating the power.  The instrument creating the 17 
power is construed as if the power expired when the disclaimer became effective.  18 
§2-910.  Disclaimer by appointee, object or taker in default of exercise of power of 19 
appo intment  20 
1.  Disclaimer by appointee.  A disclaimer of an interest in property by an appointee 21 
of a power of appointment takes effect as of the time the instrument by which the holder 22 
exercises the power becomes irrevocable.  23 
2.  Disclaimer by object or take r in default.  A disclaimer of an interest in property 24 
by an object or taker in default of an exercise of a power of appointment takes effect as of 25 
the time the instrument creating the power becomes irrevocable.  26 
§2-911.  Disclaimer of power held in fiducia ry capacity  27 
1.  Disclaimer of unexercised power.  If a fiduciary disclaims a power held in a 28 
fiduciary capacity that has not been exercised, the disclaimer takes effect as of the time 29 
the instrument creating the power becomes irrevocable.  30 
2.  Disclaimer of  exercised power.  If a fiduciary disclaims a power held in a 31 
fiduciary capacity that has been exercised, the disclaimer takes effect immediately after 32 
the last exercise of the power.  33 
3.  Effect of disclaimer by fiduciary.  A disclaimer under this section is effective as 34 
to another fiduciary if the disclaimer so provides and the fiduciary disclaiming has the 35 
authority to bind the estate, trust or other person for whom the fiduciary is acting.  36 
 
 Page 92 - 128LR0452(01) -1 
 §2-912.  Delivery or filing  1 
1.  Beneficiary designation.  As used  in this section, "beneficiary designation" 2 
means an instrument, other than an instrument creating a trust, naming the beneficiary of:  3 
A.  An annuity or insurance policy;  4 
B.  An account with a designation for payment;  5 
C.  A security registered in beneficia ry form;  6 
D.  A pension, profit -sharing, retirement or other employment -related benefit plan; or  7 
E.  Any other nonprobate transfer at death.  8 
2.  Delivery of disclaimer; generally.  Subject to subsections 3 to 12, delivery of a 9 
disclaimer may be effected by personal delivery, first -class mail or any other method 10 
likely to result in its receipt.  11 
3.  Disclaimer of interest from intestate succession or will.  In the case of an 12 
interest created under the law of intestate succession or an interest created by will,  other 13 
than an interest in a testamentary trust:  14 
A.  A disclaimer must be delivered to the personal representative of the decedent's 15 
estate or the special administrator of the decedent's estate; or  16 
B.  If no personal representative is then serving, a discl aimer must be filed with the 17 
court having jurisdiction to appoint the personal representative.  18 
4.  Disclaimer of interest in a testamentary trust.  In the case of an interest in a 19 
testamentary trust:  20 
A.  A disclaimer must be delivered to the trustee then s erving or, if no trustee is then 21 
serving, to the personal representative of the decedent's estate; or  22 
B.  If no trustee or personal representative is then serving, the disclaimer must be 23 
filed with the court having jurisdiction to enforce the trust.  24 
5.  Disclaimer of interest in inter vivos trust.  In the case of an interest in an inter 25 
vivos trust:  26 
A.  A disclaimer must be delivered to the trustee then serving;  27 
B.  If no trustee is then serving, the disclaimer must be filed with the court having 28 
jurisdicti on to enforce the trust; or  29 
C.  If the disclaimer is made before the time the instrument creating the trust becomes 30 
irrevocable, it must be delivered to the settlor of a revocable trust or the transferor of 31 
the interest.  32 
6.  Disclaimer of interest created by beneficiary designation.  In the case of an 33 
interest created by a beneficiary designation that is disclaimed before the time the 34 
designation becomes irrevocable, the disclaimer must be delivered to the person making 35 
the beneficiary designation.  36 
 
 Page 93 - 128LR0452(01) -1 
 7.  Disclaimer of interest created by irrevocable beneficiary designation.  In the 1 
case of an interest created by a beneficiary designation that is disclaimed after the 2 
designation becomes irrevocable:  3 
A.  The disclaimer of an interest in personal property must be  delivered to the person 4 
obligated to distribute the interest; and  5 
B.  The disclaimer of an interest in real property must be recorded in the registry of 6 
deeds of the county where the real property that is the subject of the disclaimer is 7 
located.  8 
8.  Disclaimer by surviving holder of jointly held property.  In the case of a 9 
disclaimer by a surviving holder of jointly held property, the disclaimer must be delivered 10 
to the person to whom the disclaimed interest passes.  11 
9.  Disclaimer by object or taker in de fault.  In the case of a disclaimer by an 12 
object or taker in default of exercise of a power of appointment at any time after the 13 
power was created:  14 
A.  The disclaimer must be delivered to the holder of the power or to the fiduciary 15 
acting under the instrum ent that created the power; or  16 
B.  If no fiduciary is then serving, the disclaimer must be filed with the court having 17 
authority to appoint the fiduciary.  18 
10.  Disclaimer by appointee.  In the case of a disclaimer by an appointee of a 19 
nonfiduciary power of  appointment:  20 
A.  The disclaimer must be delivered to the holder, the personal representative of the 21 
holder's estate or to the fiduciary under the instrument that created the power; or  22 
B.  If no fiduciary is then serving, the disclaimer must be filed with the court having 23 
authority to appoint the fiduciary.  24 
11.  Disclaimer by fiduciary.  In the case of a disclaimer by a fiduciary of a power 25 
over a trust or estate, the disclaimer must be delivered as provided in subsection 3, 4 or 5 26 
as if the power disclaime d were an interest in property.  27 
12.  Disclaimer of a power by an agent.  In the case of a disclaimer of a power by 28 
an agent, the disclaimer must be delivered to the principal or the principal's 29 
representative.  30 
§2-913.  When disclaimer barred or limited  31 
1.  Bar pursuant to written waiver.  A disclaimer is barred by a written waiver of 32 
the right to disclaim.  33 
2.  Bar pursuant to events.  A disclaimer of an interest in property is barred if any of 34 
the following events occur before the disclaimer becomes effecti ve: 35 
A.  The disclaimant accepts the interest sought to be disclaimed;  36 
 
 Page 94 - 128LR0452(01) -1 
 B.  The disclaimant voluntarily assigns, conveys, encumbers, pledges or transfers the 1 
interest sought to be disclaimed or contracts to do so; or  2 
C.  A judicial sale of the interest sough t to be disclaimed occurs.  3 
3.  Previous exercise not a bar to disclaimer of power held in fiduciary capacity.  4 
A disclaimer, in whole or part, of the future exercise of a power held in a fiduciary 5 
capacity is not barred by its previous exercise.  6 
4.  Previo us exercise not a bar to disclaimer of power not held in fiduciary 7 
capacity; exception.  A disclaimer, in whole or part, of the future exercise of a power not 8 
held in a fiduciary capacity is not barred by its previous exercise unless the power is 9 
exercisab le in favor of the disclaimant.  10 
5.  Bar pursuant to law.  A disclaimer is barred or limited if so provided by law 11 
other than this Part.  12 
6.  Effect of bar.  A disclaimer of a power over property that is barred by this section 13 
is ineffective.  A disclaimer o f an interest in property that is barred by this section takes 14 
effect as a transfer of the interest disclaimed to the persons who would have taken the 15 
interest under this Part had the disclaimer not been barred.  16 
§2-914.  Tax qualified disclaimer  17 
Notwithsta nding any other provision of this Part, if as a result of a disclaimer or 18 
transfer the disclaimed or transferred interest is treated, pursuant to the provisions of 26 19 
United States Code, as amended, or any successor statute, and the regulations 20 
promulgated  thereunder, as never having been transferred to the disclaimant, the 21 
disclaimer or transfer is effective as a disclaimer under this Part.  22 
§2-915.  Recording of disclaimer  23 
If an instrument transferring an interest in or power over property subject to a 24 
disclaimer is required or permitted by law to be filed, recorded or registered, the 25 
disclaimer may be so filed, recorded or registered.  Except as otherwise provided in 26 
section 2 -912, subsection 7, paragraph B, failure to file, record or register the disclaim er 27 
does not affect its validity as between the disclaimant and persons to whom the property 28 
interest or power passes by reason of the disclaimer.  29 
§2-916.  Application to existing relationships  30 
Except as otherwise provided in section 2 -913, an interest in o r power over property 31 
existing on January 1, 2019 as to which the time for delivering or filing a disclaimer 32 
under law superseded by this Part has not expired may be disclaimed after January 1, 33 
2019.  34

modify, limit or supersede Section 101(c) of that Act, 15 Uni ted States Code, Section 38

Maine Uniform Probate Code Com ment (§2 -203) 26 
The Uniform Probate Code  defines the values to be considered in calculating the 27 
augmented estate with more clarity and specificity than former Title 18 -A.  The Uniform 28 
Probate Code  applies a partnership theory of marriage in calculating this marita l-property 29

 Maine Uniform Probate Code Comment (§2 -204) 1 
This section  does not constitute a substantive change to Maine law.  2 
Maine Uniform Probate Code Comment (§2 -205) 3 
The Maine Uniform Probate Code, section  2-205 changes Maine law in several 4 
respects.  Subsection  1 includes in the augmented estate any property of which the 5 
decedent could have become the owner through the exercise of  certain specific rights, 6 
regardless of who created those rights.  Under former Title 18 -A, such property would be 7 
included in the augmented estate only if the decedent's rights were retained in connection 8 
with a transfer of the property made by the decede nt during the marriage.  Subsection  1 9 
also closes a perceived loophole in the elective -share statute by including in the 10 
augmented estate proceeds of insurance on the life of the decedent that are payable to 11 
someone other than the surviving spouse.  It als o clarifies that individual retirement 12 
accounts and qualified retirement assets payable to persons other than the surviving 13 
spouse are included in the gross estate.   14 
Subsection  2 expands the assets that would be included in the augmented estate under 15 
prior law by including powers that are exercisable by a "nonadverse party." Prior law had 16 
included only powers exercisable by the decedent "either alone or in conjunction with any 17 
other person . . ."  18 
Subsection 3, paragraph C increases the amount that is excl uded from the augmented 19 
estate to the excess over 50% of the amount excludable from taxable gifts pursuant to 26 20 
United States Code, Section  2503(b).  The exclusion amount had been $3,000 under prior 21 
law.   22 
Maine Uniform Probate Code Comment (§2 -207) 23 
The M aine Uniform Probate Code , section  2-207 modifies Maine law by including in 24 
the augmented estate all of the surviving spouse's property, regardless of whether it was 25 
derived from the decedent.  Former Title 18 -A included only property owned by the 26 
survivin g spouse at the decedent's death that was derived from the decedent  and property 27 
transferred by the surviving spouse during marriage that would have been included in the 28 
augmented estate had the surviving spouse predeceased the decedent.  The Maine 29 
Uniform  Probate Code , section  2-207 modifies this by including in the augmented estate 30 
any property that would have constituted the surviving spouse's nonprobate transfers to 31 
others applying the expanded rules under the Maine Uniform Probate Code , section  2-205 32 
had the surviving spouse been the decedent.   33 
Maine Uniform Probate Code Comment (§2 -208) 34 
Although the Uniform Probate Code  provides that the value of property includes the 35 
commuted value of present or future interests and amounts payable under trusts and 36 
various contractual arrangements, it provides no guidance in terms of valuing beneficial 37 
interest in fully discretionary trusts for which commuted values are not readily 38 
 
 Page 98 - 128LR0452(01) -1 
 determinable.  In adopting the Uniform Probate Code, section 2-208(b), Maine law  is 1 
modified to establish a rebuttable presumption that the value of a beneficial interest in a 2 
fully discretionary trust is 50% of the value of the trust assets.  This provision is similar to 3 
the presumption under former Title 18 -A, section  2-207, subsection (a)  with respect to the 4 
value of an electing spouse's beneficial interest in a life estate or trust.   5 
Maine Uniform Probate Code Comment (§2 -212) 6 
This section revises former Title 18 -A, section 2 -203 in 3 significant respects.  First, 7 
it makes it clear that the right of election may be exercised only by or on behalf of a 8 
living surviving spouse.  Second, the election can be pursued on behalf of the surviving 9 
spouse by the spouse's conservator or agent.  In any case, the surviving spouse must be 10 
alive when the  election is made and cannot be pursued on behalf of a decedent.  Third, it 11 
treats incapacitated spouses the same as spouses with capacity.  Previously, if  a spouse 12 
was incapacitated, the court exercised the share on behalf of the incapacitated spouse only  13 
after a judicial proceeding to determine the necessity of the share for the incapacitated 14 
spouse's life expectancy ; a spouse with capacity was able to elect regardless of need.  15 
Treating incapacitated spouses the same as spouses with capacity is a deviatio n from 16 
the Uniform Probate Code (1990) , which provides that the incapacitated spouse's share is 17 
to be distributed to a custodial trust for the surviving spouse's life, the remainder 18 
beneficiaries of which are the predeceased spouse's residuary devisees or heirs.   19 
Eliminating the disparate treatment between incapacitated spouses and spouses with 20 
capacity is consistent with the revised elective -share law , which attempts to more closely 21 
align the amounts that a spouse receives upon divorce to that which the s pouse receives 22 
upon death.  Under this partnership theory of marriage, which forms the basis of much of 23 
the revisions to elective -share law, an incapacitated spouse in a divorce proceeding does 24 
not receive less of an equitable distribution solely due to th e incapacity.  This section 25 
therefore applies the partnership theory of marriage equitably to all surviving spouses.  26

Maine’s adoption of section 2 -405 represents a deviation from the Unifor m Probate 15

portions payable under the homestead allow ance, exempt property  and family allowance 17

Maine Uniform Probate C ode Comment (§2 -502) 33 
 
 Page 100 - 128LR0452(01) -1 
 This section does not adopt the Uniform Probate Code ’s alternative method of will 1 
execution of acknowledgement by a notary in lieu of execution by 2 witnesses.  The 2 
section adopts the “conscious presence” test of the Uniform Probate Co de.  Under the 3 
“conscious presence” test, a signing is sufficient if it was done within the range of the 4 
testator’s senses , such as within the testator’s hearing; the signing need not have occurred 5 
within the testator’s line of sight.  6 
The Maine Supreme Jud icial Court held in In Re Estate of Gonzalez , 855 A.2d 1146 7 
2004 ME 109 (Me.  2004) that a pre printed form filled in with the testator’s handwriting 8 
can qualify as a holographic will.  9 
The section departs from the Uniform Probate Code  by not referencing the  harmless 10 
error standard of the Uniform Probate Code , which is not adopted in Maine.  11

Maine U niform Probate Code Comment (§2 -603) 13 
 The phrase "by representation " in the Uniform Probate Code  has been changed to 14 
"per capita at each generation " in Title 18 -C.  The phrase "by representation " is synonymous 15 
with "per stirpes ."  See the Maine Uniform Pro bate Code, section 2 -709. Maine has long 16 
considered inheritance by right of representation to be synonymous with inheritance per 17 
stirpes.   Fiduciary Trust Co. v. Brown,  131 A.2d 191 (Me. 1957).  18 
 Maine has reversed the presumption of section 2 -603(b)(3) of  the Uniform Probate 19 
Code , which created a rebuttable presumption that using words of survivorship, such as a 20 
devise to an individual "if he survives me " or in a devise to "my surviving children, " are not, 21 
in the absence of additional evidence, a sufficien t indication of an intent contrary to the 22 
application  of the anti -lapse provisions.  Under the Maine Uniform Probate Code,  words of 23 
survivorship create a rebuttable presumption of the testator 's intent to not have the anti -lapse 24 
provisions apply.  For exam ple, in a devise to "my surviving children, " if the testator had 25 
three children, X, Y and Z, and child X predeceased the testator leaving GC1 and GC2, the 26 
devise will be distributed in equal shares to Y and Z, with no distribution to GC1 and GC2.  27

ARTICLE 3  18 
PROBATE OF WILLS AND  ADMINISTRATION  19 
PART 1  20 
GENERAL PROVISIONS  21 
§3-101.  Devolution of estate at death; restrictions  22 
The power of a person to leave property by will and the rights of creditors, devisees 23 
and heirs to the person's property are subject to the restrictions and limitat ions contained 24 
in this Code to facilitate the prompt settlement of estates.  Upon the death of a person, the 25 
 
 Page 108 - 128LR0452(01) -1 
 person's real and personal property devolves to the persons to whom it is devised by the 1 
person's last will or to those indicated as substitutes fo r them in cases involving lapse, 2 
renunciation or other circumstances affecting the devolution of testate estate or, in the 3 
absence of testamentary disposition, to the person's heirs, or to those indicated as 4 
substitutes for them in cases involving renuncia tion or other circumstances affecting 5 
devolution of intestate estates, subject to homestead allowance, exempt property and 6 
family allowance, to rights of creditors, to elective share of the surviving spouse and to 7 
administration.  8 
§3-102.  Necessity of orde r of probate for will  9 
Except as provided in section 3 -1201, to be effective to prove the transfer of any 10 
property or to nominate an executor, a will must be declared to be valid by an order of 11 
informal probate by the registers or an adjudication of probate  by the court.  12 
§3-103.  Necessity of appointment for administration  13 
Except as otherwise provided in Article 4, to acquire the powers and undertake the 14 
duties and liabilities of a personal representative of a decedent, a person must be 15 
appointed by order of  the court or registers, qualify and be issued letters. Administration 16 
of an estate is commenced by the issuance of letters.  17 
§3-104.  Claims against decedent; necessity of administration  18 
A proceeding to enforce a claim against the estate of a decedent or t he decedent's 19 
successors may not be revived or commenced before the appointment of a personal 20 
representative.  After the appointment and until distribution, all proceedings and actions 21 
to enforce a claim against the estate are governed by the procedure pre scribed by this 22 
Article.  After distribution, a creditor whose claim has not been barred may recover from 23 
the distributees as provided in section 3 -1004 or from a former personal representative 24 
individually liable as provided in section 3 -1005.  This secti on has no application to a 25 
proceeding by a secured creditor of the decedent to enforce the creditor's right to the 26 
security except as to any deficiency judgment that might be sought.  27 
§3-105.  Proceedings affecting devolution and administration; jurisdictio n of subject 28 
matter  29 
Persons interested in decedents' estates may apply to the register for determination in 30 
the informal proceedings provided in this Article and may petition the court for orders in 31 
formal proceedings within the court's jurisdiction includ ing but not limited to those 32 
described in this Article.  The court has exclusive jurisdiction of formal proceedings to 33 
determine how decedents' estates subject to the laws of this State are to be administered, 34 
expended and distributed.  The court has concu rrent jurisdiction of any other action or 35 
proceeding concerning a succession or to which an estate, through a personal 36 
representative, may be a party, including actions to determine title to property alleged to 37 
belong to the estate, and of any action or pr oceeding in which property is distributed by a 38 
personal representative or its value is sought to be subjected to rights of creditors or 39 
successors of the decedent.  40 
 
 Page 109 - 128LR0452(01) -1 
 §3-106.  Proceedings within the jurisdiction of court; service; jurisdiction over 1 
persons  2 
In proceedings within the exclusive jurisdiction of the court where notice is required 3 
by this Code or by rule, and in proceedings to construe probated wills or determine heirs 4 
that concern estates that have not been and cannot now be opened for administrati on, 5 
interested persons may be bound by the orders of the court in respect to property in or 6 
subject to the laws of this State by notice in conformity with section 1 -401.  An order is 7 
binding on all who are given notice of the proceeding though fewer than a ll interested 8 
persons are notified.  9 
§3-107.  Scope of proceedings; proceedings independent; exception  10 
Unless supervised administration as described in Part 5 is involved:  11 
1.  Proceedings independent.  Each proceeding before the court or register is 12 
indepen dent of any other proceeding involving the same estate;  13 
2.  Petitions for formal orders.  Petitions for formal orders of the court may 14 
combine various requests for relief in a single proceeding if the orders sought may be 15 
finally granted without delay. Exc ept as required for proceedings that are particularly 16 
described by other sections of this Article, a petition is not defective because it fails to 17 
embrace all matters that might then be the subject of a final order;  18 
3.  Petitions for appointment of persona l representative.  Proceedings for probate 19 
of wills or adjudications of no will may be combined with proceedings for appointment of 20 
personal representatives; and  21 
4.  Order.  A proceeding for appointment of a personal representative is concluded 22 
by an order  making or declining the appointment.  23 
§3-108.  Probate, testacy and appointment proceedings; ultimate time limit  24 
1.  Limitations period; exceptions.  An informal probate or appointment proceeding 25 
or formal testacy or appointment proceeding, other than a pr oceeding to probate a will 26 
previously probated at the testator's domicile and appointment proceedings relating to an 27 
estate in which there has been a prior appointment, may not be commenced more than 3 28 
years after the decedent's death, except:  29 
A.  If a pre vious proceeding was dismissed because of doubt about the fact of the 30 
decedent's death, appropriate probate, appointment or testacy proceedings may be 31 
maintained at any time thereafter upon a finding that the decedent's death occurred 32 
prior to the initiati on of the previous proceeding and the applicant or petitioner has 33 
not delayed unduly in initiating the subsequent proceeding;  34 
B.  Appropriate probate, appointment or testacy proceedings may be maintained in 35 
relation to the estate of an absent, disappeared or missing person for whose estate a 36 
conservator has been appointed at any time within 3 years after the conservator 37 
becomes able to establish the death of the protected person;  38 
 
 Page 110 - 128LR0452(01) -1 
 C.  A proceeding to contest an informally probated will and to secure appointm ent of 1 
the person with legal priority for appointment in the event the contest is successful 2 
may be commenced within the later of 12 months from the informal probate or 3 3 
years from the decedent's death;  4 
D.  An informal appointment or a formal testacy or a ppointment proceeding may be 5 
commenced more than 3 years after the decedent's death if no proceeding concerning 6 
the succession or estate administration has occurred within the 3 -year period after the 7 
decedent's death, but the personal representative has no  right to possess estate assets 8 
as provided in section 3 -709 beyond that necessary to confirm title in the successors 9 
to the estate, and claims other than expenses of administration may not be presented 10 
against the estate; and  11 
E.  A formal testacy proceedi ng may be commenced at any time after 3 years from 12 
the decedent's death for the purpose of establishing an instrument to direct or control 13 
the ownership of property passing or distributable after the decedent's death from a 14 
person other than the decedent w hen the property is to be appointed by the terms of 15 
the decedent's will or is to pass or be distributed as a part of the decedent's estate or 16 
its transfer is otherwise to be controlled by the terms of the decedent's will.  17 
2.  Limitations period inapplicabl e.  The limitations under subsection 1 do not 18 
apply to proceedings to construe probated wills or determine heirs of an intestate.  19 
3.  Special provision regarding date of death.  In cases under subsection 1, 20 
paragraph A or B, the date on which a testacy or appointment proceeding is properly 21 
commenced is deemed to be the date of the decedent's death for purposes of other 22 
limitations provisions of this Code that relate to the date of death.  23 
§3-109.  Statutes of limitation on decedent's cause of action  24 
A statut e of limitation running on a cause of action belonging to a decedent that had 25 
not been barred as of the date of death does not apply to bar a cause of action surviving 26 
the decedent's death sooner than 4 months after death. A cause of action that but for th is 27 
section would have been barred less than 4 months after death is barred after 4 months 28 
unless tolled.  29 
§3-110.  Discovery of property  30 
1.  Examination by court.  Upon petition by a county attorney, personal 31 
representative, heir, devisee, creditor or other  person interested in the estate of a 32 
decedent, anyone suspected of having concealed, withheld or conveyed away any 33 
property of the decedent, of having fraudulently received any such property, or of aiding 34 
others in so doing, may be cited by the court to a ppear and be examined under oath.  The 35 
court may require the person to produce for the inspection of the court and parties all 36 
documents within the person's control relating to the matter under examination.  The time 37 
for filing such petitions is governed b y section 1 -105. 38 
2.  Penalties for refusal.  If a person duly cited pursuant to subsection 1 refuses to 39 
appear and submit to the court's examination, to answer all lawful interrogatories or to 40 
produce the documents ordered, the person is subject to contemp t of the court and is 41 
 
 Page 111 - 128LR0452(01) -1 
 liable to any injured party in a civil action for all the damages, expenses and charges 1 
arising from such refusal.  2 
PART 2  3 
VENUE FOR PROBATE AN D ADMINISTRATION, PR IORITY TO 4 
ADMINISTER AND DEMAN D FOR NOTICE  5 
§3-201.  Venue for first and subsequent estate proceedings; location of property  6 
1.  Venue for first estate proceedings.  Venue for the first informal or formal testacy 7 
or appointment proceedings after a decedent's death is:  8 
A.  In the county where the decedent was domiciled at the ti me of death; or  9 
B.  If the decedent was not domiciled in this State, in any county where property of 10 
the decedent was located at the time of the decedent's death.  11 
2.  Venue for subsequent proceedings.  Venue for all subsequent proceedings 12 
within the exclus ive jurisdiction of the court is in the place where the initial proceeding 13 
occurred, unless the initial proceeding has been transferred as provided in subsection 3 or 14 
section 1 -303. 15 
3.  Transfer after informal proceeding.  If the first proceeding was infor mal, on 16 
application of an interested person and after notice to the proponent in the first 17 
proceeding, the court, upon finding that venue is elsewhere, may transfer the proceeding 18 
and the file to the other court.  19 
4.  Location of property.  For the purpose of aiding determinations concerning 20 
location of property that may be relevant in cases involving non -domiciliaries, a debt, 21 
other than one evidenced by investment or commercial paper or other instrument in favor 22 
of a non -domiciliary, is located where the d ebtor resides or, if the debtor is a person other 23 
than an individual, at the place where it has its principal office. Commercial paper, 24 
investment paper and other instruments are located where the instrument is. An interest in 25 
property held in trust is loc ated where the trustee may be sued.  26 
§3-202.  Appointment or testacy proceedings; conflicting claim of domicile in 27 
another state  28 
If conflicting claims as to the domicile of a decedent are made in a formal testacy or 29 
appointment proceeding commenced in this State, and in a testacy or appointment 30 
proceeding after notice pending at the same time in another state, the court of this State 31 
must stay, dismiss or permit suitable amendment in the proceeding in this State unless it 32 
is determined that the proceeding in  this State was commenced before the proceeding 33 
elsewhere. The determination of domicile in the proceeding first commenced must be 34 
accepted as determinative in the proceeding in this State.  35 
§3-203.  Priority among persons seeking appointment as personal re presentative  36 
1.  Priority.  Whether the proceedings are formal or informal, persons who are not 37 
disqualified have priority for appointment in the following order:  38 
 
 Page 112 - 128LR0452(01) -1 
 A.  The person with priority as determined by a probated will including a person 1 
nominated by  a power conferred in a will;  2 
B.  The surviving spouse of the decedent who is a devisee of the decedent;  3 
C.  Other devisees of the decedent;  4 
D.  The surviving spouse of the decedent;  5 
E.  The surviving domestic partner of the decedent;  6 
F.  Other heirs of th e decedent;  7 
G.  Forty -five days after the death of the decedent, any creditor; and  8 
H.  Six months after the death of the decedent if no testacy proceeding have been held 9 
or no personal representative has been appointed, the State Tax Assessor upon 10 
applicat ion by the State Tax Assessor.  11 
2.  Objection.  An objection to an appointment may be made only in formal 12 
proceedings.  In case of objection the priorities stated in subsection 1 apply except that:  13 
A.  If the estate appears to be more than adequate to meet exemptions and costs of 14 
administration but inadequate to discharge anticipated unsecured claims, the court, on 15 
petition of creditors, may appoint any qualified person; or  16 
B.  In case of objection to appointment of a person other than one whose priority is 17 
determined by will by an heir or devisee appearing to have a substantial interest in the 18 
estate, the court may appoint a person who is acceptable to heirs and devisees whose 19 
interests in the estate appear to be worth in total more than 1/2 of the probable 20 
distributable value or, in default of this accord, any suitable person.  21 
3.  Nomination and renunciation.  A person entitled to letters under subsection 1, 22 
paragraphs B to F may nominate a qualified person to act as personal representative.  Any 23 
person may renounce the person's right to nominate or to an appointment by appropriate 24 
writing filed with the court. When 2 or more persons share a priority, those of them who 25 
do not renounce must concur in nominating another to act for them or in applying for 26 
appoin tment.  27 
4.  Authority of conservators and guardians.  Conservators of the estates of 28 
protected persons or, if there is no conservator, any guardian except a guardian ad litem 29 
of a minor or incapacitated person, or an agent under a power of attorney that exp ressly 30 
grants the agent the authority to do so, may exercise the same right to nominate, to object 31 
to another's appointment or to participate in determining the preference of a majority in 32 
interest of the heirs and devisees that the protected person or war d would have if qualified 33 
for appointment.  34 
5.  Appointment without priority.  Appointment of a person who does not have 35 
priority, including priority resulting from renunciation or nomination determined pursuant 36 
to this section, may be made only in formal p roceedings.  Before appointing a person 37 
without priority, the court must determine that those persons having priority, although 38 
given notice of the proceedings, have failed to request appointment or to nominate 39 
another person for appointment and that admin istration is necessary.  40 
 
 Page 113 - 128LR0452(01) -1 
 6.  Qualifications.  A person is qualified to serve as a personal representative who:  1 
A.  Is 18 years of age or older; and  2 
B.  Has not been found unsuitable by the court in formal proceedings.  3 
7.  Priority of personal representative  appointed by domiciliary court.  A 4 
personal representative appointed by a court of the decedent's domicile has priority over 5 
all other persons except when the decedent's will nominates different persons to be 6 
personal representative in this State and in t he state of domicile. The domiciliary personal 7 
representative may nominate another, who shall have the same priority as the domiciliary 8 
personal representative.  9 
8.  Applicability.  This section governs priority for appointment of a successor 10 
personal repre sentative but does not apply to the selection of a special administrator.  11 
§3-204.  Demand for notice of order or filing concerning decedent's estate  12 
A person desiring notice of an order or filing pertaining to a decedent's estate in 13 
which the person has a financial or property interest may file a demand for notice with the 14 
court at any time after the death of the decedent, stating the name of the decedent, the 15 
nature of the demandant's interest in the estate and the demandant's address or that of the 16 
demand ant's attorney.  The register shall mail a copy of the demand to the personal 17 
representative, if one has been appointed.  After filing of a demand, an order or filing to 18 
which the demand relates may not be made or accepted without notice as prescribed in 19 
section 1 -401 to the demandant or the demandant's attorney.  The validity of an order that 20 
is issued or filing that is accepted without compliance with this requirement is not 21 
affected by the error, but the petitioner receiving the order or the person makin g the filing 22 
is liable for any damage caused by the absence of notice.  The requirement of notice 23 
arising from demand under this provision may be waived in writing by the demandant 24 
and ceases upon the termination of the demandant's interest in the estate.  25 
PART 3  26 
INFORMAL PROBATE AND  APPOINTMENT PROCEEDI NGS  27 
§3-301.  Informal probate or appointment proceedings; application; contents  28 
1.  Applications for informal probate or appointment proceedings.  Applications 29 
for informal probate or informal appointment mus t be directed to the register and be 30 
verified by the applicant to be accurate and complete to the best of the applicant's 31 
knowledge and belief as to the following information and such other information and in 32 
such form as the Supreme Judicial Court may by rule provide:  33 
A.  Every application for informal probate of a will or for informal appointment of a 34 
personal representative, other than a special or successor representative, must contain 35 
the following:  36 
(1)  A statement of the interest of the applicant;  37 
(2)  The name and date of death of the decedent, the decedent's age and the 38 
county and state of the decedent's domicile at the time of death and the names 39 
 
 Page 114 - 128LR0452(01) -1 
 and addresses of the spouse, children, heirs and devisees and the ages of any who 1 
are minors so far as known or ascertainable with reasonable diligence by the 2 
applicant;  3 
(3)  If the decedent was not domiciled in the State at the time of death, a 4 
statement showing venue;  5 
(4)  A statement identifying and indicating the address of any personal 6 
representative o f the decedent appointed in this State or elsewhere whose 7 
appointment has not been terminated;  8 
(5)  A statement indicating whether the applicant has received a demand for 9 
notice or is aware of any demand for notice of any probate or appointment 10 
proceeding concerning the decedent that may have been filed in this State or 11 
elsewhere; and  12 
(6)  A statement that the time limit for informal probate or appointment as 13 
provided in this Article has not expired either because 3 years or less have passed 14 
since the deced ent's death or, if more than 3 years from death have passed, 15 
circumstances as described by section 3 -108 have occurred authorizing tardy 16 
probate or appointment;  17 
B.  An application for informal probate of a will must state the following in addition 18 
to the s tatements required by paragraph A:  19 
(1)  That the original of the decedent's last will is in the possession of the court or 20 
accompanies the application or that an authenticated copy of a will probated in 21 
another jurisdiction accompanies the application;  22 
(2)  That the applicant, to the best of the applicant's knowledge, believes the will 23 
to have been validly executed; and  24 
(3)  That after the exercise of reasonable diligence, the applicant is unaware of 25 
any instrument revoking the will and that the applicant b elieves that the 26 
instrument that is the subject of the application is the decedent's last will;  27 
C.  An application for informal appointment of a personal representative to 28 
administer an estate under a will must describe the will by date of execution and st ate 29 
the time and place of probate or the pending application or petition for probate. The 30 
application for appointment must adopt the statements in the application or petition 31 
for probate and state the name, address and priority for appointment of the perso n 32 
whose appointment is sought;  33 
D.  An application for informal appointment of an administrator in intestacy must 34

(1)  That after the exercise of reasonable diligence the applicant is unaware of 36

§3-302.  Informal probate; duty of register; effect of informal probate  17 
Upon receipt of an application requesting informal probate of a will, the register upon 18 
making the findings  required by section 3 -303 shall issue a written statement of informal 19 
probate if at least 120 hours have elapsed since the decedent's death.  Informal probate is 20 
conclusive as to all persons until superseded by an order in a formal testacy proceeding.  21 
No defect in the application or procedure that leads to informal probate of a will renders 22 
the probate void.  23 
§3-303.  Informal probate; proof and findings required  24 
1.  Informal probate; proof and findings required.  In an informal proceeding for 25 
original pro bate of a will, the register shall determine whether:  26 
A.  The application is complete;  27 
B.  The applicant has made oath or affirmation that the statements contained in the 28 
application are true to the best of the applicant's knowledge and belief;  29 
C.  The app licant appears from the application to be an interested person as defined in 30 
section 1 -201, subsection 26;  31 
D.  On the basis of the statements in the application, venue is proper;  32 
E.  An original, duly executed and apparently unrevoked will is in the regist er's 33 
possession;  34 
F.  Any notice required by section 3 -204 has been given and the application is not 35 
required to be declined under section 3 -304; and  36 
G.  It appears from the application that the time limit for original probate has not 37 
expired.  38 
 
 Page 116 - 128LR0452(01) -1 
 2.  Denial.  The application must be denied if it indicates that a personal 1 
representative has been appointed in another county of this State or, except as provided in 2 
subsection 4, if it appears that this or another will of the decedent has been the subject of 3 
a previ ous probate order.  4 
3.  Executed will.  A will that appears to have the required signatures and that 5 
contains an attestation clause showing that requirements of execution under section 2 -502 6 
or 2-505 have been met must be probated without further proof.  In  other cases, the 7 
register may assume execution if the will appears to have been properly executed or the 8 
register may accept a sworn statement or affidavit of any person having knowledge of the 9 
circumstances of execution, whether or not the person was a w itness to the will.  10 
4.  Will previously probated elsewhere.  Informal probate of a will that has been 11 
previously probated elsewhere may be granted at any time upon written application by 12 
any interested person, together with deposit of an authenticated copy  of the will and of 13 
the statement probating it from the office of court where it was first probated.  14 
5.  Will from another jurisdiction.  A will from a place that does not require 15 
probate of a will after death and that is not eligible for probate under sub section 1 may be 16 
probated in this State upon receipt by the register of a duly authenticated copy of the will 17 
and a duly authenticated certificate of its legal custodian that the copy filed is a true copy 18 
and that the will has become operative under the la w of that place.  19 
§3-304.  Informal probate; unavailable in certain cases  20 
Applications for informal probate that relate to one or more of a known series of 21 
testamentary instruments, the latest of which does not expressly revoke the earlier, other 22 
than a wil l and one or more codicils thereto, must be declined.  23 
§3-305.  Informal probate; register not satisfied  24 
If the register is not satisfied that a will is entitled to be probated in informal 25 
proceedings because of failure to meet the requirements of sections 3-303 and 3 -304 or 26 
any other reason, the register may decline the application.  A declination of informal 27 
probate is not an adjudication and does not preclude formal probate proceedings.  28 
§3-306.  Informal probate; notice requirements  29 
The moving party shall  give notice as described by section 1 -401 of the moving 30 
party's application for informal probate to any person demanding notice pursuant to 31 
section 3 -204 and to any personal representative of the decedent whose appointment has 32 
not been terminated.  If the  decedent was 55 years of age or older, the moving party shall 33 
give notice as described in section 1 -401 to the Department of Health and Human 34 
Services.  Except as provided in section 3 -705, no other notice of informal probate is 35 
required.  36 
 
 Page 117 - 128LR0452(01) -1 
 §3-307.  Informa l appointment proceedings; delay in order; duty of register; effect 1

decedent's will directs that the decedent's estate be subject to the laws of this State.  10 
2.  Effect of appointment.  The status of personal representative and the powers and 11 
duties pertaining to the office are fully established by informal appointment.  An 12

as provided in sections 3 -608 to 3 -612 but is not subject to retroactive vacation.  14 
§3-308.  Informal appointment proceedings; proof and findings required  15

appointment proceedings, the register shall determine whether:  17 
A.  The application for informal appointment of a personal representative is 18

B.  The applicant has made oath or affirmation that the statements contained in the 20

C.  The applicant appears from the application to be an interested person as defined in 22

informally probated, but this requirement does not apply to the appointment of a 26 
special administrator;  27 
F.  Any notice required by section 3 -204 has been given; and  28 
G.  From the statements i n the application, the person whose appointment is sought 29 
has priority entitling the applicant to the appointment.  30

another county of this State; that, unless the applicant is the domiciliary personal 34

met. 38

 §3-309.  Informal appointment proceedings; regist er not satisfied  1 
If the register is not satisfied that a requested informal appointment of a personal 2 
representative should be made because of failure to meet the requirements of sections 3 
3-307 and 3 -308, or for any other reason, the register may decline t he application.  A 4 
declination of informal appointment is not an adjudication and does not preclude 5

§3-310.  Informal appointment proceedings; notice requirements  7 
The moving party shall give notice as described by section  1-401 of the moving 8
