not waived in writing and filed with the court.  If the deceden t was 55 years of age or 11 
older, the moving party shall give notice as described in section 1 -401 to the Department 12 
of Health and Human Services.  No other notice of an informal appointment proceeding 13 
is required.  14 
§3-311.  Informal appointment unavailable i n certain cases  15 
If an application for informal appointment indicates the existence of a possible 16 
unrevoked testamentary instrument that may relate to property subject to the laws of this 17 
State and that is not filed for probate in the court, the register mu st decline the 18 
application.  19 
PART 4  20 
FORMAL TESTACY AND A PPOINTMENT PROCEEDIN GS 21 
§3-401.  Formal testacy proceedings; nature; when commenced  22 
A formal testacy proceeding is litigation to determine whether a decedent left a valid 23 
will.  A formal testacy proceed ing may be commenced by an interested person filing a 24 
petition as described in section 3 -402, subsection 1 in which the petitioner requests that 25 
the court, after notice and hearing, enter an order probating a will, or a petition to set 26 
aside an informal pr obate of a will or to prevent informal probate of a will that is the 27 
subject of a pending application, or a petition in accordance with section 3 -402, 28 
subsection 2 for an order that the decedent died intestate.  29 
A petition may seek formal probate of a will without regard to whether the same or a 30 
conflicting will has been informally probated.  A formal testacy proceeding may, but 31 
need not, involve a request for appointment of a personal representative.  32 
During the pendency of a formal testacy proceeding, the r egister may not act upon 33 
any application for informal probate of any will of the decedent or any application for 34 
informal appointment of a personal representative of the decedent.  35 
Unless a petition in a formal testacy proceeding also requests confirmation of the 36 
previous informal appointment, a previously appointed personal representative, after 37 
receipt of notice of the commencement of a formal probate proceeding, must refrain from 38 
 
 Page 119 - 128LR0452(01) -1 
 making any further distribution of the estate during the pendency of the for mal 1 
proceeding.  A petitioner who seeks the appointment of a different personal 2 
representative in a formal proceeding also may request an order restraining the acting 3 
personal representative from exercising any of the powers of the office and requesting th e 4 
appointment of a special administrator.  In the absence of a request, or if the request is 5 
denied, the commencement of a formal proceeding has no effect on the powers and duties 6 
of a previously appointed personal representative other than those relating to distribution.  7 
§3-402.  Formal testacy or appointment proceedings; petition; contents  8 
1.  Petition for formal probate of a will; contents.  Petitions for formal probate of a 9 
will, or for adjudication of intestacy with or without request for appointment o f a personal 10 
representative, must be directed to the court, request a judicial order after notice and 11 
hearing, contain further statements as indicated in this section and contain such other 12 
information and be in such form as the Supreme Judicial Court may by rule provide.  A 13 
petition for formal probate of a will must:  14 
A.  Request an order as to the testacy of the decedent in relation to a particular 15 
instrument that may or may not have been informally probated and determining the 16 
heirs;  17 
B.  Contain the state ments required for informal applications as stated in section 18 
3-301, subsection 1, paragraph A, subparagraphs (1) to (4) and the statements 19 
required by section 3 -301, subsection 1, paragraph B, subparagraphs (2) and (3); and  20 
C.  State whether the original of the last will of the decedent is in the possession of 21 
the court or accompanies the petition.  22 
If the original will is neither in the possession of the court nor accompanies the petition 23 
and no authenticated copy of a will probated in another jurisdiction  accompanies the 24 
petition, the petition also must state the contents of the will and indicate that it is lost, 25 
destroyed or otherwise unavailable.  26 
2.  Relief requested.  A petition for adjudication of intestacy and appointment of an 27 
administrator in intest acy must request a judicial finding and order that the decedent left 28 
no will and determining the heirs, contain the statements required by section 3 -301, 29 
subsection 1, paragraphs A and D, indicate whether supervised administration is sought 30 
and contain suc h other information and be in such form as the Supreme Judicial Court 31 
may by rule provide.  A petition may request an order determining intestacy and heirs 32 
without requesting the appointment of an administrator, in which case the statements 33 
required by sec tion 3 -301, subsection 1, paragraph D, subparagraph (2) may be omitted.  34 
§3-403.  Formal testacy proceeding; notice of hearing on petition  35 
1.  Notice of hearing on petition for formal probate of a will.  Upon 36 
commencement of a formal testacy proceeding, the  court shall fix a time and place of 37 
hearing.  Notice must be given in the manner prescribed by section 1 -401 by the 38 
petitioner to the persons enumerated in this subsection and to any additional person who 39 
has filed a demand for notice under section 3 -204. 40 
 
 Page 120 - 128LR0452(01) -1 
 Notice must be given to the following persons: the surviving spouse, children and other 1 
heirs of the decedent, the devisees and executors named in any will that is being, or has 2 
been, probated or offered for informal or formal probate in the county or tha t is known by 3 
the petitioner to have been probated or offered for informal or formal probate elsewhere 4 
and any personal representative of the decedent whose appointment has not been 5 
terminated.  If the decedent was 55 years of age or older, the petitioner shall give notice 6 
as described in section 1 -401 to the Department of Health and Human Services.  Notice 7 
may be given to other persons.  In addition, the petitioner shall give notice by publication 8 
to all unknown persons and to all known persons whose addre sses are unknown who have 9 
any interest in the matters being litigated.  10 
2.  Additional notice when death in doubt.  If it appears by the petition or otherwise 11 
that the fact of the death of the alleged decedent may be in doubt, or on the written 12 
demand of an y interested person, a copy of the notice of the hearing on the petition must 13 
be sent by registered mail to the alleged decedent at the alleged decedent's last known 14 
address.  The court shall direct the petitioner to report the results of, or make and repo rt 15 
back concerning, a reasonably diligent search for the alleged decedent in any manner that 16 
may seem advisable, including any of the following methods:  17 
A.  By inserting in one or more suitable periodicals a notice requesting information 18 
from any person ha ving knowledge of the whereabouts of the alleged decedent;  19 
B.  By notifying law enforcement officials and public welfare agencies in appropriate 20 
locations of the disappearance of the alleged decedent; and  21 
C.  By engaging the services of an investigator.  T he costs of any search directed by 22 
the court must be paid by the petitioner if there is no administration or by the estate of 23 
the decedent if there is administration.  24 
§3-404.  Formal testacy proceedings; written objections to probate  25 
Any party to a formal proceeding who opposes the probate of a will for any reason 26 
shall state in that party's pleadings that party's objections to probate of the will.  27 
§3-405.  Formal testacy proceedings; uncontested cases; hearings and proof  28 
If a petition in a testacy proceedi ng is unopposed, the court may order probate or 29 
intestacy on the strength of the pleadings if satisfied that the conditions of section 3 -409 30 
have been met or conduct a hearing in open court and require proof of the matters 31 
necessary to support the order so ught.  If evidence concerning execution of the will is 32 
necessary, the affidavit or testimony of one of any attesting witnesses to the instrument is 33 
sufficient.  If the affidavit or testimony of an attesting witness is not available, execution 34 
of the will m ay be proved by other evidence or affidavit.  35 
§3-406.  Formal testacy proceedings; contested cases  36 
In a contested case in which the proper execution of a will is at issue:  37 
1.  Self-proved will; witness not required.  If the will is self -proved pursuant to 38 
section 2 -503, the will satisfies the requirements for execution without the testimony of 39 
any attesting witness upon the filing of the will and the acknowledgment and affidavits 40 
 
 Page 121 - 128LR0452(01) -1 
 annexed or attached to it, unless there is evidence of fraud or forgery affecti ng the 1 
acknowledgment or affidavit; or  2 
2.  Will not notarized; attesting witness required.  If the will is witnessed pursuant 3 
to section 2 -502, subsection 1, paragraph C but not notarized or self -proved, the 4 
testimony of at least one of the attesting witne sses is required to establish proper 5 
execution if the witness is within this State, competent and able to testify.  Proper 6 
execution may be established by other evidence, including an affidavit of an attesting 7 
witness.  An attestation clause that is signed  by the attesting witnesses raises a rebuttable 8 
presumption that the events recited in the clause occurred.  9 
§3-407.  Formal testacy proceedings; burdens in contested cases  10 
In contested cases, petitioners who seek to establish intestacy have the burden of 11 
establishing prima facie proof of death, venue and heirship.  Proponents of a will have the 12 
burden of establishing prima facie proof of due execution in all cases and, if they are also 13 
petitioners, prima facie proof of death and venue.  Contestants of a wil l have the burden 14 
of establishing lack of testamentary intent or capacity, undue influence, fraud, duress, 15 
mistake or revocation.  Parties have the ultimate burden of persuasion as to matters with 16 
respect to which they have the initial burden of proof.  If  a will is opposed by the petition 17 
for probate of a later will revoking the former, it must be determined first whether the 18 
later will is entitled to probate, and if a will is opposed by a petition for a declaration of 19 
intestacy, it must be determined firs t whether the will is entitled to probate.  20 
§3-408.  Formal testacy proceedings; will construction; effect of final order in 21 
another jurisdiction  22 
A final order of a court of another state determining testacy or the validity or 23 
construction of a will made in  a proceeding involving notice to and an opportunity for 24 
contest by all interested persons must be accepted as determinative by the courts of this 25 
State if it includes or is based upon a finding that the decedent at death was domiciled in 26 
the state where t he order was made.  27 
§3-409.  Formal testacy proceedings; order; foreign will  28 
After the time required for any notice has expired, upon proof of notice, and after any 29 
hearing that may be necessary, if the court finds that the testator is dead, venue is proper  30 
and that the proceeding was commenced within the limitation prescribed by section 31 
3-108, the court shall determine the decedent's domicile at death, heirs and state of 32 
testacy.  Any will found to be valid and unrevoked must be formally probated.  33 
Terminat ion of any previous informal appointment of a personal representative, which 34 
may be appropriate in view of the relief requested and findings, is governed by section 35 
3-612.  The petition must be dismissed or appropriate amendment allowed if the court is 36 
not satisfied that the alleged decedent is dead.  A will from a foreign jurisdiction, 37 
including a place that does not provide for probate of a will after death, may be proved 38 
for probate in this State by a duly authenticated certificate of its legal custodian  that the 39 
copy introduced is a true copy and that the will has become effective under the law of the 40 
other place.  41 
 
 Page 122 - 128LR0452(01) -1 
 §3-410.  Formal testacy proceedings; probate of more than one instrument  1 
If 2 or more instruments are offered for probate before a final order  is entered in a 2 
formal testacy proceeding, more than one instrument may be probated if neither expressly 3 
revokes the other or contains provisions that work a total revocation by implication.  If 4 
more than one instrument is probated, the order must indicat e what provisions control in 5 
respect to the nomination of an executor, if any.  The order may, but need not, indicate 6 
how any provisions of a particular instrument are affected by the other instrument.  After 7 
a final order in a testacy proceeding has been entered, no petition for probate of any other 8 
instrument of the decedent may be entertained, except incident to a petition to vacate or 9 
modify a previous probate order and subject to the time limits of section 3 -412. 10 
§3-411.  Formal testacy proceedings; pa rtial intestacy  11 
If it becomes evident in the course of a formal testacy proceeding that, though one or 12 
more instruments are entitled to be probated, the decedent's estate is or may be partially 13 
intestate, the court shall enter an order to that effect.  14 
§3-412.  Formal testacy proceedings; effect of order; vacation  15 
Subject to appeal and subject to vacation as provided in this section and in section 16 
3-413, a formal testacy order under sections 3 -409 to 3 -411, including an order that the 17 
decedent left no valid will and determining heirs, is final as to all persons with respect to 18 
all issues concerning the decedent's estate that the court considered or might have 19 
considered incident to its rendition relevant to the question of whether the decedent left a 20 
valid wi ll and to the determination of heirs, except that:  21 
1.  Petition to modify or vacate formal testacy order.  The court shall entertain a 22 
petition for modification or vacation of its order and probate of another will of the 23 
decedent if it is shown that the pr oponents of the later -offered will:  24 
A.  Were unaware of its existence at the time of the earlier proceeding; or  25 
B.  Were unaware of the earlier proceeding and were given no notice thereof, except 26 
by publication;  27 
2.  Reconsideration of order determining hei rs.  If intestacy of all or part of the 28 
estate has been ordered, the determination of heirs of the decedent may be reconsidered if 29 
it is shown that one or more persons were omitted from the determination and it is also 30 
shown that the persons were unaware o f their relationship to the decedent, were unaware 31 
of the decedent's death or were given no notice of any proceeding concerning the 32 
decedent's estate, except by publication;  33 
3.  Time limits.  A petition for vacation under either subsection 1 or 2 must be f iled 34 
prior to the earlier of the following time limits:  35 
A.  If a personal representative has been appointed for the estate, the time of entry of 36 
any order approving final distribution of the estate or, if the estate is closed by 37 
statement, 6 months after the filing of the closing statement;  38 
 
 Page 123 - 128LR0452(01) -1 
 B.  Whether or not a personal representative has been appointed for the estate of the 1 
decedent, the time prescribed by section 3 -108 when it is no longer possible to initiate 2 
an original proceeding to probate a will of the decedent; or  3 
C.  Twelve months after the entry of the order sought to be vacated;  4 
4.  Modification or vacation order.  The order originally rendered in the testacy 5 
proceeding may be modified or vacated, if appropriate under the circumstances, by the 6 
order of probate of the later -offered will or the order redetermining heirs; and  7 
5.  Effect of finding of fact of death.  The finding of the fact of death is conclusive 8 
as to the alleged decedent only if notice of the hearing on the petition in the formal 9 
testacy proceeding was sent by registered or certified mail addressed to the alleged 10 
decedent at the decedent's last known address and the court finds that a search under 11 
section 3 -403, subsection 2 was made.  12 
If the alleged decedent is not dead, even if noti ce was sent and search was made, the 13 
alleged decedent may recover estate assets in the hands of the personal representative.  In 14 
addition to any remedies available to the alleged decedent by reason of any fraud or 15 
intentional wrongdoing, the alleged decede nt may recover any estate or its proceeds from 16 
distributees that is in their hands, or the value of distributions received by them, to the 17 
extent that any recovery from distributees is equitable in view of all of the circumstances.  18 
§3-413.  Formal testacy proceedings; vacation of order for other cause  19 
For good cause shown, an order in a formal testacy proceeding may be modified or 20 
vacated within the time allowed for appeal.  21 
§3-414.  Formal proceedings concerning appointment of personal representative  22 
1.  Formal proceeding for appointment of personal representative.  A formal 23 
proceeding for adjudication regarding the priority or qualification of a person who is an 24 
applicant for appointment as personal representative, or of a person who previously has 25 
been app ointed personal representative in informal proceedings, if an issue concerning 26 
the testacy of the decedent is or may be involved, is governed by section 3 -402 as well as 27 
by this section.  In other cases, the petition must contain or adopt the statements re quired 28 
by section 3 -301, subsection 1, paragraph A and describe the question relating to priority 29 
or qualification of the personal representative that is to be resolved.  If the proceeding 30 
precedes any appointment of a personal representative, it shall sta y any pending informal 31 
appointment proceedings as well as any commenced thereafter.  If the proceeding is 32 
commenced after appointment, the previously appointed personal representative, after 33 
receipt of notice, shall refrain from exercising any power of adm inistration except as 34 
necessary to preserve the estate or unless the court orders otherwise.  35 
2.  Notice and decision.  After notice to interested persons, including all persons 36 
interested in the administration of the estate as successors under the applicab le 37 
assumption concerning testacy, any previously appointed personal representative and any 38 
person having or claiming priority for appointment as personal representative, the court 39 
shall determine who is entitled to appointment under section 3 -203, make a p roper 40 
 
 Page 124 - 128LR0452(01) -1 
 appointment and, if appropriate, terminate any prior appointment found to have been 1 
improper as provided in cases of removal under section 3 -611. 2 
PART 5  3 
SUPERVISED ADMINISTR ATION  4 
§3-501.  Supervised administration; nature of proceeding  5 
Supervised adm inistration is a single in rem proceeding to secure complete 6 
administration and settlement of a decedent's estate under the continuing authority of the 7 
court that extends until entry of an order approving distribution of the estate and 8 
discharging the pers onal representative or other order terminating the proceeding.  A 9 
supervised personal representative is responsible to the court, as well as to the interested 10 
parties, and is subject to directions concerning the estate made by the court on its own 11 
motion o r on the motion of any interested party.  Except as otherwise provided in this 12 
Part, or as otherwise ordered by the court, a supervised personal representative has the 13 
same duties and powers as a personal representative who is not supervised.  14 
§3-502.  Supe rvised administration; petition; order  15 
A petition for supervised administration may be filed by any interested person or by a 16 
personal representative at any time or the prayer for supervised administration may be 17 
joined with a petition in a testacy or appo intment proceeding.  If the testacy of the 18 
decedent and the priority and qualification of any personal representative have not been 19 
adjudicated previously, the petition for supervised administration must include the 20 
matters required of a petition in a form al testacy proceeding and the notice requirements 21 
and procedures applicable to a formal testacy proceeding apply.  If not previously 22 
adjudicated, the court shall adjudicate the testacy of the decedent and questions relating to 23 
the priority and qualificatio ns of the personal representative in any case involving a 24 
request for supervised administration, even though the request for supervised 25 
administration may be denied.  After notice to interested persons:  26 
1.  Will directing supervised administration.  If the  decedent's will directs 27 
supervised administration, the court must order supervised administration of the 28 
decedent's estate unless the court finds that circumstances bearing on the need for 29 
supervised administration have changed since the execution of the will and that there is 30 
no necessity for supervised administration;  31 
2.  Will directing unsupervised administration.  If the decedent's will directs 32 
unsupervised administration, the court may order supervised administration of the 33 
decedent's estate only upon  a finding that it is necessary for protection of persons 34 
interested in the estate; or  35 
3.  Other cases.  In other cases when the court finds that supervised administration is 36 
necessary under the circumstances, the court must order supervised administration  of the 37 
decedent's estate.  38 
 
 Page 125 - 128LR0452(01) -1 
 §3-503.  Supervised administration; effect on other proceedings  1 
1.  Effect on application for informal proceedings.  The pendency of a proceeding 2 
for supervised administration of a decedent's estate stays action on any informal 3 
application then pending or thereafter filed.  4 
2.  Effect on will probated in informal proceedings.  If a will has been previously 5 
probated in informal proceedings, the effect of the filing of a petition for supervised 6 
administration is as provided for forma l testacy proceedings by section 3 -401. 7 
3.  Effect on personal representative.  After receiving notice of the filing of a 8 
petition for supervised administration, a personal representative who has been appointed 9 
previously may not exercise the power to dist ribute any estate.  The filing of the petition 10 
does not affect the personal representative's other powers and duties unless the court 11 
restricts the exercise of any of them pending full hearing on the petition.  12 
§3-504.  Supervised administration; powers of personal representative  13 
Unless restricted by the court, a supervised personal representative has, without 14 
interim orders approving exercise of a power, all powers of personal representatives 15 
under this Code, but the personal representative may not exercise  the power to make any 16 
distribution of the estate without prior order of the court.  Any other restriction on the 17 
power of a personal representative that is ordered by the court must be endorsed on the 18 
personal representative's letters of appointment and, unless so endorsed, is ineffective as 19 
to persons dealing in good faith with the personal representative.  20 
§3-505.  Supervised administration; interim orders; distribution and closing orders  21 
Unless otherwise ordered by the court, supervised administration is  terminated by 22 
order in accordance with time restrictions, notices and contents of orders prescribed for 23 
proceedings under section 3 -1001.  Interim orders approving or directing partial 24 
distributions or granting other relief may be issued by the court at a ny time during the 25 
pendency of a supervised administration on the application of the personal representative 26 
or any interested person.  27 
PART 6  28 
PERSONAL REPRESENTAT IVE: APPOINTMENT, CO NTROL AND 29 
TERMINATION OF AUTHO RITY  30 
§3-601.  Qualification  31 
Prior to receivi ng letters, a personal representative must qualify by filing with the 32 
appointing court any required bond and a statement of acceptance of the duties of the 33 
office.  34 
§3-602.  Acceptance of appointment; consent to jurisdiction  35 
By accepting appointment, a pers onal representative submits personally to the 36 
jurisdiction of the court in any proceeding relating to the estate that may be instituted by 37 
 
 Page 126 - 128LR0452(01) -1 
 any interested person.  Notice of any proceeding must be delivered to the personal 1 
representative, or mailed to the p ersonal representative by ordinary first class mail at the 2 
address listed in the application or petition for appointment or as thereafter reported to the 3 
court and to the personal representative's address as then known to the petitioner.  4 
§3-603.  Bond not required without court order; exceptions  5 
Bond is not required of a personal representative appointed in informal proceedings, 6 
except upon the appointment of a special administrator, when an executor or other 7 
personal representative is appointed to administ er an estate under a will containing an 8 
express requirement of bond or when bond is required under section 3 -605.  Bond may be 9 
required by court order at the time of appointment of a personal representative appointed 10 
in any formal proceeding except that bo nd is not required of a personal representative 11 
appointed in formal proceedings if the will relieves the personal representative of bond, 12 
unless bond has been requested by an interested party and the court is satisfied that it is 13 
desirable, or as provided in section 3 -619, subsection 7.  Bond required by any will or 14 
under this section may be dispensed with in formal proceedings upon determination by 15 
the court that it is not necessary.  Bond is not required of any personal representative 16 
who, pursuant to sta tute, has deposited cash or collateral with an agency of this State to 17 
secure performance of the personal representative's duties.  18 
§3-604.  Bond amount; security; procedure; reduction  19 
If bond is required and the provisions of the will or order do not speci fy the amount, 20 
unless stated in the application or petition, the person qualifying shall file a statement 21 
under oath with the register indicating that person's best estimate of the value of the 22 
personal estate of the decedent and of the income expected fro m the personal and real 23 
estate during the next year, and that person shall execute and file a bond with the register, 24 
or give other suitable security, in an amount not less than the estimate.  The register shall 25 
determine that the bond is duly executed by a corporate surety, or one or more individual 26 
sureties whose performance is secured by pledge of personal property, mortgage on real 27 
property or other adequate security.  The register may permit the amount of the bond to 28 
be reduced by the value of assets o f the estate deposited with a domestic financial 29 
institution, as defined in section 6 -101, in a manner that prevents their unauthorized 30 
disposition.  On petition of the personal representative or another interested person the 31 
court may excuse a requirement  of bond, increase or reduce the amount of the bond, 32 
release sureties or permit the substitution of another bond with the same or different 33 
sureties.  34 
§3-605.  Demand for bond by interested person  35 
Any person apparently having an interest in the estate worth  in excess of $5,000, or 36 
any creditor having a claim in excess of $5,000, may make a written demand that a 37 
personal representative give bond.  The demand must be filed with the register and a copy 38 
mailed to the personal representative, if appointment and q ualification have occurred.  39 
Thereupon, bond is required, but the requirement ceases if the person demanding bond 40 
ceases to be interested in the estate or if bond is excused as provided in section 3 -603 or 41 
3-604.  After the personal representative has rece ived notice and until the filing of the 42 
bond or cessation of the requirement of bond, the personal representative shall refrain 43 
 
 Page 127 - 128LR0452(01) -1 
 from exercising any powers of the personal representative's office except as necessary to 1 
preserve the estate.  Failure of the p ersonal representative to meet a requirement of bond 2 
by giving suitable bond within 30 days after receipt of notice is cause for the personal 3 
representative's removal and appointment of a successor personal representative.  4 
§3-606.  Terms and conditions of bonds  5 
1.  Required terms and conditions.  The following requirements and provisions 6 
apply to any bond required by this Part.  7 
A.  Bonds must name the State of Maine as obligee for the benefit of the persons 8 
interested in the estate and must be conditioned u pon the faithful discharge by the 9 
fiduciary of all duties according to law.  10 
B.  Unless otherwise provided by the terms of the approved bond, sureties are jointly 11 
and severally liable with the personal representative and with each other.  The 12 
address of sur eties must be stated in the bond.  13 
C.  By executing an approved bond of a personal representative, the surety consents 14 
to the jurisdiction of the court that issued letters to the primary obligor in any 15 
proceedings pertaining to the fiduciary duties of the p ersonal representative and 16 
naming the surety as a party.  Notice of any proceeding must be delivered to the 17 
surety or mailed to the surety by registered or certified mail at the surety's address as 18 
listed with the court where the bond is filed and to the s urety's address as then known 19 
to the petitioner.  20 
D.  On petition of a successor personal representative, any other personal 21 
representative of the same decedent or any interested person, a proceeding in the 22 
court may be initiated against a surety for breach  of the obligation of the bond of the 23 
personal representative.  24 
E.  The bond of the personal representative is not void after the first recovery but may 25 
be proceeded against from time to time until the whole penalty is exhausted.  26 
2.  Limitation on action ag ainst surety.  An action or proceeding may not be 27 
commenced against the surety on any matter as to which an action or proceeding against 28 
the primary obligor is barred by adjudication or limitation.  29 
§3-607.  Order restraining personal representative  30 
On peti tion of any person who appears to have an interest in the estate, the court by 31 
temporary order may restrain a personal representative from performing specified acts of 32 
administration, disbursement or distribution, or exercise of any powers or discharge of 33 
any duties of the personal representative's office, or make any other order to secure 34 
proper performance of the personal representative's duty, if it appears to the court that the 35 
personal representative otherwise may take some action that would jeopardize  36 
unreasonably the interest of the applicant or of some other interested person.  Persons 37 
with whom the personal representative may transact business may be made parties.  38 
 
 Page 128 - 128LR0452(01) -1 
 §3-608.  Termination of appointment; general  1 
Termination of appointment of a personal representative occurs as indicated in 2 
sections 3 -609 to 3 -612.  Termination ends the right and power pertaining to the office of 3 
personal representative as conferred by this Code or any will, except that a personal 4 
representative, at any time prior to dist ribution or until restrained or enjoined by court 5 
order, may perform acts necessary to protect the estate and may deliver the assets to a 6 
successor representative.  Termination does not discharge a personal representative from 7 
liability for transactions or  omissions occurring before termination, or relieve the personal 8 
representative of the duty to preserve assets subject to the personal representative's 9 
control and to account for and to deliver the assets.  Termination does not affect the 10 
jurisdiction of t he court over the personal representative, but terminates the personal 11 
representative's authority to represent the estate in any pending or future proceeding.  12 
§3-609.  Termination of appointment; death or disability  13 
The death of a personal representative o r the appointment of a conservator for the 14 
estate of a personal representative terminates the personal representative's appointment.  15 
Until appointment and qualification of a successor or special personal representative to 16 
replace the deceased or protected  personal representative, the personal representative of 17 
the estate of the deceased or protected personal representative, if any, has the duty to 18 
protect the estate possessed and being administered by the personal representative's 19 
decedent or ward at the t ime the personal representative's appointment terminates, has the 20 
power to perform acts necessary for protection and shall account for and deliver the estate 21 
assets to a successor or special personal representative upon the successor personal 22 
representativ e's appointment and qualification.  23 
§3-610.  Termination of appointment; voluntary  24 
1.  One year after closing of estate by sworn statement.  An appointment of a 25 
personal representative terminates as provided in section 3 -1003, one year after the filing 26 
of a closing statement.  27 
2.  Upon court order closing an estate.  An order closing an estate as provided in 28 
section 3 -1001 or 3 -1002 terminates an appointment of a personal representative.  29 
3.  Resignation; effect.  A personal representative may resign by filing  a written 30 
statement of resignation with the register after the personal representative has given at 31 
least 15 days' written notice to the persons known to be interested in the estate.  If no one 32 
applies or petitions for appointment of a successor represent ative within the time 33 
indicated in the notice, the filed statement of resignation is ineffective as a termination of 34 
appointment and in any event is effective only upon the appointment and qualification of 35 
a successor representative and delivery of the ass ets to the successor representative.  36 
§3-611.  Termination of appointment by removal; cause; procedure  37 
1.  Petition for removal of personal representative.  A person interested in the 38 
estate may petition for removal of a personal representative for cause at  any time.  Upon 39 
filing of the petition, the court shall fix a time and place for hearing.  Notice must be 40 
 
 Page 129 - 128LR0452(01) -1 
 given by the petitioner to the personal representative and to other persons as the court 1 
may order.  Except as otherwise ordered as provided in secti on 3 -607, after receipt of 2 
notice of removal proceedings, the personal representative may not act except to account, 3 
to correct maladministration or to preserve the estate.  If removal is ordered, the court 4 
also shall direct by order the disposition of the  assets remaining in the name of, or under 5 
the control of, the personal representative being removed.  6 
2.  Grounds for removal.  Cause for removal exists when removal would be in the 7 
best interests of the estate or if it is shown that a personal representat ive or the person 8 
seeking the personal representative's appointment intentionally misrepresented material 9 
facts in the proceedings leading to the appointment or that the personal representative has 10 
disregarded an order of the court, has become incapable of  discharging the duties of the 11 
office, has mismanaged the estate or has failed to perform any duty pertaining to the 12 
office.  Unless the decedent's will directs otherwise, a personal representative appointed 13 
at the decedent's domicile, incident to securing  appointment as ancillary personal 14 
representative or the appointment of a nominee as ancillary personal representative, may 15 
obtain removal of another who was appointed personal representative in this State to 16 
administer local assets.  17 
§3-612.  Termination o f appointment; change of testacy status  18 
Except as otherwise ordered in formal proceedings, the probate of a will subsequent 19 
to the appointment of a personal representative in intestacy or under a will that is 20 
superseded by formal probate of another will, o r the vacation of an informal probate of a 21 
will subsequent to the appointment of the personal representative under the will, does not 22 
terminate the appointment of the personal representative although the personal 23 
representative's powers may be reduced as p rovided in section 3 -401.  Termination occurs 24 
upon appointment in informal or formal appointment proceedings of a person entitled to 25 
appointment under the later assumption concerning testacy.  If no request for new 26 
appointment is made within 30 days after expiration of time for appeal from the order in 27 
formal testacy proceedings, or from the informal probate, changing the assumption 28 
concerning testacy, the previously appointed personal representative upon request may be 29 
appointed personal representative und er the subsequently probated will, or as in intestacy 30 
as the case may be.  31 
§3-613.  Successor personal representative  32 
Parts 3 and 4 of this Article govern proceedings for appointment of a personal 33 
representative to succeed a personal representative whose ap pointment has been 34 
terminated.  After appointment and qualification, a successor personal representative may 35 
be substituted in all actions and proceedings to which the former personal representative 36 
was a party, and no notice, process or claim that was giv en or served upon the former 37 
personal representative need be given to or served upon the successor in order to preserve 38 
any position or right the person giving the notice or filing the claim may thereby have 39 
obtained or preserved with reference to the form er personal representative.  Except as 40 
otherwise ordered by the court, the successor personal representative has the powers and 41 
duties in respect to the continued administration that the former personal representative 42 
would have had if the appointment had not been terminated.  43 
 
 Page 130 - 128LR0452(01) -1 
 §3-614.  Special administrator; appointment  1 
A special administrator may be appointed:  2 
1.  Informal proceedings.  Informally by the register on the application of any 3 
interested person when necessary to protect the estate of a decedent prior to the 4 
appointment of a general personal representative or if a prior appointment has been 5 
terminated as provided in section 3 -609; and  6 
2.  Formal proceedings.  In a formal proceeding by order of the court on the petition 7 
of any interested person and  finding, after notice and hearing, that appointment is 8 
necessary to preserve the estate or to secure its proper administration including its 9 
administration in circumstances where a general personal representative cannot or should 10 
not act.  If it appears t o the court that an emergency exists, appointment may be ordered 11 
without notice.  12 
§3-615.  Special administrator; who may be appointed  13 
1.  Named executor, if available.  If a special administrator is to be appointed 14 
pending the probate of a will that is the  subject of a pending application or petition for 15 
probate, the person named executor in the will must be appointed if available and 16 
qualified.  17 
2.  Any proper person.  In cases other than those set out in subsection 1, any proper 18 
person may be appointed spe cial administrator.  19 
§3-616.  Special administrator; appointed informally; powers and duties  20 
A special administrator appointed by the register in informal proceedings pursuant to 21 
section 3 -614, subsection 1 has the duty to collect and manage the assets of t he estate, to 22 
preserve them, to account for them and to deliver them to the general personal 23 
representative upon the general personal representative's qualification.  The special 24 
administrator has the power of a personal representative under the Code neces sary to 25 
perform the special administrator's duties.  26 
§3-617.  Special administrator; formal proceedings; power and duties  27 
A special administrator appointed by order of the court in any formal proceeding has 28 
the power of a general personal representative exc ept as limited in the appointment and 29 
duties as prescribed in the order.  The appointment may be for a specified time, to 30 
perform particular acts or on other terms as the court may direct.  31 
§3-618.  Termination of appointment; special administrator  32 
The appo intment of a special administrator terminates in accordance with the 33 
provisions of the order of appointment or on the appointment of a general personal 34 
representative.  In other cases, the appointment of a special administrator is subject to 35 
termination as  provided in sections 3 -608 to 3 -611. 36 
 
 Page 131 - 128LR0452(01) -1 
 §3-619.  Public administrators  1 
1.  Public administrators; appointment; powers and duties.  The Governor shall 2 
appoint in each county for a term of 4 years, unless sooner removed, a public 3 
administrator who shall, upon petition to the court and after notice and hearing, be 4 
appointed to administer the estates of persons who die intestate within the county, or who 5 
die intestate elsewhere leaving property within the county, and who are not known to 6 
have within the state any  heirs who can lawfully inherit the estate, and for whom no other 7 
administration has been commenced.  The public administrator has the same powers and 8 
duties of a personal representative under supervised administration as provided in section 9 
3-504 and, exc ept as provided in subsection 7, shall give bond as provided for other 10 
personal representatives in cases of ordinary administration under sections 3 -603 to 11 
3-606.  If any person entitled to appointment as personal representative under section 12 
3-203, prior to the appointment of the public administrator, files a petition for informal or 13 
formal appointment as personal representative, the court shall withhold any appointment 14 
of the public administrator pending denial of the petition for the appointment of the 15 
private personal representative.  16 
2.  Compensation.  The public administrator may be allowed fees and compensation 17 
for the public administrator's services as in the case of ordinary administration as 18 
provided in sections 3 -719 to 3 -721, except that no fee fo r the public administrator's own 19 
services may be paid without prior approval by the court.  20 
3.  Authority pending appointment.  Pending the appointment of the public 21 
administrator, and in the absence of any local administration or any administration by a 22 
domiciliary foreign personal representative under sections 4 -204 and 4 -205, the public 23 
administrator may proceed to conserve the property of the estate when it appears 24 
necessary or expedient.  25 
4.  Termination.  If before the estate of a decedent in the hands of the public 26 
administrator is fully settled any last will and testament of the decedent is granted 27 
informal or formal probate, or if any person entitled under section 3 -203 to appointment 28 
as personal representative is informally or formally appointed, the  appointment of the 29 
public administrator is terminated as provided in section 3 -608, and the public 30 
administrator shall account for and deliver the assets of the estate to the private personal 31 
representative or to the successors under the will as provided by law if no private 32 
personal representative has been appointed.  33 
5.  Decedent's assets disposed of as unclaimed property.  When there are assets 34 
other than real property remaining in the hands of the public administrator after the 35 
payment of the decedent's  debts and all costs of administration and no heirs have been 36 
discovered, the public administrator must be ordered by the court to deposit the assets 37 
with the Treasurer of State, who shall receive the assets and dispose of them according to 38 
Title 33, chapt er 41.  These assets must, for the purposes of Title 33, chapter 41, be 39 
presumed unclaimed when the court orders the public administrator to deposit them with 40 
the Treasurer of State.  41 
6.  Notice to treasurer; annual audit.  In all cases where a public admin istrator is 42 
appointed, the register shall immediately send to the Treasurer of State a copy of the 43 
 
 Page 132 - 128LR0452(01) -1 
 petition and the decree, and in all cases in which the public administrator is ordered to 1 
pay the balance of the estate as provided in subsection 5 the court  shall give notice to the 2 
county treasurer of the amount and from what estate it is receivable.  If the public 3 
administrator neglects for 3 months after the order of the court to deposit the money, the 4 
county treasurer shall petition the court for enforcem ent of the order or bring a civil 5 
action upon any bond of the public administrator for the recovery of the money.  The 6 
records and accounts of the public administrator must be audited annually by the Office 7 
of the State Auditor.  8 
7.  Exemption from notice a nd bond requirements.  Estates administered under 9 
this section having a value at the decedent's death not exceeding $5,000 are exempt from 10 
all notice and filing costs and from giving bond.  The cost of notice must be paid by the 11 
court.  12 
PART 7  13 
DUTIES AND PO WERS OF PERSONAL REP RESENTATIVES  14 
§3-701.  Time of accrual of duties and powers  15 
The duties and powers of a personal representative commence upon appointment.  16 
The powers of a personal representative relate back in time to give acts by the person 17 
appointed t hat are beneficial to the estate occurring prior to appointment the same effect 18 
as those occurring after appointment.  Subject to the priorities of Title 22, section 19 
2843 -A, prior to appointment, a person named executor in a will may carry out written 20 
instructions of the decedent relating to the decedent's body, funeral and burial 21 
arrangements.  A personal representative may ratify and accept acts on behalf of the 22 
estate done by others where the acts would have been proper for a personal 23 
representative.  24 
§3-702.  Priority among different letters  25 
A person to whom general letters are first issued has exclusive authority under the 26 
letters until that person's appointment is terminated or modified.  If through error general 27 
letters are later issued to another, the  first appointed representative may recover any 28 
property of the estate in the hands of the representative subsequently appointed, but the 29 
acts of the latter done in good faith before notice of the first letters are not void for want 30 
of validity of appointm ent. 31 
§3-703.  General duties; relation and liability to persons interested in estate; 32 
standing to sue  33 
1.  General duties.  A personal representative is a fiduciary who shall observe the 34 
standards of care applicable to trustees.  A personal representative i s under a duty to settle 35 
and distribute the estate of the decedent in accordance with the terms of any probated and 36 
effective will and this Code, and as expeditiously and efficiently as is consistent with the 37 
best interests of the estate.  The personal rep resentative shall use the authority conferred 38 
upon the personal representative by this Code, the terms of the will, if any, and any order 39 
in proceedings to which the personal representative is party for the best interests of 40 
 
 Page 133 - 128LR0452(01) -1 
 successors to the estate.  A pe rsonal representative is a fiduciary who shall observe the 1 
standards of care applicable to trustees as described in Title 18 -B, sections 802, 803, 805, 2 
806 and 807 and Title 18 -B, chapter 9, except as follows.  3 
A.  A personal representative, in developing a n investment strategy, shall take into 4 
account the expected duration of the period reasonably required to effect distribution 5 
of the estate's assets.  6 
B.  Except as provided in section 3 -906, subsection 1, paragraphs A and B, a personal 7 
representative may m ake distribution of an estate's assets in cash or in kind, in 8 
accordance with the devisees' best interests, and is not required either to liquidate the 9 
estate's assets or to preserve them for distribution.  10 
C.  If all devisees whose devises are to be funded  from the residue of an estate agree, 11 
in a written instrument signed by each of them and presented to the personal 12 
representative, on an investment manager to direct the investment of the estate's 13 
residuary assets, the personal representative may, but need  not, rely on the investment 14 
advice of the investment manager so identified or delegate the investment 15 
management of the estate's residuary assets to the investment manager and, in either 16 
case, may pay reasonable compensation to the investment manager from  the residue 17 
of the estate.  A personal representative who relies on the advice of, or delegates 18 
management discretion to, an investment manager in accordance with the terms of 19 
this section is not liable for the investment performance of the assets investe d in the 20 
discretion of, or in accordance with the advice of, the investment manager.  21 
2.  Authority.  A personal representative may not be surcharged for acts of 22 
administration or distribution if the conduct in question was authorized at the time.  23 
Subject to other obligations of administration, an informally probated will is authority to 24 
administer and distribute the estate according to its terms.  An order of appointment of a 25 
personal representative, whether issued in informal or formal proceedings, is aut hority to 26 
distribute apparently intestate assets to the heirs of the decedent if, at the time of 27 
distribution, the personal representative is not aware of a pending testacy proceeding, a 28 
proceeding to vacate an order entered in an earlier testacy proceedin g, a formal 29 
proceeding questioning the personal representative's appointment or fitness to continue or 30 
a supervised administration proceeding.  This section does not affect the duty of the 31 
personal representative to administer and distribute the estate in accordance with the 32 
rights of claimants whose claims have been allowed, the surviving spouse, any minor and 33 
dependent children and any pretermitted child of the decedent as described elsewhere in 34 
this Code.  35 
3.  Standing to sue.  Except as to proceedings th at do not survive the death of the 36 
decedent, a personal representative of a decedent domiciled in this State at the decedent's 37 
death has the same standing to sue and be sued in the courts of this State and the courts of 38 
any other jurisdiction as the decede nt had immediately prior to death.  39 
§3-704.  Personal representative to proceed without court order; exception  40 
A personal representative shall proceed expeditiously with the settlement and 41 
distribution of a decedent's estate and, except as otherwise specifi ed or ordered in regard 42 
to a supervised personal representative, do so without adjudication, order or direction of 43 
 
 Page 134 - 128LR0452(01) -1 
 the court, but the personal representative may invoke the jurisdiction of the court in 1 
proceedings authorized by this Code to resolve questio ns concerning the estate or its 2 
administration.  3 
§3-705.  Duty of personal representative; information to heirs and devisees  4 
Not later than 30 days after appointment every personal representative, except any 5 
special administrator, shall give information of the appointment to the heirs and devisees, 6 
including, if there has been no formal testacy proceeding and if the personal 7 
representative was appointed on the assumption that the decedent died intestate, the 8 
devisees in any will mentioned in the application for appointment of a personal 9 
representative.  The information must be delivered or sent by ordinary mail to each of the 10 
heirs and devisees whose address is reasonably available to the personal representative.  11 
The duty does not extend to require informati on to persons who have been adjudicated in 12 
a prior formal testacy proceeding to have no interest in the estate.  The information must 13 
include a statement that the estate is being administered by the personal representative 14 
under the Code without supervisio n by the court but that recipients are entitled to 15 
information regarding the administration from the personal representative and may 16 
petition the court in any matter relating to the estate, including distribution of assets and 17 
expenses of administration.  The information must include the name and address of the 18 
personal representative, indicate that it is being sent to persons who have or may have 19 
some interest in the estate being administered, indicate whether bond has been filed and 20 
describe the court whe re papers relating to the estate are on file.  The personal 21 
representative's failure to give this information is a breach of duty to the persons 22 
concerned but does not affect the validity of the personal representative's appointment, 23 
powers or other duties .  A personal representative may inform other persons of the 24 
personal representative's appointment by delivery or ordinary first class mail.  25 
§3-706.  Duty of personal representative; inventory and appraisal  26 
1.  Duty to file or mail inventory.  Within 3 mon ths after appointment, a personal 27 
representative who is not a special administrator or a successor to another personal 28 
representative who has previously discharged this duty shall prepare and file with the 29 
court or mail to all interested persons an invento ry of property owned by the decedent at 30 
the time of death, listing it with reasonable detail and indicating as to each listed item its 31 
fair market value as of the date of the decedent's death and the type and amount of any 32 
encumbrance that may exist with r eference to any item.  The inventory must also include 33 
a schedule of credits of the decedent, with the names of the obligors, the amounts due, a 34 
description of the nature of the obligation and the amount of all such credits, exclusive of 35 
expenses and risk of settlement or collection.  36 
2.  Inventory furnished on request.  If the personal representative filed the 37 
inventory with the court pursuant to subsection 1, the personal representative shall furnish 38 
the inventory to interested persons who request it.  If the personal representative mailed 39 
the inventory to all interested persons who requested it pursuant to subsection 1, the 40 
personal representative may also file the inventory with the court.  41 
3.  Failure to file, mail or furnish inventory; missing property.  When an 42 
inventory has not been filed, mailed or furnished as required under subsection 1 or 2 and 43 
 
 Page 135 - 128LR0452(01) -1 
 an interested party makes a prima facie case that property that should have been 1 
inventoried is now missing, the personal representative has the burden of pr oving by a 2 
preponderance of the evidence that the specific property would properly be excluded 3 
from the inventory.  4 
§3-707.  Employment of appraisers  5 
The personal representative may employ a qualified and disinterested appraiser to 6 
assist in ascertaining th e fair market value as of the date of the decedent's death of any 7 
asset the value of which may be subject to reasonable doubt.  Different persons may be 8 
employed to appraise different kinds of assets included in the estate.  The names and 9 
addresses of any appraiser must be indicated on the inventory with the item or items 10 
appraised.  11 
§3-708.  Duty of personal representative; supplementary inventory  12 
If any property not included in the original inventory comes to the knowledge of a 13 
personal representative or i f the personal representative learns that the value or 14 
description indicated in the original inventory for any item is erroneous or misleading, the 15 
personal representative shall make a supplementary inventory or appraisement showing 16 
the market value as of the date of the decedent's death of the new item or the revised 17 
market value or descriptions, and the appraisers or other data relied upon, if any, and file 18 
the supplementary inventory or appraisement with the court or mail or furnish copies of 19 
the supplem entary inventory or appraisement or information about the supplementary 20 
inventory or appraisement to persons interested in the new information.  21 
§3-709.  Duty of personal representative; possession of estate  22 
Except as otherwise provided by a decedent's will , every personal representative has a 23 
right to and shall take possession or control of the decedent's property, except that any 24 
real property or tangible personal property may be left with or surrendered to the person 25 
presumptively entitled to it until, in  the judgment of the personal representative, 26 
possession of the property by the personal representative will be necessary for purposes 27 
of administration.  The request by a personal representative for delivery of any property 28 
possessed by an heir or devisee  is conclusive evidence in any action against the heir or 29 
devisee for possession of the property that the possession of the property by the personal 30 
representative is necessary for purposes of administration.  The personal representative 31 
shall pay taxes on  and take all steps reasonably necessary for the management, protection 32 
and preservation of the estate in the personal representative's possession.  The personal 33 
representative may maintain an action to recover possession of property or to determine 34 
the ti tle of the property.  35 
§3-710.  Power to avoid transfers  36 
The property liable for the payment of unsecured debts of a decedent includes all 37 
property transferred by the decedent by any means that is in law void or voidable as 38 
against the decedent's creditors, and, subject to prior liens, the right to recover this 39 
property, so far as necessary for the payment of unsecured debts of the decedent, is 40 
exclusively in the personal representative.  The personal representative is not required to 41 
 
 Page 136 - 128LR0452(01) -1 
 institute such an action  unless requested by creditors, who must pay or secure the cost and 1 
expenses of litigation.  2 
§3-711.  Powers of personal representatives; in general  3 
Until termination of the personal representative's appointment, a personal 4 
representative has the same power  over the title to property of the estate that an absolute 5 
owner would have, in trust however, for the benefit of the creditors and others interested 6 
in the estate.  This power may be exercised without notice, hearing or order of court.  7 
§3-712.  Improper e xercise of power; breach of fiduciary duty  8 
If the exercise of power concerning the estate is improper, the personal representative 9 
is liable to interested persons for damage or loss resulting from breach of the personal 10 
representative's fiduciary duty to t he same extent as a trustee of an express trust.  The 11 
rights of purchasers and others dealing with a personal representative must be determined 12 
as provided in sections 3 -713 and 3 -714. 13 
§3-713.  Sale, encumbrance or transaction involving conflict of interes t; voidable; 14 
exceptions  15 
Any sale or encumbrance to the personal representative, the personal representative's 16 
spouse, agent or attorney, or any corporation or trust in which the personal representative 17 
has a substantial beneficial interest, or any transact ion that is affected by a substantial 18 
conflict of interest on the part of the personal representative, is voidable by any person 19 
interested in the estate except a person who has consented after fair disclosure, unless:  20 
1.  Express authorization by decedent .  The will or a contract entered into by the 21 
decedent expressly authorized the transaction; or  22 
2.  Court approval.  The transaction is approved by the court after notice to 23 
interested persons.  24 
§3-714.  Persons dealing with personal representative; protect ion 25 
A person who in good faith either assists a personal representative or deals with the 26 
personal representative for value is protected as if the personal representative's power was 27 
properly exercised.  The fact that a person knowingly deals with a person al representative 28 
does not alone require the person to inquire into the existence of a power or the propriety 29 
of its exercise.  Except for restrictions on powers of supervised personal representatives 30 
that are endorsed on letters as provided in section 3 -504, no provision in any will or order 31 
of court purporting to limit the power of a personal representative is effective except as to 32 
persons with actual knowledge.  A person is not bound to see to the proper application of 33 
estate assets paid or delivered to  a personal representative.  The protection in this section 34 
extends to instances in which some procedural irregularity or jurisdictional defect 35 
occurred in proceedings leading to the issuance of letters, including a case in which the 36 
alleged decedent is fo und to be alive.  The protection in this section is not by substitution 37 
for that provided by comparable provisions of the laws relating to commercial 38 
transactions and laws simplifying transfers of securities by fiduciaries.  39 
 
 Page 137 - 128LR0452(01) -1 
 §3-715.  Transactions authorized  for personal representatives; exceptions  1 
Except as restricted or otherwise provided by the will or by an order in a formal 2 
proceeding and subject to the priorities stated in section 3 -902, a personal representative, 3 
acting reasonably for the benefit of th e interested persons, may properly:  4 
1.  Retain assets pending distribution.  Retain assets owned by the decedent 5 
pending distribution or liquidation including those in which the representative is 6 
personally interested or that are otherwise improper for tru st investment;  7 
2.  Receive assets.  Receive assets from fiduciaries, or other sources;  8 
3.  Perform decedent's contracts.  Perform, compromise or refuse performance of 9 
the decedent's contracts that continue as obligations of the estate, as the personal 10 
representative may determine under the circumstances.  In performing enforceable 11 
contracts by the decedent to convey or lease land, the personal representative, among 12 
other possible courses of action, may:  13 
A.  Execute and deliver a deed of conveyance for cash payment of all sums remaining 14 
due or the purchaser's note for the sum remaining due secured by a mortgage or deed 15 
of trust on the land; or  16 
B.  Deliver a deed in escrow with directions that the proceeds, when paid in 17 
accordance with the escrow agreement, be  paid to the successors of the decedent, as 18 
designated in the escrow agreement;  19 
4.  Satisfy charitable pledges.  Satisfy written charitable pledges of the decedent 20 
irrespective of whether the pledges constituted binding obligations of the decedent or 21 
were properly presented as claims, if in the judgment of the personal representative the 22 
decedent would have wanted the pledges completed under the circumstances;  23 
5.  Invest liquid assets.  If funds are not needed to meet debts and expenses currently 24 
payable an d are not immediately distributable, deposit or invest liquid assets of the estate, 25 
including money received from the sale of other assets, in federally insured interest - 26 
bearing accounts, readily marketable secured loan arrangements or other prudent 27 
invest ments that would be reasonable for use by trustees generally;  28 
6.  Acquire, sell, manage or abandon assets.  Acquire or dispose of an asset, 29 
including land in this or another state, for cash or on credit, at public or private sale; and 30 
manage, develop, impr ove, exchange, partition, change the character of or abandon an 31 
estate asset;  32 
7.  Make repairs or alterations.  Make ordinary or extraordinary repairs or 33 
alterations in buildings or other structures, demolish any improvements and raze existing 34 
or erect new  party walls or buildings;  35 
8.  Manage real estate.  Subdivide, develop or dedicate land to public use; make or 36 
obtain the vacation of plats and adjust boundaries; adjust differences in valuation on 37 
exchange or partition by giving or receiving consideration s; or dedicate easements to 38 
public use without consideration;  39 
 
 Page 138 - 128LR0452(01) -1 
 9.  Enter leases.  Enter for any purpose into a lease as lessor or lessee, with or 1 
without option to purchase or renew, for a term within or extending beyond the period of 2 
administration;  3 
10.  Enter mineral leases.  Enter into a lease or arrangement for exploration and 4 
removal of minerals or other natural resources or enter into a pooling or unitization 5 
agreement;  6 
11.  Abandon property.  Abandon property when, in the opinion of the personal 7 
repre sentative, it is valueless or is so encumbered or is in condition that it is of no benefit 8 
to the estate;  9 
12.  Vote securities.  Vote stocks or other securities in person or by general or 10 
limited proxy;  11 
13.  Pay sums chargeable against securities.  Pay cal ls, assessments and other sums 12 
chargeable or accruing against or on account of securities, unless barred by the provisions 13 
relating to claims;  14 
14.  Hold security through nominee.  Hold a security in the name of a nominee or in 15 
other form without disclosure  of the interest of the estate, but the personal representative 16 
is liable for any act of the nominee in connection with the security;  17 
15.  Obtain insurance.  Insure the assets of the estate against damage, loss and 18 
liability and the personal representative  against liability as to 3rd persons;  19 
16.  Borrow or advance money.  Borrow money with or without security to be 20 
repaid from the estate assets or otherwise; and advance money for the protection of the 21 
estate;  22 
17.  Compromise claims.  Effect a fair and reas onable compromise with any debtor 23 
or obligor or extend, renew or in any manner modify the terms of any obligation owing to 24 
the estate.  If the personal representative holds a mortgage, pledge or other lien upon 25 
property of another person, the personal repr esentative may, in lieu of foreclosure, accept 26 
a conveyance or transfer of encumbered assets from the owner in satisfaction of the 27 
indebtedness secured by lien;  28 
18.  Pay expenses.  Pay taxes, assessments, compensation of the personal 29 
representative and oth er expenses incident to the administration of the estate;  30 
19.  Exercise stock rights.  Sell or exercise stock subscription or conversion rights; 31 
consent, directly or through a committee or other agent, to the reorganization, 32 
consolidation, merger, dissolut ion or liquidation of a corporation or other business 33 
enterprise;  34 
20.  Allocate income and expenses.  Allocate items of income or expense to either 35 
estate income or principal, as permitted or provided by law;  36 
21.  Employ and act through agents.  Employ per sons, including attorneys, 37 
auditors, investment advisors or agents, even if they are associated with the personal 38 
 
 Page 139 - 128LR0452(01) -1 
 representative, to advise or assist the personal representative in the performance of 1 
administrative duties; act without independent investiga tion upon their recommendations; 2 
and instead of acting personally, employ one or more agents to perform any act of 3 
administration, whether or not discretionary;  4 
22.  Prosecute or defend claims.  Prosecute or defend claims or proceedings in any 5 
jurisdiction  for the protection of the estate and of the personal representative in the 6 
performance of the personal representative's duties;  7 
23.  Alienate property.  Sell, mortgage or lease any real or personal property of the 8 
estate or any interest in the property fo r cash or credit or for part cash and part credit, 9 
with or without security for unpaid balances;  10 
24.  Continue any business.  Continue any unincorporated business or venture in 11 
which the decedent was engaged at the time of death:  12 
A.  In the same business f orm for a period of not more than 4 months from the date of 13 
appointment of a general personal representative if continuation is a reasonable 14 
means of preserving the value of the business including good will;  15 
B.  In the same business form for any additional  period of time that may be approved 16
