C.  Throughout the period of administration if the business is incorporated by the 19 
personal representative and i f none of the probable distributees of the business who 20 
are competent adults object to its incorporation and retention in the estate;  21 
25.  Incorporate any business.  Incorporate any business or venture in which the 22 
decedent was engaged at the time of death ; 23 
26.  Contract without personal liability.  Provide for exoneration of the personal 24 
representative from personal liability in any contract entered into on behalf of the estate;  25 
27.  Distribute the estate.  Satisfy and settle claims and distribute the esta te as 26 
provided in this Code; and  27 
28.  Environmental compliance.  Exercise any power described in section 1 -110 28 
relating to compliance with environmental laws.  29 
§3-716.  Powers and duties of successor personal representative  30 
A successor personal representati ve has the same power and duty as the original 31 
personal representative to complete the administration and distribution of the estate, as 32 
expeditiously as possible, but the successor personal representative may not exercise any 33 
power expressly made personal  to the executor named in the will.  34 
§3-717.  Corepresentatives; when joint action required  35 
If 2 or more persons are appointed corepresentatives and unless the will provides 36 
otherwise, the concurrence of all is required on all acts connected with the admini stration 37 
 
 Page 140 - 128LR0452(01) -1 
 and distribution of the estate.  This restriction does not apply when any corepresentative 1 
receives and receipts for property due the estate, when the concurrence of all cannot 2 
readily be obtained in the time reasonably available for emergency act ion necessary to 3 
preserve the estate or when a corepresentative has been delegated to act for the others.  4 
Persons dealing with a corepresentative if actually unaware that another has been 5 
appointed to serve with that corepresentative or if advised by the personal representative 6 
with whom they deal that the personal representative has authority to act alone for any of 7 
the reasons mentioned in this section are as fully protected as if the person with whom 8 
they dealt had been the sole personal representative.  9 
§3-718.  Powers of surviving personal representative  10 
Unless the terms of the will otherwise provide, every power exercisable by personal 11 
corepresentatives may be exercised by the one or more remaining after the appointment 12 
of one or more is terminated, an d if one of 2 or more nominated as coexecutors is not 13 
appointed, those appointed may exercise all the powers incident to the office.  14 
§3-719.  Compensation of personal representative  15 
A personal representative is entitled to reasonable compensation for the p ersonal 16 
representative's services.  If a will provides for compensation of the personal 17 
representative and there is no contract with the decedent regarding compensation, the 18 
personal representative may renounce the provision before qualifying and be entitl ed to 19 
reasonable compensation.  A personal representative also may renounce the personal 20 
representative's right to all or any part of the compensation.  A written renunciation of fee 21 
may be filed with the court.  22 
§3-720.  Expenses in estate litigation  23 
If any personal representative or person nominated as personal representative defends 24 
or prosecutes any proceeding in good faith, whether successful or not, the personal 25 
representative or nominee is entitled to receive from the estate necessary expenses and 26 
disbursements including reasonable attorney's fees incurred.  27 
§3-721.  Proceedings for review of employment of agents and compensation of 28 
personal representatives and employees of estate  29 
1.  Procedure.  After notice to all interested persons, on petition of an  interested 30 
person or on appropriate motion if administration is supervised, the propriety of 31 
employment of any person by a personal representative, including any attorney, auditor, 32 
investment advisor or other specialized agent or assistant, the reasonable ness of the 33 
compensation of any person so employed or the reasonableness of the compensation 34 
determined by the personal representative for the personal representative's own services 35 
may be reviewed by the court.  Any person who has received excessive compe nsation 36 
from an estate for services rendered may be ordered to make appropriate refunds.  37 
2.  Reasonable fee factors.  Factors to be considered as guides in determining the 38 
reasonableness of a fee include the following:  39 
 
 Page 141 - 128LR0452(01) -1 
 A.  The time and labor required, the  novelty and difficulty of the questions involved 1 
and the skill requisite to perform the service properly;  2 
B.  The likelihood, if apparent to the personal representative, that the acceptance of 3 
the particular employment will preclude the person employed fr om other 4 
employment;  5 
C.  The fee customarily charged in the locality for similar services;  6 
D.  The amount involved and the results obtained;  7 
E.  The time limitations imposed by the personal representative or by the 8 
circumstances; and  9 
F.  The experience, re putation and ability of the person performing the services.  10 
PART 8  11 
CREDITORS' CLAIMS  12 
§3-801.  Notice to creditors  13 
1.  Notice by publication.  Unless notice has already been given under this section, a 14 
personal representative upon appointment shall publish a notice to creditors announcing 15 
the appointment and the personal representative's address and notifying creditors of the 16 
estate to present their claims within 4 months after the date of the first publication of the 17 
notice or be forever barred.  The notice  to creditors must be published once a week for 2 18 
successive weeks in a newspaper of general circulation in the county in which the court 19 
that appointed the personal representative is located.  20 
2.  Notice by mail.  A personal representative may give written  notice by mail or 21 
other delivery to a creditor, notifying the creditor to present the creditor's claim within 4 22 
months after the published notice, if given as provided in subsection 1, or within 60 days 23 
after the mailing or other delivery of the notice, w hichever is later, or be forever barred.  24 
Written notice must be the notice described in subsection 1 or a similar notice.  25 
3.  No liability for failure to give notice.  The personal representative is not liable to 26 
a creditor or to a successor of the decede nt for giving or failing to give notice under this 27 
section.  28 
§3-802.  Statutes of limitations  29 
1.  Applicability of statutes of limitations; waiver.  Unless an estate is insolvent, 30 
the personal representative, with the consent of all successors whose interes ts would be 31 
affected, may waive any defense of limitations available to the estate.  If the defense is 32 
not waived, no claim barred by a statute of limitations at the time of the decedent's death 33 
may be allowed or paid.  34 
2.  Suspension for 4 months after dea th.  The running of any statute of limitations 35 
measured from some other event than death or the giving of notice to creditors is 36 
suspended for 4 months after the decedent's death, but resumes thereafter as to claims not 37 
barred by other laws.  38 
 
 Page 142 - 128LR0452(01) -1 
 3.  Commenceme nt of action by presentation of claim.  For purposes of any statute 1 
of limitations, the presentation of a claim pursuant to section 3 -804 is equivalent to 2 
commencement of a proceeding on the claim.  3 
§3-803.  Limitations on presentation of claims  4 
1.  Claims arising before death.  All claims against a decedent's estate that arose 5 
before the death of the decedent, including claims of the State and any subdivision of the 6 
State, whether due or to become due, absolute or contingent, liquidated or unliquidated, 7 
founded on contract, tort or other legal basis, if not barred earlier by another statute of 8 
limitations or nonclaim statute, are barred against the estate, the personal representative 9 
and the heirs and devisees and nonprobate transferees of the decedent, unle ss presented 10 
within the earlier of the following:  11 
A.  Nine months after the decedent's death; or  12 
B.  The time provided by section 3 -801, subsection 2 for creditors who are given 13 
actual notice, and the time provided in section 3 -801, subsection 1 for all cr editors 14 
barred by publication.  15 
2.  Claim barred by nonclaim statute.  A claim described in subsection 1 that is 16 
barred by the nonclaim statute of the decedent's domicile before the giving of notice to 17 
creditors in this State is barred in this State.  18 
3.  Claims arising after death.  All claims against a decedent's estate that arise at or 19 
after the death of the decedent, including claims of the State and any subdivision of the 20 
State, whether due or to become due, absolute or contingent, liquidated or unliquid ated, 21 
founded on contract, tort or other legal basis, are barred against the estate, the personal 22 
representative and the heirs and devisees of the decedent, unless presented as follows:  23 
A.  A claim based on a contract with the personal representative, with in 4 months 24 
after performance by the personal representative is due; or  25 
B.  Any other claim, within the later of 4 months after it arises or the time specified in 26 
subsection 1, paragraph A.  27 
4.  Exceptions.  Nothing in this section affects or prevents:  28 
A.  Any proceeding to enforce any mortgage, pledge or other lien upon property of 29 
the estate;  30 
B.  To the limits of the insurance protection only, any proceeding to establish liability 31 
of the decedent or the personal representative for which the decedent or the  personal 32 
representative is protected by liability insurance;  33 
C.  Collection of compensation for services rendered and reimbursement for expenses 34 
advanced by the personal representative or by the attorney or accountant for the 35 
personal representative of th e estate; or  36 
D.  The State from filing and enforcing a claim for Medicaid reimbursement under 37 
Title 22, section 14.  Notwithstanding subsection 1, paragraph A, if this claim is filed 38 
within 4 months of published or actual notice of creditors, the claim is considered 39 
timely filed.  40 
 
 Page 143 - 128LR0452(01) -1 
 §3-804.  Manner of presentation of claims  1 
Claims against a decedent's estate may be presented as described in this section.  2 
1.  Written statement of claim.  The claimant may deliver or mail to the personal 3 
representative a written statement of the claim indicating its basis, the name and address 4 
of the claimant and the amount claimed, or may file a written statement of the claim, in 5 
the form prescribed by rule, with the clerk of the court.  The claim is deemed presented 6 
on the first  to occur of receipt of the written statement of claim by the personal 7 
representative or the filing of the claim with the court.  If a claim is not yet due, the date 8 
when it will become due must be stated.  If the claim is contingent or unliquidated, the 9 
nature of the uncertainty must be stated.  If the claim is secured, the security must be 10 
described.  Failure to describe correctly the security, the nature of any uncertainty and the 11 
due date of a claim not yet due does not invalidate the presentation made.  12 
2.  Proceeding on claim.  The claimant may commence a proceeding against the 13 
personal represensative in any court where the personal representative may be subjected 14 
to jurisdiction to obtain payment of the claimant's claim against the estate, but the 15 
comm encement of the proceeding must occur within the time limited for presenting the 16 
claim.  No presentation of claim is required in regard to matters claimed in proceedings 17 
against the decedent that were pending at the time of death.  18 
3.  Time limit for procee ding after disallowance.  If a claim is presented under 19 
subsection 1, no proceeding on the claim may be commenced more than 60 days after the 20 
personal representative has mailed a notice of disallowance; but, in the case of a claim 21 
that is not presently due  or that is contingent or unliquidated, the personal representative 22 
may consent to an extension of the 60 -day period or, to avoid injustice, the court on 23 
petition may order an extension of the 60 -day period, but in no event may the extension 24 
run beyond the  applicable statute of limitations.  25 
4.  Presenting claims before administration.  When a decedent's estate has not been 26 
commenced at the time a claimant wishes to present a claim, a claim is deemed presented 27 
when the claimant files with the clerk of the co urt a written statement of claim meeting 28 
the requirements of subsection 1 and a demand for notice pursuant to section 3 -204.  The 29 
provisions of subsection 3 apply upon the appointment of a personal representative.  30 
§3-805.  Classification of claims  31 
1.  Priority of claims.  If the applicable assets of the estate are insufficient to pay all 32 
claims in full, the personal representative shall make payment in the following order:  33 
A.  Costs and expenses of administration;  34 
B.  Reasonable funeral expenses;  35 
C.  Debts and taxes with preference under federal law;  36 
D.  Medicaid benefits recoverable under Title 22, section 14, subsection 2 -I and 37 
reasonable and necessary medical and hospital expenses of the last illness of the 38 
decedent, including compensation of persons atte nding the decedent;  39 
 
 Page 144 - 128LR0452(01) -1 
 E.  Debts and taxes with preference under other laws of this State; and  1 
F.  All other claims.  2 
2.  No priority within class or for claims not due.  Preference may not be given in 3 
the payment of any claim over any other claim of the same class, and a claim due and 4 
payable is not entitled to a preference over claims not due.  5 
§3-806.  Allowance of claims  6 
1.  Allowance or disallowance by personal representative.  As to claims presented 7 
in the manner described in section 3 -804 within the time limit prescribed in section 8 
3-803, the personal representative may mail a notice to any claimant stating that the claim 9 
has been disallowed.  If, after allowing or disallowing a claim, the personal representative 10 
changes the decision concerning the claim, the personal representative shall notify the 11 
claimant.  The personal representative may not change a disallowance of a claim after the 12 
time for the claimant to file a petition for allowance or to commence a proceeding on the 13 
claim has run and the claim has  been barred.  Every claim that is disallowed in whole or 14 
in part by the personal representative is barred so far as not allowed unless the claimant 15 
files a petition for allowance in the court or commences a proceeding against the personal 16 
representative n ot later than 60 days after the mailing of the notice of disallowance or 17 
partial allowance if the notice warns the claimant of the impending bar.  Failure of the 18 
personal representative to mail notice to a claimant of action on the claim for 60 days 19 
after the time for original presentation of the claim has expired has the effect of a notice 20 
of allowance.  21 
2.  Change of claim status by personal representative.  After allowing or 22 
disallowing a claim, the personal representative may change the allowance or 23 
disallowance as provided in this subsection.  The personal representative may prior to 24 
payment change the allowance to a disallowance in whole or in part, but not after 25 
allowance by a court order or judgment or an order directing payment of the claim.  The 26 
personal representative shall notify the claimant of the change to disallowance, and the 27 
disallowed claim is then subject to bar as provided in subsection 1.  The personal 28 
representative may change a disallowance to an allowance, in whole or in part, until it  is 29 
barred under subsection 1; after it is barred, it may be allowed and paid only if the estate 30 
is solvent and all successors whose interests would be affected consent.  31 
3.  Allowance by court.  Upon the petition of the personal representative or of a 32 
claimant in a proceeding for the purpose, the court may allow in whole or in part any 33 
claim or claims presented to the personal representative or filed with the clerk of the court 34 
in due time and not barred by subsection 1.  Notice in this proceeding must be g iven to 35 
the claimant, the personal representative and those other persons interested in the estate as 36 
the court may direct by order entered at the time the proceeding is commenced.  37 
4.  Judgment of another court; effect.  A judgment in a proceeding in anoth er court 38 
against a personal representative to enforce a claim against a decedent's estate is an 39 
allowance of the claim.  40 
5.  Interest.  Unless otherwise provided in any judgment in another court entered 41 
against the personal representative, allowed claims be ar prejudgment interest at the rate 42 
 
 Page 145 - 128LR0452(01) -1 
 specified in Title 14, section 1602 -B for the period commencing 60 days after the time for 1 
original presentation of the claim has expired unless based on a contract making a 2 
provision for interest, in which case they bea r interest in accordance with that provision.  3 
A.  Interest may not accrue on any allowed claims, however allowed, against an 4 
insolvent estate, except to the extent that insurance coverage or other nonprobate 5 
assets are available to pay the claim in full.  6 
B.  To the extent that an allowed claim against an insolvent estate is secured by 7 
property, the value of which, as determined under section 3 -809, is greater than the 8 
amount of the claim, the holder of the claim may receive interest on the principal 9 
amount of the claim and any reasonable fees, costs or charges provided for under an 10 
agreement under which the claim arose.  11 
§3-807.  Payment of claims  12 
1.  Payment upon expiration of limitations period.  Upon the expiration of the 13 
earlier of the time limitations pr ovided in section 3 -803 for the presentation of claims, the 14 
personal representative shall proceed to pay the claims allowed against the estate in the 15 
order of priority prescribed, after making provision for homestead, family and support 16 
allowances, for cla ims already presented that have not yet been allowed or whose 17 
allowance has been appealed, and for unbarred claims that may yet be presented, 18 
including costs and expenses of administration.  By petition to the court in a proceeding 19 
for the purpose, or by a ppropriate motion if the administration is supervised, a claimant 20 
whose claim has been allowed but not paid may secure an order directing the personal 21 
representative to pay the claim to the extent that funds of the estate are available to pay it.  22 
2.  Earli er payment; liability of personal representative.  The personal 23 
representative at any time may pay any just claim that has not been barred, with or 24 
without formal presentation, but the personal representative is personally liable to any 25 
other claimant whos e claim is allowed and who is injured by its payment if:  26 
A.  Payment was made before the expiration of the time limit stated in subsection 1 27 
and the personal representative failed to require the payee to give adequate security 28 
for the refund of any of the payment necessary to pay other claimants; or  29 
B.  Payment was made, due to the negligence or willful fault of the personal 30 
representative, in a manner that deprives the injured claimant of priority.  31 
§3-808.  Individual liability of personal representative  32 
1.  Contractual liability.  Unless otherwise provided in the contract, a personal 33 
representative is not individually liable on a contract properly entered into in a fiduciary 34 
capacity in the course of administration of the estate unless the personal represe ntative 35 
fails to reveal the representative capacity and identify the estate in the contract.  36 
2.  Liability for ownership or control of property; torts.  A personal representative 37 
is individually liable for obligations arising from ownership or control of t he estate or for 38 
torts committed in the course of administration of the estate only if the personal 39 
representative is personally at fault.  40 
 
 Page 146 - 128LR0452(01) -1 
 3.  Proceedings against personal representative in fiduciary capacity.  Claims 1 
based on contracts entered into by a p ersonal representative in a fiduciary capacity, on 2 
obligations arising from ownership or control of the estate or on torts committed in the 3 
course of estate administration may be asserted against the estate by proceeding against 4 
the personal representative  in a fiduciary capacity, whether or not the personal 5 
representative is individually liable.  6 
4.  Allocating liability between estate and personal representative.  Issues of 7 
liability as between the estate and the personal representative individually may be  8 
determined in a proceeding for accounting, surcharge or indemnification or other 9 
appropriate proceeding.  10 
§3-809.  Secured claims  11 
Payment of a secured claim is upon the basis of the amount allowed if the creditor 12 
surrenders the creditor's security; otherwi se payment is upon the basis of one of the 13 
following:  14 
1.  Security exhausted.  If the creditor exhausts the creditor's security before 15 
receiving payment, unless precluded by other law, upon the amount of the claim allowed 16 
less the fair value of the securit y; or 17 
2.  Security not exhausted.  If the creditor does not have the right to exhaust the 18 
creditor's security or has not done so, upon the amount of the claim allowed less the value 19 
of the security determined by converting it into money according to the te rms of the 20 
agreement pursuant to which the security was delivered to the creditor or by the creditor 21 
and personal representative by agreement, arbitration, compromise or litigation.  22 
§3-810.  Claims not due and contingent or unliquidated claims  23 
1.  Claim du e or certain before distribution.  If a claim that will become due at a 24 
future time or a contingent or unliquidated claim becomes due or certain before the 25 
distribution of the estate and if the claim has been allowed or established by a proceeding, 26 
it is p aid in the same manner as presently due and absolute claims of the same class.  27 
2.  Other cases.  In other cases the personal representative or, on petition of the 28 
personal representative or the claimant in a special proceeding for the purpose, the court 29 
may provide for payment as follows:  30 
A.  If the claimant consents, the claimant may be paid the present or agreed value of 31 
the claim, taking any uncertainty into account; or  32 
B.  Arrangement for future payment or possible payment on the happening of the 33 
conti ngency or on liquidation may be made by creating a trust, giving a mortgage, 34 
obtaining a bond or security from a distributee or otherwise.  35 
§3-811.  Counterclaims  36 
In allowing a claim the personal representative may deduct any counterclaim that the 37 
estate ha s against the claimant.  In determining a claim against an estate a court shall 38 
reduce the amount allowed by the amount of any counterclaims and, if the counterclaims 39 
 
 Page 147 - 128LR0452(01) -1 
 exceed the claim, render a judgment against the claimant in the amount of the excess.  A 1 
counterclaim, liquidated or unliquidated, may arise from a transaction other than that 2 
upon which the claim is based.  A counterclaim may give rise to relief exceeding in 3 
amount or different in kind from that sought in the claim.  4 
§3-812.  Execution and lev ies prohibited  5 
No execution may issue upon nor may any levy be made against any property of the 6 
estate under any judgment against a decedent or a personal representative, but this section 7 
may not be construed to prevent the enforcement of mortgages, pledge s or liens upon real 8 
or personal property in an appropriate proceeding.  9 
§3-813.  Compromise of claims  10 
When a claim against the estate has been presented in any manner, the personal 11 
representative may, if it appears for the best interest of the estate, comp romise the claim, 12 
whether due or not due, absolute or contingent, liquidated or unliquidated.  13 
§3-814.  Encumbered assets  14 
If any assets of the estate are encumbered by mortgage, pledge, lien or other security 15 
interest, the personal representative may pay th e encumbrance or any part of the 16 
encumbrance, renew or extend any obligation secured by the encumbrance or convey or 17 
transfer the assets to the creditor in satisfaction of the lien, in whole or in part, whether or 18 
not the holder of the encumbrance has pres ented a claim, if it appears to be for the best 19 
interest of the estate.  Payment of an encumbrance does not increase the share of the 20 
distributee entitled to the encumbered assets unless the distributee is entitled to 21 
exoneration.  22 
§3-815.  Administration i n more than one state; duty of personal representative  23 
1.  Estate assets subject to all claims, allowances and charges.  All assets of estates 24 
being administered in this State are subject to all claims, allowances and charges existing 25 
or established agains t the personal representative wherever appointed.  26 
2.  Estate insufficient; claimants to receive equal proportion of claims.  If the 27 
estate either in this State or as a whole is insufficient to cover all family exemptions and 28 
allowances determined by the la w of the decedent's domicile, prior charges and claims 29 
after satisfaction of the exemptions, allowances and charges, each claimant whose claim 30 
has been allowed either in this State or elsewhere in administrations of which the personal 31 
representative is awa re is entitled to receive payment of an equal proportion of the 32 
claimant's claim.  If a preference or security in regard to a claim is allowed in another 33 
jurisdiction but not in this State, the creditor so benefited is to receive dividends from 34 
local asset s only upon the balance of the creditor's claim after deducting the amount of 35 
the benefit.  36 
3.  Local assets apply first to claims allowed in this State.  In case the family 37 
exemptions and allowances, prior charges and claims of the entire estate exceed the  total 38 
value of the portions of the estate being administered separately and this State is not the 39 
state of the decedent's last domicile, the claims allowed in this State must be paid their 40 
 
 Page 148 - 128LR0452(01) -1 
 proportion if local assets are adequate for the purpose, and the b alance of local assets 1 
must be transferred to the domiciliary personal representative.  If local assets are not 2 
sufficient to pay all claims allowed in this State the amount to which they are entitled, 3 
local assets must be marshalled so that each claim all owed in this State is paid its 4 
proportion as far as possible, after taking into account all dividends on claims allowed in 5 
this State from assets in other jurisdictions.  6 
§3-816.  Final distribution to domiciliary representative  7 
The estate of a nonresident decedent being administered by a personal representative 8 
appointed in this State must, if there is a personal representative of the decedent's 9 
domicile willing to receive it, be distributed to the domiciliary personal representative for 10 
the benefit of the successors of the decedent unless:  11 
1.  Maine law governs.  By virtue of the decedent's will, if any, and applicable 12 
choice of law provisions, the successors are identified pursuant to the law of this State 13 
without reference to the law of the decedent's dom icile;  14 
2.  No domiciliary personal representative exists.  The personal representative of 15 
this State, after reasonable inquiry, is unaware of the existence or identity of a domiciliary 16 
personal representative; or  17 
3.  Court order.  The court orders otherwis e in a proceeding for a closing order 18 
under section 3 -1001 or incident to the closing of a supervised administration.  19 
In other cases, distribution of the estate of a decedent must be made in accordance 20 
with the other Parts of this Article.  21 
§3-817.  Surviva l of actions  22 
1.  Survival of actions.  No personal action or cause of action is lost by the death of 23 
either party, but the same survives for and against the personal representative of the 24 
deceased, except that actions or causes of action for the recovery o f penalties and fines 25 
under criminal statutes do not survive the death of the defendant.  A personal 26 
representative may seek relief from a judgment in an action to which the deceased was a 27 
party to the same extent that the deceased might have done so.  28 
2.  Death of plaintiff or defendant.  When the only plaintiff or defendant dies while 29 
an action that survives is pending, or after its commencement and before entry of 30 
judgment, the decedent's personal representative may appear and enter the action or any 31 
appe al that has been made, and suggest on the record the death of the party.  If the 32 
personal representative does not appear within 90 days after the appointment, the 33 
personal representative may be cited to appear, and after due notice judgment may be 34 
entered against the personal representative by dismissal or default if no such appearance 35 
is made.  36 
3.  Death of one of several plaintiffs or one of several defendants.  When either of 37 
several plaintiffs or defendants in an action that survives dies, the death may be suggested 38 
on the record, and the personal representative of the deceased may appear or be cited to 39 
appear as provided in subsection 2.  The action may be further prosecuted or defended by 40 
 
 Page 149 - 128LR0452(01) -1 
 the survivors and the personal representative jointly or by eithe r of them.  The survivors, 1 
if any, on both sides of the action may testify as witnesses.  2 
4.  Death of judgment creditor.  When a judgment creditor dies before the first 3 
execution issues or before an execution issued in the judgment creditor's lifetime is f ully 4 
satisfied, the execution may be issued or be effective in favor of the deceased judgment 5 
creditor's personal representative, but an execution may not be issued or be effective 6 
beyond the time within which it would have been effective or issued if the party had not 7 
died.  8 
5.  Execution in favor of deceased judgment creditor.  An execution issued under 9 
subsection 4 must set forth the fact that the judgment creditor has died since the rendition 10 
of the judgment and that the substituted party is the personal  representative of the 11 
decedent's estate.  12 
6.  Liability of personal representative.  The personal representative proceeding 13 
under this section is liable, and shall hold any recovered property or award, in a 14 
representative capacity, except as otherwise prov ided in section 3 -808. 15 
§3-818.  Damages limited to actual damages  16 
In any tort action against the personal representative of a decedent's estate, in the 17 
personal representative's representative capacity, the plaintiff may recover only the value 18 
of the goods  taken or damage actually sustained.  19 
PART 9  20 
SPECIAL PROVISIONS R ELATING TO DISTRIBUT ION  21 
§3-901.  Successors' rights if no administration  22 
In the absence of administration, the heirs and devisees are entitled to the estate in 23 
accordance with the terms of a p robated will or the laws of intestate succession. Devisees 24 
may establish title by the probated will to devised property. Persons entitled to property 25 
by homestead allowance, exemption or intestacy may establish title by proof of the 26 
decedent's ownership an d death and their relationship to the decedent. Successors take 27 
subject to all charges incident to administration, including the claims of creditors and 28 
allowances of surviving spouse and dependent children, and subject to the rights of others 29 
resulting fr om abatement, retainer, advancement and ademption.  30 
§3-902.  Distribution; order in which assets appropriated; abatement  31 
1.  Order in which assets appropriated; abatement.  Except as provided in 32 
subsection 2 and except as provided in connection with the sha re of the surviving spouse 33 
who elects to take an elective share, shares of distributees abate, without any preference 34 
or priority as between real and personal property, in the following order: property not 35 
disposed of by the will, residuary devises, genera l devises and specific devises.  For 36 
purposes of abatement, a general devise charged on any specific property or fund is a 37 
specific devise to the extent of the value of the property on which it is charged, and upon 38 
the failure or insufficiency of the prope rty on which it is charged, a general devise to the 39 
 
 Page 150 - 128LR0452(01) -1 
 extent of the failure or insufficiency.  Abatement within each classification is in 1 
proportion to the amounts of property each of the beneficiaries would have received if 2 
full distribution of the property  had been made in accordance with the terms of the will.  3 
2.  Intention of the testator controls.  If the will expresses an order of abatement or 4 
if the testamentary plan or the express or implied purpose of the devise would be defeated 5 
by the order of abat ement stated in subsection 1, the shares of the distributees abate as 6 
may be found necessary to give effect to the intention of the testator.  7 
3.  Adjustments.  If the subject of a preferred devise is sold or used incident to 8 
administration, abatement must be achieved by appropriate adjustments in or contribution 9 
from other interests in the remaining assets.  10 
§3-903.  Right of retainer  11 
The amount of a noncontingent indebtedness of a successor to the estate if due, or its 12 
present value if not due, must be offs et against the successor's interest, but the successor 13 
has the benefit of any defense that would be available to the debtor in a direct proceeding 14 
for recovery of the debt.  The debt constitutes a lien on the successor's interest in favor of 15 
the estate, ha ving priority over any attachment or transfer of the interest by the successor.  16 
§3-904.  Interest on general pecuniary devise  17 
General pecuniary devises bear interest at the legal rate of 5% per year beginning one 18 
year after the first appointment of a perso nal representative until payment, unless a 19 
contrary intent is indicated in the will.  20 
§3-905.  Penalty clause for contest  21 
A provision in a will purporting to penalize any interested person for contesting the 22 
will or instituting other proceedings relating to  the estate is unenforceable if probable 23 
cause exists for instituting proceedings.  24 
§3-906.  Distribution in kind; valuation; method  25 
1.  Distribution in kind; valuation; distribution of residuary estate.  Unless a 26 
contrary intention is indicated by the will , the distributable assets of a decedent's estate 27 
must be distributed in kind to the extent possible through application of the following 28 
provisions.  29 
A.  A specific devisee is entitled to distribution of the thing devised to that devisee, 30 
and a spouse or c hild who has selected particular assets of an estate as provided in 31 
section 2 -403 must receive the items selected.  32 
B.  Any homestead or family allowance or devise of a stated sum of money may be 33 
satisfied by value in kind, in the personal representative's discretion, as long as:  34 
(1)  The person entitled to the payment has not demanded payment in cash;  35 
(2)  The property distributed in kind is valued at fair market value as of the date 36 
of its distribution; and  37 
 
 Page 151 - 128LR0452(01) -1 
 (3)  No residuary devisee has requested that the asset to be distributed remain a 1 
part of the residue of the estate or, if a residuary devisee has requested that the 2 
asset to be distributed remain a part of the residue of the estate, there are 3 
insufficient other assets to which no residuary devisee has m ade such a request to 4 
permit satisfaction of the estate's obligations and funding of all pecuniary devises 5 
made under the decedent's will.  6 
C.  For the purpose of valuation under paragraph B, securities regularly traded on 7 
recognized exchanges, if distribut ed in kind, are valued at the price for the last sale of 8 
like securities traded on the business day prior to distribution or, if there was no sale 9 
on that day, at the median between amounts bid and offered at the close of that day.  10 
Assets consisting of su ms owed the decedent or the estate by solvent debtors as to 11 
which there is no known dispute or defense are valued at the sum due with accrued 12 
interest or discounted to the date of distribution.  For assets that do not have readily 13 
ascertainable values, a v aluation as of a date not more than 30 days prior to the date 14 
of distribution, if otherwise reasonable, controls. For purposes of facilitating 15 
distribution, the personal representative may ascertain the value of the assets as of the 16 
time of the proposed di stribution in any reasonable way, including the employment of 17 
qualified appraisers, even if the assets may have been previously appraised.  18 
D.  The residuary estate may be distributed by the personal representative in cash or 19 
in kind, in accordance with the  best interests of the residuary devisees.  Residuary 20 
assets may be distributed, at the personal representative's discretion, in pro rata or non 21 
pro rata shares, except that residuary assets not distributed pro rata must be valued as 22 
of the date on which t hey are distributed.  23 
2.  Right of distributee to object.  After the probable charges against the estate are 24 
known, the personal representative may mail or deliver a proposal for distribution to all 25 
persons who have a right to object to the proposed distrib ution. The right of any 26 
distributee to object to the proposed distribution on the basis of the kind or value of asset 27 
the distributee is to receive, if not waived earlier in writing, terminates if the distributee  28 
fails to object in writing received by the  personal representative within 30 days after 29 
mailing or delivery of the proposal.  30 
§3-907.  Distribution in kind; evidence  31 
If distribution in kind is made, the personal representative shall execute an instrument 32 
or deed of distribution assigning, transferr ing or releasing the assets to the distributee as 33 
evidence of the distributee's title to the property.  34 
§3-908.  Distribution; right or title of distributee  35 
Proof that a distributee has received an instrument or deed of distribution of assets in 36 
kind, or pa yment in distribution, from a personal representative, is conclusive evidence 37 
that the distributee has succeeded to the interest of the estate in the distributed assets, as 38 
against all persons interested in the estate, except that the personal representati ve may 39 
recover the assets or their value if the distribution was improper.  40 
 
 Page 152 - 128LR0452(01) -1 
 §3-909.  Improper distribution; liability of distributee  1 
Unless the distribution or payment no longer can be questioned because of 2 
adjudication, estoppel or limitation, a distribute e of property improperly distributed or 3 
paid, or a claimant who was improperly paid, is liable to return the property improperly 4 
received and its income since distribution if the distributee or claimant has the property.  5 
If the distributee or claimant doe s not have the property, then the distributee or claimant 6 
is liable to return the value as of the date of disposition of the property improperly 7 
received and income and gain received by the distributee or claimant.  8 
§3-910.  Purchasers from distributees pro tected  9 
If property distributed in kind or a security interest in the property is acquired for 10 
value by a purchaser from or lender to a distributee who has received an instrument or 11 
deed of distribution from the personal representative, or is acquired by a purchaser from 12 
or lender to a transferee from a distributee, the purchaser or lender takes title free of 13 
rights of any interested person in the estate and incurs no personal liability to the estate, 14 
or to any interested person, whether or not the distribut ion was proper or supported by 15 
court order or the authority of the personal representative was terminated before 16 
execution of the instrument or deed.  This section protects a purchaser from or lender to a 17 
distributee who, as personal representative, has ex ecuted a deed of distribution to the 18 
personal representative, as well as a purchaser from or lender to any other distributee or 19 
transferee.  To be protected under this provision, a purchaser or lender need not inquire 20 
whether a personal representative acte d properly in making the distribution in kind, even 21 
if the personal representative and the distributee are the same person, or whether the 22 
authority of the personal representative had terminated before the distribution.  Any 23 
recorded instrument described i n this section on which the register of deeds notes by an 24 
appropriate stamp "Maine Real Estate Transfer Tax Paid" is prima facie evidence that the 25 
transfer was made for value.  26 
§3-911.  Partition for purpose of distribution  27 
When 2 or more heirs or devisees are entitled to distribution of undivided interests in 28 
any real or personal property of the estate, the personal representative or one or more of 29 
the heirs or devisees may petition the court prior to the formal or informal closing of the 30 
estate to make par tition. After notice to the interested heirs or devisees, the court shall 31 
partition the property in the same manner as provided by the law for civil actions of 32 
partition. The court may direct the personal representative to sell any property that cannot 33 
be partitioned without prejudice to the owners and that cannot conveniently be allotted to 34 
any one party.  35 
§3-912.  Private agreements among successors to decedent binding on personal 36 
representative  37 
Subject to the rights of creditors and taxing authorities, co mpetent successors may 38 
agree among themselves to alter the interests, shares or amounts to which they are 39 
entitled under the will of the decedent, or under the laws of intestacy, in any way that 40 
they provide in a written contract executed by all who are af fected by its provisions.  The 41 
personal representative shall abide by the terms of the agreement subject to the personal 42 
 
 Page 153 - 128LR0452(01) -1 
 representative's obligation to administer the estate for the benefit of creditors, to pay all 1 
taxes and costs of administration and to carry out the responsibilities of the office for the 2 
benefit of any successors of the decedent who are not parties.  Personal representatives of 3 
decedents' estates are not required to see to the performance of trusts if the trustee of such 4 
a trust is anoth er person who is willing to accept the trust.  Accordingly, trustees of a 5 
testamentary trust are successors for the purposes of this section.  Nothing in this section 6 
relieves trustees of any duties owed to beneficiaries of trusts.  7 
§3-913.  Distributions t o trustee  8 
1.  Personal representative authority to require bond.  If the trust instrument does 9 
not excuse the trustee from giving bond, the personal representative may petition the 10 
appropriate court to require that the trustee post bond if the personal rep resentative 11 
apprehends that distribution might jeopardize the interests of persons who are not able to 12 
protect themselves, and the personal representative may withhold distribution until the 13 
court has acted.  14 
2.  Personal representative not negligent for fa iling to require bond.  An 15 
inference of negligence on the part of the personal representative may not be drawn from 16 
the personal representative's failure to exercise the authority conferred by subsection 1.  17 
§3-914.  Disposition of unclaimed assets  18 
If an he ir, devisee or claimant cannot be found, the personal representative shall 19 
distribute the share of the missing person to the person's conservator, if any; otherwise it 20 
must be disposed of according to Title 33, chapter 41.  21 
§3-915.  Distribution to person u nder disability  22 
1.  Discharge according to will.  A personal representative may discharge the 23 
personal representative's obligation to distribute to any person under legal disability by 24 
distributing in a manner expressly provided in the will.  25 
2.  Discharge under section 5 -103 or to conservator.  Unless contrary to an express 26 
provision in the will, a personal representative may discharge the personal 27 
representative's obligation to distribute to a minor or person under other disability as 28 
authorized by section  5-103 or any other statute.  If the personal representative knows 29 
that a conservator has been appointed or that a proceeding for appointment of a 30 
conservator is pending, the personal representative is authorized to distribute only to the 31 
conservator.  32 
3.  Discharge to attorney in fact or close relative.  If the heir or devisee is under 33 
disability other than minority, a personal representative is authorized to distribute to:  34 
A.  An attorney in fact who has authority under a power of attorney to receive 35 
prope rty for that person; or  36 
B.  The spouse, parent or other close relative with whom the person under disability 37 
resides if the distribution is of amounts not exceeding $10,000 a year or property not 38 
 
 Page 154 - 128LR0452(01) -1 
 exceeding $10,000 in value, unless the court authorizes a la rger amount or greater 1 
value.  2 
Persons receiving money or property for the person with a disability are obligated to 3 
apply the money or property to the support of that person, but may not pay themselves 4 
except by way of reimbursement for out -of-pocket expen ses for goods and services 5 
necessary for the support of the person with a disability.  Excess sums must be preserved 6 
for future support of the person with a disability.  The personal representative is not 7 
responsible for the proper application of money or property distributed pursuant to this 8 
subsection.  9 
§3-916.  Uniform Estate Tax Apportionment Act  10 
1.  Short title.  This section may be known and cited as the Uniform Estate Tax 11 
Apportionment Act.  12 
2.  Definitions.  As used in this section, unless the context  otherwise indicates, the 13 
following terms have the following meanings.  14 
A.  "Apportionable estate" means the value of the gross estate as finally determined 15 
for purposes of the estate tax to be apportioned reduced by:  16 
(1)  Any claim or expense allowable as a deduction for purposes of the tax;  17 
(2)  The value of any interest in property that, for purposes of the tax, qualifies 18 
for a marital or charitable deduction or otherwise is deductible or is exempt; and  19 
(3)  Any amount added to the decedent's gross estate  because of a gift tax on 20 
transfers made before death.  21 
B.  "Estate tax" means a federal, state or foreign tax imposed because of the death of 22 
an individual and interest and penalties associated with the tax.  The term does not 23 
include an inheritance tax, i ncome tax or generation -skipping transfer tax other than a 24 
generation -skipping transfer tax incurred on a direct skip taking effect at death.  25 
C.  "Gross estate" means, with respect to an estate tax, all interests in property subject 26 
to the tax.  27 
D.  "Person " means an individual, corporation, business trust, estate, trust, 28 
partnership, limited liability company, association, joint venture, public corporation, 29 
government, governmental subdivision, agency or instrumentality or any other legal 30 
or commercial enti ty. 31 
E.  "Ratable" or "ratably" means apportioned or allocated pro rata according to the 32 
relative values of interests to which the term is to be applied.  33 
F.  "Time -limited interest" means an interest in property that terminates on a lapse of 34 
time or on the occurrence or nonoccurrence of an event or that is subject to the 35 
exercise of discretion that could transfer a beneficial interest to another person.  The 36 
term does not include a cotenancy unless the cotenancy itself is a time -limited 37 
interest.  38 
G.  "Value"  means, with respect to an interest in property, fair market value as finally 39 
determined for purposes of the estate tax that is to be apportioned, reduced by any 40 
 
 Page 155 - 128LR0452(01) -1 
 outstanding debt secured by the interest without reduction for taxes paid or required 1 
to be pa id or for any special valuation adjustment.  2 
3.  Apportionment by will or other dispositive instrument.  This subsection 3 
applies when estate tax is apportioned expressly and unambiguously by a will, revocable 4 
trust or other dispositive instrument.  5 
A.  Excep t as otherwise provided in paragraph C:  6 
(1)  To the extent that a provision of a decedent's will expressly and 7 
unambiguously directs the apportionment of an estate tax, the tax must be 8 
apportioned accordingly;  9 
(2)  Any portion of an estate tax not apportio ned pursuant to subparagraph (1) 10 
must be apportioned in accordance with any provision of a revocable trust of 11 
which the decedent was the settlor that expressly and unambiguously directs the 12 
apportionment of an estate tax.  If conflicting apportionment prov isions appear in 13 
2 or more revocable trust instruments, the provision in the most recently dated 14 
instrument prevails.  For purposes of this subparagraph:  15 
(a)  A trust is revocable if it was revocable immediately after the trust 16 
instrument was executed, eve n if the trust subsequently becomes irrevocable; 17 
and 18 
(b)  The date of an amendment to a revocable trust instrument is the date of 19 
the amended instrument only if the amendment contains an apportionment 20 
provision; and  21 
(3)  If any portion of an estate tax is not apportioned pursuant to subparagraph (1) 22 
or (2), and a provision in any other dispositive instrument expressly and 23 
unambiguously directs that any interest in the property disposed of by the 24 
instrument is or is not to be applied to the payment of the es tate tax attributable to 25 
the interest disposed of by the instrument, the provision controls the 26 
apportionment of the tax to that interest.  27 
B.  Subject to paragraph C, and unless the decedent expressly and unambiguously 28 
directs the contrary:  29 
(1)  If an appo rtionment provision directs that a person receiving an interest in 30 
property under an instrument is to be exonerated from the responsibility to pay an 31 
estate tax that would otherwise be apportioned to the interest:  32 
(a)  The tax attributable to the exonerate d interest must be apportioned 33 
among the other persons receiving interests passing under the instrument; or  34 
(b)  If the values of the other interests are less than the tax attributable to the 35 
exonerated interest, the deficiency must be apportioned ratably among the 36 
other persons receiving interests in the apportionable estate that are not 37 
exonerated from apportionment of the tax;  38 
(2)  If an apportionment provision directs that an estate tax is to be apportioned to 39 
an interest in property a portion of which qualifies for a marital or charitable 40 
deduction, the estate tax must first be apportioned ratably among the holders of 41 
the portion that does not qualify for a marital or charitable deduction and then 42 
 
 Page 156 - 128LR0452(01) -1 
 apportioned ratably among the holders of the deductible portion to the extent that 1 
the value of the nondeductible portion is insufficient;  2 
(3)  Except as otherwise provided in subparagraph (4), if an apportionment 3 
provision directs that an estate tax be apportioned to property in which one or 4 
more time -limited interests exist, other than interests in specified property under 5 
subsection 7, the tax must be apportioned to the principal of that property, 6 
regardless of the deductibility of some of the interests in that property; and  7 
(4)  If an apportionment provision  directs that an estate tax is to be apportioned to 8 
the holders of interests in property in which one or more time -limited interests 9 
exist and a charity has an interest that otherwise qualifies for an estate tax 10 
charitable deduction, the tax must first be apportioned, to the extent feasible, to 11 
interests in property that have not been distributed to the persons entitled to 12 
receive the interests.  13 
C.  A provision that apportions an estate tax is ineffective to the extent that it 14 
increases the tax apportioned to a person having an interest in the gross estate over 15 
which the decedent had no power to transfer immediately before the decedent 16 
executed the instrument in which the apportionment direction was made.  For 17 
purposes of this subsection, a testamentary powe r of appointment is a power to 18 
transfer the property that is subject to the power.  19 
4.  Statutory apportionment of estate taxes.  To the extent that apportionment of an 20 
estate tax is not controlled by an instrument described in subsection 3 and except as 21 
otherwise provided in subsections 6 and 7:  22 
A.  Subject to paragraphs B, C and D, the estate tax is apportioned ratably to each 23 
person that has an interest in the apportionable estate;  24 
B.  A generation -skipping transfer tax incurred on a direct skip taking ef fect at death 25 
is charged to the person to whom the interest in property is transferred;  26 
C.  If property is included in the decedent's gross estate pursuant to Section 2044 of 27 
the United States Internal Revenue Code of 1986, as amended, or any similar estat e 28 
tax provision, the difference between the total estate tax for which the decedent's 29 
estate is liable and the amount of estate tax for which the decedent's estate would 30 
have been liable if the property had not been included in the decedent's gross estate is 31 
apportioned ratably among the holders of interests in the property.  The balance of the 32 
tax, if any, is apportioned ratably to each other person having an interest in the 33 
apportionable estate; and  34 
D.  Except as otherwise provided in subsection 3, paragr aph B, subparagraph (4) and 35 
except as to property to which subsection 7 applies, an estate tax apportioned to 36 
persons holding interests in property subject to a time -limited interest must be 37 
apportioned, without further apportionment, to the principal of t hat property.  38 
5.  Credits and deferrals.  Except as otherwise provided in subsections 6 and 7, this 39 
subsection applies to credits and deferrals of estate taxes.  40 
 
 Page 157 - 128LR0452(01) -1 
 A.  A credit resulting from the payment of gift taxes or from estate taxes paid on 1 
property pre viously taxed inures ratably to the benefit of all persons to whom the 2 
estate tax is apportioned.  3 
B.  A credit for state or foreign estate taxes inures ratably to the benefit of all persons 4 
to whom the estate tax is apportioned, except that the amount of a  credit for a state or 5 
foreign tax paid by a beneficiary of the property on which the state or foreign tax was 6 
imposed, directly or by a charge against the property, inures to the benefit of the 7 
beneficiary.  8 
C.  If payment of a portion of an estate tax is deferred because of the inclusion in the 9 
gross estate of a particular interest in property, the benefit of the deferral inures 10 
ratably to the persons to whom the estate tax attributable to the interest is 11 
apportioned.  The burden of any interest charges in curred on a deferral of taxes and 12 
the benefit of any tax deduction associated with the accrual or payment of the interest 13 
charge are allocated ratably among the persons receiving an interest in the property.  14 
6.  Insulated property; advancement of tax.  This subsection applies when the 15 
estate includes property that is unavailable for payment of estate tax due to impossibility 16 
or impracticability.  17 
A.  As used in this subsection, unless the context otherwise indicates, the following 18 
terms have the following me anings.  19 
(1)  "Advanced fraction" means a fraction that has as its numerator the amount of 20 
the advanced tax and as its denominator the value of the interests in insulated 21 
property to which that tax is attributable.  22 
(2)  "Advanced tax" means the aggregate am ount of estate tax attributable to 23 
interests in insulated property that is required to be advanced by uninsulated 24 
holders under paragraph C.  25 
(3)  "Insulated property" means property subject to a time -limited interest that is 26 
included in the apportionable e state but is unavailable for payment of an estate 27 
tax because of impossibility or impracticability.  28 
(4)  "Uninsulated holder" means a person who has an interest in uninsulated 29 
property.  30 
(5)  "Uninsulated property" means property included in the apportionab le estate 31 
other than insulated property.  32 
B.  If an estate tax is to be advanced pursuant to paragraph C by persons holding 33 
interests in uninsulated property subject to a time -limited interest other than property 34 
to which subsection 7 applies, the tax must be advanced, without further 35 
apportionment, from the principal of the uninsulated property.  36 
C.  Subject to subsection 9, paragraphs B and D, an estate tax attributable to interests 37 
in insulated property must be advanced ratably by uninsulated holders.  If the value of 38 
an interest in uninsulated property is less than the amount of estate taxes otherwise 39 
required to be advanced by the holder of that interest, the deficiency must be 40 
advanced ratably by the persons holding interests in properties that are exclu ded from 41 
 
 Page 158 - 128LR0452(01) -1 
 the apportionable estate under subsection 2, paragraph A, subparagraph (2) as if those 1 
interests were in uninsulated property.  2 
D.  A court having jurisdiction to determine the apportionment of an estate tax may 3 
require a beneficiary of an interest  in insulated property to pay all or part of the estate 4 
tax otherwise apportioned to the interest if the court finds that it would be 5 
substantively more equitable for that beneficiary to bear the tax liability personally 6 
than for that part of the tax to be  advanced by uninsulated holders.  7 
E.  When a distribution of insulated property is made, each uninsulated holder may 8 
recover from the distributee a ratable portion of the advanced fraction of the property 9 
distributed.  To the extent that undistributed insu lated property ceases to be insulated, 10 
each uninsulated holder may recover from the property a ratable portion of the 11 
advanced fraction of the total undistributed property.  12 
F.  Upon a distribution of insulated property for which, pursuant to paragraph D, t he 13 
distributee becomes obligated to make a payment to uninsulated holders, a court may 14 
award an uninsulated holder a recordable lien on the distributee's property to secure 15 
the distributee's obligation to that uninsulated holder.  16 
7.  Apportionment and reca pture of special elective benefits.  The reduction in 17 
estate tax due to election of a special elective benefit must be apportioned in accordance 18 
with this subsection.  19 
A.  As used in this subsection, unless the context otherwise indicates, the following 20 
terms have the following meanings.  21 
(1)  "Special elective benefit" means a reduction in an estate tax obtained by an 22 
election for:  23 
(a)  A reduced valuation of specified property that is included in the gross 24 
estate;  25 
(b)  A deduction from the gross estate, oth er than a marital or charitable 26 
deduction, allowed for specified property; or  27 
(c)  An exclusion from the gross estate of specified property.  28 
(2)  "Specified property" means property for which an election has been made for 29 
a special elective benefit.  30 
B.  If an election is made for one or more special elective benefits, an initial 31 
apportionment of a hypothetical estate tax must be computed as if no election for any 32 
of those benefits had been made.  The aggregate reduction in estate tax resulting from 33 
all elec tions made must be allocated among holders of interests in the specified 34 
property in the proportion that the amount of deduction, reduced valuation or 35 
exclusion attributable to each holder's interest bears to the aggregate amount of 36 
deductions, reduced val uations and exclusions obtained by the decedent's estate from 37 
the elections.  If the estate tax initially apportioned to the holder of an interest in 38 
specified property is reduced to zero, any excess amount of reduction reduces ratably 39 
the estate tax appor tioned to other persons that receive interests in the apportionable 40 
estate.  41 
 
 Page 159 - 128LR0452(01) -1 
 C.  An additional estate tax imposed to recapture all or part of a special elective 1 
benefit must be charged to the persons that are liable for the additional tax under the 2 
law prov iding for the recapture.  3 
8.  Securing payment of estate tax from property in possession of fiduciary.  A 4 
fiduciary may ensure that a distributee will pay the distributee's share of the estate tax 5 
through one of the following methods.  6 
A.  A fiduciary may de fer a distribution of property until the fiduciary is satisfied that 7 
adequate provision for payment of the estate tax has been made.  8 
B.  A fiduciary may withhold from a distributee an amount equal to the amount of 9 
estate tax apportioned to an interest of t he distributee.  10 
C.  As a condition to a distribution, a fiduciary may require the distributee to provide 11 
a bond or other security for the portion of the estate tax apportioned to the distributee.  12 
9.  Collection of estate tax by fiduciary.  A fiduciary resp onsible for payment of an 13 
estate tax may collect the tax due using the following methods.  14 
A.  A fiduciary responsible for payment of an estate tax may collect from any person 15 
the tax apportioned to and the tax required to be advanced by the person.  16 
B.  Except as otherwise provided in subsection 6, any estate tax due from a person 17 
that cannot be collected from the person may be collected by the fiduciary from other 18 
persons in the following order of priority:  19 
(1)  Any person having an interest in the apportio nable estate that is not 20 
exonerated from the tax;  21 
(2)  Any other person having an interest in the apportionable estate; and  22 
(3)  Any person having an interest in the gross estate.  23 
C.  A domiciliary fiduciary may recover from an ancillary personal represent ative the 24 
estate tax apportioned to the property controlled by the ancillary personal 25 
representative.  26 
D.  The total tax collected from a person pursuant to this section may not exceed the 27 
value of the person's interest.  28 
10.  Right of reimbursement.  A pers on may obtain reimbursement of estate tax as 29 
provided in this subsection.  30 
A.  A person required under subsection 9 to pay an estate tax greater than the amount 31 
due from the person under subsection 3 or 4 has a right to reimbursement from 32 
another person to the extent that the other person has not paid the tax required by 33 
subsection 3 or 4 and a right to reimbursement ratably from other persons to the 34 
extent that each has not contributed a portion of the amount collected under 35 
subsection 9, paragraph B.  36 
B.  A fiduciary may enforce the right of reimbursement under paragraph A on behalf 37 
of the person that is entitled to the reimbursement and shall take reasonable steps to 38 
do so if requested by the person.  39 
 
 Page 160 - 128LR0452(01) -1 
 11.  Action to determine or enforce section.  A fiduciary , transferee or beneficiary 1 
of the gross estate may maintain an action for declaratory judgment to have a court 2 
determine and enforce this section.  3 
12.  Delayed application.  The applicability of subsections 3 to 7 is governed by this 4 
subsection.  5 
A.  Subse ctions 3 to 7 do not apply to the estate of a decedent who dies on or within 3 6 
years after January 1, 2019 nor to the estate of a decedent who dies more than 3 years 7 
after January 1, 2019 if the decedent continuously lacked testamentary capacity from 8 
the e xpiration of the 3 -year period until the date of death.  9 
B.  For the estate of a decedent who dies on or after January 1, 2019 to which 10 
subsections 3 to 7 do not apply, estate taxes must be apportioned pursuant to the law 11 
in effect immediately before Januar y 1, 2019.  12
