CLOSING ESTATES  14 
§3-1001.  Formal proceedings terminating administration; testate or intestate; order 15 
of general protection  16 
1.  Formal proceedings terminating administration.  A personal representative or 17 
any interested person may petitio n for an order of complete settlement of the estate.  The 18 
personal representative may petition at any time and any other interested person may 19 
petition after one year from the appointment of the original personal representative except 20 
that no petition unde r this section may be entertained until the time for presenting claims 21 
that arose prior to the death of the decedent has expired.  The petition may request the 22 
court to determine testacy, if not previously determined, to consider the final account or 23 
compe l or approve an accounting and distribution, to construe any will or determine heirs 24 
and to adjudicate the final settlement and distribution of the estate.  After notice to all 25 
interested persons and hearing, the court may enter an order or orders on appro priate 26 
conditions, determining the persons entitled to distribution of the estate and, as 27 
circumstances require, approving settlement and directing or approving distribution of the 28 
estate and discharging the personal representative from further claim or de mand of any 29 
interested person.  30 
2.  Omitted parties.  If one or more heirs or devisees were omitted as parties in, or 31 
were not given notice of, a previous formal testacy proceeding, the court, on proper 32 
petition for an order of complete settlement of the es tate under this section, and after 33 
notice to the omitted or unnotified persons and other interested parties determined to be 34 
interested on the assumption that the previous order concerning testacy is conclusive as to 35 
those given notice of the earlier proce eding, may determine testacy as it affects the 36 
omitted persons and confirm or alter the previous order of testacy as it affects all 37 
interested persons as appropriate in the light of the new proofs.  In the absence of 38 
objection by an omitted or unnotified p erson, evidence received in the original testacy 39 
proceeding constitutes prima facie proof of due execution of any will previously admitted 40 
to probate or of the fact that the decedent left no valid will if the prior proceedings 41 
determined this fact.  42 
 
 Page 161 - 128LR0452(01) -1 
 §3-1002 .  Formal proceedings terminating testate administration; order construing 1 
will without adjudicating testacy  2 
A personal representative administering an estate under an informally probated will 3 
or any devisee under an informally probated will may petition f or an order of settlement 4 
of the estate that will not adjudicate the testacy status of the decedent.  The personal 5 
representative may petition at any time, and a devisee may petition after one year, from 6 
the appointment of the original personal representat ive, except that no petition under this 7 
section may be entertained until the time for presenting claims that arose prior to the 8 
death of the decedent has expired.  The petition may request the court to consider the 9 
final account or compel or approve an acc ounting and distribution, to construe the will 10 
and to adjudicate final settlement and distribution of the estate.  After notice to all 11 
devisees and the personal representative and hearing, the court may enter an order or 12 
orders, on appropriate conditions, determining the persons entitled to distribution of the 13 
estate under the will and, as circumstances require, approving settlement and directing or 14 
approving distribution of the estate and discharging the personal representative from 15 
further claim or demand  of any devisee who is a party to the proceeding and those the 16 
devisee represents.  If it appears that a part of the estate is intestate, the proceedings must 17 
be dismissed or amendments made to meet the provisions of section 3 -1001.  18 
§3-1003.  Closing estat es; by sworn statement of personal representative  19 
1.  Closing estate by sworn statement of personal representative.  Unless 20 
prohibited by order of the court and except for estates being administered in supervised 21 
administration proceedings, a personal repr esentative may close an estate by filing with 22 
the court no earlier than 6 months after the date of original appointment of a general 23 
personal representative for the estate a verified statement stating that the personal 24 
representative, or a previous persona l representative, has:  25 
A.  Determined that the time limited for presentation of creditors' claims has expired;  26 
B.  Fully administered the estate of the decedent by making payment, settlement or 27 
other disposition of all claims that were presented, expenses of administration and 28 
estate, inheritance and other death taxes, except as specified in the statement, and that 29 
the assets of the estate have been distributed to the persons entitled.  If any claims 30 
remain undischarged, the statement must state whether the  personal representative 31 
has distributed the estate subject to possible liability with the agreement of the 32 
distributees or it shall state in detail other arrangements that have been made to 33 
accommodate outstanding liabilities; and  34 
C.  Sent a copy of the s tatement to all distributees of the estate and to all creditors or 35 
other claimants of whom the personal representative is aware whose claims are 36 
neither paid nor barred and has furnished a full account in writing of the personal 37 
representative's administra tion to the distributees whose interests are affected thereby.  38 
2.  Termination of personal representative appointment.  If no proceedings 39 
involving the personal representative are pending in the court one year after the closing 40 
statement is filed, the appo intment of the personal representative terminates.  41 
 
 Page 162 - 128LR0452(01) -1 
 §3-1004.  Liability of distributees to claimants  1 
After assets of an estate have been distributed and subject to section 3 -1006, an 2 
undischarged claim not barred may be prosecuted in a proceeding against on e or more 3 
distributees.  A distributee is not liable to claimants for amounts received as exempt 4 
property or homestead or family allowances or for amounts in excess of the value of the 5 
distribution as of the time of distribution.  As between distributees, each bears the cost of 6 
satisfaction of unbarred claims as if the claim had been satisfied in the course of 7 
administration.  Any distributee who fails to notify other distributees of the demand made 8 
by the claimant in sufficient time to permit them to join in any proceeding in which the 9 
claim was asserted loses the right of contribution against other distributees.  10 
§3-1005.  Limitations on proceedings against personal representative  11 
Unless previously barred by adjudication and except as provided in the closin g 12 
statement, the rights of successors and of creditors whose claims have not otherwise been 13 
barred against the personal representative for breach of fiduciary duty are barred unless a 14 
proceeding to assert those rights is commenced within 6 months after the  filing of the 15 
closing statement.  The rights barred by this section do not include rights to recover from 16 
a personal representative for fraud, misrepresentation or inadequate disclosure related to 17 
the settlement of the decedent's estate.  18 
§3-1006.  Limitat ions on actions and proceedings against distributees  19 
Unless previously adjudicated in a formal testacy proceeding or in a proceeding 20 
settling the accounts of a personal representative or otherwise barred, the claim of any 21 
claimant to recover from a distrib utee who is liable to pay the claim, and the right of an 22 
heir or devisee, or of a successor personal representative acting in the heir's or devisee's 23 
behalf, to recover property improperly distributed or its value from any distributee is 24 
forever barred at the later of 3 years after the decedent's death or one year after the time 25 
of its distribution, but all claims of creditors of the decedent are barred 9 months after the 26 
decedent's death.  This section does not bar an action to recover property or value 27 
received as the result of fraud.  28 
§3-1007.  Certificate discharging liens securing fiduciary performance  29 
After the personal representative's appointment has terminated, the personal 30 
representative, the personal representative's sureties or any successor of ei ther, upon the 31 
filing of a verified application showing, so far as is known by the applicant, that no action 32 
concerning the estate is pending in any court, is entitled to receive a certificate from the 33 
register that the personal representative appears to h ave fully administered the estate in 34 
question.  The certificate evidences discharge of any lien on any property given to secure 35 
the obligation of the personal representative in lieu of bond or any surety, but does not 36 
preclude action against the personal r epresentative or the surety.  37 
§3-1008.  Subsequent administration  38 
If other property of the estate is discovered after an estate has been settled and the 39 
personal representative discharged or after one year after a closing statement has been 40 
 
 Page 163 - 128LR0452(01) -1 
 filed, the court  upon petition of any interested person and upon notice as it directs may 1 
appoint the same or a successor personal representative to administer the subsequently 2 
discovered estate.  If a new appointment is made, unless the court orders otherwise, the 3 
provis ions of this Code apply as appropriate, but no claim previously barred may be 4 
asserted in the subsequent administration.  5 
PART 11  6 
COMPROMISE OF CONTRO VERSIES  7 
§3-1101.  Effect of approval of agreements involving trusts, inalienable interests or 8 
interests of 3rd persons  9 
A compromise of any controversy as to admission to probate of any instrument 10 
offered for formal probate as the will of a decedent, the construction, validity or effect of 11 
any governing instrument, the rights or interests in the estate of the de cedent, of any 12 
successor or the administration of the estate, if approved in a formal proceeding in the 13 
court for that purpose, is binding on all the parties thereto including those unborn, 14 
unascertained or who could not be located.  An approved compromise  is binding even 15 
though it may affect a trust or an inalienable interest. A compromise does not impair the 16 
rights of creditors or of taxing authorities who are not parties to it.  17 
§3-1102.  Procedure for securing court approval of compromise  18 
The procedure f or securing court approval of a compromise is as follows.  19 
1.  Written, signed agreement.  The terms of the compromise must be set forth in an 20 
agreement in writing that must be executed by all competent persons and parents or legal 21 
guardians who have both a ctual custody and legal responsibility for a minor child acting 22 
for any minor child who has beneficial interests or claims that will or may be affected by 23 
the compromise.  Execution is not required by any person whose identity cannot be 24 
ascertained or whos e whereabouts are unknown and cannot reasonably be ascertained.  25 
2.  Submission to court for approval.  Any interested person, including the personal 26 
representative or a trustee, then may submit the agreement to the court for its approval 27 
and for execution by the personal representative, the trustee of every affected 28 
testamentary trust and other fiduciaries and representatives.  29 
3.  Hearing and order.  After notice to all interested persons or their representatives, 30 
including the personal representative of th e estate and all affected trustees of trusts, the 31 
court, if it finds that the contest or controversy is in good faith and that the effect of the 32 
agreement upon the interests of persons represented by fiduciaries or other 33 
representatives is just and reasona ble, shall make an order approving the agreement and 34 
directing all fiduciaries subject to its jurisdiction to execute the agreement.  Minor 35 
children represented only by their parents are bound only if their parents join with other 36 
competent persons in exec ution of the compromise.  Upon the making of the order and 37 
the execution of the agreement, all further disposition of the estate must be in accordance 38 
with the terms of the agreement.  39 
PART 12  40 
 
 Page 164 - 128LR0452(01) -1 
 COLLECTION OF PERSON AL PROPERTY BY AFFID AVIT AND SUMMARY 1 
ADMINIS TRATION PROCEDURES F OR SMALL ESTATES  2 
§3-1201.  Collection of personal property by affidavit  3 
1.  Affidavit; duty to deliver property.  Thirty days after the death of a decedent, 4 
any person indebted to the decedent or having possession of personal property o r an 5 
instrument evidencing a debt, obligation, stock or chose in action belonging to the 6 
decedent shall make payment of the indebtedness or deliver the personal property or an 7 
instrument evidencing a debt, obligation, stock or chose in action to a person c laiming to 8 
be the successor of the decedent upon being presented an affidavit made by or on behalf 9 
of the successor stating that:  10 
A.  The value of the entire estate, wherever located, less liens and encumbrances, 11 
does not exceed $50,000;  12 
B.  Thirty days ha ve elapsed since the death of the decedent;  13 
C.  No application or petition for the appointment of a personal representative is 14 
pending or has been granted in any jurisdiction; and  15 
D.  The claiming successor is entitled to payment or delivery of the propert y. 16 
2.  Securities.  A transfer agent of any security shall change the registered ownership 17 
on the books of a corporation from the decedent to the successor or successors upon the 18 
presentation of an affidavit as provided in subsection 1.  19 
§3-1202.  Effect of  affidavit  20 
The person paying, delivering, transferring or issuing personal property or the 21 
evidence of personal property pursuant to affidavit is discharged and released to the same 22 
extent as if the person dealt with a personal representative of the decede nt.  The person is 23 
not required to see to the application of the personal property or evidence of personal 24 
property or to inquire into the truth of any statement in the affidavit.  If any person to 25 
whom an affidavit is delivered refuses to pay, deliver, tr ansfer or issue any personal 26 
property or evidence of personal property, it may be recovered or its payment, delivery, 27 
transfer or issuance compelled upon proof of their right in a proceeding brought for the 28 
purpose by or on behalf of the persons entitled t hereto. Any person to whom payment, 29 
delivery, transfer or issuance is made is answerable and accountable to any personal 30 
representative of the estate or to any other person having a superior right.  31 
§3-1203.  Small estates; summary administrative procedure  32 
If it appears from the inventory and appraisal that the value of the entire estate, less 33 
liens and encumbrances, does not exceed homestead allowance, exempt property, family 34 
allowance, costs and expenses of administration, reasonable funeral expenses and 35 
reasonable and necessary medical and hospital expenses of the last illness of the 36 
decedent, the personal representative, without giving notice to creditors, may 37 
immediately disburse and distribute the estate to the persons entitled to the estate and file 38 
a closing statement as provided in section 3 -1204.  39 
 
 Page 165 - 128LR0452(01) -1 
 §3-1204.  Small estates; closing by sworn statement of personal representative  1 
1.  Verified statement; contents.  Unless prohibited by order of the court and except 2 
for estates being administered by supervis ed personal representatives, a personal 3 
representative may close an estate administered under the summary procedures of section 4 
3-1203 by filing with the court, at any time after disbursement and distribution of the 5 
estate, a verified statement stating tha t: 6 
A.  To the best knowledge of the personal representative, the value of the entire 7 
estate, less liens and encumbrances, did not exceed homestead allowance, exempt 8 
property, family allowance, costs and expenses of administration, reasonable funeral 9 
expens es and reasonable, necessary medical and hospital expenses of the last illness 10 
of the decedent;  11 
B.  The personal representative has fully administered the estate by disbursing and 12 
distributing it to the persons entitled thereto; and  13 
C.  The personal repres entative has sent a copy of the closing statement to all 14 
distributees of the estate and to all creditors or other claimants of whom the personal 15 
representative is aware whose claims are neither paid nor barred and has furnished a 16 
full account in writing of  the administration to the distributees whose interests are 17 
affected.  18 
2.  Termination of personal representative appointment.  If no actions or 19 
proceedings involving the personal representative are pending in the court one year after 20 
the closing statement is filed, the appointment of the personal representative terminates.  21 
3.  Effect of verified statement.  A closing statement filed under this section has the 22 
same effect as one filed under section 3 -1003.  23 
§3-1205.  Social security payments  24 
If not less than 30 days after the death of a Maine resident entitled at the time of the 25 
resident's death to a monthly benefit or benefits under Title II of the Social Security Act, 26 
all or part of the amount of such benefit or benefits not in excess of $1,000 is paid by th e 27 
United States to the surviving spouse, one or more of the decedent's children or 28 
descendants of the deceased children, the decedent's father or mother or the decedent's 29 
brother or sister, preference being given in the order named if more than one request  for 30 
payment has been made by or for such individuals, upon an affidavit made and filed with 31 
the federal Department of Health and Human Services by the surviving spouse or other 32 
relative by whom or on whose behalf request for payment is made; and if the af fidavit 33 
shows the date of death of the decedent, the relationship of the affiant to the decedent, 34 
that no personal representative for the decedent has been appointed and qualified and that, 35 
to the affiant's knowledge, there exists at the time of filing of the affidavit no relative of a 36 
closer degree of kindred to the decedent than the affiant, then such payment pursuant to 37 
the affidavit is deemed to be a payment to the legal representative of the decedent and, 38 
regardless of the truth or falsity of the state ments made in the affidavit, constitutes a full 39 
discharge and release of the United States from any further claim for such payment to the 40 
same extent as if such payment had been made to the personal representative of the 41 
decedent's estate.  42

Maine Uniform Probate Code Comment (§3-203) 4 
 This section deviates from the Uniform Probate Code in subsections 1, 3 and 4.  In 5 
subsection 1, this section adds the decedent's dome stic partner and the State Tax Assessor as 6 
paragraphs E and H respectively in keeping with prior Maine law.  In subsection 3, this 7 
section does not include the uniform language that references "a person who would be 8 
entitled to letters but for the person's  age" and does not include the language in the next 9 
sentence that references a person "18 years of age or older."  The language is not needed in 10 
Maine because a person aged 18 or over may serve as a personal representative in Maine.  11 
The default age under the Uniform Probate Code requires that a person be at least 21 years 12 
old to serve as a personal representative.  Finally, in subsection 4, this section deviates from 13 
the Uniform Probate Code by adding the right of an agent under a power of attorney that  14 
expressly grants the agent the authority to do so,  to exercise the same right to nominate, to 15 
object to another's appointment or to participate in determining the preference of a majority in 16 
interest of the heirs and devisees that the protected person or war d would have if qualified for 17 
appointment.  18

ARTICLE 4  9 
FOREIGN PERSONAL REP RESENTATIVE; ANCILLA RY 10 
PART 1  11 
DEFINITIONS  12 
§4-101.  Definitions  13 
As used in this Article, unless the context otherwise indicates, the following terms 14 
have the following meanings.  15 
1.  Local administratio n.  "Local administration" means administration by a 16 
personal representative appointed in this State pursuant to appointment proceedings 17 
described in Article 3.  18 
2.  Local personal representative.  "Local personal representative" includes any 19 
personal repre sentative appointed in this State pursuant to appointment proceedings 20 
described in Article 3 and excludes foreign personal representatives who acquire the 21 
power of a local personal representative pursuant to section 4 -205. 22 
3.  Resident creditor.  "Resident  creditor" means a person domiciled in or doing 23 
business in this State who is, or could be, a claimant against an estate of a nonresident 24 
decedent.  25 
PART 2  26 
POWERS OF FOREIGN PE RSONAL REPRESENTATIV ES 27 
 
 Page 179 - 128LR0452(01) -1 
 §4-201.  Payment of debt and delivery of property to domic iliary foreign personal 1 
representative without local administration  2 
At any time after the expiration of 60 days from the death of a nonresident decedent, 3 
any person indebted to the estate of the nonresident decedent or having possession or 4 
control of perso nal property or of an instrument evidencing a debt, obligation, stock or 5 
chose in action belonging to the estate of the nonresident decedent may pay the debt or 6 
deliver the personal property or the instrument evidencing the debt, obligation, stock or 7 
chose  in action to the domiciliary foreign personal representative of the nonresident 8 
decedent upon being presented with proof of the domiciliary foreign personal 9 
representative's appointment and an affidavit made by or on behalf of the representative 10 
stating:  11 
1.  Date of death.  The date of the death of the nonresident decedent;  12 
2.  No local administration.  That no local administration, or application or petition 13 
for local administration, is pending in this State; and  14 
3.  Personal representative authority.  That the domiciliary foreign personal 15 
representative is entitled to payment or delivery.  16 
§4-202.  Payment or delivery discharges  17 
Payment or delivery made in good faith on the basis of the proof of authority and 18 
affidavit releases the debtor or person having possession of the personal property to the 19 
same extent as if payment or delivery had been made to a local personal representative.  20 
§4-203.  Resident creditor notice  21 
Payment or delivery under section 4 -201 may not be made if a resident creditor of the 22 
nonre sident decedent has notified the debtor of the nonresident decedent or the person 23 
having possession of the personal property belonging to the nonresident decedent that the 24 
debt should not be paid nor the property delivered to the domiciliary foreign person al 25 
representative.  26 
§4-204.  Proof of authority; bond  27 
If no local administration or application or petition for local administration is pending 28 
in this State, a domiciliary foreign personal representative may file with a court in this 29 
State in a county in w hich property belonging to the decedent is located authenticated 30 
copies of the foreign personal representative's appointment and of any official bond the 31 
foreign personal representative has given.  32 
§4-205.  Powers  33 
A domiciliary foreign personal representati ve who has complied with section 4 -204 34 
may exercise as to assets in this State all powers of a local personal representative and 35 
may maintain actions and proceedings in this State subject to any conditions imposed 36 
upon nonresident parties generally.  37 
 
 Page 180 - 128LR0452(01) -1 
 §4-206.  Power of representatives in transition  1 
The power of a domiciliary foreign personal representative under section 4 -201 or 2 
4-205 may be exercised only if there is no administration or application for 3 
administration pending in this State.  An application o r petition for local administration of 4 
the estate terminates the power of the foreign personal representative to act under section 5 
4-205, but the local court may allow the foreign personal representative to exercise 6 
limited powers to preserve the estate.  A person who, before receiving actual notice of a 7 
pending local administration, has changed position in reliance upon the powers of a 8 
foreign personal representative may not be prejudiced by reason of the application or 9 
petition for, or grant of, local adm inistration.  The local personal representative is subject 10 
to all duties and obligations that have accrued by virtue of the exercise of the powers by 11 
the foreign personal representative and may be substituted for the foreign personal 12 
representative in any action or proceedings in this State.  13 
§4-207.  Ancillary and other local administrations; provisions governing  14 
In respect to a nonresident decedent, the provisions of Article 3 govern:  15 
1.  Court proceedings in this State.  Proceedings, if any, in a court of  this State for 16 
probate of the will, appointment, removal, supervision and discharge of the local personal 17 
representative and any other order concerning the estate; and  18 
2.  Rights of local personal representative and parties.  The status, powers, duties 19 
and liabilities of any local personal representative and the rights of claimants, purchasers, 20 
distributees and others in regard to a local administration.  21 
PART 3  22 
JURISDICTION OVER FO REIGN REPRESENTATIVE S 23 
§4-301.  Jurisdiction by act of foreign personal repre sentative  24 
A foreign personal representative submits personally to the jurisdiction of the courts 25 
of this State in any proceeding relating to the estate by:  26 
1.  Filing appointment with court.  Filing authenticated copies of the foreign 27 
personal representati ve's appointment as provided in section 4 -204; 28 
2.  Receiving estate assets.  Receiving payment of money or taking delivery of 29 
personal property under section 4 -201. 30 
Jurisdiction under this subsection is limited to the money or value of personal property 31 
collected; or  32 
3.  Acting as personal representative within State.  Doing any act as a personal 33 
representative in this State that would have given the State jurisdiction over the foreign 34 
personal representative as an individual.  35 
 
 Page 181 - 128LR0452(01) -1 
 §4-302.  Jurisdiction by act o f decedent  1 
In addition to jurisdiction conferred by section 4 -301, a foreign personal 2 
representative is subject to the jurisdiction of the courts of this State to the same extent 3 
that the decedent was subject to jurisdiction immediately prior to death.  4 
§4-303.  Service on foreign personal representative  5 
Service of process may be made upon the foreign personal representative in such 6 
manner as the Supreme Judicial Court shall by rule provide.  7 
PART 4  8 
JUDGMENTS AND PERSON AL REPRESENTATIVE  9 
§4-401.  Effect of adj udication for or against personal representative  10 
An adjudication rendered in any jurisdiction in favor of or against any personal 11 
representative of the estate is as binding on the local personal representative as if the local 12 
personal representative were a  party to the adjudication.  13

ARTICLE 5  13 
UNIFORM GUARDIANSHIP  AND PROTECTIVE PROCE EDINGS ACT  14 
PART 1  15 
GENERAL PROVISIONS  16 
§5-101.  Short title  17 
This Article may be known and cited as "the Uniform Guardianship and Protective 18 
Proceedings Act."  19 
§5-102.  Definitio ns 20 
As used in this Article, unless the context otherwise indicates, the following terms 21 
have the following meanings.  22 
1.  Best interest of the minor.  "Best interest of the minor" means the best interest as 23 
determined under Title 19 -A, section 1653, subsect ion 3.  24 
2.  Court.  "Court" means any one of the several courts of probate in this State as 25 
described in Title 4, section 201.  26 
 
 Page 183 - 128LR0452(01) -1 
 3.  Legal representative.  "Legal representative" includes the attorney for the 1 
respondent, a representative payee, a guardian or conservator acting for a respondent in 2 
this State or elsewhere, a trustee or custodian of a trust or custodianship of which the 3 
respondent is a beneficiary and an agent designated under a power of attorney, whether 4 
for health care or property, in which the  respondent is identified as the principal.  5 
4.  Parent.  "Parent" means a person who has established a parent -child relationship 6 
with the child under Title 19 -A, chapter 61 and whose parental rights have not been 7 
terminated.  8 
5.  Respondent.  "Respondent" m eans an individual for whom the appointment of a 9 
guardian or conservator or other protective order is sought.  10 
§5-103.  Facility of transfer  11 
1.  Transfer of money or personal property to minor.  Unless a person required to 12 
transfer money or personal propert y to a minor knows that a conservator has been 13 
appointed or that a proceeding for appointment of a conservator of the estate of the minor 14 
is pending, the person may do so, as to an amount or value not exceeding $10,000 a year, 15 
by transferring it to:  16 
A.  A person who has the care and custody of the minor and with whom the minor 17 
resides;  18 
B.  A guardian of the minor;  19 
C.  A custodian under the Maine Uniform Transfers to Minors Act;  20 
D.  A financial institution as a deposit in an interest -bearing account or cer tificate in 21 
the sole name of the minor and giving notice of the deposit to the minor; or  22 
E.  The minor, if married.  23 
2.  Responsibility for proper application.  A person who transfers money or 24 
property in compliance with this section is not responsible for its proper application.  25 
3.  For benefit of minor; no personal financial benefit.  A guardian or other person 26 
who receives money or property for a minor under subsection 1, paragraph A or B may 27 
apply it only to the support, care, education, health and welfa re of the minor and may not 28 
derive a personal financial benefit except for reimbursement for necessary expenses.  Any 29 
excess must be preserved for the future support, care, education, health and welfare of the 30 
minor, and any balance must be transferred to the minor upon emancipation or attaining 31 
majority.  32 
§5-104.  Delegation of power by parent or guardian  33 
1.  Delegation; up to 12 months.  A parent or a guardian of a minor or incapacitated 34 
person, by a power of attorney, may delegate to another person, for a  period not 35 
exceeding 12 months, any power regarding care, custody or property of the minor or 36 
ward, except the power to consent to marriage, adoption or termination of parental rights 37 
to the minor.  A delegation of powers by a court -appointed guardian bec omes effective 38 
only when the power of attorney is filed with the court.  A delegation of powers under 39 
 
 Page 184 - 128LR0452(01) -1 
 this section does not deprive the parent or guardian of any parental or legal authority 1 
regarding the care and custody of the minor or incapacitated perso n. 2 
2.  National Guard or Reserves; extension.  Notwithstanding subsection 1, unless 3 
otherwise stated in the power of attorney, if the parent or guardian is a member of the 4 
National Guard or Reserves of the United States Armed Forces under an order to activ e 5 
duty for a period of more than 30 days, a power of attorney that would otherwise expire is 6 
automatically extended until 30 days after the parent or guardian is no longer under that 7 
active duty order or until an order of the court so provides.  8 
This subsec tion applies only if the parent's or guardian's service is in support of:  9 
A.  An operational mission for which members of the reserve components have been 10 
ordered to active duty without their consent; or  11 
B.  Forces activated during a period of war declared  by the United States Congress or 12 
a period of national emergency declared by the President of the United States or the 13 
United States Congress.  14 
3.  Temporary care of minor.  This subsection applies when a parent or guardian 15 
executes a power of attorney unde r subsection 1 for the purpose of providing for the 16 
temporary care of a minor.  17 
A.  The execution of a power of attorney under subsection 1, without other evidence, 18 
does not constitute abandonment, abuse or neglect.  A parent or guardian of a minor 19 
may not execute a power of attorney with the intention of permanently avoiding or 20 
divesting the parent or guardian of parental and legal responsibility for the care of the 21 
minor. Upon the expiration or termination of the power of attorney, the minor must 22 
be return ed to the custody of the parent or guardian as soon as reasonably possible 23 
unless otherwise ordered by the court.  24 
B.  Unless the power of attorney is terminated, the agent named in the power of 25 
attorney shall exercise parental or legal authority on a conti nuous basis without 26 
compensation from the State for the duration of the power of attorney authorized by 27 
subsection 1. Nothing in this subsection disqualifies the agent from applying for and 28 
receiving benefits from any state or federal program of assistance  for the minor or the 29 
agent.  Nothing in this subsection prevents individuals or religious, community or 30 
other charitable organizations from voluntarily providing the agent with support 31 
related to the care of the minor while the minor is in the temporary c are of the agent.  32 
C.  A minor may not be considered placed in foster care or in any way a ward of the 33 
State by virtue of the parent's or guardian's execution of a power of attorney 34 
authorized by subsection 1. The agent named in the power of attorney may no t be 35 
considered a family foster home by virtue of the parent's or guardian's execution of a 36 
power of attorney authorized by subsection 1 and is not subject to any laws regarding 37 
the licensure or regulation of family foster homes unless licensed as a family  foster 38 
home.  Nothing in this subsection disqualifies the agent from being or becoming a 39 
family foster home licensed by the State or prevents the placement of the minor in the 40 
agent's care if the minor enters state custody.  41 
 
 Page 185 - 128LR0452(01) -1 
 D.  An organization, other than  an organization whose primary purpose is to provide 1 
free legal services, that is exempt from federal income taxation under Section 501(a) 2 
of the United States Internal Revenue Code of 1986 as an organization described by 3 
Section 501(c)(3) and that assists  parents or guardians with the process of executing a 4 
power of attorney for the temporary care of a minor shall ensure that a background 5 
check is conducted for the agent and any adult members of the agent's household, 6 
whether by completing the background c heck directly or by verifying that a current 7 
background check has already been conducted.  The background check must include 8 
the following sources, and the results must be shared with the parent or guardian and 9 
the proposed agent:  10 
(1)  A screening for chil d and adult abuse, neglect or exploitation cases in the 11 
records of the Department of Health and Human Services; and  12 
(2)  A criminal history record check that includes information obtained from the 13 
Federal Bureau of Investigation.  14 
The organization shall mai ntain records on the training and background checks of 15 
agents, including the content and dates of training and full transcripts of background 16 
checks, for a period of not less than 5 years after the minor attains 18 years of age.  17 
The organization shall mak e the records available to a parent or guardian executing a 18 
power of attorney under this subsection and to the ombudsman under Title 22, section 19 
4087 -A and any local, state or federal authority conducting an investigation involving 20 
the agent, the parent or  guardian or the minor.  21 
E.  An employee or volunteer for an organization described in paragraph D may not 22 
further assist with a process that results in the completion of a power of attorney for 23 
the temporary care of a minor if the background checks conduct ed pursuant to 24 
paragraph D, subparagraphs (1) and (2) disclose any substantiated allegations of child 25 
abuse, neglect or exploitation or any crimes that would disqualify the agent from 26 
becoming a licensed family foster home in the State.  27 
F.  The following p enalties apply to violations of this subsection.  28 
(1)  An organization that knowingly fails to perform or verify the background 29 
checks or fails to share the background check information as required by this 30 
subsection is subject to a civil penalty not to exc eed $5,000, payable to the State 31 
and recoverable in a civil action.  32 
(2) An organization or an employee or volunteer of an organization that continues 33 
to assist a parent, guardian or agent in completing a power of attorney under this 34 
subsection if the backg round checks conducted pursuant to paragraph D disclose 35 
any substantiated allegations of child abuse, neglect or exploitation or any crimes 36 
that would disqualify the agent from becoming a licensed family foster home is 37 
subject to a civil penalty not to exc eed $5,000, payable to the State and 38 
recoverable in a civil action.  39 
(3)  An organization or an employee or volunteer of an organization that 40 
knowingly fails to maintain records or to disclose information as required by this 41 
subsection is subject to a civil  penalty not to exceed $5,000, payable to the State 42 
and recoverable in a civil action.  43

 §5-105.  Subject matter jurisdiction  1 
1.  Guardianship, protective proceedings for minors; exception.  Except to the 2 
extent the guardianship is subject to the Uniform Chi ld Custody Jurisdiction and 3 
Enforcement Act and Title 4, section 152, subsection 5 -A, the court has jurisdiction over 4 
guardianship for minors domiciled or present in this State.  The court has jurisdiction 5 
over protective proceedings for minors domiciled i n or having property located in this 6 
State.  7 
2.  Guardianship, protective proceedings for adults.  The court has jurisdiction 8 
over guardianship and protective proceedings for an adult as provided in the Uniform 9 
Adult Guardianship and Protective Proceedings Jurisdiction Act.  10 
§5-106.  Transfer of jurisdiction  11 
1.  Rules for transfer of jurisdiction.  Except as otherwise provided in subsection 2, 12 
the following rules apply.  13 
A.  After the appointment of a guardian or conservator or entry of another protective 14 
order, the court making the appointment or entering the order may transfer the 15 
proceeding to a court in another county in this State or to another state if the court is 16 
satisfied that a transfer will serve the best interest of the ward or protected person.  17 
B.  If a guardianship or protective proceeding is pending in another state or a foreign 18 
country and a petition for guardianship or protective proceeding is filed in a court in 19 
this State, the court in this State shall notify the original court and, after cons ultation 20 
with the original court, assume or decline jurisdiction, whichever is in the best 21 
interest of the ward or protected person.  22 
C.  A guardian, conservator or like fiduciary appointed in another state may petition 23 
the court for appointment as a guardi an or conservator in this State if venue in this 24 
State is or will be established.  The appointment may be made upon proof of 25 
appointment in the other state and presentation of a certified copy of the portion of 26 
the court record in the other state specified  by the court in this State.  Notice of 27 
hearing on the petition, together with a copy of the petition, must be given to the 28 
ward or protected person, if the ward or protected person has attained 14 years of age, 29 
and to the persons who would be entitled to notice if the regular procedures for 30 
appointment of a guardian or conservator under this Article were applicable.  The 31 
court shall make the appointment in this State unless the court concludes that the 32 
appointment would not be in the best interest of the w ard or protected person.  On the 33 
filing of an acceptance of office and any required bond, the court shall issue 34 
appropriate letters of guardianship or conservatorship.  Not later than 14 days after an 35 
appointment, the guardian or conservator shall send or deliver a copy of the order of 36 
appointment to the ward or protected person, if the ward or protected person has 37 
attained 14 years of age, and to all persons given notice of the hearing on the petition.  38 
2.  Adult subject to transfer provisions of this Artic le.  Subsection 1 does not 39 
apply to a guardianship or protective proceeding for an adult who is subject to the transfer 40 
provisions of this Article.  41 
 
 Page 187 - 128LR0452(01) -1 
 §5-107.  Venue  1 
1.  Guardianship for minor.  Venue for a guardianship proceeding for a minor is in 2 
the county  of this State in which the minor resides or is present at the time the proceeding 3 
is commenced.  4 
2.  Guardianship for incapacitated person.  Venue for a guardianship proceeding 5 
for an incapacitated person is in the county of this State in which the respond ent resides 6 
and, if the respondent has been admitted to an institution by order of a court of competent 7 
jurisdiction, in the county in which the court is located.  Venue for the appointment of an 8 
emergency or a temporary substitute guardian of an incapacit ated person is also in the 9 
county in which the incapacitated person is present.  10 
3.  Protective proceeding.  Venue for a protective proceeding is in the county of this 11 
State in which the respondent resides, whether or not a guardian has been appointed in 12 
another place or, if the respondent does not reside in this State, in any county of this State 13 
in which property of the respondent is located.  14 
4.  Where first brought; exceptions.  If a proceeding under this Article is brought in 15 
more than one county in this  State, the court of the county in which the proceeding is first 16 
brought has the exclusive right to proceed unless that court determines that venue is 17 
properly in another court or that the interests of justice otherwise require that the 18 
proceeding be trans ferred.  19 
§5-108.  Letters of appointment  20 
Upon the guardian's filing of an acceptance of appointment, the court shall issue 21 
appropriate letters of guardianship.  Upon the conservator's filing of an acceptance of 22 
appointment and any required bond, the court s hall issue appropriate letters of 23 
conservatorship.  Letters of guardianship must indicate whether the guardian was 24 
appointed by the court, a parent or the spouse.  Any limitation on the powers of a 25 
guardian or conservator or of the assets subject to a cons ervatorship must be endorsed on 26 
the guardian's or conservator's letters.  27 
§5-109.  Effect of acceptance of appointment  28 
By accepting appointment, a guardian or conservator submits personally to the 29 
jurisdiction of the court in any proceeding relating to the guardianship or conservatorship.  30 
The petitioner shall send or deliver notice of any proceeding to the guardian or 31 
conservator at the guardian's or conservator's address shown in the court records and at 32 
any other address then known to the petitioner.  33 
§5-110.  Termination of or change in guardian's or conservator's appointment  34 
1.  Termination of appointment.  The appointment of a guardian or conservator 35 
terminates upon the death, resignation or removal of the guardian or conservator or upon 36 
termination of t he guardianship or conservatorship.  A resignation of a guardian or 37 
conservator is effective when approved by the court.  A parental or spousal appointment 38 
as guardian under an informally probated will terminates if the will is later denied probate 39 
in a fo rmal proceeding. Termination of the appointment of a guardian or conservator does 40 
 
 Page 188 - 128LR0452(01) -1 
 not affect the liability of either for previous acts or the obligation to account for money 1 
and other assets of the ward or protected person.  2 
2.  Petition for removal or perm ission to resign.  A ward, protected person or 3 
person interested in the welfare of a ward or protected person may petition for removal of 4 
a guardian or conservator on the ground that removal would be in the best interest of the 5 
ward or protected person or for other good cause.  A guardian or conservator may petition 6 
for permission to resign.  A petition for removal or permission to resign may include a 7 
request for appointment of a successor guardian or conservator.  8 
3.  Appointment of additional, successor g uardian or conservator.  The court may 9 
appoint an additional guardian or conservator at any time to serve immediately or upon 10 
some other designated event, and may appoint a successor guardian or conservator in the 11 
event of a vacancy or make the appointment  in contemplation of a vacancy to serve if a 12 
vacancy occurs.  An additional or successor guardian or conservator may file an 13 
acceptance of appointment at any time after the appointment, but not later than 30 days 14 
after the occurrence of the vacancy or othe r designated event.  The additional or 15 
successor guardian or conservator becomes eligible to act on the occurrence of the 16 
vacancy or designated event, or the filing of the acceptance of appointment, whichever 17 
last occurs.  A successor guardian or conservat or succeeds to the predecessor's powers, 18 
and a successor conservator succeeds to the predecessor's title to the protected person's 19 
assets.  20 
4.  Court appointment of attorney for ward, guardian, petitioner.  If, at any time 21 
in the proceeding, the court deter mines that the interests of the ward are, or may be, 22 
inadequately represented, the court may appoint an attorney to represent the ward, giving 23 
consideration to the preference of the ward if the ward is 14 or more years of age.  In a 24 
contested action, the c ourt also may appoint counsel for any indigent guardian or 25 
petitioner.  26 
5.  Termination without consent, best interest; subsequent petitions.  The court 27 
may not terminate the guardianship in the absence of the guardian's consent unless the 28 
court finds by a preponderance of the evidence that the termination is in the best interest 29 
of the ward.  The petitioner has the burden of showing by a preponderance of the 30 
evidence that termination of the guardianship is in the best interest of the ward.  If the 31 
court doe s not terminate the guardianship, the court may dismiss subsequent petitions for 32 
termination of the guardianship unless there has been a substantial change of 33 
circumstances.  34 
6.  Parent's petition to terminate guardianship; burden of proof.  A party 35 
opposin g a parent's petition to terminate a guardianship bears the burden of proving by a 36 
preponderance of the evidence that the parent seeking to terminate the guardianship is 37 
currently unfit to regain custody of the child.  If the party opposing termination of the 38 
guardianship fails to meet its burden of proof on the question of the parent's fitness to 39 
regain custody, the court shall terminate the guardianship and make any further order that 40 
may be appropriate.  41 
 
 Page 189 - 128LR0452(01) -1 
 §5-111.  Notice  1 
1.  Notice by petitioner; rules.  Except as otherwise ordered by the court for good 2 
cause, if notice of a hearing on a petition is required, other than a notice for which 3 
specific requirements are otherwise provided, the petitioner shall give notice of the time 4 
and place of the hearing to t he person to be notified.  Notice must be given, in such 5 
manner as the Supreme Judicial Court by rule provides, at least 14 days before the 6 
hearing.  7 
2.  Proof of notice.  Proof of notice under subsection 1 must be made before or at the 8 
hearing and filed in  the proceeding.  9 
3.  Plain language.  A notice under this Article must be given in plain language.  10 
§5-112.  Waiver of notice  11 
A person may waive notice by a writing signed by the person or the person's attorney 12 
and filed in the proceeding.  However, a respo ndent, ward or protected person may not 13 
waive notice.  14 
§5-113.  Guardian ad litem  15 
At any stage of a proceeding, a court may appoint a guardian ad litem if the court 16 
determines that representation of the interest otherwise would be inadequate.  If not 17 
preclu ded by a conflict of interest, a guardian ad litem may be appointed to represent 18 
several individuals or interests.  The court shall state on the record the duties of the 19 
guardian ad litem and the court's reasons for the appointment.  20 
§5-114.  Request for no tice; interested persons  21 
An interested person not otherwise entitled to notice who desires to be notified before 22 
any order is made in a guardianship proceeding, including a proceeding after the 23 
appointment of a guardian, or in a protective proceeding may f ile a request for notice with 24 
the clerk of the court in which the proceeding is pending.  The clerk shall send or deliver 25 
a copy of the request to the guardian and to the conservator if one has been appointed.  A 26 
request is not effective unless it contains  a statement showing the interest of the person 27 
making it and the address of that person or an attorney to whom notice is to be given.  28 
The request is effective only as to proceedings conducted after its filing.  A governmental 29 
agency paying or planning to  pay benefits to the respondent or protected person is an 30 
interested person in a protective proceeding.  31 
§5-115.  Multiple appointments or nominations  32 
If a respondent or other person makes more than one written appointment or 33 
nomination of a guardian or a c onservator, the most recent controls.  34 
PART 2  35 
GUARDIANSHIP OF MINO R 36 
 
 Page 190 - 128LR0452(01) -1 
 §5-201.  Appointment and status of guardian  1 
A person becomes a guardian of a minor by parental appointment or upon 2 
appointment by the court.  The guardianship status continues until termina ted, without 3 
regard to the location of the guardian or minor ward.  This section does not apply to 4 
permanency guardians appointed in District Court child protective proceedings under 5 
Title 22, section 4038 -C.  If a minor has a permanency guardian, the cour t may not 6 
appoint another guardian without leave of the District Court in which the child protective 7 
proceeding is pending.  8 
§5-202.  Parental appointment of guardian  9 
1.  Appointment by parent.  A guardian may be appointed by will or other signed 10 
writing by  a parent for any minor child the parent has or may have in the future.  The 11 
appointment may specify the desired limitations on the powers to be given to the 12 
guardian.  The appointing parent may revoke or amend the appointment before 13 
confirmation by the co urt. 14 
2.  Petition to confirm selection, terminate right to object.  Upon petition of an 15 
appointing parent and a finding that the appointing parent will likely become unable to 16 
care for the child within 2 years, and after notice as provided in section 5 -205, subsection 17 
1, the court, before the appointment becomes effective, may confirm the parent's selection 18 
of a guardian and terminate the rights of others to object.  19 
3.  Appointment effective.  Subject to section 5 -203, the appointment of a guardian 20 
becomes effective upon the appointing parent's death, an adjudication that the parent is an 21 
incapacitated person or a written determination by a physician who has examined the 22 
parent that the parent is no longer able to care for the child, whichever first occurs.  23 
4.  Acceptance of appointment.  The guardian becomes eligible to act upon the 24 
filing of an acceptance of appointment, which must be filed within 30 days after the 25 
guardian's appointment becomes effective.  The guardian shall:  26 
A.  File the acceptance of app ointment and a copy of the will with the court of the 27 
county in which the will was or could be probated or, in the case of another 28 
appointing instrument, file the acceptance of appointment and the appointing 29 
instrument with the court of the county in which  the minor resides or is present; and  30 
B.  Give written notice of the acceptance of appointment to the appointing parent, if 31 
living, the minor, if the minor has attained 14 years of age, and a person other than 32 
the parent having care and custody of the mino r. 33 
5.  Notice of right to object.  Unless the appointment was previously confirmed by 34 
the court, the notice given under subsection 4, paragraph B must include a statement of 35 
the right of those notified to terminate the appointment by filing a written objec tion in the 36 
court as provided in section 5 -203. 37 
6.  Petition to confirm appointment.  Unless the appointment was previously 38 
confirmed by the court, within 30 days after filing the notice and the appointing 39 
 
 Page 191 - 128LR0452(01) -1 
 instrument, a guardian shall petition the court fo r confirmation of the appointment, giving 1 
notice in the manner provided in section 5 -205, subsection 1.  2 
7.  Parental rights not superseded; priority.  The appointment of a guardian by a 3 
parent does not supersede the parental rights of either parent.  If bo th parents are dead or 4 
have been adjudged incapacitated persons, an appointment by the last parent who died or 5 
was adjudged incapacitated has priority.  An appointment by a parent that is effected by 6 
filing the guardian's acceptance under a will probated i n the state of the testator's domicile 7 
is effective in this State.  8 
8.  Relation back of powers.  The powers of a guardian who timely complies with 9 
the requirements of subsections 4 and 6 relate back to give acts by the guardian that are of 10 
benefit to the m inor and occurred on or after the date the appointment became effective 11 
the same effect as those that occurred after the filing of the acceptance of the 12 
appointment.  13 
9.  Termination of authority.  The authority of a guardian appointed under this 14 
section te rminates upon the first to occur of the appointment of a guardian by the court or 15 
the giving of written notice to the guardian of the filing of an objection pursuant to 16 
section 5 -203. 17 
§5-203.  Objection by minor or others to parental appointment  18 
Until the court has confirmed an appointee under section 5 -202, a minor who is the 19 
subject of an appointment by a parent and who has attained 14 years of age, the other 20 
parent or a person other than a parent or guardian having care or custody of the minor 21 
may preven t or terminate the appointment at any time by filing a written objection in the 22 
court in which the appointing instrument is filed and giving notice of the objection to the 23 
guardian and any other persons entitled to notice of the acceptance of the appointme nt.  24 
An objection may be withdrawn and if withdrawn is of no effect.  The objection does not 25 
preclude judicial appointment of the person selected by the parent.  The court may treat 26 
the filing of an objection as a petition for the appointment of an emergen cy or a 27 
temporary guardian under section 5 -204 and proceed accordingly.  28 
§5-204.  Judicial appointment of guardian; conditions for appointment  29 
1.  Petition.  A minor or a person interested in the welfare of a minor may petition for 30 
appointment of a guardian . 31 
2.  Appointment.  The court may appoint a guardian for a minor if the court finds the 32 
appointment is in the minor's best interest and finds:  33 
A.  That the parents consent;  34 
B.  That all parental rights have been terminated; or  35 
C.  By clear and convincing e vidence that the parents are unwilling or unable to 36 
exercise their parental rights.  37 
3.  Priority for appointment.  If a guardian is appointed by a parent pursuant to 38 
section 5 -202 and the appointment has not been prevented or terminated under section 39 
 
 Page 192 - 128LR0452(01) -1 
 5-203, that appointee has priority for appointment.  However, the court may proceed with 1 
another appointment upon a finding that the appointee under section 5 -202 has failed to 2 
accept the appointment within 30 days after notice of the guardianship proceeding.  3 
4.  Temporary guardian.  If necessary, the court may appoint a temporary guardian, 4 
with the status of an ordinary guardian of a minor, but the authority of a temporary 5 
guardian may not last longer than 6 months, except as provided in subsection 5.  6 
Notice of  hearing on the petition for the appointment of a temporary guardian must be as 7 
provided under section 5 -111 and section 5 -205, except that the notice must be given at 8 
least 5 days before the hearing, and notice need not be given to any person whose addres s 9 
and present whereabouts are unknown and cannot be ascertained by due diligence.  Upon 10 
a showing of good cause, the court may waive service of the notice of hearing on any 11 
person, other than the minor, if the minor is at least 14 years of age.  12 
5.  Parent member of National Guard or Reserves.  If one of the parents of a 13 
minor is a member of the National Guard or the Reserves of the United States Armed 14 
Forces under an order to active duty for a period of more than 30 days, a temporary 15 
guardianship that would  otherwise expire is automatically extended until 30 days after the 16 
parent is no longer under that active duty order or until an order of the court so provides.  17 
This subsection applies only if the parent's service is in support of:  18 
A.  An operational miss ion for which members of the reserve components have been 19 
ordered to active duty without their consent; or  20 
B.  Forces activated during a period of war declared by the United States Congress or 21 
a period of national emergency declared by the President of the  United States or the 22 
United States Congress.  23 
6.  Appointment of counsel.  A nonconsenting parent whose parental rights have not 24 
been terminated is entitled to court -appointed legal counsel if indigent.  In a contested 25 
action, the court may also appoint co unsel for any indigent guardian or petitioner when a 26 
parent or legal custodian has counsel.  27 
7.  Child support.  In a proceeding on a petition for judicial appointment of a 28 
guardian, the court may order a parent to pay child support in accordance with Title  19-A, 29 
Part 3.  When the Department of Health and Human Services provides child support 30 
enforcement services, the Commissioner of Health and Human Services may designate 31 
employees of the department who are not attorneys to represent the department in court  if 32 
a hearing is held.  The commissioner shall ensure that appropriate training is provided to 33 
all employees who are designated to represent the department under this subsection.  34 
8.  Limited guardian.  If the court appoints a limited guardian, the court sh all 35 
specify the duties and powers of the guardian, as required in section 5 -108 and section 36 
5-206, and any parental rights and responsibilities retained by the parent of the minor.  37 
§5-205.  Judicial appointment of guardian; procedure  38 
1.  Petition; notice o f hearing.  After a petition for appointment of a guardian is 39 
filed, the court shall schedule a hearing, and the petitioner shall give notice of the time 40 
and place of the hearing, together with a copy of the petition, to:  41 
 
 Page 193 - 128LR0452(01) -1 
 A.  The minor, if the minor has at tained 14 years of age and is not the petitioner;  1 
B.  Any person alleged to have had the primary care and custody of the minor during 2 
the 60 days before the filing of the petition;  3 
C.  Each living parent of the minor or, if there is none, the adult nearest  in kinship 4 
who can be found;  5 
D.  Any person nominated as guardian by the minor if the minor has attained 14 years 6 
of age;  7 
E.  Any appointee of a parent whose appointment has not been prevented or 8 
terminated under section 5 -203; and  9 
F.  Any guardian or con servator currently acting for the minor in this State or 10 
elsewhere.  11 
2.  Appointment; other disposition.  The court, after the hearing scheduled pursuant 12 
to subsection 1, shall make the appointment of a guardian if the court finds that a 13 
qualified person se eks appointment, venue is proper, the required notices have been 14 
given, the conditions of section 5 -204, subsection 2 have been met and the best interest of 15 
the minor will be served by the appointment.  In other cases, the court may dismiss the 16 
proceeding or make any other disposition of the matter that will serve the best interest of 17 
the minor.  18 
3.  Court -appointed attorney.  If the court determines at any stage of the 19 
proceeding, before or after appointment, that the interests of the minor are or may be 20 
inadequately represented, the court may appoint an attorney to represent the minor, giving 21 
consideration to the choice of the minor if the minor has attained 14 years of age.  22 
§5-206.  Judicial appointment of guardian; priority of minor's nominee; limited 23 
guardianship  24 
1.  Appointment of guardian or coguardians.  The court shall appoint as guardian 25 
or coguardians of a minor a person or persons whose appointment will be in the best 26 
interest of the minor.  The court shall appoint a person or persons nominated by the 27 
minor, if the minor has attained 14 years of age, unless the court finds the appointment 28 
will be contrary to the best interest of the minor.  29 
2.  Limited powers of guardian or coguardian.  In the interest of developing self - 30 
reliance of a ward or for oth er good cause, the court, at the time of appointment or later, 31 
on the court's own motion or on motion of the minor or other interested person, may limit 32 
the powers of a guardian or coguardian otherwise granted by this Part and thereby create 33 
a limited guar dianship.  Following the same procedure, the court may grant additional 34 
powers or withdraw powers previously granted.  35 
§5-207.  Duties of guardian  36 
1.  Duties and responsibilities of a parent.  Except as otherwise limited by the 37 
court, a guardian of a minor ward has the duties and responsibilities of a parent regarding 38 
the ward's support, care, education, health and welfare.  A guardian shall act at all times 39 
in the ward's best interest and exercise reasonable care, diligence and prudence.  40 
 
 Page 194 - 128LR0452(01) -1 
 2.  Specific duties  and responsibilities.  A guardian shall:  1 
A.  Become or remain personally acquainted with the ward and maintain sufficient 2 
contact with the ward to know of the ward's capacities, limitations, needs, 3 
opportunities and physical and mental health;  4 
B.  Take re asonable care of the ward's personal effects and bring a protective 5 
proceeding if necessary to protect other property of the ward;  6 
C.  Expend money of the ward that has been received by the guardian for the ward's 7 
current needs for support, care, education , health and welfare;  8 
D.  Conserve any excess money of the ward for the ward's future needs, but if a 9 
conservator has been appointed for the estate of the ward, the guardian shall pay the 10 
money at least quarterly to the conservator to be conserved for the ward's future 11 
needs;  12 
E.  Report the condition of the ward and account for money and other assets in the 13 
guardian's possession or subject to the guardian's control, as ordered by the court on 14 
application of any person interested in the ward's welfare or as required by court rule; 15 
and 16 
F.  Inform the court of any change in the ward's custodial dwelling or address.  17 
§5-208.  Powers of guardian  18 
1.  Powers of a parent.  Except as otherwise limited by the court, a guardian of a 19 
minor ward has the powers of a parent  regarding the ward's support, care, education, 20 
health and welfare.  21 
2.  Specific powers.  A guardian may:  22 
A.  Apply for and receive money for the support of the ward otherwise payable to the 23 
ward's parent, guardian or custodian under the terms of any statu tory system of 24 
benefits or insurance or any private contract, devise, trust, conservatorship or 25 
custodianship;  26 
B.  If otherwise consistent with the terms of any order by a court of competent 27 
jurisdiction relating to custody of the ward, take custody of the  ward and establish the 28 
ward's place of custodial dwelling, but may establish or move the ward's custodial 29 
dwelling outside the State only upon express authorization of the court;  30 
C.  If a conservator for the estate of a ward has not been appointed with ex isting 31 
authority, commence a proceeding, including an administrative proceeding, or take 32 
other appropriate action to compel a person to support the ward or to pay money for 33 
the benefit of the ward;  34 
D.  Except as limited by section 5 -707, consent to medical  or other care, treatment or 35 
service for the ward;  36 
E.  Consent to the marriage of the ward; and  37 
F.  If reasonable under all of the circumstances, delegate to the ward certain 38 
responsibilities for decisions affecting the ward's well -being.  39 
 
 Page 195 - 128LR0452(01) -1 
 3.  Consent to ad option.  The court may specifically authorize the guardian to 1 
consent to the adoption of the ward.  2 
4.  Powers of coguardians.  If coguardians are appointed, the powers of the 3 
guardians are joint and several, unless limited by the appointing document.  4 
§5-209.  Rights and immunities of guardian  5 
1.  Reasonable compensation and reimbursement.  A guardian is entitled to 6 
reasonable compensation for services as guardian and to reimbursement for room, board 7 
and clothing provided by the guardian to the ward, but onl y as approved by the court.  If a 8 
conservator, other than the guardian or a person who is affiliated with the guardian, has 9 
been appointed for the estate of the ward, reasonable compensation and reimbursement to 10 
the guardian may be approved and paid by the  conservator without order of the court.  11 
2.  Personal liability.  A guardian need not use the guardian's personal funds for the 12 
ward's expenses.  A guardian is not liable to a 3rd person for acts of the ward solely by 13 
reason of the guardianship.  A guardia n is not liable for injury to the ward resulting from 14 
the negligence or act of a 3rd person providing medical or other care, treatment or service 15 
for the ward except to the extent that a parent would be liable under the circumstances.  16 
§5-210.  Termination of guardianship; other proceedings after appointment  17 
1.  Termination of guardianship.  A guardianship of a minor terminates upon the 18 
minor's death, adoption, emancipation, marriage or attainment of majority or as ordered 19 
by the court.  20 
2.  Petition for orde r.  A ward or a person interested in the welfare of a ward may 21 
petition for any order that is in the best interest of the ward.  The petitioner shall give 22 
notice of the hearing on the petition to the ward, if the ward has attained 14 years of age 23 
and is no t the petitioner, the guardian and any other person as ordered by the court.  24 
§5-211.  Transitional arrangement for minors  25 
In issuing, modifying or terminating an order of guardianship for a minor, the court 26 
may enter an order providing for transitional arr angements for the minor if the court 27 
determines that such arrangements will assist the minor with a transition of custody and 28 
are in the best interest of the minor.  Orders providing for transitional arrangements may 29 
include, but are not limited to, rights  of contact, housing, counseling or rehabilitation.  30 
PART 3  31 
GUARDIANSHIP OF INCA PACITATED PERSON  32 
§5-301.  Appointment and status of guardian  33 
A person becomes a guardian of an incapacitated person by a parental, spousal or 34 
domestic partner appointment or upo n appointment by the court.  The guardianship 35 
continues until terminated, without regard to the location of the guardian or ward.  36 
 
 Page 196 - 128LR0452(01) -1 
 §5-302.  Appointment of guardian by will or other writing  1 
1.  Appointment by parent.  A parent, by will or other signed writin g, may appoint a 2 
guardian for an unmarried child who the parent believes is an incapacitated person, 3 
specify desired limitations on the powers to be given to the guardian and revoke or amend 4 
the appointment before confirmation by the court.  5 
2.  Appointment  by spouse or domestic partner.  An individual, by will or other 6 
signed writing, may appoint a guardian for the individual's spouse or domestic partner 7 
who the appointing spouse or domestic partner believes is an incapacitated person, 8 
specify desired limit ations on the powers to be given to the guardian and revoke or amend 9 
the appointment before confirmation by the court.  10 
3.  Written objection; petition for emergency, limited or unlimited guardian.  11 
The incapacitated person, the person having care or custod y of the incapacitated person if 12 
other than the appointing parent, spouse or domestic partner or the adult nearest in 13 
kinship to the incapacitated person may file a written objection to an appointment, unless 14 
the court has confirmed the appointment under s ubsection 4.  The filing of the written 15 
objection terminates the appointment.  An objection may be withdrawn and, if 16 
withdrawn, is of no effect.  The objection does not preclude judicial appointment of the 17 
person selected by the parent, spouse or domestic partner.  Notice of the objection must 18 
be given to the guardian and any other person entitled to notice of the acceptance of the 19 
appointment.  The court may treat the filing of an objection as a petition for the 20 
appointment of an emergency guardian under s ection 5 -312 or for the appointment of a 21 
limited or unlimited guardian under section 5 -304 and proceed accordingly.  22 
4.  Court confirmation of certain appointees' selection of successor.  Upon 23 
petition of the appointing parent, spouse or domestic partner an d a finding that the 24 
appointing parent, spouse or domestic partner will likely become unable to care for the 25 
incapacitated person within 2 years and after notice as provided in this section, the court, 26 
before the appointment becomes effective, may confirm the appointing parent's, spouse's 27 
or domestic partner's selection of a guardian and terminate the rights of others to object.  28 
§5-303.  Appointment of guardian by will or other writing; effectiveness; 29 
acceptance; confirmation  30 
1.  Appointment effective.  The appointment of a guardian under section 5 -302 31 
becomes effective upon the death of the appointing parent, spouse or domestic partner, 32 
the adjudication of incapacity of the appointing parent, spouse or domestic partner or a 33 
written determination by a physic ian who has examined the appointing parent, spouse or 34 
domestic partner that the appointing parent, spouse or domestic partner is no longer able 35 
to care for the incapacitated person, whichever first occurs.  36 
2.  Acceptance of appointment.  A guardian appoint ed under section 5 -302 becomes 37 
eligible to act upon the filing of an acceptance of appointment, which must be filed within 38 
30 days after the guardian's appointment becomes effective.  The guardian shall:  39 
A.  File the notice of acceptance of appointment and  a copy of the will with the court 40 
of the county in which the will was or could be probated or, in the case of another 41 
 
 Page 197 - 128LR0452(01) -1 
 appointing instrument, file the acceptance of appointment and the appointing 1 
instrument with the court in the county in which the incapac itated person resides or is 2 
present; and  3 
B.  Give written notice of the acceptance of appointment to the appointing parent, 4 
spouse or domestic partner, if living, the incapacitated person, a person having care 5 
or custody of the incapacitated person other t han the appointing parent, spouse or 6 
domestic partner and the adult nearest in kinship.  7 
3.  Notice of right to object.  Unless the appointment was previously confirmed by 8 
the court, the notice given under subsection 2, paragraph B must include a statement of 9 
the right of those notified to terminate the appointment by filing a written objection as 10 
provided in section 5 -302. 11 
4.  Acceptance under will probated in another state.  An appointment effected by 12 
filing the guardian's acceptance under a will probated in the state of the testator's domicile 13 
is effective in this State.  14 
5.  Petition to confirm appointment.  Unless the appointment was previously 15 
confirmed by the court, within 30 days after filing the notice and the appointing 16 
instrument, a guardian appoint ed under section 5 -302 shall file a petition in the court for 17 
confirmation of the appointment.  Notice of the filing must be given in the manner 18 
provided in section 5 -309. 19 
6.  Termination of authority.  The authority of a guardian appointed under section 20 
5-302 terminates upon the appointment of a guardian by the court or the giving of written 21 
notice to the guardian of the filing of an objection pursuant to section 5 -302, whichever 22 
first occurs.  23 
7.  Appointment not a determination of incapacity.  The appoint ment of a guardian 24 
under this section is not a determination of incapacity.  25 
8.  Relation back of powers.  The powers of a guardian who timely complies with 26 
the requirements of subsections 2 and 5 relate back to give acts by the guardian that are of 27 
benefit  to the incapacitated person and occurred on or after the date the appointment 28 
became effective the same effect as those that occurred after the filing of the acceptance 29 
of appointment.  30 
§5-304.  Judicial appointment of guardian; petition  31 
1.  Petition for d etermination of incapacity and appointment.  An individual or a 32 
person interested in the individual's welfare may petition for a determination of 33 
incapacity, in whole or in part, and for the appointment of a limited or unlimited guardian 34 
for the individual . 35 
2.  Petition contents.  The petition under subsection 1 must set forth the petitioner's 36 
name, residence, current address if different from residence, relationship to the 37 
respondent and interest in the appointment and, to the extent known, state or contai n the 38 
following with respect to the respondent and the relief requested:  39 
 
 Page 198 - 128LR0452(01) -1 
 A.  The respondent's name, age, principal residence, current street address and, if 1 
different, the address of the dwelling in which it is proposed that the respondent will 2 
reside if t he appointment is made;  3 
B.  The name and address of the respondent's:  4 
(1)  Spouse or, if the respondent has none, an adult with whom the respondent 5 
has resided for more than 6 months before the filing of the petition; and  6 
(2)  Adult children or, if the res pondent has none, the respondent's parents and 7 
adult brothers and sisters or, if the respondent has none, at least one of the adults 8 
nearest in kinship to the respondent who can be found or, if none, an adult friend 9 
if any can be found;  10 
C.  The name and ad dress of any person responsible for care or custody of the 11 
respondent;  12 
D.  The name and address of any legal representative of the respondent;  13 
E.  The name and address of any person nominated as guardian by the respondent;  14 
F.  The name and address of any p roposed guardian and the reason why the proposed 15 
guardian should be selected;  16 
G.  The reason why guardianship is necessary, including a brief description of the 17 
nature and extent of the respondent's alleged incapacity;  18 
H.  If an unlimited guardianship is r equested, the reason why limited guardianship is 19 
inappropriate and, if a limited guardianship is requested, the powers to be granted to 20 
the limited guardian; and  21 
I.  A general statement of the respondent's property with an estimate of its value, 22 
including any insurance or pension, and the source and amount of any other 23 
anticipated income or receipts.  24 
3.  Plan.  The person nominated or proposed to serve as guardian shall file a plan 25 
that, as relevant, must include, but is not limited to, the type of proposed  living 26 
arrangement for the respondent, how the respondent's financial needs will be met, how 27 
the respondent's medical and other remedial needs will be met and how the respondent's 28 
social needs will be met and a plan for the respondent's continuing contact  with relatives 29 
and friends.  30 
4.  Examination of respondent; report to court.  The respondent must be examined 31 
by a physician, a psychologist or other individual who is qualified to evaluate the 32 
respondent's alleged impairment.  The person who examines the respondent shall submit 33 
a report in writing to the court, providing diagnoses, a description of the respondent's 34 
actual mental and functional limitations, including the ability to receive and evaluate 35 
information, make decisions and communicate decisions, and prognoses.  36 
§5-305.  Judicial appointment of guardian; preliminaries to hearing  37 
1.  Hearing date; appointment of visitor.  Upon receipt of a petition to establish a 38 
guardianship, the court shall set a date and time for hearing the petition and appoint a  39 
visitor.  The duties and reporting requirements of the visitor are limited to the relief 40 
 
 Page 199 - 128LR0452(01) -1 
 requested in the petition.  The visitor must be an individual having training or experience 1 
in the type of incapacity alleged.  2 
2.  Court -appointed attorney.  The cour t shall appoint an attorney to represent the 3 
respondent in the proceeding if:  4 
A.  Requested by the respondent;  5 
B.  Recommended by the visitor; or  6 
C.  The court determines that the respondent needs representation.  7 
3.  Duties of visitor.  The visitor shall i nterview the respondent in person outside the 8 
presence of the person or persons seeking guardianship and, to the extent that the 9 
respondent is able to understand:  10 
A.  Explain to the respondent the substance of the petition, the nature, purpose and 11 
effect o f the proceeding, the respondent's rights at the hearing and the general powers 12 
and duties of a guardian;  13
