B.  Determine the respondent's views about the proposed guardian, the proposed 14 
guardian's powers and duties and the scope and duration of the proposed  15 
guardianship;  16 
C.  Inform the respondent of the right to employ and consult with an attorney at the 17 
respondent's own expense and the right to request a court -appointed attorney; and  18 
D.  Inform the respondent that all costs and expenses of the proceeding, i ncluding 19 
respondent's attorney's fees, will be paid from the respondent's estate.  20 
4.  Additional duties of visitor.  In addition to the duties imposed by subsection 3, 21 
the visitor shall:  22 
A.  Interview the petitioner and the proposed guardian;  23 
B.  Visit the  respondent's present dwelling and any dwelling in which the respondent 24 
will live if the appointment is made;  25 
C.  Obtain information from any physician or other person who is known to have 26 
treated, advised or assessed the respondent's relevant physical or mental condition; 27 
and 28 
D.  Make any other investigation the court directs.  29 
5.  Report to court.  The visitor shall promptly file a report in writing with the court, 30 
which must include:  31 
A.  A recommendation as to whether an attorney should be appointed to re present the 32 
respondent;  33 
B.  The respondent's medical conditions, cognitive functioning, everyday functioning, 34 
values and preferences, risks and levels of supervision needed and any means to 35 
enhance the respondent's capacity;  36 
 
 Page 200 - 128LR0452(01) -1 
 C.  A statement of the qualific ations of the proposed guardian, together with a 1 
statement as to whether the respondent approves or disapproves of the proposed 2 
guardian, and the powers and duties proposed or the scope of the guardianship;  3 
D.  A statement as to whether the proposed dwelli ng meets the respondent's 4 
individual needs;  5 
E.  A recommendation as to whether a professional evaluation or further evaluation is 6 
necessary; and  7 
F.  Any other matters the court directs.  8 
§5-306.  Judicial appointment of guardian; professional evaluation  9 
At or before a hearing under this Part, the court may order a professional evaluation 10 
of the respondent and shall order the evaluation if the respondent so demands or if 11 
necessary to satisfy the requirements of section 5 -304, subsection 4.  The cost of the 12 
evaluation must be paid from the estate of the allegedly incapacitated person if the court 13 
is satisfied sufficient funds are available.  If the court orders the evaluation, the 14 
respondent must be examined by a physician, psychologist or other individual appo inted 15 
by the court who is qualified to evaluate the respondent's alleged impairment.  The 16 
examiner shall promptly file a written report with the court.  Unless otherwise directed by 17 
the court, the report must contain:  18 
1.  Description of cognitive and funct ional limitations.  A description of the nature, 19 
type and extent of the respondent's specific cognitive and functional limitations, including 20 
the ability to receive and evaluate information, make decisions and communicate 21 
decisions;  22 
2.  Evaluation of menta l and physical condition; additional evaluations.  An 23 
evaluation of the respondent's mental and physical condition and, if appropriate, 24 
educational potential, adaptive behavior and social skills;  25 
3.  Prognosis; recommendation.  A prognosis for improvement and a 26 
recommendation as to the appropriate treatment or habilitation plan; and  27 
4.  Date of assessment or examination.  The date of any assessment or examination 28 
upon which the report is based.  29 
§5-307.  Confidentiality of records  30 
The written report of a vis itor under section 5 -305 and any professional evaluation 31 
under section 5 -306 are confidential and must be sealed upon filing.  The person who 32 
files the visitor's report or a professional evaluation must provide notice of filing and a 33 
copy of the report or evaluation to the respondent at the time of filing.  34 
1.  Copies available without limitation.  Copies of the report under section 5 -305 or 35 
evaluation under section 5 -306 are available to:  36 
A.  The court; and  37 
B.  The respondent without limitation as to use.  38 
 
 Page 201 - 128LR0452(01) -1 
 2.  Copies available with limitations; objection by respondent.  Unless the 1 
respondent files an objection with the court within 10 days of receiving a copy of the 2 
report or evaluation under subsection 1, with a showing of good cause, copies of the 3 
report ar e available to:  4 
A.  The petitioner, the visitor and the petitioner's and respondent's attorneys for 5 
purposes of the proceeding; and  6 
B.  Other persons for such purposes as the court may order for good cause.  7 
§5-308.  Judicial appointment of guardian; presen ce and rights at hearing  8 
1.  Attendance; rights.  Unless excused by the court for good cause, the proposed 9 
guardian shall attend the hearing.  In contested proceedings, the respondent and witnesses 10 
shall attend the hearing in person, unless excused by the court for good cause.  The 11 
respondent may present evidence and subpoena witnesses and documents; examine 12 
witnesses, including any court -appointed physician, psychologist or other individual 13 
qualified to evaluate the alleged impairment, and the visitor; and  otherwise participate in 14 
the hearing.  The hearing may be held in a location convenient to the respondent or may 15 
be held by telephonic or other electronic conferencing and may be closed upon the 16 
request of the respondent and a showing of good cause.  The court may allow any 17 
interested person to attend a hearing by telephonic or other electronic conferencing, 18 
subject however to the requirement that in contested cases the respondent and witnesses 19 
shall attend in person unless excused by the court for good ca use. 20 
2.  Permission to participate.  Any person may request permission to participate in 21 
the proceeding.  The court may grant the request, with or without hearing, upon 22 
determining that the best interest of the respondent will be served.  The court may att ach 23 
appropriate conditions to the participation.  24 
§5-309.  Notice  25 
1.  Served personally on respondent; notice contents; failure.  A copy of a petition 26 
for guardianship and notice of the hearing on the petition must be served personally on 27 
the respondent.  T he notice must:  28 
A.  Include a statement informing the respondent of the respondent's right to attend 29 
the hearing in uncontested proceedings and of the respondent's obligation to be 30 
present at the hearing in contested proceedings unless excused by the court ; 31 
B.  Inform the respondent of the respondent's rights at the hearing; and  32 
C.  Include a description of the nature, purpose and consequences of an appointment.  33 
A failure to serve the respondent with a notice substantially complying with this 34 
subsection pre cludes the court from granting the petition.  35 
2.  Notice to persons in petition.  In a proceeding to establish a guardianship, notice 36 
of the hearing must be given to the persons listed in the petition.  Failure to give notice 37 
under this subsection does not preclude the appointment of a guardian or the making of a 38 
protective order.  39 
 
 Page 202 - 128LR0452(01) -1 
 3.  Notice on petition for order after appointment.  Notice of the hearing on a 1 
petition for an order after appointment of a guardian, together with a copy of the petition, 2 
must be  given to the ward, the guardian and any other person the court directs.  3 
4.  Notice and copy of report.  A guardian shall give notice of the filing of the 4 
guardian's report, together with a copy of the report, to the ward and any other person the 5 
court dir ects.  The notice must be delivered or sent within 14 days after the filing of the 6 
report.  7 
§5-310.  Who may be guardian; priorities  8 
1.  Priority for appointment.  Subject to subsection 3, the court in appointing a 9 
guardian shall consider persons otherwise qualified in the following order of priority:  10 
A.  A guardian, other than a temporary or emergency guardian, currently acting for 11 
the respondent in this State or elsewhere;  12 
B.  A person nominated as guardian by the respondent, including the respondent's 13 
most recent nomination made in a durable power of attorney, if at the time of the 14 
nomination the respondent had sufficient capacity to express a preference;  15 
C.  An agent appointed by the respondent under the Uniform Health Care Decisions 16 
Act; 17 
D.  The spouse o r domestic partner of the respondent or an individual nominated by 18 
will or other signed writing of a deceased spouse or deceased domestic partner;  19 
E.  An adult child of the respondent;  20 
F.  A parent of the respondent or an individual nominated by will or ot her signed 21 
writing of a deceased parent;  22 
G.  An adult with whom the respondent has resided for more than 6 months before 23 
the filing of the petition; and  24 
H.  A person nominated by the person who is caring for the respondent or paying 25 
benefits to the respond ent. 26 
2.  Equal priority.  With respect to persons having equal priority pursuant to 27 
subsection 1, the court shall select the one the court considers best qualified.  The court, 28 
acting in the best interest of the respondent, may decline to appoint a person having 29 
priority and appoint a person having a lower priority or no priority.  30 
3.  Disqualification; exception.  An owner, operator or employee of a long -term care 31 
institution at which a respondent is receiving care may not be appointed as guardian 32 
unless re lated to the respondent by blood, marriage or adoption or unless a domestic 33 
partner of the respondent.  34 
§5-311.  Findings; order of appointment  35 
1.  Required findings for appointment; protective order.  The court may:  36 
A.  Appoint a limited or unlimited guard ian or coguardians for a respondent only if 37 
the court finds by clear and convincing evidence that:  38 
 
 Page 203 - 128LR0452(01) -1 
 (1)  The respondent is an incapacitated person;  1 
(2)  The respondent's identified needs cannot be met by less restrictive means, 2 
including use of reasonably a vailable appropriate technological assistance; and  3 
(3)  The appointment is necessary or desirable; or  4 
B.  With appropriate findings, treat the petition as one for a protective order under 5 
section 5 -401, enter any other appropriate order or dismiss the proc eeding.  6 
2.  Limited guardian unless specific findings.  The court shall appoint a limited 7 
guardian unless the court makes specific findings why the appointment of an unlimited 8 
guardian is appropriate and grant to a guardian only those powers necessitated b y the 9 
ward's limitations and demonstrated needs and make appointive and other orders that will 10 
encourage the development of the ward's maximum self -reliance and independence.  11 
3.  Copy of order of appointment and right to request termination or 12 
modification .  Within 14 days after an appointment, a guardian shall send or deliver to 13 
the ward and to all other persons given notice of the hearing on the petition a copy of the 14 
order of appointment, together with a notice of the right to request termination or 15 
modi fication.  16 
§5-312.  Emergency guardian  17 
1.  Petition; appointment.  If the court finds that compliance with the procedures of 18 
this Part will likely result in substantial harm to a respondent's health, safety or welfare, 19 
and that no other person appears to ha ve authority and willingness to act in the 20 
circumstances, the court, on petition by a person interested in the respondent's welfare, 21 
may appoint an emergency guardian whose authority may not exceed 6 months and who 22 
may exercise only the powers specified in  the order.  A petition for emergency 23 
guardianship must be accompanied by an affidavit that sets forth the factual basis for the 24 
emergency and the specific powers requested by the proposed guardian.  25 
2.  Notice before petition.  Prior to filing a petition u nder this section, notice must be 26 
provided as follows.  27 
A.  The petitioner shall provide notice orally or in writing to the following:  28 
(1)  The allegedly incapacitated person and the person's spouse, parents, adult 29 
children and any domestic partner known to  the court;  30 
(2)  Any person who is serving as guardian or conservator or who has care and 31 
custody of the allegedly incapacitated person; and  32 
(3)  In case no other person is notified under subparagraph (1), at least one of the 33 
closest adult relatives of the  allegedly incapacitated person or, if none, an adult 34 
friend, if any can be found.  35 
B.  Notice under paragraph A must include the following information:  36 
(1)  The temporary authority that the petitioner is requesting;  37 
(2)  Location and telephone number of th e court in which the petition is being 38 
filed; and  39 
 
 Page 204 - 128LR0452(01) -1 
 (3)  The name of the petitioner and the intended date of filing.  1 
C.  The petitioner shall state in the affidavit required under this subsection the date, 2 
time, location and method of providing the required notice under paragraph A and to 3 
whom the notice was provided.  The court shall make a determination as to the 4 
adequacy of the method of providing notice and whether the petitioner complied with 5 
the notice requirements of this subsection.  The requirements of section 5 -309 do not 6 
apply to this section.  7 
D.  Notice is not required under this subsection in the following circumstances:  8 
(1)  Giving notice would place the allegedly incapacitated person at substantial 9 
risk of abuse, neglect or exploitation;  10 
(2)  No tice, if provided, would not be effective; or  11 
(3)  The court determines that there is good cause not to provide notice.  12 
E.  If, prior to filing the petition, the petitioner did not provide notice as required 13 
under this subsection, the petitioner must state  in the affidavit the reasons for not 14 
providing notice.  If notice has not been provided, the court shall make a 15 
determination as to the sufficiency of the reason for not providing notice before 16 
issuing a temporary order.  17 
3.  Reasonable notice of hearing.  Except as otherwise provided in subsection 4, 18 
reasonable notice of the time and place of a hearing on the petition must be given to the 19 
respondent and the respondent's spouse, parents, adult children, any domestic partner 20 
known to the court and any other persons as the court directs.  21 
4.  Notice after appointment of emergency guardian.  If the court appoints an 22 
emergency guardian without notice as provided in subsection 2, notice of the appointment 23 
must be given within 48 hours after the appointment to the persons specified in 24 
subsection 2.  25 
5.  Visitor; duties of visitor; rights of respondent; report to court.  If the court 26 
takes action to appoint an emergency guardian, then the court, within 2 days, excluding 27 
Saturdays, Sundays and legal holidays, of taking  the action, shall appoint a visitor or 28 
guardian ad litem to visit the respondent and make a report to the court within 10 days of 29 
the appointment of the visitor or guardian ad litem.  The visitor or guardian ad litem shall 30 
serve the respondent with a copy  of the order appointing the emergency guardian and 31 
shall explain the meaning and consequences of the appointment.  The visitor or guardian 32 
ad litem shall inquire of the respondent whether that person wishes to contest any aspect 33 
of the emergency guardians hip or seek any limitation of the emergency guardian's 34 
powers.  The visitor or guardian ad litem shall advise the respondent of that person's right 35 
to be represented in the proceeding by counsel of that person's own choice or by counsel 36 
appointed by the co urt.  The visitor or guardian ad litem shall also interview the 37 
emergency guardian, except in cases where the court itself has taken action to exercise 38 
the powers of an emergency guardian.  In the report to the court, the visitor or guardian 39 
ad litem shall  inform the court that the respondent has received a copy of the order 40 
appointing the emergency guardian.  The visitor or guardian ad litem shall advise the 41 
court if circumstances indicate the respondent wishes to contest any aspect of the 42 
 
 Page 205 - 128LR0452(01) -1 
 emergency guardi anship or seek a limitation of the emergency guardian's powers and 1 
whether the respondent is already represented by counsel.  The visitor or guardian ad 2 
litem shall also advise the court whether any issue exists with respect to whether the 3 
appointment of t he emergency guardian is in the respondent's best interest.  4 
6.  Expedited hearing on appropriateness of appointment.  If it comes to the 5 
court's attention, through the report of the visitor or guardian ad litem or otherwise, that 6 
the respondent wishes to c ontest any aspect of the emergency guardianship or seek a 7 
limitation of the emergency guardian's powers, or that an issue exists with respect to 8 
whether the emergency guardianship is in the respondent's best interest, the court shall 9 
hold an expedited hear ing on the appropriateness of the appointment within 40 days after 10 
the appointment.  The court may continue the expedited hearing if the petitioner and the 11 
attorney for the respondent, or, if there is no attorney, the visitor or the guardian ad litem, 12 
agree to such a continuance.  The court may continue the hearing on its own motion due 13 
to circumstances beyond the control of the court and the parties as long as the hearing is 14 
held within 60 days of the signing of the order.  If the appointment of a guardian  is 15 
contested by the respondent and the person is not already represented by an attorney, the 16 
court shall appoint counsel to represent the respondent in the proceeding.  The cost of the 17 
appointment of the visitor, guardian ad litem or attorney must be paid  from the estate of 18 
the respondent if the court is satisfied that sufficient funds are available.  At the hearing, 19 
the petitioner has the burden of showing by clear and convincing evidence that 20 
emergency guardianship continues to be necessary to provide th e person with continuing 21 
care, protection or support pending a final hearing.  22 
7.  Notice of expedited hearing.  Notice of the expedited hearing under subsection 6 23 
must be served as provided in section 5 -309, except that the notice must be given at least 24 
5 days before the expedited hearing, and notice need not be served on any person whose 25 
address or present whereabouts is unknown and cannot be ascertained by due diligence.  26 
The court may waive service of the notice of the expedited hearing on any person, ot her 27 
than the respondent, upon a showing of good cause.  28 
8.  Appointment not a determination of incapacity.  Appointment of an emergency 29 
guardian, with or without notice, is not a determination of the respondent's incapacity.  30 
9.  Removal of emergency guardia n.  The court may remove an emergency 31 
guardian at any time.  An emergency guardian shall make any report the court requires.  32 
In other respects, the provisions of this Article concerning guardians apply to an 33 
emergency guardian.  34 
§5-313.  Temporary substitu te guardian  35 
1.  Appointment; powers; notice.  If the court finds that a guardian is not effectively 36 
performing the guardian's duties and that the welfare of the ward requires immediate 37 
action, the court may appoint a temporary substitute guardian for the w ard for a specified 38 
period not exceeding 6 months.  Except as otherwise ordered by the court, a temporary 39 
substitute guardian so appointed has the powers set forth in the previous order of 40 
appointment, except that a temporary substitute guardian may not se ek the involuntary 41 
hospitalization of the ward in any institution outside the State.  The authority of any 42 
unlimited or limited guardian previously appointed by the court is suspended as long as a 43 
 
 Page 206 - 128LR0452(01) -1 
 temporary substitute guardian has authority.  If an appoint ment is made without previous 1 
notice to the ward or the affected guardian, the court, within 5 days after the appointment, 2 
shall inform the ward or guardian of the appointment.  3 
2.  Removal of temporary substitute guardian.  The court may remove a temporary  4 
substitute guardian at any time.  A temporary substitute guardian shall make any report 5 
the court requires.  In other respects, the provisions of this Article concerning guardians 6 
apply to a temporary substitute guardian.  7 
§5-314.  Duties of guardian  8 
1.  Decisions; best interest; reasonable care, diligence and prudence.  Except as 9 
otherwise limited by the court, a guardian shall make decisions regarding the ward's 10 
support, care, education, health and welfare.  A guardian shall exercise authority only as 11 
necessitated by the ward's limitations and, to the extent possible, shall encourage the ward 12 
to participate in decisions, act on the ward's own behalf and develop or regain the 13 
capacity to manage the ward's personal affairs.  A guardian, in making decisions, shall 14 
consider the expressed desires and personal values of the ward to the extent known to the 15 
guardian.  A guardian at all times shall act in the ward's best interest and exercise 16 
reasonable care, diligence and prudence.  17 
2.  Specific duties.  A guardian shall:  18 
A.  Become or remain personally acquainted with the ward and maintain sufficient 19 
contact with the ward to know of the ward's capacities, limitations, needs, 20 
opportunities and physical and mental health;  21 
B.  Take reasonable care of the ward's persona l effects and bring protective 22 
proceedings if necessary to protect the property of the ward;  23 
C.  Expend money of the ward that has been received by the guardian for the ward's 24 
current needs for support, care, education, health and welfare;  25 
D.  Conserve any  excess money of the ward for the ward's future needs. But if a 26 
conservator has been appointed for the estate of the ward, the guardian shall pay the 27 
money to the conservator, at least quarterly, to be conserved for the ward's future 28 
needs;  29 
E.  Immediately  notify the court if the ward's condition has changed so that the ward 30 
is capable of exercising rights previously removed; and  31 
F.  Inform the court of any change in the ward's custodial dwelling or address.  32 
§5-315.  Powers of guardian  33 
1.  Specific powers.  Except as otherwise limited by the court, a guardian may:  34 
A.  Apply for and receive money payable to the ward or the ward's guardian or 35 
custodian for the support of the ward under the terms of any statutory system of 36 
benefits or insurance or any private c ontract, devise, trust, conservatorship or 37 
custodianship;  38 
 
 Page 207 - 128LR0452(01) -1 
 B.  If otherwise consistent with the terms of any order by a court of competent 1 
jurisdiction relating to custody of the ward, take custody of the ward and establish the 2 
ward's place of custodial dwe lling, but may establish or move the ward's place of 3 
dwelling outside this State only upon express authorization of the court;  4 
C.  If a conservator for the estate of the ward has not been appointed with existing 5 
authority, commence a proceeding, including an administrative proceeding, or take 6 
other appropriate action to compel a person to support the ward or to pay money for 7 
the benefit of the ward;  8 
D.  Except as limited by section 5 -707, consent to medical or other care, treatment or 9 
service for the ward;  10 
E.  Consent to the marriage or divorce of the ward; and  11 
F.  If reasonable under all of the circumstances, delegate to the ward certain 12 
responsibilities for decisions affecting the ward's well -being.  13 
2.  Consent to adoption.  The court may specifically aut horize the guardian to 14 
consent to the adoption of the ward.  15 
3.  Powers of coguardians.  If coguardians are appointed, the powers of the 16 
guardians are joint and several, unless limited by the appointing document.  17 
§5-316.  Rights and immunities of guardian; limitations  18 
1.  Reasonable compensation and reimbursement.  A guardian is entitled to 19 
reasonable compensation for services as guardian based on the factors set forth in section 20 
3-721, subsection 2 and to reimbursement for room, board and clothing provided to the 21 
ward, but only as approved by order of the court.  If a conservator, other than the 22 
guardian or one who is affiliated with the guardian, has been appointed for the estate of 23 
the ward, reasonable compensation and reimbursement to the guardian may be approved 24 
and paid by the conservator without order of the court.  25 
2.  Personal liability.  A guardian need not use the guardian's personal funds for the 26 
ward's expenses.  A guardian is not liable to a 3rd person for acts of the ward solely by 27 
reason of the relationship.  A guardian who exercises reasonable care in choosing a 3rd 28 
person to provide medical or other care, treatment or service for the ward is not liable for 29 
injury to the ward resulting from the wrongful conduct of the 3rd party.  30 
3.  Power of att orney for health care.  A guardian, without authorization of the 31 
court, may not revoke a power of attorney for health care made pursuant to the Uniform 32 
Health Care Decisions Act of which the ward is the principal.  If a power of attorney for 33 
health care ma de pursuant to the Uniform Health Care Decisions Act is in effect, absent 34 
an order of the court to the contrary, a health care decision of the agent takes precedence 35 
over that of a guardian.  36 
4.  Commitment of ward.  A guardian may not initiate the commitme nt of a ward to 37 
a psychiatric hospital except in accordance with the State's statutes and procedure for 38 
involuntary civil commitment.  39 
 
 Page 208 - 128LR0452(01) -1 
 §5-317.  Reports; monitoring of guardianship  1 
1.  Reports; within 30 days and annually.  Within 30 days after appointment, a 2 
guardian shall report to the court in writing on the condition of the ward and account for 3 
money and other assets in the guardian's possession or subject to the guardian's control.  4 
A guardian shall report at least annually or as otherwise specified by t he court or 5 
provided by court rule.  A report must state or contain:  6 
A.  The current mental, physical and social condition of the ward;  7 
B.  The living arrangements for all addresses of the ward during the reporting period;  8 
C.  The medical, educational, voc ational and other services provided to the ward and 9 
the guardian's opinion as to the adequacy of the ward's care;  10 
D.  A summary of the guardian's visits with the ward and activities on the ward's 11 
behalf and the extent to which the ward has participated in decision making;  12 
E.  If the ward is institutionalized, whether the guardian considers the current plan for 13 
care, treatment or habilitation to be in the ward's best interest;  14 
F.  Plans for future care; and  15 
G.  A recommendation as to the need for continued g uardianship and any 16 
recommended changes in the scope of the guardianship.  17 
2.  Appoint visitor.  The court may appoint a visitor to review a report, interview the 18 
ward or guardian and make any other investigation the court directs.  19 
3.  System for monitoring  guardianships. The court may establish a system for 20 
monitoring guardianships, including the filing and review of annual reports.  21 
4.  Report as directed.  Notwithstanding the requirements of subsection 1, a 22 
guardian appointed before January 1, 2019 is requ ired to report only as directed by the 23 
court.  24 
§5-318.  Termination or modification of guardianship  25 
1.  Termination.  A guardianship terminates upon the death of the ward or upon 26 
order of the court.  27 
2.  Petition to terminate; termination or modification.  On petition of a ward, a 28 
guardian or another person interested in the ward's welfare, the court may terminate a 29 
guardianship if the ward no longer needs the assistance or protection of a guardian.  A 30 
request for this order may be made by informal letter to the court and any person who 31 
knowingly interferes with transmission of this kind of request to the court may be 32 
adjudged guilty of contempt of court.  The court may modify the type of appointment or 33 
powers granted to the guardian if the extent of protectio n or assistance previously granted 34 
is currently excessive or insufficient or the ward's capacity to provide for support, care, 35 
education, health and welfare has so changed as to warrant that action.  36 
 
 Page 209 - 128LR0452(01) -1 
 3.  Petition of guardian to resign; other order.  On peti tion of the guardian, the 1 
court may accept the guardian's resignation and make any other order that may be 2 
appropriate.  3 
4.  Petition to remove and appoint successor.  On petition of the ward or any 4 
person interested in the ward's welfare, the court may rem ove a guardian and appoint a 5 
successor if it is in the best interest of the ward.  6 
5.  Procedures.  Except as otherwise ordered by the court for good cause, the court, 7 
before terminating a guardianship or accepting the resignation of a guardian, shall follo w 8 
the same procedures to safeguard the rights of the ward as apply to a petition for 9 
guardianship.  Upon presentation by the petitioner of evidence establishing a prima facie 10 
case for termination, the court shall order the termination unless it is proven b y clear and 11 
convincing evidence that:  12 
A.  The respondent is an incapacitated person;  13 
B.  The respondent's needs cannot be met by less restrictive means, including use of 14 
appropriate reasonably available technological assistance; and  15 
C.  Continuation of the  appointment is necessary or desirable.  16 
PART 4  17 
PROTECTION OF PROPER TY OF PROTECTED PERS ON 18 
§5-401.  Protective proceeding  19 
Upon petition and after notice and hearing, the court may appoint a limited or 20 
unlimited conservator or make any other protective order  provided in this Part in relation 21 
to the estate and affairs of:  22 
1.  A minor.  A minor, if the court determines that the minor owns money or property 23 
requiring management or protection that cannot otherwise be provided or has or may 24 
have business affairs t hat may be put at risk or prevented because of the minor's age, or 25 
that money is needed for support and education and that protection is necessary or 26 
desirable to obtain or provide money; or  27 
2.  Any individual.  Any individual, including a minor, if the co urt determines that, 28 
for reasons other than age:  29 
A.  By clear and convincing evidence, the individual is unable to manage property 30 
and business affairs because of an impairment in the ability to receive and evaluate 31 
information or make or communicate infor med decisions, even with the use of 32 
reasonably available appropriate technological assistance, or because the individual is 33 
missing, detained or unable to return to the United States; and  34 
B.  By a preponderance of the evidence, the individual has property that will be 35 
wasted or dissipated unless management is provided or money is needed for the 36 
support, care, education, health and welfare of the individual or of individuals who 37 
are entitled to the individual's support and that protection is necessary or des irable to 38 
obtain or provide money.  39 
 
 Page 210 - 128LR0452(01) -1 
 If an allegedly incapacitated adult files voluntary written consent to the appointment of a 1 
conservator with the court or appears in court and consents to the appointment, unless the 2 
court finds the consent suspect, the c ourt may appoint a conservator as requested upon a 3 
finding by a preponderance of the evidence that the individual is unable to manage 4 
property and business affairs because of an impairment in the ability to receive and 5 
evaluate information or make or commu nicate informed decisions, even with the use of 6 
reasonably available appropriate technological assistance.  For the purposes of this 7 
subsection, voluntary written consent is valid only if the consent was obtained by a 8 
visitor, a guardian ad litem or an att orney representing the allegedly incapacitated person 9 
and the allegedly incapacitated person gave the consent outside the presence of the person 10 
or persons seeking conservatorship.  11 
§5-402.  Jurisdiction over business affairs of protected person  12 
After the s ervice of notice in a proceeding seeking a conservatorship or other 13 
protective order and until termination of the proceeding, the court in which the petition is 14 
filed has:  15 
1.  Determination of need.  Exclusive jurisdiction to determine the need for a 16 
conse rvatorship or other protective order;  17 
2.  Determination of how estate managed, expended or distributed.  Exclusive 18 
jurisdiction to determine how the estate of the protected person that is subject to the laws 19 
of this State must be managed, expended or distr ibuted to or for the use of the protected 20 
person, individuals who are in fact dependent upon the protected person or other 21 
claimants; and  22 
3.  Determination of claims and questions.  Concurrent jurisdiction to determine 23 
the validity of claims against the pe rson or estate of the protected person and questions of 24 
title concerning assets of the estate.  25 
§5-403.  Original petition for appointment or protective order  26 
1.  Petitioner.  The following may petition for the appointment of a conservator or 27 
for any other appropriate protective order:  28 
A.  The person to be protected;  29 
B.  An individual interested in the estate, affairs or welfare of the person to be 30 
protected, including a parent, guardian or custodian; or  31 
C.  A person who would be adversely affected by lack of effective management of 32 
the property and business affairs of the person to be protected.  33 
2.  Petition contents.  A petition under subsection 1 must set forth the petitioner's 34 
name, residence, current street address if different from residence, relations hip to the 35 
respondent and interest in the appointment or other protective order and, to the extent 36 
known, must state or contain the following with respect to the respondent and the relief 37 
requested:  38 
 
 Page 211 - 128LR0452(01) -1 
 A.  The respondent's name, age, principal residence, curr ent street address and, if 1 
different, the address of the dwelling where it is proposed that the respondent will 2 
reside if the appointment is made;  3 
B.  If the petition alleges impairment in the respondent's ability to receive and 4 
evaluate information, a bri ef description of the nature and extent of the respondent's 5 
alleged impairment;  6 
C.  If the petition alleges that the respondent is missing, detained or unable to return 7 
to the United States, a statement of the relevant circumstances, including the time and  8 
nature of the disappearance or detention and a description of any search or inquiry 9 
concerning the respondent's whereabouts;  10 
D.  The name and address of the respondent's:  11 
(1)  Spouse or, if the respondent has none, an adult with whom the respondent 12 
has re sided for more than 6 months before the filing of the petition; and  13 
(2)  Adult children or, if the respondent has none, the respondent's parents and 14 
adult brothers and sisters or, if the respondent has none, at least one of the adults 15 
nearest in kinship to  the respondent who can be found or, if none, an adult friend 16 
if any can be found;  17 
E.  The name and address of the person responsible for care or custody of the 18 
respondent;  19 
F.  The name and address of any legal representative of the respondent;  20 
G.  A gener al statement of the respondent's property with an estimate of its value, 21 
including any insurance or pension, and the source and amount of other anticipated 22 
income or receipts; and  23 
H.  The reason why a conservatorship or other protective order is in the be st interest 24 
of the respondent.  25 
3.  Conservatorship request.  If a conservatorship is requested, the petition under 26 
subsection 1 must also set forth to the extent known:  27 
A.  The name and address of any proposed conservator and the reason why the 28 
proposed co nservator should be selected;  29 
B.  The name and address of any person nominated as conservator by the respondent 30 
if the respondent has attained 14 years of age; and  31 
C.  The type of conservatorship requested and, if an unlimited conservatorship, the 32 
reason w hy limited conservatorship is inappropriate or, if a limited conservatorship, 33 
the property to be placed under the conservator's control and any limitation on the 34 
conservator's powers and duties.  35 
§5-404.  Notice  36 
1.  Notice to respondent; failure.  A copy of  a petition under section 5 -403 and the 37 
notice of hearing on a petition for conservatorship or other protective order must be 38 
served personally on the respondent, but if the respondent's whereabouts are unknown or 39 
personal service cannot be made, service o n the respondent must be made by substituted 40 
 
 Page 212 - 128LR0452(01) -1 
 service or publication.  The notice must include a statement that the respondent must be 1 
physically present unless excused by the court, inform the respondent of the respondent's 2 
rights at the hearing and, if th e appointment of a conservator is requested, include a 3 
description of the nature, purpose and consequences of an appointment.  A failure to 4 
serve the respondent with a notice substantially complying with this subsection precludes 5 
the court from granting th e petition.  6 
2.  Notice of hearing to persons listed in petition.  In a proceeding to establish a 7 
conservatorship or for another protective order, notice of the hearing must be given to the 8 
persons listed in the petition.  Failure to give notice under this subsection does not 9 
preclude the appointment of a conservator or the making of another protective order.  10 
3.  Notice to protected person; petition for order after appointment.  Notice of 11 
the hearing on a petition for an order after the appointment of a cons ervator or the making 12 
of another protective order, together with a copy of the petition, must be given to the 13 
protected person, if the protected person has attained 14 years of age and is not missing, 14 
detained or unable to return to the United States, any conservator of the protected person's 15 
estate and any other person as ordered by the court.  16 
4.  Notice of filing of inventory, report or plan.  A conservator shall give notice of 17 
the filing of the conservator's inventory, report or plan of conservatorship, together with a 18 
copy of the inventory, report or plan of conservatorship to the protected person, if the 19 
person can be located, has attained 14 years of age and has sufficient mental capacity to 20 
understand these matters, and any other person the court dire cts.  The notice must be 21 
delivered or sent within 14 days after the filing of the inventory, report or plan of 22 
conservatorship.  23 
§5-405.  Original petition; minors; preliminaries to hearing  24 
1.  Hearing; court -appointed attorney.  Upon the filing of a petiti on to establish a 25 
conservatorship or for another protective order for the reason that the respondent is a 26 
minor, the court shall set a date for hearing.  If the court determines at any stage of the 27 
proceeding that the interests of the minor are or may be i nadequately represented, it may 28 
appoint an attorney to represent the minor, giving consideration to the choice of the minor 29 
if the minor has attained 14 years of age.  30 
2.  Orders to preserve and apply property; visitor.  While a petition to establish a 31 
conservatorship or for another protective order is pending, after preliminary hearing and 32 
without notice to others, the court may make orders to preserve and apply the property of 33 
the minor as may be required for the support of the minor or individuals who are  in fact 34 
dependent upon the minor.  The court may appoint a visitor to assist in that task.  35 
§5-406.  Original petition; preliminaries to hearing  36 
1.  Hearing; visitor.  Upon the filing of a petition for a conservatorship or other 37 
protective order for a resp ondent for reasons other than being a minor, the court shall set 38 
a date for hearing.  The court shall appoint a visitor unless the petition does not request 39 
the appointment of a conservator and the respondent is represented by an attorney.  The 40 
duties and reporting requirements of the visitor are limited to the relief requested in the 41 
 
 Page 213 - 128LR0452(01) -1 
 petition.  The visitor must be an individual having training or experience in the type of 1 
incapacity alleged.  2 
2.  Court -appointed attorney.  The court shall appoint an attorne y to represent the 3 
respondent in the proceeding if:  4 
A.  Requested by the respondent;  5 
B.  Recommended by the visitor; or  6 
C.  The court determines that the respondent needs representation.  7 
3.  Visitor duties.  The visitor shall interview the respondent in pe rson and, to the 8 
extent that the respondent is able to understand:  9 
A.  Explain to the respondent the substance of the petition and the nature, purpose 10 
and effect of the proceeding;  11 
B.  If the appointment of a conservator is requested, inform the respondent  of the 12 
general powers and duties of a conservator and determine the respondent's views 13 
regarding the proposed conservator, the proposed conservator's powers and duties and 14 
the scope and duration of the proposed conservatorship;  15 
C.  Inform the respondent o f the respondent's rights, including the right to employ 16 
and consult with an attorney at the respondent's own expense and the right to request 17 
a court -appointed attorney; and  18 
D.  Inform the respondent that all costs and expenses of the proceeding, includin g the 19 
respondent's attorney's fees, will be paid from the respondent's estate.  20 
4.  Additional specific duties.  In addition to the duties imposed by subsection 3, the 21 
visitor shall:  22 
A.  Interview the petitioner and the proposed conservator, if any; and  23 
B.  Make any other investigation the court directs.  24 
5.  Report.  The visitor shall promptly file a report with the court, which must 25 
include:  26 
A.  A recommendation as to whether an attorney should be appointed to represent the 27 
respondent;  28 
B.  Recommendations r egarding the appropriateness of a conservatorship, including 29 
whether less restrictive means of intervention are available, the type of 30 
conservatorship and, if it is a limited conservatorship, the powers and duties to be 31 
granted the limited conservator and the assets over which the conservator should be 32 
granted authority;  33 
C.  A statement of the qualifications of the proposed conservator, together with a 34 
statement as to whether the respondent approves or disapproves of the proposed 35 
conservator, and a statemen t of the powers and duties proposed or the scope of the 36 
conservatorship;  37 
 
 Page 214 - 128LR0452(01) -1 
 D.  A recommendation as to whether a professional evaluation or further evaluation is 1 
necessary; and  2 
E.  Any other matters the court directs.  3 
6.  Evaluation of respondent.  The court may appoint a physician, psychologist or 4 
other individual qualified to evaluate the alleged impairment to conduct an examination 5 
of the respondent.  6 
7.  Orders to preserve and apply property; visitor.  While a petition to establish a 7 
conservatorship or for another protective order is pending, after preliminary hearing and 8 
without notice to others, the court may issue orders to preserve and apply the property of 9 
the respondent as may be required for the support of the respondent or individuals who 10 
are in fact  dependent upon the respondent.  The court may appoint a visitor to assist in 11 
that task.  12 
§5-407.  Confidentiality of records  13 
The written report of a visitor and any professional evaluation pursuant to section 14 
5-406 are confidential and must be sealed upon filing.  The person who files the visitor's 15 
report or a professional evaluation must provide notice of filing and a copy of the report 16 
or evaluation to the respondent at the time of filing.  17 
1.  Copies available.  Copies of the report or evaluation pursuant  to section 5 -406 are 18 
available to:  19 
A.  The court; and  20 
B.  The respondent without limitation as to use.  21 
2.  Copies available with limitations; objection by respondent.  Unless the 22 
respondent files an objection with the court within 10 days of receiving a c opy of the 23 
report or evaluation under subsection 1, with a showing of good cause, copies of the 24 
report or evaluation are available to:  25 
A.  The petitioner, the visitor and the petitioner's and respondent's attorneys, for 26 
purposes of the proceeding; and  27 
B.  Any persons for such purposes as the court may order for good cause.  28 
§5-408.  Original petition; procedure at hearing  29 
1.  Hearing; attendance; location.  Unless excused by the court for good cause, a 30 
proposed conservator shall attend the hearing on the pet ition under section 5 -406.  In a 31 
contested hearing, the respondent and witnesses shall attend the hearing in person, unless 32 
excused by the court for good cause.  The respondent may present evidence and subpoena 33 
witnesses and documents, examine witnesses, i ncluding any court -appointed physician, 34 
psychologist or other individual qualified to evaluate the alleged impairment, and the 35 
visitor, and otherwise participate in the hearing.  The hearing may be held in a location 36 
convenient to the respondent or may be held by telephonic or other electronic 37 
conferencing and may be closed upon request of the respondent and a showing of good 38 
cause.  The court may allow any interested person to attend a hearing by telephonic or 39 
 
 Page 215 - 128LR0452(01) -1 
 other electronic conferencing, subject however  to the requirement that in contested cases 1 
the respondent and witnesses shall attend in person unless excused by the court for good 2 
cause.  3 
2.  Permission to participate.  Any person may request permission to participate in 4 
the hearing on the petition unde r section 5 -406.  The court may grant the request, with or 5 
without hearing, upon determining that the best interest of the respondent will be served.  6 
The court may attach appropriate conditions to the participation.  7 
§5-409.  Original petition; orders  8 
1.  Minor; appointment or other protective order.  If a proceeding is brought for 9 
the reason that the respondent is a minor, after a hearing on the petition and upon finding 10 
that the appointment of a conservator or other protective order is in the best interes t of the 11 
minor, the court shall make an appointment or other appropriate protective order.  12 
2.  Least restrictive order.  If a proceeding is brought for reasons other than that the 13 
respondent is a minor, after a hearing on the petition and upon finding that  a basis exists 14 
for a conservatorship or other protective order, the court shall make the least restrictive 15 
order consistent with its findings.  The court shall make orders necessitated by the 16 
protected person's limitations and demonstrated needs, includin g appointive and other 17 
orders that will encourage the development of maximum self -reliance and independence 18 
of the protected person.  19 
3.  Order of appointment; right to seek termination or modification.  Within 14 20 
days after an appointment, the conservator shall deliver or send a copy of the order of 21 
appointment, together with a statement of the right to seek termination or modification, to 22 
the protected person, if the protected person has attained 14 years of age and is not 23 
missing, detained or unable to re turn to the United States, and to all other persons given 24 
notice of the petition.  25 
4.  Appointment or protective order not a determination of incapacity.  The 26 
appointment of a conservator or the entry of another protective order is not a 27 
determination of in capacity of the protected person.  28 
§5-410.  Powers of court  29 
1.  Powers of court; directly or through conservator.  After hearing and upon 30 
determining that a basis for a conservatorship or other protective order exists, the court 31 
has the following powers, wh ich may be exercised directly or through a conservator:  32 
A.  With respect to a minor for reasons of age, all the powers over the estate and 33 
business affairs of the minor that may be necessary for the best interest of the minor 34 
and members of the minor's imm ediate family; and  35 
B.  With respect to an adult, or to a minor for reasons other than age, for the benefit 36 
of the protected person and individuals who are in fact dependent on the protected 37 
person for support, all the powers over the estate and business af fairs of the protected 38 
person that the protected person could exercise if the protected person were an adult, 39 
present and not under conservatorship or other protective order.  40 
 
 Page 216 - 128LR0452(01) -1 
 2.  Limitation of powers.  Subject to section 5 -108 which requires endorsement of  1 
limitations on the letters of appointment, the court may limit at any time the powers of a 2 
conservator otherwise conferred and may remove or modify any limitation.  3 
§5-411.  Required court approval  4 
1.  Powers with express authorization.  After notice to in terested persons and upon 5 
express authorization of the court, a conservator may:  6 
A.  Make gifts not otherwise authorized in section 5 -427, subsection 2;  7 
B.  Convey, release or disclaim contingent and expectant interests in property, 8 
including marital prope rty rights and any right of survivorship incident to joint 9 
tenancy or tenancy by the entireties;  10 
C.  Exercise or release a power of appointment;  11 
D.  Create a revocable or irrevocable trust of property of the estate, whether or not the 12 
trust extends beyond the duration of the conservatorship, or revoke or amend a trust 13 
revocable by the protected person;  14 
E.  Exercise rights to elect options and change beneficiaries under insurance policies 15 
and annuities or surrender the policies and annuities for their cash v alue;  16 
F.  Exercise any right to an elective share in the estate of the protected person's 17 
deceased spouse and to renounce or disclaim any interest by testate or intestate 18 
succession or by transfer inter vivos; and  19 
G.  Make, amend or revoke the protected pe rson's will.  20 
2.  Protected person's will.  A conservator, in making, amending or revoking the 21 
protected person's will, shall comply with section 2 -502 on the execution of wills.  22 
3.  Court considerations.  The court, in exercising or in approving a conserva tor's 23 
exercise of the powers listed in subsection 1, shall consider primarily the decision that the 24 
protected person would have made, to the extent that the decision can be ascertained.  25 
The court shall also consider:  26 
A.  The financial needs of the protect ed person and the needs of individuals who are 27 
in fact dependent on the protected person for support and the interest of creditors;  28 
B.  Possible reduction of income, estate, inheritance or other tax liabilities;  29 
C.  Eligibility for governmental assistance;  30 
D.  The protected person's previous pattern of giving or level of support;  31 
E.  The existing estate plan;  32 
F.  The protected person's life expectancy and the probability that the conservatorship 33 
will terminate before the protected person's death; and  34 
G.  Any other factors the court considers relevant.  35 
4.  Durable power of attorney.  Without authorization of the court, a conservator 36 
may not revoke or amend a durable power of attorney of which the protected person is the 37 
 
 Page 217 - 128LR0452(01) -1 
 principal.  If a durable power of attor ney is in effect, absent a court order to the contrary, 1 
a decision of the agent takes precedence over that of a conservator.  2 
§5-412.  Protective arrangements and single transactions  3 
1.  Protective order.  If a basis is established for a protective order wi th respect to an 4 
individual, the court, without appointing a conservator, may:  5 
A.  Authorize, direct or ratify any transaction necessary or desirable to achieve any 6 
arrangement for security, service or care meeting the foreseeable needs of the 7 
protected pe rson, including:  8 
(1)  Payment, delivery, deposit or retention of funds or property;  9 
(2)  Sale, mortgage, lease or other transfer of property;  10 
(3)  Purchase of an annuity;  11 
(4)  Making a contract for life care, deposit contract or contract for training and 12 
education; or  13 
(5)  Addition to or establishment of a suitable trust; and  14 
B.  Authorize, direct or ratify any other contract, trust, will or transaction relating to 15 
the protected person's property and business affairs, including a settlement of a claim, 16 
upon  determining that it is in the best interest of the protected person.  17 
2.  Court considerations.  In deciding whether to approve a protective arrangement 18 
or other transaction under this section, the court shall consider the factors described in 19 
section 5 -411, subsection 3.  20 
3.  Visitor.  The court may appoint a visitor to assist in the accomplishment of any 21 
protective arrangement or other transaction authorized under this section.  The visitor has 22 
the authority conferred by the order and shall serve until dis charged by order after report 23 
to the court.  24 
§5-413.  Who may be conservator; priorities  25 
1.  Priority.  Except as otherwise provided in subsection 4, the court, in appointing a 26 
conservator, shall consider persons otherwise qualified in the following order o f priority:  27 
A.  A conservator, guardian of the estate or other like fiduciary appointed or 28 
recognized by an appropriate court of any other jurisdiction in which the protected 29 
person resides;  30 
B.  A person nominated as conservator by the respondent, includin g the respondent's 31 
most recent nomination made in a durable power of attorney, if the respondent has 32 
attained 14 years of age and at the time of the nomination had sufficient capacity to 33 
express a preference;  34 
C.  An agent appointed by the respondent to man age the respondent's property under 35 
a durable power of attorney;  36 
D.  The spouse of the respondent;  37 
 
 Page 218 - 128LR0452(01) -1 
 E.  An adult child of the respondent;  1 
F.  A parent of the respondent; and  2 
G.  An adult with whom the respondent has resided for more than 6 months before 3 
the filing of the petition.  4 
2.  Transfer priority.  A person having priority under subsection 1, paragraph A, D, 5 
E or F may designate in writing a substitute to serve instead and thereby transfer the 6 
priority to the substitute.  7 
3.  Equal priority.  With respe ct to persons having equal priority, the court shall 8 
select the one it considers best qualified.  The court, acting in the best interest of the 9 
protected person, may decline to appoint a person having priority and appoint a person 10 
having a lower priority o r no priority.  11 
4.  Disqualification; exception.  An owner, operator or employee of a long -term care 12 
facility or institution at which the respondent is receiving care may not be appointed as 13 
conservator unless related to the respondent by blood, marriage or  adoption.  14 
§5-414.  Petition for order subsequent to appointment  15 
1.  Petition for order.  A protected person or a person interested in the welfare of a 16 
protected person may file a petition in the appointing court for an order:  17 
A.  Requiring bond or collate ral, or additional bond or collateral, or reducing bond;  18 
B.  Requiring an accounting for the administration of the protected person's estate;  19 
C.  Directing distribution;  20 
D.  Removing the conservator and appointing a temporary or successor conservator;  21 
E.  Modifying the type of appointment or powers granted to the conservator if the 22 
extent of protection or management previously granted is currently excessive or 23 
insufficient or the protected person's ability to manage the estate and business affairs 24 
has so ch anged as to warrant the action; or  25 
F.  Granting other appropriate relief.  26 
2.  Petition for instructions.  A conservator may petition the appointing court for 27 
instructions concerning fiduciary responsibility.  28 
3.  Court instructions and orders.  Upon notice and hearing the petition, the court 29 
may give appropriate instructions and make any appropriate order.  30 
§5-415.  Bond  31 
1.  Bond; amount; sureties.  The court may require a conservator to furnish a bond 32 
conditioned upon faithful discharge of all duties of the conservatorship according to law, 33 
with sureties as it may specify.  Unless otherwise directed by the court, the bond must be 34 
in the amount of the aggregate capital value of the property of the estate in the 35 
conservator's control, plus one year's estimated income, and minus the value of assets 36 
deposited under arrangements requiring an order of the court for their removal and the 37 
 
 Page 219 - 128LR0452(01) -1 
 value of any real property that the fiduciary, by express limitation, lacks power to sell or 1 
convey without court authorization.  T he court, in place of sureties on a bond, may accept 2 
collateral for the performance of the bond, including a pledge of securities or a mortgage 3 
of real property.  4 
2.  Exempt from furnishing a bond.  The following persons wishing to serve as 5 
conservators are  exempt from furnishing a bond under this section:  6 
A.  A spouse;  7 
B.  A financial institution authorized to do business in this State, as defined in Title 8 
9-B, section 131, subsection 17 -A, or its employees; and  9 
C.  A person who is already bonded in the cou rse of the person's business if the bond 10 
is sufficient to cover the duties of conservator.  11 
§5-416.  Terms and requirements of bond  12 
1.  Rules applicable to bonds.  The following rules apply to any bond required under 13 
section 5 -415: 14 
A.  Except as otherwise p rovided by the terms of the bond, sureties and the 15 
conservator are jointly and severally liable;  16 
B.  By executing the bond of a conservator, a surety submits to the jurisdiction of the 17 
court that issued letters to the primary obligor in any proceeding pert aining to the 18 
fiduciary duties of the conservator in which the surety is named as a party.  Notice of 19 
any proceeding must be sent or delivered to the surety at the address shown in the 20 
court records at the place where the bond is filed and to any other add ress then known 21 
to the petitioner;  22 
C.  On petition of a successor conservator or any interested person, a proceeding may 23 
be brought against a surety for breach of the obligation of the bond of the 24 
conservator; and  25 
D.  The bond of the conservator may be pro ceeded against until liability under the 26 
bond is exhausted.  27 
2.  Proceedings against surety.  A proceeding may not be brought against a surety 28 
on any matter as to which an action or proceeding against the primary obligor is barred.  29 
§5-417.  Compensation and  expenses  30 
If not otherwise compensated for services rendered, a guardian, conservator, attorney 31 
for the respondent or attorney whose services resulted in a protective order or in an order 32 
beneficial to a protected person's estate or any other person appoin ted by the court is 33 
entitled to reasonable compensation from the estate.  Compensation may be paid and 34 
expenses reimbursed without court order.  If the court determines that the compensation 35 
is excessive or the expenses are inappropriate, the excessive or inappropriate amount 36 
must be repaid to the estate.  37 
The factors set forth in section 3 -721, subsection 2 must be considered in determining 38 
the reasonableness of compensation under this section.  39 
 
 Page 220 - 128LR0452(01) -1 
 §5-418.  General duties of conservator; plan  1 
1.  Fiduciary; sta ndard of care.  A conservator, in relation to powers conferred by 2 
this Part or implicit in the title acquired by virtue of the proceeding, is a fiduciary and 3 
shall observe the standards of care applicable to a trustee.  4 
2.  Only as necessitated by limitatio ns.  A conservator may exercise authority only 5 
as necessitated by the limitations of the protected person and, to the extent possible, shall 6 
encourage the protected person to participate in decisions, act in the protected person's 7 
own behalf and develop or  regain the ability to manage the protected person's estate and 8 
business affairs.  9 
3.  Plan for estate; develop and restore protected person's ability.  Within 60 days 10 
after appointment, a conservator shall file with the appointing court a plan for protecti ng, 11 
managing, expending and distributing the assets of the protected person's estate.  The plan 12 
must be based on the actual needs of the protected person and take into consideration the 13 
best interest of the protected person.  The conservator shall include in the plan steps to 14 
develop or restore the protected person's ability to manage the protected person's 15 
property, an estimate of the duration of the conservatorship and projections of expenses 16 
and resources.  17 
4.  Estate plan; will; other instrument of prote cted person.  In investing an estate, 18 
selecting assets of the estate for distribution and invoking powers of revocation or 19 
withdrawal available for the use and benefit of the protected person and exercisable by 20 
the conservator, a conservator shall take int o account any estate plan of the protected 21 
person known to the conservator and may examine the will and any other donative, 22 
nominative or other appointive instrument of the protected person.  23 
§5-419.  Inventory; records  24 
1.  Inventory.  Within 60 days after appointment, a conservator shall prepare and file 25 
with the appointing court a detailed inventory of the estate subject to the conservatorship, 26 
together with an oath or affirmation that the inventory is believed to be complete and 27 
accurate as far as informa tion permits.  The conservator shall provide a copy of the 28 
completed inventory to the protected person if the person can be located, has attained 14 29 
years of age and has sufficient mental capacity to understand these matters, and to any 30 
parent or guardian with whom the protected person resides.  31 
2.  Records of administration.  A conservator shall keep records of the 32 
administration of the estate and make them available for examination on reasonable 33 
request of an interested person.  34 
3.  Penalty for failure to f ile inventory.  If a conservator fails without good cause to 35 
file an inventory, the court may require the conservator or the conservator's surety to pay 36 
to the protected person's estate a minimum of $100 and a maximum of the amount the 37 
court determines is just to compensate the estate for any damage resulting from the failure 38 
to file the inventory.  The payments required by this subsection are in addition to any 39 
other award or remedy available at law or in equity for fiduciary misconduct of the 40 
conservator.  41 
 
 Page 221 - 128LR0452(01) -1 
 §5-420.  Reports; appointment of visitor; monitoring  1 
1.  Reports; annual, intermediate, final.  A conservator shall report to the court for 2 
administration of the protected person's estate annually unless the court otherwise directs, 3 
upon resignation or re moval, upon termination of the conservatorship and at other times 4 
as the court directs.  An order, after notice and hearing, allowing an intermediate report of 5 
a conservator adjudicates liabilities concerning the matters adequately disclosed in the 6 
account ing.  An order, after notice and hearing, allowing a final report adjudicates all 7 
previously unsettled liabilities relating to the conservatorship.  8 
2.  Contents of report.  A report must state or contain:  9 
A.  A list of the assets of the estate under the co nservator's control and a list of the 10 
receipts, disbursements and distributions during the period for which the report is 11 
made;  12 
B.  A list of the services provided to the protected person; and  13 
C.  Any recommended changes in the plan for the conservatorship  as well as a 14 
recommendation as to the continued need for conservatorship and any recommended 15 
changes in the scope of the conservatorship.  16 
3.  Visitor.  The court may appoint a visitor to review a report or plan, interview the 17 
protected person or conservat or and make any other investigation the court directs.  In 18 
connection with a report, the court may order a conservator to submit the assets of the 19 
estate to an appropriate examination to be made in a manner the court directs.  20 
4.  Report as directed.  Notwi thstanding subsections 1 to 4, a private conservator 21 
appointed before January 2, 2008 is not required to submit reports pursuant to subsection 22 
1, but is only required to submit such periodic reports as may be directed in the order of 23 
appointment.  24 
5.  Penal ty for failure to file accounting.  If the conservator fails without good 25 
cause to file the accounting required by the court, the court may require the conservator 26 
or the conservator's surety to pay to the protected person's estate a minimum of $100 and 27 
a maximum of the amount the court determines is just to compensate the estate for any 28 
damage resulting from the failure to file the accounting.  The payments required by this 29 
subsection are in addition to any other award or remedy available at law or in equi ty for 30 
fiduciary misconduct of the conservator.  31 
§5-421.  Title by appointment  32 
1.  Appointment vests title to property.  The appointment of a conservator vests in 33 
the conservator as trustee title to all property of the protected person, or to the part there of 34 
specified in the order, held at the time of appointment or thereafter acquired.  An order 35 
vesting in the conservator title to only a part of the property of the protected person 36 
creates a conservatorship limited to assets specified in the order.  37 
2.  Evidence of vesting title.  Letters of conservatorship are evidence of vesting title 38 
to the protected person's assets in the conservator.  An order terminating a 39 
conservatorship transfers title to assets remaining subject to the conservatorship, 40 
 
 Page 222 - 128LR0452(01) -1 
 including any  described in the order, to the formerly protected person or the protected 1 
person's successors.  2 
3.  Recording of letters and orders.  Subject to the requirements of other statutes 3 
governing the filing or recordation of documents of title to land or other p roperty, letters 4 
of conservatorship and orders terminating conservatorships may be filed or recorded to 5 
give notice of title as between the conservator and the protected person.  6 
4.  Appointment not transfer or alienation.  The appointment of a conservator is 7 
not a transfer or alienation within the meaning of general provisions of any federal or 8 
state statute or regulation, insurance policy, pension plan, contract, will or trust 9 
instrument imposing restrictions upon or penalties for transfer or alienation by  the 10 
protected person of the protected person's rights or interest, but this section does not 11 
restrict the ability of persons to make specific provision by contract or dispositive 12 
instrument relating to a conservator.  13 
§5-422.  Protected person's interest i nalienable  14 
1.  Interest not transferable or assignable by protected person.  Except as 15 
otherwise provided in subsections 3 and 4, the interest of a protected person in property 16 
vested in a conservator is not transferable or assignable by the protected pers on.  An 17 
attempted transfer or assignment by the protected person, although ineffective to affect 18 
property rights, may give rise to a claim against the protected person for restitution or 19 
damages that, subject to presentation and allowance, may be satisfied  as provided in 20 
section 5 -429. 21 
2.  Property not subject to process against protected person.  Property vested in a 22 
conservator by appointment and the interest of the protected person in that property are 23 
not subject to levy, garnishment or similar process for claims against the protected person 24 
unless allowed under section 5 -429. 25 
3.  Tangible personal property transferred by protected person.  A person 26 
without knowledge of the conservatorship who in good faith and for security or 27 
substantially equivalent va lue receives delivery from a protected person of tangible 28 
personal property of a type normally transferred by delivery of possession is protected as 29 
if the protected person or transferee had valid title.  30 
4.  Protection of 3rd party.  A 3rd party who deals with the protected person with 31 
respect to property vested in a conservator is entitled to any protection provided in other 32 
law. 33 
§5-423.  Sale, encumbrance or other transaction involving conflict of interest  34 
Any transaction involving the conservatorship est ate that is affected by a substantial 35 
conflict between the conservator's fiduciary and personal interests is voidable unless the 36 
transaction is expressly authorized by the court after notice to interested persons.  A 37 
transaction affected by a substantial c onflict between personal and fiduciary interests 38 
includes any sale, encumbrance or other transaction involving the conservatorship estate 39 
entered into by the conservator, the spouse, descendant, agent or attorney of a conservator 40 
 
 Page 223 - 128LR0452(01) -1 
 or a corporation or other enterprise in which the conservator has a substantial beneficial 1 
interest.  2 
§5-424.  Protection of person dealing with conservator  3 
1.  Protection of 3rd persons.  A person who assists or deals with a conservator in 4 
good faith and for value in any transactio n other than one requiring a court order under 5 
section 5 -410 or 5 -411 is protected as though the conservator properly exercised the 6 
power.  That a person knowingly deals with a conservator does not alone require the 7 
person to inquire into the existence of a power or the propriety of its exercise, but 8 
restrictions on powers of conservators that are endorsed on letters as provided in section 9 
5-108 are effective as to 3rd persons.  A person who pays or delivers assets to a 10 
conservator is not responsible for th eir proper application.  11 
2.  Application of protection.  Protection provided by this section extends to any 12 
procedural irregularity or jurisdictional defect that occurred in proceedings leading to the 13 
issuance of letters and is not a substitute for protecti on provided to persons assisting or 14 
dealing with a conservator by comparable provisions in other law relating to commercial 15 
transactions or to simplifying transfers of securities by fiduciaries.  16 
§5-425.  Powers of conservator in administration  17 
1.  Powers; powers of trustee.  Except as otherwise qualified or limited by the court 18 
in its order of appointment and endorsed on the letters, a conservator has all of the powers 19 
granted in this section and any additional powers granted by law to a trustee in this Sta te. 20 
2.  Specific powers.  A conservator, acting reasonably and in an effort to accomplish 21 
the purpose of the appointment, and without further court authorization or confirmation, 22 
may:  23 
A.  Collect, hold and retain assets of the estate, including assets in w hich the 24 
conservator has a personal interest and real property in another state, until the 25 
conservator considers that disposition of an asset should be made;  26 
B.  Receive additions to the estate;  27 
C.  Continue or participate in the operation of any business or other enterprise;  28 
D.  Acquire an undivided interest in an asset of the estate in which the conservator, in 29 
any fiduciary capacity, holds an undivided interest;  30 
E.  Invest assets of the estate as though the conservator were a trustee;  31 
F.  Deposit money o f the estate in a financial institution, including one operated by 32 
the conservator;  33 
G.  Acquire or dispose of an asset of the estate, including real property in another 34 
state, for cash or on credit, at public or private sale and manage, develop, improve, 35 
exchange, partition, change the character of or abandon an asset of the estate;  36 
H.  Make ordinary or extraordinary repairs or alterations in buildings or other 37 
structures, demolish any improvements and raze existing or erect new party walls or 38 
buildings;  39 
 
 Page 224 - 128LR0452(01) -1 
 I.  Subdivide, develop or dedicate land to public use, make or obtain the vacation of 1 
plats and adjust boundaries, adjust differences in valuation or exchange or partition 2 
by giving or receiving considerations and dedicate easements to public use without 3 
consideration;  4 
J.  Enter for any purpose into a lease as lessor or lessee, with or without option to 5 
purchase or renew, for a term within or extending beyond the term of the 6 
conservatorship;  7 
K.  Enter into a lease or arrangement for exploration and removal of  minerals or other 8 
natural resources or enter into a pooling or unitization agreement;  9 
L.  Grant an option involving disposition of an asset of the estate and take an option 10 
for the acquisition of any asset;  11 
M.  Vote a security, in person or by general or  limited proxy;  12 
N.  Pay calls, assessments and any other sums chargeable or accruing against or on 13 
account of securities;  14 
O.  Sell or exercise stock -subscription or conversion rights;  15 
P.  Consent, directly or through a committee or other agent, to the reor ganization, 16 
consolidation, merger, dissolution or liquidation of a corporation or other business 17 
enterprise;  18 
Q.  Hold a security in the name of a nominee or in other form without disclosure of 19 
the conservatorship so that title to the security may pass by d elivery;  20 
R.  Insure the assets of the estate against damage or loss and the conservator against 21 
liability with respect to a 3rd person;  22 
S.  Borrow money, with or without security, to be repaid from the estate or otherwise 23 
and advance money for the protecti on of the estate or the protected person and for all 24 
expenses, losses and liability sustained in the administration of the estate or because 25 
of the holding or ownership of any assets, for which the conservator has a lien on the 26 
estate as against the protec ted person for advances so made;  27 
T.  Pay or contest any claim, settle a claim by or against the estate or the protected 28 
person by compromise, arbitration or otherwise and release, in whole or in part, any 29 
claim belonging to the estate to the extent the cla im is uncollectible;  30 
U.  Pay taxes, assessments and compensation of the conservator and any guardian and 31 
other expenses incurred in the collection, care, administration and protection of the 32 
estate;  33 
V.  Allocate items of income or expense to income or prin cipal of the estate, as 34 
provided by other law, including creation of reserves out of income for depreciation, 35 
obsolescence or amortization or for depletion of minerals or other natural resources;  36 
W.  Pay any sum distributable to a protected person or indiv idual who is in fact 37 
dependent on the protected person by paying the sum to the distributee or by paying 38 
the sum for the use of the distributee:  39 
(1)  To the guardian of the distributee;  40 
 
 Page 225 - 128LR0452(01) -1 
 (2)  To a distributee's custodian under the Maine Uniform Transfers to  Minors 1 
Act or custodial trustee under the laws of another state; or  2 
(3)  If there is no guardian, custodian or custodial trustee, to a relative or other 3 
person having physical custody of the distributee;  4 
X.  Prosecute or defend actions, claims or proceedi ngs in any jurisdiction for the 5 
protection of assets of the estate and of the conservator in the performance of 6 
fiduciary duties;  7 
Y.  Execute and deliver all instruments that will accomplish or facilitate the exercise 8 
of the powers vested in the conservato r; and  9 
Z.  Exercise any powers described in section 1 -110 relating to compliance with 10 
environmental laws.  11 
§5-426.  Delegation  12 
1.  Not entire administration; performance of functions.  A conservator may not 13 
delegate to an agent or another conservator the en tire administration of the estate, but a 14 
conservator may otherwise delegate the performance of functions that a prudent trustee of 15 
comparable skills may delegate under similar circumstances.  16 
2.  Reasonable care, skill and caution.  The conservator shall ex ercise reasonable 17 
care, skill and caution in:  18 
A.  Selecting an agent;  19 
B.  Establishing the scope and terms of a delegation, consistent with the purposes and 20 
terms of the conservatorship;  21 
C.  Periodically reviewing an agent's overall performance and complia nce with the 22 
terms of the delegation; and  23 
D.  Redressing an action or decision of an agent that would constitute a breach of 24 
trust if performed by the conservator.  25 
3.  Liability.  A conservator who complies with subsections 1 and 2 is not liable to 26 
the pro tected person or to the estate for the decisions or actions of the agent to whom a 27 
function was delegated.  28 
4.  Reasonable care of agent.  In performing a delegated function, an agent shall 29 
exercise reasonable care to comply with the terms of the delegation . 30 
5.  Agent submits to jurisdiction.  By accepting a delegation from a conservator 31 
subject to the law of this State, an agent submits to the jurisdiction of the courts of this 32 
State.  33 
§5-427.  Principles of distribution by conservator  34 
1.  Expend or distribu te income or principal.  Unless otherwise specified in the 35 
order of appointment and endorsed on the letters of appointment or contrary to the plan 36 
filed pursuant to section 5 -418, a conservator may expend or distribute income or 37 
principal of the estate of the protected person without further court authorization or 38 
 
 Page 226 - 128LR0452(01) -1 
 confirmation for the support, care, education, health and welfare of the protected person 1 
and individuals who are in fact dependent on the protected person, including the payment 2 
of child or spous al support, in accordance with the following rules.  3 
A.  A conservator shall consider recommendations relating to the appropriate 4
