standard of support, care, education, health and welfare for the protected person or an 5 
individual who is in fact dependent on the protected person made by a guardian, if 6 
any, and, if the protected person is a minor, the conservator shall consider 7 
recommendations made by a parent.  8 
B.  A conservator may not be surcharged for money paid to persons furnishing 9 
support, care, education  or benefit to a protected person or an individual who is in 10 
fact dependent on the protected person in accordance with the recommendations of a 11 
parent or guardian of the protected person unless the conservator knows that the 12 
parent or guardian derives pers onal financial benefit therefrom, including relief from 13 
any personal duty of support, or the recommendations are not in the best interest of 14 
the protected person.  15 
C.  In making distributions under this subsection, the conservator shall consider:  16 
(1)  The s ize of the estate, the estimated duration of the conservatorship and the 17 
likelihood that the protected person, at some future time, may be fully self - 18 
sufficient and able to manage business affairs and the estate;  19 
(2)  The accustomed standard of living of the protected person and individuals 20 
who are in fact dependent on the protected person; and  21 
(3)  Other money or sources used for the support of the protected person.  22 
D.  Money expended under this subsection may be paid by the conservator to any 23 
person, in cluding the protected person, as reimbursement for expenditures that the 24 
conservator might have made, or in advance for services to be rendered to the 25 
protected person if it is reasonable to expect the services will be performed and 26 
advance payments are cu stomary or reasonably necessary under the circumstances.  27 
2.  Gifts not to exceed 20% of annual income.  If the estate is ample to provide for 28 
the distributions authorized by subsection 1, a conservator for a protected person other 29 
than a minor may make gif ts that the protected person might have been expected to make, 30 
in amounts that do not exceed in the aggregate for any calendar year 20% of the income 31 
of the estate in that year.  32 
§5-428.  Death of protected person  33 
1.  Will; inform personal representative or  beneficiary; retain estate.  If a 34 
protected person dies, the conservator shall deliver to the court for safekeeping any will 35 
of the protected person that may have come into the conservator's possession, inform the 36 
personal representative or beneficiary na med in the will of the delivery and retain the 37 
estate for delivery to the personal representative of the decedent or to another person 38 
entitled to it.  39 
2.  Apply to exercise powers and duties of personal representative; notice.  If a 40 
personal representative  has not been appointed within 40 days after the death of a 41 
 
 Page 227 - 128LR0452(01) -1 
 protected person and an application or petition for appointment is not before the court, the 1 
conservator may apply to exercise the powers and duties of a personal representative in 2 
order to admini ster and distribute the decedent's estate.  Upon application for an order 3 
conferring upon the conservator the powers of a personal representative, after notice 4 
given by the conservator to the following, the court may grant the application upon 5 
determining that there is no objection and endorse the letters of conservatorship to note 6 
that the formerly protected person is deceased and that the conservator has acquired all of 7 
the powers and duties of a personal representative:  8 
A.  Any person nominated as person al representative by any will of which the 9 
applicant is aware;  10 
B.  All of the decedent's heirs; and  11 
C.  All devisees of the will, if any.  12 
3.  Effect of appointment as personal representative.  The issuance of an order 13 
under this section has the effect of a n order of appointment of a personal representative as 14 
provided in section 3 -308 and Article 3, Parts 6 to 10.  However, the estate in the name of 15 
the conservator, after administration, may be distributed to the decedent's successors 16 
without retransfer to the conservator as personal representative.  17 
§5-429.  Presentation and allowance of claims  18 
1.  Claims against estate or protected person.  A conservator may pay, or secure by 19 
encumbering assets of the estate, claims against the estate or against the protect ed person 20 
arising before or during the conservatorship upon their presentation and allowance in 21 
accordance with the priorities stated in subsection 4.  A claimant may present a claim by:  22 
A.  Sending or delivering to the conservator a written statement of t he claim, 23 
indicating its basis, the name and address of the claimant and the amount claimed; or  24 
B.  Filing a written statement of the claim, in a form acceptable to the court, with the 25 
clerk of court and sending or delivering a copy of the statement to the  conservator.  26 
2.  Presented claim; allowance; disallowance.  A claim is considered presented on 27 
receipt of the written statement of claim by the conservator or the filing of the claim with 28 
the court, whichever first occurs.  A presented claim is allowed if  it is not disallowed by 29 
written statement sent or delivered by the conservator to the claimant within 60 days after 30 
its presentation.  The conservator before payment may change an allowance to a 31 
disallowance in whole or in part, but not after allowance un der a court order or judgment 32 
or an order directing payment of the claim.  The presentation of a claim tolls the running 33 
of any statute of limitations relating to the claim until 30 days after its disallowance.  34 
3.  Unpaid claim.  A claimant whose claim has  not been paid may petition the court 35 
for determination of the claim at any time before it is barred by a statute of limitations 36 
and, upon due proof, procure an order for its allowance, payment or security by 37 
encumbering assets of the estate.  If a proceed ing is pending against a protected person at 38 
the time of appointment of a conservator or is initiated against the protected person 39 
thereafter, the moving party shall give to the conservator notice of any proceeding that 40 
could result in creating a claim aga inst the estate.  41 
 
 Page 228 - 128LR0452(01) -1 
 4.  Distribution; order.  If it appears that the estate is likely to be exhausted before 1 
all existing claims are paid, the conservator shall distribute the estate in money or in kind 2 
in payment of claims in the following order:  3 
A.  Costs a nd expenses of administration;  4 
B.  Claims of the Federal Government or State Government having priority under 5 
other law;  6 
C.  Claims incurred by the conservator for support, care, education, health and 7 
welfare previously provided to the protected person or individuals who are in fact 8 
dependent on the protected person;  9 
D.  Claims arising before the conservatorship; and  10 
E.  Any claims other than those specified in paragraphs A to D.  11 
5.  Preference of claims.  Preference may not be given in the payment of a cla im 12 
over any other claim of the same class, and a claim due and payable may not be preferred 13 
over a claim not due.  14 
6.  Security interest in conservatorship estate.  If assets of the conservatorship are 15 
adequate to meet all existing claims, the court, acting  in the best interest of the protected 16 
person, may order the conservator to grant a security interest in the conservatorship estate 17 
for payment of all claims at a future date.  18 
§5-430.  Personal liability of conservator  19 
1.  Not personally liable.  Except as  otherwise agreed, a conservator is not 20 
personally liable on a contract properly entered into in a fiduciary capacity in the course 21 
of administration of the estate unless the conservator fails to reveal in the contract the 22 
representative capacity and ident ify the estate.  23 
2.  Personally liable.  A conservator is personally liable for obligations arising from 24 
ownership or control of property of the estate or for other acts or omissions occurring in 25 
the course of administration of the estate, including liabili ty for violation of 26 
environmental law, only if personally at fault.  27 
3.  Claims asserted against conservator.  Claims based on contracts entered into by 28 
a conservator in a fiduciary capacity, obligations arising from ownership or control of the 29 
estate and c laims based on torts committed in the course of administration of the estate 30 
may be asserted against the estate by proceeding against the conservator in a fiduciary 31 
capacity, whether or not the conservator is personally liable therefor.  32 
4.  Determination o f liability.  A question of liability between the estate and the 33 
conservator personally may be determined in a proceeding for accounting, surcharge or 34 
indemnification or in another appropriate proceeding or action.  35 
§5-431.  Termination of proceedings  36 
1.  Death; order of court; minor attains majority or is emancipated.  A 37 
conservatorship terminates upon the death of the protected person or upon order of the 38 
 
 Page 229 - 128LR0452(01) -1 
 court.  Unless created for reasons other than that the protected person is a minor, a 1 
conservatorship created for a minor also terminates when the protected person attains 2 
majority or is emancipated.  3 
2.  Distribution upon death; report and petition for discharge.  Upon the death of 4 
a protected person, the conservator shall conclude the administration of th e estate by 5 
distribution to the person's successors.  The conservator shall file a final report and 6 
petition for discharge within 30 days after distribution.  7 
3.  Petition to terminate; termination; liability.  On petition of a protected person, 8 
a conservat or or another person interested in a protected person's welfare, the court may 9 
terminate the conservatorship if the protected person no longer needs the assistance or 10 
protection of a conservator.  Termination of the conservatorship does not affect a 11 
conser vator's liability for previous acts or the obligation to account for funds and assets of 12 
the protected person.  13 
4.  Procedures for termination.  Except as otherwise ordered by the court for good 14 
cause, before terminating a conservatorship the court shall fo llow the same procedures to 15 
safeguard the rights of the protected person that apply to a petition for conservatorship.  16 
Upon the establishment of a prima facie case for termination, the court shall order 17 
termination unless it is proved that continuation of  the conservatorship is in the best 18 
interest of the protected person.  19 
5.  Title to assets passes upon termination; final report. Upon termination of a 20 
conservatorship and whether or not formally distributed by the conservator, title to assets 21 
of the estate  passes to the formerly protected person or the person's successors.  The order 22 
of termination must provide for expenses of administration and direct the conservator to 23 
execute appropriate instruments to evidence the transfer of title or confirm a distribu tion 24 
previously made and to file a final report and a petition for discharge upon approval of 25 
the final report.  26 
6.  Final order of discharge.  The court shall enter a final order of discharge upon 27 
the approval of the final report and satisfaction by the co nservator of any other conditions 28 
placed by the court on the conservator's discharge.  29 
§5-432.  Registration of guardianship orders  30 
If a guardian has been appointed in another state and a petition for the appointment of 31 
a guardian is not pending in this Sta te, the guardian appointed in the other state, after 32 
giving notice to the appointing court of an intent to register, may register the guardianship 33 
order in this State by filing as a foreign judgment in a court in any appropriate county of 34 
this State certif ied copies of the order and letters of appointment.  35 
§5-433.  Registration of protective orders  36 
If a conservator has been appointed in another state and a petition for a protective 37 
order is not pending in this State, the conservator appointed in the other s tate, after giving 38 
notice to the appointing court of an intent to register, may register the protective order in 39 
this State by filing as a foreign judgment in a court in any county in which property 40 
 
 Page 230 - 128LR0452(01) -1 
 belonging to the protected person is located certified co pies of the order and letters of 1 
appointment and of any bond.  2 
§5-434.  Effect of registration  3 
1.  Registration.  Upon registration of a guardianship or protective order from 4 
another state, under the guardian or conservator may exercise in this State all po wers 5 
authorized in the order of appointment except as prohibited under the laws of this State, 6 
including maintaining actions and proceedings in this State, and, if the guardian or 7 
conservator is not a resident of this State, subject to any conditions impos ed upon 8 
nonresident parties.  9 
2.  Enforce registered order.  A court of this State may grant any relief available 10 
under this Article and other laws of this State to enforce a registered order.  11 
PART 5  12 
UNIFORM ADULT GUARDI ANSHIP AND PROTECTIV E PROCEEDINGS 13 
JUR ISDICTION ACT  14 
SUBPART 1  15 
GENERAL PROVISIONS  16 
§5-501.  Short title  17 
This Part may be known and cited as "the Uniform Adult Guardianship and 18 
Protective Proceedings Jurisdiction Act."  19 
§5-502.  Definitions  20 
As used in this Part, unless the context otherwise indica tes, the following terms have 21 
the following meanings.  22 
1.  Adult.  "Adult" means an individual who has attained 18 years of age.  23 
2.  Conservator.  "Conservator" means a person appointed by the court to administer 24 
the property of an adult, including a person  appointed under Part 4.  25 
3.  Guardian.  "Guardian" means a person appointed by the court to make decisions 26 
regarding the person of an adult, including a person appointed under Part 3.  27 
4.  Guardianship proceeding.  "Guardianship proceeding" means a judicial  28 
proceeding in which an order for the appointment of a guardian is sought or has been 29 
issued.  30 
5.  Incapacitated person.  "Incapacitated person" means an adult for whom a 31 
guardian has been appointed or an adult who is an incapacitated person within the 32 
mean ing of section 5 -102, subsection 5.  33 
 
 Page 231 - 128LR0452(01) -1 
 6.  Party.  "Party" means an interested person within the meaning of section 1 -201, 1 
subsection 26, including the respondent, petitioner, guardian, conservator or any other 2 
person allowed by the court to participate in a guardianship or protective proceeding.  3 
7.  Person.  "Person," except in the term "incapacitated person" or "protected 4 
person," means an individual; corporation; business trust; estate; trust; partnership; 5 
limited liability company; association; joint ventu re; public corporation; government or 6 
governmental subdivision, agency or instrumentality; or any other legal or commercial 7 
entity.  8 
8.  Protected person.  "Protected person" means an adult for whom a protective 9 
order has been issued.  10 
9.  Protective order.  "Protective order" means an order appointing a conservator or 11 
other order related to management or disposition of an adult's property.  12 
10.  Protective proceeding.  "Protective proceeding" means a judicial proceeding in 13 
which a protective order is sought o r has been issued.  14 
11.  Respondent.  "Respondent" means an adult for whom a protective order or the 15 
appointment of a guardian is sought.  16 
§5-503.  International application of Part  17 
A court of this State may treat a foreign country as if it were a state for the purpose of 18 
applying this Part.  19 
§5-504.  Communication between courts  20 
1.  Communication between courts; participation; record.  A court of this State 21 
may communicate with a court in another state concerning a proceeding arising under this 22 
Part.  The cou rt may allow the parties to participate in the communication.  Except as 23 
otherwise provided in subsection 2, the court shall make a record of the communication.  24 
The record may be limited to the fact that the communication occurred.  25 
2.  No record required.   Courts may communicate concerning schedules, calendars, 26 
court records and other administrative matters without making a record.  27 
§5-505.  Cooperation between courts  28 
1.  Request of court of another state.  In a guardianship proceeding or protective 29 
proceed ing in this State, a court of this State may request the appropriate court of another 30 
state to do any of the following:  31 
A.  Hold an evidentiary hearing;  32 
B.  Order a person in that state to produce evidence or give testimony pursuant to 33 
procedures of that s tate; 34 
C.  Order that an evaluation or assessment be made of the respondent;  35 
D.  Order any appropriate investigation of a person involved in a proceeding;  36 
 
 Page 232 - 128LR0452(01) -1 
 E.  Forward to the court a certified copy of the transcript or other record of a hearing 1 
under paragra ph A or any other proceeding, any evidence otherwise produced under 2 
paragraph B and any evaluation or assessment prepared in compliance with an order 3 
under paragraph C or D;  4 
F.  Issue any order necessary to ensure the appearance in the proceeding of a pers on 5 
whose presence is necessary for the court to make a determination, including the 6 
respondent or the incapacitated person or protected person; and  7 
G.  Issue an order authorizing the release of medical, financial, criminal or other 8 
relevant information in that state, including protected health information as defined in 9 
45 Code of Federal Regulations, Section 160.103, as amended.  10 
2.  Jurisdiction to comply with request.  If a court of another state in which a 11 
guardianship proceeding or protective proceeding is pending requests assistance of the 12 
kind provided in subsection 1, a court of this State has jurisdiction for the limited purpose 13 
of granting the request or making reasonable efforts to comply with the request.  14 
§5-506.  Taking testimony in another state  15 
1.  Testimony of witness in another state.  In a guardianship proceeding or 16 
protective proceeding, in addition to other procedures that may be available, testimony of 17 
a witness who is located in another state may be offered by deposition or other means 18 
allowable in this State for testimony taken in another state.  The court on its own motion 19 
may order that the testimony of a witness be taken in another state and may prescribe the 20 
manner in which and the terms upon which the testimony is to be taken.  21 
2.  Deposition or testimony by electronic means.  In a guardianship proceeding or 22 
protective proceeding, a court in this State may permit a witness located in another state 23 
to be deposed or to testify by telephone or audiovisual or other electronic means.  A cour t 24 
of this State shall cooperate with the court of the other state in designating an appropriate 25 
location for the deposition or testimony.  26 
3.  Documentary evidence transmitted, no original writing.  Documentary 27 
evidence transmitted from another state to a c ourt of this State by technological means 28 
that do not produce an original writing may not be excluded from evidence on an 29 
objection based on the best evidence rule.  30 
SUBPART 2  31 
JURISDICTION  32 
§5-521.  Definitions; significant connection factors  33 
1.  Definitions .  As used in this subpart, unless the context otherwise indicates, the 34 
following terms have the following meanings.  35 
A.  "Emergency" means a circumstance that likely will result in substantial harm to a 36 
respondent's health, safety or welfare and for which the appointment of a guardian is 37 
necessary.  38 
 
 Page 233 - 128LR0452(01) -1 
 B.  "Home state" means the state in which the respondent was physically present, 1 
including any period of temporary absence, for at least 6 consecutive months 2 
immediately before the filing of a petition for a prot ective order or the appointment of 3 
a guardian or, if none, the state in which the respondent was physically present, 4 
including any period of temporary absence, for at least 6 consecutive months ending 5 
within the 6 months prior to the filing of the petition . 6 
C.  "Significant -connection state" means a state, other than the home state, with 7 
which a respondent has a significant connection other than mere physical presence 8 
and in which substantial evidence concerning the respondent is available.  9 
2.  Significant -connection factors.  In determining under section 5 -523 and section 10 
5-531, subsection 5 whether a respondent has a significant connection with a particular 11 
state, the court shall consider:  12 
A.  The location of the respondent's family and other persons requi red to be notified 13 
of the guardianship proceeding or protective proceeding;  14 
B.  The length of time the respondent at any time was physically present in the state 15 
and the duration of any absence;  16 
C.  The location of the respondent's property; and  17 
D.  The ex tent to which the respondent has ties to the state such as voting registration, 18 
state or local tax return filing, vehicle registration, driver's license, social relationship 19 
and receipt of services.  20 
§5-522.  Exclusive basis  21 
This subpart provides the exclus ive jurisdictional basis for a court of this State to 22 
appoint a guardian or issue a protective order for an adult.  23 
§5-523.  Jurisdiction  24 
A court of this State has jurisdiction to appoint a guardian or issue a protective order 25 
for a respondent if:  26 
1.  Respo ndent's home state.  This State is the respondent's home state; or  27 
2.  Significant -connection state and other factors.  On the date the petition is filed, 28 
this State is a significant -connection state and:  29 
A.  The respondent does not have a home state or a court of the respondent's home 30 
state has declined to exercise jurisdiction because this State is a more appropriate 31 
forum;  32 
B.  The respondent has a home state, a petition for an appointment or order is not 33 
pending in a court of that state or another signif icant -connection state and, before the 34 
court makes the appointment or issues the order:  35 
(1)  A petition for an appointment or order is not filed in the respondent's home 36 
state;  37 
 
 Page 234 - 128LR0452(01) -1 
 (2)  An objection to the court's jurisdiction is not filed by a person required  to be 1 
notified of the proceeding; and  2 
(3)  The court in this State concludes that it is an appropriate forum under the 3 
factors set forth in section 5 -526; 4 
C.  This State does not have jurisdiction under either paragraph A or B, the 5 
respondent's home state  and all significant -connection states have declined to 6 
exercise jurisdiction because this State is the more appropriate forum and jurisdiction 7 
in this State is consistent with the Constitution of Maine and the United States 8 
Constitution; or  9 
D.  The requir ements for special jurisdiction under section 5 -524 are met.  10 
§5-524.  Special jurisdiction  11 
1.  Special jurisdiction.  If this State is not the respondent's home state and not a 12 
significant -connection state, a court of this State has special jurisdiction to  do any of the 13 
following:  14 
A.  Appoint a guardian in an emergency for a term not exceeding 6 months for a 15 
respondent who is physically present in this State;  16 
B.  Issue a protective order with respect to real or tangible personal property located 17 
in this Sta te; or  18 
C.  Appoint a guardian or conservator for an incapacitated person or protected person 19 
for whom a provisional order to transfer the proceeding from another state has been 20 
issued under procedures similar to those in section 5 -531. 21 
2.  Emergency appoin tment.  If a petition for the appointment of a guardian in an 22 
emergency is brought in this State and this State was not the respondent's home state on 23 
the date the petition was filed, the court shall dismiss the proceeding at the request of the 24 
court of th e home state, if any, whether dismissal is requested before or after the 25 
emergency appointment.  26 
§5-525.  Exclusive and continuing jurisdiction  27 
Except as otherwise provided in section 5 -524, a court that has appointed a guardian 28 
or issued a protective order  consistent with this Part has exclusive and continuing 29 
jurisdiction over the proceeding until it is terminated by the court or the appointment or 30 
order expires by its own terms.  31 
§5-526.  Appropriate forum  32 
1.  Decline jurisdiction.  A court of this State h aving jurisdiction under section 5 -523 33 
to appoint a guardian or issue a protective order may decline to exercise its jurisdiction if 34 
it determines at any time that a court of another state is a more appropriate forum.  35 
2.  Actions by court that declines jur isdiction.  If a court of this State declines to 36 
exercise its jurisdiction under subsection 1, it shall either:  37 
A.  Dismiss or stay the proceeding; or  38 
 
 Page 235 - 128LR0452(01) -1 
 B.  Impose any condition the court considers just and proper, including the condition 1 
that a petition for  the appointment of a guardian or issuance of a protective order be 2 
filed promptly in another state.  3 
3.  Appropriate forum factors.  In determining whether it is an appropriate forum, 4 
the court shall consider all relevant factors, which may include:  5 
A.  Any expressed preference of the respondent;  6 
B.  Whether abuse, neglect or exploitation of the respondent has occurred or is likely 7 
to occur and which state could best protect the respondent from the abuse, neglect or 8 
exploitation;  9 
C.  The length of time the respondent was physically present in or was a legal 10 
resident of this State or another state;  11 
D.  The distance of the respondent from the court in each state;  12 
E.  The financial circumstances of the respondent's estate;  13 
F.  The nature and location of the evi dence;  14 
G.  The ability of the court in each state to decide the issue expeditiously and the 15 
procedures necessary to present evidence;  16 
H.  The familiarity of the court of each state with the facts and issues in the 17 
proceeding; and  18 
I.  If an appointment were  made, the court's ability to monitor the conduct of the 19 
guardian or conservator.  20 
§5-527.  Jurisdiction declined by reason of conduct  21 
1.  Jurisdiction because of unjustifiable conduct.  If at any time a court of this 22 
State determines that it acquired juris diction to appoint a guardian or issue a protective 23 
order because of unjustifiable conduct, the court may:  24 
A.  Decline to exercise jurisdiction;  25 
B.  Exercise jurisdiction for the limited purpose of fashioning an appropriate remedy 26 
to ensure the health, saf ety and welfare of the respondent or the protection of the 27 
respondent's property or prevent a repetition of the unjustifiable conduct, including 28 
staying the proceeding until a petition for the appointment of a guardian or issuance 29 
of a protective order is filed in a court of another state having jurisdiction; or  30 
C.  Continue to exercise jurisdiction after considering:  31 
(1)  The extent to which the respondent and all persons required to be notified of 32 
the proceedings have acquiesced in the exercise of the cou rt's jurisdiction;  33 
(2)  Whether it is a more appropriate forum than the court of any other state under 34 
the factors set forth in section 5 -526, subsection 3; and  35 
(3)  Whether the court of any other state would have jurisdiction under factual 36 
circumstances i n substantial conformity with the jurisdictional standards of 37 
section 5 -523. 38 
 
 Page 236 - 128LR0452(01) -1 
 2.  Assessment of expenses.  If a court of this State determines that it acquired 1 
jurisdiction to appoint a guardian or issue a protective order because a party seeking to 2 
invoke its jurisdiction engaged in unjustifiable conduct, it may assess against that party 3 
necessary and reasonable expenses, including attorney's fees, investigative fees, court 4 
costs, communication expenses, witness fees and expenses and travel expenses.  The 5 
court may not assess fees, costs or expenses of any kind against this State or a 6 
governmental subdivision, agency or instrumentality of this State unless authorized by 7 
law other than this Part.  8 
§5-528.  Notice of proceeding  9 
If a petition for the appointment  of a guardian or issuance of a protective order is 10 
brought in this State and this State was not the respondent's home state on the date the 11 
petition was filed, in addition to complying with the notice requirements of this State, 12 
notice of the petition mus t be given to those persons who would be entitled to notice of 13 
the petition if a proceeding were brought in the respondent's home state.  The notice must 14 
be given in the same manner as notice is required to be given in this State.  15 
§5-529.  Proceedings in m ore than one state  16 
Except for a petition for the appointment of a guardian in an emergency or issuance 17 
of a protective order limited to property located in this State under section 5 -524, 18 
subsection 1, paragraph A or B, if a petition for the appointment of  a guardian or issuance 19 
of a protective order is filed in this State and in another state and neither petition has been 20 
dismissed or withdrawn, the following apply.  21 
1.  Jurisdiction proper; proceed with case.  If the court in this State has jurisdiction 22 
under section 5 -523, it may proceed with the case unless a court in another state acquires 23 
jurisdiction under provisions similar to section 5 -523 before the appointment or issuance 24 
of the order.  25 
2.  Lack of jurisdiction; communication with court.  If the cou rt in this State does 26 
not have jurisdiction under section 5 -523, whether at the time the petition is filed or at 27 
any time before the appointment or issuance of the order, the court shall stay the 28 
proceeding and communicate with the court in the other state .  If the court in the other 29 
state has jurisdiction, the court in this State shall dismiss the petition unless the court in 30 
the other state determines that the court in this State is a more appropriate forum.  31 
SUBPART 3  32 
TRANSFER OF GUARDIAN SHIP OR CONSERVAT ORSHIP  33 
§5-531.  Transfer of guardianship or conservatorship to another state  34 
1.  Petition.  A guardian or conservator appointed in this State may petition the court 35 
to transfer the guardianship or conservatorship to another state.  36 
2.  Notice.  Notice of a petition under subsection 1 must be given to the persons that 37 
would be entitled to notice of a petition in this State for the appointment of a guardian or 38 
conservator.  39 
 
 Page 237 - 128LR0452(01) -1 
 3.  Hearing or opportunity for hearing.  On the court's own motion or on request of 1 
the guardian or conservator, the incapacitated person or protected person or other person 2 
required to be notified of the petition, the court shall hold a hearing or provide an 3 
opportunity for a hearing to be held on a petition filed pursuant to subsection 1.  4 
4.  Provisional order; guardianship.  The court shall issue an order provisionally 5 
granting a petition to transfer a guardianship and shall direct the guardian to petition for 6 
guardianship in the other state if the court is satisfied that the guardianship w ill be 7 
accepted by the court in the other state and the court finds that:  8 
A.  The incapacitated person is physically present in or is reasonably expected to 9 
move permanently to the other state;  10 
B.  An objection to the transfer has not been made or, if an o bjection has been made, 11 
the objector has not established by a preponderance of the evidence that the transfer 12 
would be contrary to the best interests of the incapacitated person; and  13 
C.  Plans for care and services for the incapacitated person in the other  state are 14 
reasonable and sufficient.  15 
5.  Provisional order; conservatorship.  The court shall issue a provisional order 16 
granting a petition to transfer a conservatorship and shall direct the conservator to petition 17 
for conservatorship in the other state i f the court is satisfied that the conservatorship will 18 
be accepted by the court of the other state and the court finds that:  19 
A.  The protected person is physically present in or is reasonably expected to move 20 
permanently to the other state or the protected  person has a significant connection to 21 
the other state considering the factors in section 5 -521, subsection 2;  22 
B.  An objection to the transfer has not been made or, if an objection has been made, 23 
the objector has not established by a preponderance of the  evidence that the transfer 24 
would be contrary to the best interests of the protected person; and  25 
C.  Adequate arrangements will be made for management or disposition of the 26 
protected person's property.  27 
6.  Final order.  The court shall issue a final order confirming the transfer and 28 
terminating the guardianship or conservatorship upon its receipt of:  29 
A.  A provisional order accepting the proceeding from the court to which the 30 
proceeding is to be transferred that is issued under provisions similar to section  31 
5-532; and  32 
B.  The documents required to terminate a guardianship or conservatorship in this 33 
State.  34 
§5-532.  Accepting guardianship or conservatorship transferred from another state  35 
1.  Petition.  To confirm transfer of a guardianship or conservatorship t ransferred to 36 
this State under provisions similar to section 5 -531, the guardian or conservator must 37 
petition the court in this State to accept the guardianship or conservatorship.  The petition 38 
must include a certified copy of the other state's provisiona l order of transfer.  39 
 
 Page 238 - 128LR0452(01) -1 
 2.  Notice.  Notice of a petition under subsection 1 must be given to those persons 1 
who would be entitled to notice if the petition were a petition for the appointment of a 2 
guardian or issuance of a protective order in both the transfe rring state and this State.  3 
The notice must be given in the same manner as notice is required to be given in this 4 
State.  5 
3.  Hearing.  On the court's own motion or on request of the guardian or conservator, 6 
the incapacitated person or protected person or other person required to be notified of the 7 
proceeding, the court shall hold a hearing on a petition filed pursuant to subsection 1.  8 
4.  Provisional order.  The court shall issue an order provisionally granting a petition 9 
filed under subsection 1 unless:  10 
A.  An objection is made and the objector establishes by a preponderance of the 11 
evidence that transfer of the proceeding would be contrary to the best interests of the 12 
incapacitated person or protected person; or  13 
B.  The guardian or conservator is ineligibl e for appointment in this State.  14 
5.  Final order.  The court shall issue a final order accepting the proceeding and 15 
appointing the guardian or conservator as guardian or conservator in this State upon its 16 
receipt from the court from which the proceeding is  being transferred of a final order 17 
issued under provisions similar to section 5 -531 transferring the proceeding to this State.  18 
6.  Recognition of order from other state.  In granting a petition under this section, 19 
the court shall recognize a guardianship or conservatorship order from the other state, 20 
including the determination of the incapacitated person's or protected person's incapacity 21 
and the appointment of the guardian or conservator.  22 
7.  Denial; other proceedings unaffected.  The denial by a court o f this State of a 23 
petition to accept a guardianship or conservatorship transferred from another state does 24 
not affect the ability of the guardian or conservator to seek appointment as guardian or 25 
conservator in this State under Part 3 or 4 if the court has  jurisdiction to make an 26 
appointment other than by reason of the provisional order of transfer.  27 
SUBPART 4  28 
MISCELLANEOUS PROVIS IONS  29 
§5-541.  Uniformity of application and construction  30 
In applying and construing this Part, consideration must be given to the need to 31 
promote uniformity of the law with respect to its subject matter among states that enact it.  32 
§5-542.  Relation to Electronic Signatures in Global and National Commerce Act  33 
This Part modifies, limits and supersedes the federal Electronic Signatures in Global 34 
and National Commerce Act, 15 United States Code, Section 7001 et seq., but does not 35 
modify, limit or supersede 15 United States Code, Section 7001(c) or authorize electronic 36 
delivery of any of the notices described in 15 United States Code, Sect ion 7003(b).  37 
 
 Page 239 - 128LR0452(01) -1 
 §5-543.  Transitional provisions  1 
1.  Proceedings on or after July 1, 2013.  This Part applies to guardianship and 2 
protective proceedings begun on or after July 1, 2013.  3 
2.  Proceedings before July 1, 2013.  Subparts 1, 3 and 4 and sections 5 -551 and 4 
5-552 apply to proceedings begun before July 1, 2013, regardless of whether a 5 
guardianship or protective order has been issued.  6 
PART 6  7 
PUBLIC GUARDIAN AND CONSERVATOR  8 
§5-601.  Public guardians and conservators; general  9 
1.  Appointment of public guar dian or conservator.  In any case in which a 10 
guardian or conservator may be appointed by the court under this Article, the court may 11 
appoint a public guardian or conservator as provided in this Part for incapacitated persons 12 
who are in need of protective s ervices.  13 
2.  Department of Health and Human Services.  The Department of Health and 14 
Human Services shall act as the public guardian or conservator for incapacitated persons 15 
in need of protective services.  16 
3.  Article applies to public guardians and conserv ators.  Except as otherwise 17 
provided in this Part, the appointment, termination, rights and duties and other provisions 18 
for guardians and conservators in this Article apply to public guardians and conservators.  19 
§5-602.  Priority of private guardian or cons ervator  20 
A public guardian or conservator may not be appointed if the court determines that a 21 
suitable private guardian or conservator is available and willing to assume the 22 
responsibilities of a guardian or conservator.  23 
§5-603.  Exclusiveness of public gua rdian or conservator  24 
When the court has appointed a public guardian or conservator under this Part, no 25 
other guardian or conservator may be appointed for the same ward or protected person 26 
during the continuation of the public guardianship or public conserv atorship.  27 
§5-604.  Nomination of public guardian or conservator  28 
1.  Nomination of public guardian.  Any person who is eligible to petition for 29 
appointment of a guardian under section 5 -304, subsection 1, including the commissioner 30 
of any state department, the head of any state institution, the overseers of the poor and the 31 
welfare director or health officer of any municipality, may nominate the public guardian.  32 
2.  Nomination of public conservator.  Any person who is eligible to petition for 33 
appointment of a conservator under section 5 -403, subsection 1, including the 34 
commissioner of any state department, the head of any state institution, the overseer of 35 
 
 Page 240 - 128LR0452(01) -1 
 the poor and the welfare director or health officer of any municipality, may nominate the 1 
public conserv ator. 2 
3.  Article applies to proceedings for determining appointment.  Except as 3 
supplemented by section 5 -605, the proceedings for determining the appointment of a 4 
public guardian or conservator are governed by the provisions of this Article for the 5 
appoi ntment of guardians and conservators generally.  6 
§5-605.  Acceptance by public guardian or conservator; plan  7 
Prior to the appointment of a public guardian or conservator, the appropriate agency 8 
nominated shall accept or reject the nomination in writing with in 30 days of its receipt of 9 
notification that it has been nominated and if the nomination is accepted shall file a 10 
detailed plan that, as relevant, must include but is not limited to the type of proposed 11 
living arrangement for the ward, how the ward's fin ancial needs will be met, how the 12 
ward's medical and other remedial needs will be met, how the ward's social needs will be 13 
met and a plan for the ward's continuing contact with relatives and friends, as well as a 14 
plan for the management of the ward's or pr otected person's estate in the case of a public 15 
conservatorship.  16 
§5-606.  Officials authorized to act as public guardian or conservator  17 
1.  Commissioner of Health and Human Services.  When the Department of Health 18 
and Human Services is appointed public gua rdian or conservator of an incapacitated 19 
person, the authority of the public guardian or conservator must be exercised by the 20 
Commissioner of Health and Human Services and by any persons duly delegated by the 21 
commissioner to exercise such authority.  22 
2.  Delegation of authority.  Persons duly delegated by the officials authorized to act 23 
under subsection 1 may include a staff of competent social workers or competent social 24 
workers assigned to the public guardian or conservator by the Department of Health and 25 
Human Services.  In the event that the delegation is to an individual, such individual must 26 
be qualified by reason of education or experience, or both, in administering to the needs 27 
of the individual or individuals over whom the individual is to exercise a dministrative or 28 
supervisory authority under the public guardian.  29 
§5-607.  Duties and powers of a public guardian or conservator  30 
A public guardian or conservator has the same powers, rights and duties respecting 31 
the ward or the protected person as provided  for guardians and conservators by the other 32 
Parts of this Article except as otherwise specifically provided in this Part, including the 33 
following particular provisions.  34 
1.  Placement in licensed facility; removal.  A public guardian may place a ward in 35 
a facility described in Title 22, section 1811 only if the facility is duly licensed.  In the 36 
event that the license of any such facility is suspended or revoked, the public guardian 37 
having any ward placed in that facility shall remove the ward and effect an  appropriate 38 
placement of the ward as soon as practicable after knowledge of the suspension or 39 
revocation of the license.  40 
 
 Page 241 - 128LR0452(01) -1 
 2.  Examination and evaluation; report to court. A public guardian or conservator 1 
at least annually, and at any time when ordered by t he court, shall review the case of 2 
every person for whom the public guardian or conservator is acting under this Part.  A 3 
report of each review must be filed with the court.  Each review must contain an 4 
examination and evaluation of the plan created under section 5 -605 for the ward or 5 
protected person and recommendations for a modification of the plan, as appropriate or 6 
necessary.  7 
3.  Records.  A public guardian or conservator shall keep books of account or other 8 
records showing separately the principal amo unt received, increments thereto and 9 
disbursements therefrom for the benefit of the ward or protected person, and such other 10 
records as are appropriate for the particular situation, together with the name of the ward 11 
or protected person, the source from wh ich the money was received and the purpose for 12 
which the money was expended.  13 
4.  In absence of kin, autopsy and burial.  A public guardian, in the absence of 14 
available next of kin, may authorize the performance of an autopsy upon the body of a 15 
deceased war d.  The public guardian, in the absence of available next of kin, or in the 16 
event that next of kin refuses to assume responsibility for the deceased ward, shall cause 17 
any deceased ward to be suitably buried and has authority to expend funds of the ward for  18 
that purpose, and in the event the ward is without funds at the time of death, the public 19 
guardian shall cause the ward to be suitably buried at public expense, as in the case of the 20 
burial of any other deceased indigent person.  21 
§5-608.  No change in righ ts to services  22 
The appointment of a public guardian or conservator in no way enlarges or 23 
diminishes the ward's or protected person's right to services made available to all 24 
incapacitated persons in the State except for the provision of guardianship or 25 
conservatorship services as provided under this Article.  26 
§5-609.  No change in powers and duties of agency heads and trustees  27 
Nothing in this Article abrogates any other powers or duties vested by law in the head 28 
of any public institution, or vested by the set tlor of a trust in the trustee thereof, for the 29 
benefit of any ward or protected person for whom the public guardian or conservator is 30 
appointed.  31 
§5-610.  Bond  32 
The public guardian or conservator is not required to file bonds in individual 33 
guardianships or conservatorships, but shall give a surety bond for the joint benefit of the 34 
wards or protected persons placed under the responsibility of the public guardian or 35 
conservator and the State, with a surety company or companies authorized to do business 36 
within the State, in an amount not less than the total value of all assets held by the public 37 
guardian or conservator, which amount must be computed at the end of each state fiscal 38 
year and approved by the Probate Court for Kennebec County.  At no time may the bo nd 39 
of each of the public guardians or conservators be less than $500 respectively.  40 
 
 Page 242 - 128LR0452(01) -1 
 §5-611.  Compensation  1 
1.  Reasonable expenses; account for costs.  The public guardian or conservator 2 
may receive such reasonable amounts for its expenses as guardian or con servator as the 3 
Probate Court may allow.  The amounts so allowed must be allocated to an account from 4 
which may be drawn expenses for filing fees, bond premiums, court costs and other 5 
expenses required in the administration of the functions of the public g uardian or 6 
conservator.  No amounts thus received may inure to the benefit of any employee of the 7 
public guardian or conservator.  Any balance in the account at the end of a fiscal year 8 
does not lapse but is carried forward from year to year and used for t he purposes provided 9 
for in this subsection.  10 
2.  Reimbursement of personal expenditures.  Any personal expenditures made on 11 
the ward's or protected person's behalf by the public guardian or conservator must, when 12 
properly evidenced, be reimbursed out of th e ward's or protected person's estate.  Claims 13 
for services rendered by state agencies must be submitted to the Probate Court for 14 
approval before payment.  15 
§5-612.  Incapacitated persons; guardian ad litem costs  16 
1.  Guardian ad litem, other special costs.  The costs of the guardian ad litem or 17 
any other special costs may be paid by the Department of Health and Human Services, 18 
within the limits of the department's budget, when:  19 
A.  An allegedly incapacitated person is in need of protective services and:  20 
(1)  A guardian ad litem is appointed under the provisions of this Code; or  21 
(2)  A court incurs special costs in a proceeding concerning the allegedly 22 
incapacitated person; and  23 
B.  Appointment of a public guardian or conservator is sought or the allegedly 24 
incap acitated person, within 3 months prior to the filing of the petition:  25 
(1)  Is or has been a client of the Department of Health and Human Services; or  26 
(2)  Has received services from a worker from the Department of Health and 27 
Human Services.  28 
2.  Payment of costs.  The Department of Health and Human Services is not liable 29 
for the costs set out in subsection 1 if the department can demonstrate that the allegedly 30 
incapacitated person has assets against which the costs may be assessed or that another 31 
more approp riate funding source is available and subject to the court's jurisdiction.  32 
§5-613.  Limited public guardianships  33 
The provisions of section 5 -206 regarding limited guardianships apply to the 34 
appointment of public guardians.  35 
PART 7  36 
UNIFORM HEALTH CARE DECISI ONS ACT  37 
 
 Page 243 - 128LR0452(01) -1 
 §5-701.  Short title  1 
This Part may be known and cited as "the Uniform Health Care Decisions Act."  2 
§5-702.  Definitions  3 
As used in this Part, unless the context otherwise indicates, the following terms have 4 
the following meanings.  5 
1.  Advance healt h care directive.  "Advance health care directive" means an 6 
individual instruction from, or a power of attorney for health care by, an individual with 7 
capacity.  8 
2.  Agent.  "Agent" means an individual with capacity designated in a power of 9 
attorney for hea lth care to make a health care decision for the individual granting the 10 
power.  11 
3.  Capacity.  "Capacity" means the ability to have a basic understanding of the 12 
diagnosed condition and to understand the significant benefits, risks and alternatives to 13 
the pr oposed health care and the consequences of forgoing the proposed treatment, the 14 
ability to make and communicate a health care decision and the ability to understand the 15 
consequences of designating an agent or surrogate to make health care decisions.  16 
4.  Guardian.  "Guardian" means a judicially appointed guardian or conservator 17 
having authority to make a health care decision for an individual.  18 
5.  Health care.  "Health care" means any care, treatment, service or procedure to 19 
maintain, diagnose or otherwise a ffect an individual's physical or mental condition.  20 
6.  Health care decision.  "Health care decision" means a decision made by an 21 
individual with capacity or by the individual's agent, guardian or surrogate regarding the 22 
individual's health care, including : 23 
A.  Selection and discharge of health care providers and institutions;  24 
B.  Approval or disapproval of diagnostic tests, surgical procedures, programs of 25 
medication and orders not to resuscitate; and  26 
C.  Directions to provide, withhold or withdraw artific ial nutrition and hydration and 27 
all other forms of health care, including life -sustaining treatment.  28 
7.  Health care institution.  "Health care institution" means an institution, facility or 29 
agency licensed, certified or otherwise authorized or permitted b y law to provide health 30 
care in the ordinary course of business.  31 
8.  Health care provider.  "Health care provider" means an individual licensed, 32 
certified or otherwise authorized or permitted by law to provide health care in the 33 
ordinary course of business  or practice of a profession.  34 
9.  Individual instruction.  "Individual instruction" means a direction from an 35 
individual with capacity concerning a health care decision for the individual.  36 
 
 Page 244 - 128LR0452(01) -1 
 10.  Life-sustaining treatment.  "Life -sustaining treatment" means any medical 1 
procedure or intervention that, when administered to a person without capacity and in 2 
either a terminal condition or a persistent vegetative state, will serve only to prolong the 3 
process of dying.  "Life -sustaining treatment" may include artifi cially administered 4 
nutrition and hydration, which is the provision of nutrients and liquids through the use of 5 
tubes, intravenous procedures or similar medical interventions.  6 
11.  Persistent vegetative state.  "Persistent vegetative state" means a state t hat 7 
occurs after coma in which the patient totally lacks higher cortical and cognitive function, 8 
but maintains vegetative brain stem processes, with no realistic possibility of recovery, as 9 
diagnosed in accordance with acceptable medical standards.  10 
12.  Person.  "Person" means an individual, corporation, business trust, estate, trust, 11 
partnership, association, joint venture, government, governmental subdivision, agency or 12 
instrumentality or any other legal or commercial entity.  13 
13.  Physician.  "Physician" means an individual authorized to practice medicine 14 
under Title 32.  15 
14.  Power of attorney for health care.  "Power of attorney for health care" means 16 
the designation of an agent with capacity to make health care decisions for the individual 17 
granting the p ower.  18 
15.  Primary physician.  "Primary physician" means a physician designated by an 19 
individual with capacity or by the individual's agent, guardian or surrogate to have 20 
primary responsibility for the individual's health care or, in the absence of a desig nation 21 
or if the designated physician is not reasonably available, a physician who undertakes the 22 
responsibility.  23 
16.  Reasonably available.  "Reasonably available" means readily able to be 24 
contacted without undue effort and willing and able to act in a ti mely manner considering 25 
the urgency of the patient's health care needs.  26 
17.  Supervising health care provider.  "Supervising health care provider" means 27 
the primary physician or, if there is no primary physician or the primary physician is not 28 
reasonably a vailable, the health care provider who has undertaken primary responsibility 29 
for a patient's health care.  30 
18.  Surrogate.  "Surrogate" means an individual with capacity, other than a patient's 31 
agent or guardian, authorized under this Part to make health ca re decisions as provided in 32 
section 5 -706. 33 
19.  Terminal condition.  "Terminal condition" means an incurable and irreversible 34 
condition that, without the administration of life -sustaining treatment, in the opinion of 35 
the primary physician, will result in d eath within a relatively short time.  36 
§5-703.  Advance health care directives  37 
1.  Individual instruction.  An adult or emancipated minor with capacity may give 38 
an individual instruction.  The instruction may be oral or written.  The instruction may be 39 
 
 Page 245 - 128LR0452(01) -1 
 limit ed to take effect only if a specified condition arises.  An oral instruction is valid only 1 
if made to a health care provider or to an individual who may serve as a surrogate under 2 
section 5 -706, subsection 2.  3 
2.  Power of attorney for health care.  An adul t or emancipated minor with capacity 4 
may execute a power of attorney for health care, which may authorize the agent to make 5 
any health care decision the principal could have made while having capacity.  The power 6 
must be in writing and signed by the princi pal and 2 witnesses.  Notwithstanding any law 7 
validating electronic or digital signatures, signatures of the principal and witnesses must 8 
be made in person and not by electronic means.  The power remains in effect 9 
notwithstanding the principal's later inca pacity and may include individual instructions.  10 
Unless related to the principal by blood, marriage or adoption, an agent may not be an 11 
owner, operator or employee of a residential long -term health care institution at which the 12 
principal is receiving care.  13 
3.  Effective upon determination that principal lacks capacity.  Unless otherwise 14 
specified in a power of attorney for health care, the authority of an agent becomes 15 
effective only upon a determination that the principal lacks capacity and ceases to be 16 
effective upon a determination that the principal has recovered capacity.  17 
4.  Determination.  Unless otherwise specified in a written advance health care 18 
directive, a determination that an individual lacks or has recovered capacity or that 19 
another condition exists that affects an individual instruction, the authority of an agent or 20 
the validity of an advance health care directive must be made by the primary physician, 21 
by a court of competent jurisdiction or, for an individual who has included a directive 22 
authorizing mental health treatment in an advance health care directive, by a person 23 
qualified to conduct an examination pursuant to Title 34 -B, section 3863.  24 
5.  Decision in accordance with instructions, wishes, best interest.  An agent shall 25 
make a health ca re decision in accordance with the principal's individual instructions, if 26 
any, and other wishes to the extent known to the agent.  Otherwise, the agent shall make 27 
the decision in accordance with the agent's determination of the principal's best interest.  28 
In determining the principal's best interest, the agent shall consider the principal's 29 
personal values to the extent known to the agent.  30 
6.  Effective without judicial approval.  A health care decision made by an agent 31 
for a principal is effective without  judicial approval.  32 
7.  Nomination of guardian.  A written advance health care directive may include 33 
the individual's nomination of a guardian of the person.  34 
8.  Validity of advance health care directive.  An advance health care directive is 35 
valid for purp oses of this Part if it complies with this Part, regardless of when or where 36 
executed or communicated, or if it is valid under the laws of the state in which it was 37 
executed.  An advance health care directive that is valid where executed or communicated 38 
is valid for the purposes of this Part.  39 
 
 Page 246 - 128LR0452(01) -1 
 9.  Directing mental health treatment.  An advance health care directive is valid for 1 
purposes of directing mental health treatment.  The terms of the directive must be 2 
construed in accordance with this Part and Title 34-B, sections 3831 and 3862.  3 
10.  Personal representative for purposes of federal law.  A surrogate or an agent 4 
named in an advance health care directive has the power and authority to serve as the 5 
personal representative of the patient who executed the h ealth care directive for all 6 
purposes of the federal Health Insurance Portability and Accountability Act of 1996, 42 7 
United States Code, Section 1320d et seq. and its regulations, 45 Code of Federal 8 
Regulations, Parts 160 -164.  The surrogate or agent has a ll the rights of the patient with 9 
respect to the use and disclosure of the individually identifiable health information and 10 
other medical records of the patient.  11 
§5-704.  Revocation of advance health care directive  12 
1.  Revocation of designation of agent.  An individual with capacity may revoke the 13 
designation of an agent only by a signed writing or by personally informing the 14 
supervising health care provider.  15 
2.  Revocation of advance health care directive.  An individual with capacity may 16 
revoke all or par t of an advance health care directive, other than the designation of an 17 
agent, at any time and in any manner that communicates an intent to revoke.  18 
3.  Communication of revocation.  A health care provider, agent, guardian or 19 
surrogate who is informed of a revocation by an individual with capacity shall promptly 20 
communicate the fact of the revocation to the supervising health care provider and to any 21 
health care institution at which the patient is receiving care.  22 
4.  Revocation of spouse as agent.  A decree of annulment, divorce, dissolution of 23 
marriage or legal separation revokes a previous designation of a spouse as agent unless 24 
otherwise specified in the decree or in a power of attorney for health care.  25 
5.  Revocation of earlier advance health care directi ve in conflict.  An advance 26 
health care directive that conflicts with an earlier advance health care directive revokes 27 
the earlier directive to the extent of the conflict.  28 
§5-705.  Optional form  29 
The following form may, but need not, be used to create an ad vance health care 30 
directive.  The other sections of this Part govern the effect of this or any other writing 31 
used to create an advance health care directive.  An individual with capacity may 32 
complete or modify all or any part of the following form.  33 
ADVANCE  HEALTH CARE DIRECTIVE  34 
 
Explanation  35 
 
 Page 247 - 128LR0452(01) -1 
 You have the right to give instructions about your own health care.  You also have 1 
the right to name someone else to make health care decisions for you.  This form lets you 2 
do either or both of these things.  It also let s you express your wishes regarding donation 3 
of organs and the designation of your primary physician.  If you use this form, you may 4 
complete or modify all or any part of it.  You are free to use a different form.  5 
Part 1 of this form is a power of attorney  for health care.  Part 1 lets you name 6 
another individual as agent to make health care decisions for you if you become incapable 7 
of making your own decisions or if you want someone else to make those decisions for 8 
you now even though you are still capable .  You may also name an alternate agent to act 9 
for you if your first choice is not willing, able or reasonably available to make decisions 10 
for you.  Unless related to you, your agent may not be an owner, operator or employee of 11 
a residential long -term heal th care institution at which you are receiving care.  12 
Unless the form you sign limits the authority of your agent, your agent may make all 13 
health care decisions for you.  This form has a place for you to limit the authority of your 14 
agent.  You need not limi t the authority of your agent if you wish to rely on your agent 15 
for all health care decisions that may have to be made.  If you choose not to limit the 16 
authority of your agent, your agent will have the right to:  17 
(1)  Consent or refuse consent to any care, treatment, service or procedure to 18 
maintain, diagnose or otherwise affect a physical or mental condition;  19 
(2)  Select or discharge health care providers and institutions;  20 
(3)  Approve or disapprove diagnostic tests, surgical procedures, programs of 21 
medicat ion and orders not to resuscitate; and  22 
(4)  Direct the provision, withholding or withdrawal of artificial nutrition and 23 
hydration and all other forms of health care, including life -sustaining treatment.  24 
Part 2 of this form lets you give specific instructio ns about any aspect of your health 25 
care.  Choices are provided for you to express your wishes regarding the provision, 26 
withholding or withdrawal of treatment to keep you alive, including the provision of 27 
artificial nutrition and hydration, as well as the p rovision of pain relief.  Space is also 28 
provided for you to add to the choices you have made or for you to write out any 29 
additional wishes.  30 
Part 3 of this form lets you express an intention to donate your bodily organs and 31 
tissues following your death.  32 
Part 4 of this form lets you designate a physician to have primary responsibility for 33 
your health care.  34 
After completing this form, sign and date the form at the end.  You must have 2 other 35 
individuals sign as witnesses.  Give a copy of the signed and complet ed form to your 36 
physician, to any other health care providers you may have, to any health care institution 37 
at which you are receiving care and to any health care agents you have named.  You 38 
should talk to the person you have named as agent to make sure tha t he or she 39 
understands your wishes and is willing to take the responsibility.  40 
 
 Page 248 - 128LR0452(01) -1 
 You have the right to revoke this advance health care directive or replace this form at 1 
any time.  2
