§5-706.  Decisions by surrogate  2 
1.  Decisions by surrogate.  A surrogate may make a decision to withhold or 3 
withdraw life -sustaining treatment for a patient who is an adult or emancip ated minor if 4 
the patient has been determined by the primary physician to lack capacity, no agent or 5 
guardian has been appointed or the agent or guardian is not reasonably available and the 6 
patient is in a terminal condition or a persistent vegetative stat e as determined by the 7 
primary physician.  8 
A surrogate also is authorized to make any other health care decision for a patient who is 9 
an adult or emancipated minor if the patient has been determined by the primary 10 
physician to lack capacity and no agent or guardian exists, except that a surrogate may 11 
not deny surgery, procedures or other interventions that are lifesaving and medically 12 
necessary.  13 
A medically necessary procedure is one providing the most patient -appropriate 14 
intervention or procedure that can b e safely and effectively given.  15 
2.  Priority of who may act as surrogate.  Any member of the following classes of 16 
the patient's family who is reasonably available, in descending order of priority, may act 17 
as surrogate:  18 
A.  The spouse, unless legally separa ted; 19 
B.  An adult who shares an emotional, physical and financial relationship with the 20 
patient similar to that of a spouse;  21 
C.  An adult child;  22 
D.  A parent;  23 
E.  An adult brother or sister;  24 
F.  An adult grandchild;  25 
G.  An adult niece or nephew, related by  blood or adoption;  26 
H.  An adult aunt or uncle, related by blood or adoption; or  27 
I.  Any adult relative of the patient, related by blood or adoption, who is familiar with 28 
the patient's personal values and is reasonably available for consultation.  29 
3.  Adult  who has exhibited special concern.  If none of the individuals eligible to 30 
act as surrogate under subsection 2 is reasonably available, an adult who has exhibited 31 
special concern for the patient, who is familiar with the patient's personal values and who 32 
is reasonably available may act as surrogate.  33 
4.  Communication of assumption of authority.  A surrogate shall communicate the 34 
surrogate's assumption of authority as promptly as practicable to the members of the 35 
patient's family specified in subsection 2 w ho can be readily contacted.  36 
5.  Conflict among potential surrogates; neutral 3rd party or court.  If more than 37 
one member of a class assumes authority to act as surrogate and they, or members of 38 
 
 Page 254 - 128LR0452(01) -1 
 different classes who are reasonably available, do not agree  on a health care decision and 1 
the supervising health care provider is so informed, the supervising health care provider 2 
may comply with the decision of the class having priority or a majority of the members of 3 
that class who have communicated their views to the provider.  The health care provider 4 
may refer the members of the class or classes to a neutral 3rd party for assistance in 5 
resolving the dispute or to a court of competent jurisdiction.  If the class is evenly divided 6 
concerning the health care deci sion and the supervising health care provider is so 7 
informed, that class and all individuals having lower priority are disqualified from 8 
making the decision.  9 
6.  Decision in accordance with instructions, wishes, best interest.  A surrogate 10 
shall make a hea lth care decision in accordance with the patient's individual instructions, 11 
if any, and other wishes to the extent known to the surrogate.  Otherwise, the surrogate 12 
shall make the decision in accordance with the surrogate's determination of the patient's 13 
best interest and in good faith.  In determining the patient's best interest, the surrogate 14 
shall consider the patient's personal values to the extent known to the surrogate.  A 15 
consent is not valid if it conflicts with the intention of the patient previous ly expressed to 16 
the surrogate.  17 
7.  Effective without judicial approval.  A health care decision made by a surrogate 18 
for a patient lacking capacity is effective without judicial approval.  19 
8.  Disqualification.  An individual with capacity at any time may di squalify another, 20 
including a member of the individual's family, from acting as the individual's surrogate 21 
by a signed writing or by personally informing the supervising health care provider of the 22 
disqualification.  23 
9.  Conflict of interest.  A surrogate m ay not be an owner, operator or employee of a 24 
residential long -term health care institution at which the patient is receiving care unless 25 
the surrogate is one of the following:  26 
A.  The spouse of the patient;  27 
B.  An adult child of the patient;  28 
C.  A parent of the patient; or  29 
D.  A relative of the patient with whom the patient has resided for more than 6 30 
months prior to the decision.  31 
10.  Written declaration supporting authority.  A supervising health care provider 32 
may require an individual claiming the right  to act as surrogate for a patient to provide a 33 
written declaration under penalty of perjury stating facts and circumstances reasonably 34 
sufficient to establish the claimed authority.  35 
§5-707.  Decisions by guardian  36 
1.  Compliance with expressed wishes; cann ot revoke advance health care 37 
directive.  Except as authorized by a court of competent jurisdiction, a guardian shall 38 
comply with the ward's individual instructions and other wishes, if any, expressed while 39 
 
 Page 255 - 128LR0452(01) -1 
 the ward had capacity and to the extent known to the guardian and may not revoke the 1 
ward's advance health care directive unless the appointing court expressly so authorizes.  2 
2.  Agent's decision takes precedence.  Absent a court order to the contrary, a health 3 
care decision of an agent takes precedence over that of a guardian.  4 
3.  Effective without judicial approval; exceptions.  A health care decision made 5 
by a guardian for the ward is effective without judicial approval, except under the 6 
following circumstances:  7 
A.  The guardian's decision is contrary to the ward's individual instructions and other 8 
wishes, expressed while the ward had capacity; or  9 
B.  The guardian seeks to withhold or withdraw life -sustaining treatment from the 10 
ward, against the advice of the ward's primary physician and in the absence of 11 
instructions from the ward, made while the ward had capacity.  12 
§5-708.  Obligations of health care provider  13 
1.  Communicate to patient.  Before implementing a health care decision made for a 14 
patient, a supervising health care provider, if possible, shall  promptly communicate to the 15 
patient the decision made and the identity of the person making the decision.  16 
2.  Include in record advance health care directive, surrogate, revocation, 17 
disqualification.  A supervising health care provider who knows of the ex istence of an 18 
advance health care directive, a revocation of an advance health care directive or a 19 
designation or disqualification of a surrogate shall promptly record its existence in the 20 
patient's health care record and, if it is in writing, shall reques t a copy and if one is 21 
furnished shall arrange for its maintenance in the health care record.  22 
3.  Include in record determinations on capacity; communicate.  A primary 23 
physician who makes or is informed of a determination that a patient lacks or has 24 
recove red capacity or that another condition exists that affects an individual instruction or 25 
the authority of an agent, guardian or surrogate or the validity of an advance health care 26 
directive shall promptly record the determination in the patient's health car e record and 27 
communicate the determination to the patient, if possible, and to any person then 28 
authorized to make health care decisions for the patient.  29 
4.  Compliance.  Except as provided in subsections 5 and 6, a health care provider or 30 
health care insti tution providing care to a patient shall:  31 
A.  Comply with an individual instruction of the patient and with a reasonable 32 
interpretation of that instruction made by a person then authorized to make health 33 
care decisions for the patient; and  34 
B.  Comply with a health care decision for the patient made by a person then 35 
authorized to make health care decisions for the patient to the same extent as if the 36 
decision had been made by the patient while having capacity.  37 
5.  Decline to comply; not in compliance; reason s of conscience; contrary to 38 
policy.  A health care provider may decline to comply with an individual instruction or 39 
 
 Page 256 - 128LR0452(01) -1 
 health care decision if the instruction or decision appears not to be in compliance with 1 
this Part or for reasons of conscience.  A health care institution may decline to comply 2 
with an individual instruction or health care decision if the instruction or decision appears 3 
not to be in compliance with this Part or if the instruction or decision is contrary to a 4 
policy of the institution that is  expressly based on reasons of conscience and if the policy 5 
was timely communicated to the patient or to a person then authorized to make health 6 
care decisions for the patient.  7 
6.  Decline to comply; ineffective health care; contrary to generally accepted 8 
standards.  A health care provider or health care institution may decline to comply with 9 
an individual instruction or health care decision that requires medically ineffective health 10 
care or health care contrary to generally accepted health care standards a pplicable to the 11 
health care provider or institution.  12 
7.  Duties if decline to comply.  A health care provider or health care institution that 13 
declines to comply with an individual instruction or health care decision shall:  14 
A.  Promptly so inform the patie nt, if possible, and any person then authorized to 15 
make health care decisions for the patient;  16 
B.  Provide continuing care to the patient until a transfer can be effected or a court of 17 
competent jurisdiction issues a final order regarding the decision; and  18 
C.  Unless the patient or person then authorized to make health care decisions for the 19 
patient refuses assistance, immediately make all reasonable efforts to assist in the 20 
transfer of the patient to another health care provider or institution that is will ing to 21 
comply with the instruction or decision.  22 
8.  Not as a condition for providing health care.  A health care provider or health 23 
care institution may not require or prohibit the execution or revocation of an advance 24 
health care directive as a condition for providing health care.  25 
§5-709.  Health care information  26 
Unless otherwise specified in an advance health care directive, a person then 27 
authorized to make health care decisions for a patient has the same rights as the patient to 28 
request, receive, examine , copy and consent to the disclosure of medical or any other 29 
health care information.  30 
§5-710.  Immunities  31 
1.  Health care provider or institution.  A health care provider or health care 32 
institution acting in good faith and in accordance with generally acce pted health care 33 
standards applicable to the health care provider or health care institution is not subject to 34 
civil or criminal liability or to discipline for unprofessional conduct for:  35 
A.  Complying with a health care decision of a person apparently hav ing authority 36 
and capacity to make a health care decision for a patient, including a decision to 37 
withhold or withdraw health care;  38 
 
 Page 257 - 128LR0452(01) -1 
 B.  Declining to comply with a health care decision of a person based on a belief that 1 
the person then lacked authority or ca pacity or that the decision otherwise does not 2 
comply with this Part;  3 
C.  Complying with an advance health care directive and assuming that the directive 4 
was valid when made and has not been revoked or terminated; or  5 
D.  Seeking judicial relief from a cour t of competent jurisdiction.  6 
2.  Agent, guardian or surrogate.  An individual acting as agent, guardian or 7 
surrogate under this Part is not subject to civil or criminal liability or to discipline for 8 
unprofessional conduct for health care decisions made in  good faith.  9 
§5-711.  Statutory damages  10 
1.  Health care provider or institution; intentional violation.  A health care 11 
provider or health care institution that intentionally violates this Part is subject to liability 12 
to the aggrieved individual for damages  of $500 or actual damages resulting from the 13 
violation, whichever is greater, plus reasonable attorney's fees.  14 
2.  Interference with autonomy to make health care decisions.  A person who 15 
intentionally falsifies, forges, conceals, defaces or obliterates an  individual's advance 16 
health care directive or a revocation of an advance health care directive without the 17 
individual's consent, or who coerces or fraudulently induces an individual to give, revoke 18 
or not to give an advance health care directive, is subje ct to liability to that individual for 19 
damages of $2,500 or actual damages resulting from the action, whichever is greater, plus 20 
reasonable attorney's fees.  21 
§5-712.  Capacity  22 
1.  Right to make health care decisions while having capacity.  This Part does no t 23 
affect the right of an individual to make health care decisions while having capacity to do 24 
so. 25 
2.  Presumed to have capacity; rebuttal.  An individual is presumed to have 26 
capacity to make a health care decision, to give or revoke an advance health care directive 27 
and to designate or disqualify a surrogate.  This presumption may be rebutted by a 28 
determination by the individual's primary physician or by a court of competent 29 
jurisdiction.  30 
§5-713.  Effect of copy  31 
A copy of a written advance health care direct ive, revocation of an advance health 32 
care directive or designation or disqualification of a surrogate has the same effect as the 33 
original.  34 
§5-714.  Effect of Part  35 
1.  No presumption concerning intention if no advance health care directive or if 36 
revoked.  This Part does not create a presumption concerning the intention of an 37 
individual who has not made or who has revoked an advance health care directive.  38 
 
 Page 258 - 128LR0452(01) -1 
 2.  Death resulting from withholding or withdrawing health care.  Death resulting 1 
from the withholding or  withdrawal of health care in accordance with this Part does not 2 
for any purpose constitute a suicide or homicide or legally impair or invalidate a policy of 3 
insurance or an annuity providing a death benefit, notwithstanding any term of the policy 4 
or annui ty to the contrary.  5 
3.  Prohibited by other statutes.  This Part does not authorize mercy killing, assisted 6 
suicide, euthanasia or the provision, withholding or withdrawal of health care to the 7 
extent prohibited by other statutes of this State.  8 
4.  Health care contrary to generally accepted health care standards.  This Part 9 
does not authorize or require a health care provider or health care institution to provide 10 
health care contrary to generally accepted health care standards applicable to the health 11 
care provider or health care institution.  12 
5.  Admission to a mental health institution.  This Part does not authorize an agent 13 
or surrogate to consent to the admission of an individual to a mental health institution 14 
unless the individual's written advance healt h care directive expressly so provides.  15 
6.  Other statutes governing treatment for mental illness.  This Part does not 16 
affect other statutes of this State governing treatment for mental illness of an individual 17 
involuntarily committed to a mental health in stitution.  18 
§5-715.  Judicial relief  19 
On petition of a patient, the patient's agent, guardian or surrogate, a health care or 20 
social services provider or health care institution involved with the patient's care, a state 21 
agency mandated to provide adult protec tive services pursuant to Title 22, chapter 958 -A, 22 
or an adult relative or adult friend of the patient, the court may enjoin or direct a health 23 
care decision or other equitable relief.  24 
§5-716.  Uniformity of application and construction  25 
This Part must be a pplied and construed to effectuate its general purpose to make 26 
uniform the law with respect to the subject matter of this Part among states enacting it.  27 
§5-717.  Military advanced medical directives  28 
A military advanced medical directive executed in accorda nce with 10 United States 29 
Code, Section 1044c is valid in this State.  30 
PART 8  31 
MAINE UNIFORM POWER OF ATTORNEY ACT  32 
SUBPART 1  33 
GENERAL PROVISIONS A ND DEFINITIONS  34 
 
 Page 259 - 128LR0452(01) -1 
 §5-801.  Short title  1 
This Part may be known and cited as "the Maine Uniform Power of Attorney Act. " 2 
§5-802.  Definitions  3 
As used in this Part, unless the context otherwise indicates, the following terms have 4 
the following meanings.  5 
1.  Agent.  "Agent" means a person granted authority to act for a principal under a 6 
power of attorney, whether denominated  an agent, attorney -in-fact or otherwise.  "Agent" 7 
includes an original agent, coagent, successor agent and a person to whom an agent's 8 
authority is delegated.  9 
2.  Durable.  "Durable," with respect to a power of attorney, means not terminated by 10 
the princi pal's incapacity.  11 
3.  Electronic.  "Electronic" means relating to technology having electrical, digital, 12 
magnetic, wireless, optical, electromagnetic or similar capabilities.  13 
4.  Good faith.  "Good faith" means honesty in fact.  14 
5.  Incapacity.  "Incapacity " means inability of an individual to effectively manage 15 
property or business affairs because the individual:  16 
A.  Is impaired by reason of mental illness, mental deficiency, physical illness or 17 
disability, chronic use of drugs, chronic intoxication or othe r cause to the extent that 18 
the individual lacks sufficient understanding, capacity or ability to receive and 19 
evaluate information or make or communicate decisions regarding the individual's 20 
property or business affairs; or  21 
B.  Is: 22 
(1)  Missing;  23 
(2)  Detai ned, including incarcerated in a penal system; or  24 
(3)  Outside the United States and unable to return.  25 
6.  Person.  "Person" means an individual, corporation, business trust, estate, trust, 26 
partnership, limited liability company, association, joint venture , public corporation, 27 
government or governmental subdivision, agency or instrumentality or any other legal or 28 
commercial entity.  29 
7.  Power of attorney.  "Power of attorney" means a writing or other record that 30 
grants authority to an agent to act in the pla ce of the principal, whether or not the term 31 
"power of attorney" is used.  32 
8.  Presently exercisable general power of appointment.  "Presently exercisable 33 
general power of appointment," with respect to property or a property interest subject to a 34 
power of a ppointment, means power exercisable at the time in question to vest absolute 35 
ownership in the principal individually, the principal's estate, the principal's creditors or 36 
 
 Page 260 - 128LR0452(01) -1 
 the creditors of the principal's estate.  "Presently exercisable general power of 1 
appointment" includes a power of appointment not exercisable until the occurrence of a 2 
specified event, the satisfaction of an ascertainable standard or the passage of a specified 3 
period only after the occurrence of the specified event, the satisfaction of th e 4 
ascertainable standard or the passage of the specified period.  "Presently exercisable 5 
general power of appointment" does not include a power exercisable in a fiduciary 6 
capacity or only by will.  7 
9.  Principal.  "Principal" means an individual who grants authority to an agent in a 8 
power of attorney.  9 
10.  Property.  "Property" means anything that may be the subject of ownership, 10 
whether real or personal or legal or equitable, or any interest or right therein.  11 
11.  Sign.  "Sign" means, with present intent to  authenticate or adopt a record:  12 
A.  To execute or adopt a tangible symbol; or  13 
B.  To attach to or logically associate with the record an electronic sound, symbol or 14 
process.  15 
12.  Stocks and bonds.  "Stocks and bonds" means stocks, bonds, mutual funds and 16 
all other types of securities and financial instruments, whether held directly, indirectly or 17 
in any other manner.  "Stocks and bonds" does not include commodity futures contracts 18 
and call or put options on stocks or stock indexes.  19 
§5-803.  Applicability  20 
This Part applies to all powers of attorney except:  21 
1.  Coupled with an interest in the subject of the power.  A power to the extent it 22 
is coupled with an interest in the subject of the power, including a power given to or for 23 
the benefit of a creditor in c onnection with a credit transaction;  24 
2.  Health care decisions.  A power to make health care decisions;  25 
3.  Proxy or other delegation to exercise rights.  A proxy or other delegation to 26 
exercise voting rights or management rights with respect to an entity;  and 27 
4.  Governmental purpose.  A power created on a form prescribed by a government 28 
or governmental subdivision, agency or instrumentality for a governmental purpose.  29 
§5-804.  Power of attorney is durable  30 
A power of attorney created under this Part is dur able unless it expressly provides 31 
that it is terminated by the incapacity of the principal.  32 
§5-805.  Execution of power of attorney; notices  33 
1.  Signed by principal; acknowledged.  A power of attorney must be signed by the 34 
principal or in the principal's c onscious presence by another individual directed by the 35 
principal to sign the principal's name on the power of attorney.  A signature on a power of 36 
 
 Page 261 - 128LR0452(01) -1 
 attorney is presumed to be genuine if the principal acknowledges the signature before a 1 
notary public or oth er individual authorized by law to take acknowledgments.  A power 2 
of attorney under this Part is not valid unless it is acknowledged before a notary public or 3 
other individual authorized by law to take acknowledgments.  4 
2.  Notices for durable power of atto rney.  A durable power of attorney under this 5 
Part is not valid unless it contains the following notices substantially in the following 6 
form:  7 
"Notice to the Principal:  As the "Principal" you are using this power of attorney to grant 8 
power to another perso n (called the Agent) to make decisions about your property and to 9 
use your property on your behalf.  Under this power of attorney you give your Agent 10 
broad and sweeping powers to sell or otherwise dispose of your property without notice 11 
to you.  Under this  document your Agent will continue to have these powers after you 12 
become incapacitated.  The powers that you give your Agent are explained more fully in 13 
the Maine Uniform Power of Attorney Act, Maine Revised Statutes, Title 18 -C, Article 5, 14 
Part 8.  You ha ve the right to revoke this power of attorney at any time as long as you are 15 
not incapacitated.  If there is anything about this power of attorney that you do not 16 
understand, you should ask an attorney to explain it to you.  17 
Notice to the Agent:  As the "Ag ent" you are given power under this power of attorney to 18 
make decisions about the property belonging to the Principal and to dispose of the 19 
Principal's property on the Principal's behalf in accordance with the terms of this power 20 
of attorney.  This power o f attorney is valid only if the Principal is of sound mind when 21 
the Principal signs it.  When you accept the authority granted under this power of 22 
attorney, a special legal relationship is created between you and the Principal.  This 23 
relationship imposes u pon you legal duties that continue until you resign or the power of 24 
attorney is terminated or revoked.  The duties are more fully explained in the Maine 25 
Uniform Power of Attorney Act, Maine Revised Statutes, Title 18 -C, Article 5, Part 8 and 26 
Title 18 -B, se ctions 802 to 807 and Title 18 -B, chapter 9.  As the Agent, you are 27 
generally not entitled to use the Principal's property for your own benefit or to make gifts 28 
to yourself or others unless the power of attorney gives you such authority.  If you violate 29 
your duty under this power of attorney, you may be liable for damages and may be 30 
subject to criminal prosecution.  You must stop acting on behalf of the Principal if you 31 
learn of any event that terminates this power of attorney or your authority under this 32 
power of attorney.  Events of termination are more fully explained in the Maine Uniform 33 
Power of Attorney Act and include, but are not limited to, revocation of your authority or 34 
of the power of attorney by the Principal, the death of the Principal or the c ommencement 35 
of divorce proceedings between you and the Principal.  If there is anything about this 36 
power of attorney or your duties under it that you do not understand, you should ask an 37 
attorney to explain it to you."  38 
§5-806.  Validity of power of attorne y 39 
1.  Executed on or after January 1, 2019.  A power of attorney executed in this 40 
State on or after January 1, 2019 is valid if its execution complies with section 5 -805. 41 
 
 Page 262 - 128LR0452(01) -1 
 2.  Executed on or after July 1, 2010 but before January 1, 2019.  A power of 1 
attorne y executed on or after July 1, 2010 but before January 1, 2019 is valid if its 2 
execution complied with former Title 18 -A, section 5 -906. 3 
3.  Executed before July 1, 2010.  A power of attorney executed in this State before 4 
July 1, 2010 is valid if its execu tion complied with the law of this State as it existed at the 5 
time of execution.  6 
4.  Executed other than in this State.  A power of attorney executed other than in 7 
this State is valid in this State if, when the power of attorney was executed, the execution  8 
complied with:  9 
A.  The law of the jurisdiction that determines the meaning and effect of the power of 10 
attorney pursuant to section 5 -807; or  11 
B.  The requirements for a military power of attorney pursuant to 10 United States 12 
Code, Section 1044b, as amended . 13 
5.  Copy.  Except as otherwise provided by statute other than this Part, a photocopy 14 
or electronically transmitted copy of an original power of attorney has the same effect as 15 
the original.  16 
§5-807.  Meaning and effect of power of attorney  17 
The meaning and  effect of a power of attorney are determined by the law of the 18 
jurisdiction indicated in the power of attorney and, in the absence of an indication of 19 
jurisdiction, by the law of the jurisdiction in which the power of attorney was executed.  20 
§5-808.  Nomin ation of conservator or guardian; relation of agent to court - 21 
appointed fiduciary  22 
1.  Nomination of conservator or guardian.  In a power of attorney, a principal may 23 
nominate a conservator of the principal's estate or guardian of the principal’s person for 24 
consideration by the court if protective proceedings for the principal's estate or person are 25 
begun after the principal executes the power of attorney.  Except for good cause shown or 26 
disqualification, the court shall make its appointment in accordance wit h the principal's 27 
most recent nomination.  28 
2.  Relation of agent to court -appointed fiduciary.  If, after a principal executes a 29 
power of attorney, a court appoints a conservator of the principal's estate or other 30 
fiduciary charged with the management of so me or all of the principal's property, the 31 
agent is accountable to the fiduciary as well as to the principal.  The power of attorney is 32 
not terminated and the agent's authority continues unless limited, suspended or terminated 33 
by the court.  34 
§5-809.  When p ower of attorney effective  35 
1.  Effective when executed unless otherwise provided.  A power of attorney is 36 
effective when executed unless the principal provides in the power of attorney that it 37 
becomes effective at a future date or upon the occurrence of a future event or 38 
contingency.  39 
 
 Page 263 - 128LR0452(01) -1 
 2.  Future event or contingency; determination.  If a power of attorney becomes 1 
effective upon the occurrence of a future event or contingency, the principal, in the power 2 
of attorney, may authorize one or more persons to dete rmine in a writing or other record 3 
that the event or contingency has occurred.  4 
3.  Incapacity; determination.  If a power of attorney becomes effective upon the 5 
principal's incapacity and the principal has not authorized a person to determine whether 6 
the principal is incapacitated, or the person authorized is unable or unwilling to make the 7 
determination, the power of attorney becomes effective upon a determination in a writing 8 
or other record by:  9 
A.  A physician that the principal is incapacitated within the meaning of section 10 
5-802, subsection 5, paragraph A; or  11 
B.  An attorney, a judge or an appropriate governmental official that the principal is 12 
incapacitated within the meaning of section 5 -802, subsection 5, paragraph B.  13 
4.  Personal representative pur suant to federal law.  A person authorized by the 14 
principal in the power of attorney to determine that the principal is incapacitated may act 15 
as the principal's personal representative pursuant to the federal Health Insurance 16 
Portability and Accountability  Act of 1996, 42 United States Code, Section 1320d et seq., 17 
as amended, and applicable regulations, to obtain access to the principal's health care 18 
information and communicate with the principal's health care provider.  19 
§5-810.  Termination of power of atto rney or agent's authority  20 
1.  Termination of power of attorney.  A power of attorney terminates when:  21 
A.  The principal dies;  22 
B.  The principal becomes incapacitated, if the power of attorney is not durable;  23 
C.  The principal revokes the power of attorney;  24 
D.  The power of attorney provides that it terminates;  25 
E.  The purpose of the power of attorney is accomplished; or  26 
F.  The principal revokes the agent's authority or the agent dies, becomes 27 
incapacitated or resigns and the power of attorney does not prov ide for another agent 28 
to act under the power of attorney.  29 
2.  Termination of agent's authority.  An agent's authority terminates:  30 
A.  When the principal revokes the authority;  31 
B.  When the agent dies, becomes incapacitated or resigns;  32 
C.  When an action is  filed for the termination or annulment of the agent's marriage to 33 
the principal or their legal separation, unless the power of attorney otherwise 34 
provides;  35 
D.  Upon the sooner to occur of either:  36 
 
 Page 264 - 128LR0452(01) -1 
 (1)  The marriage of the principal to a person other than t he agent if upon or after 1 
execution of the power of attorney the principal and the agent are or became 2 
registered domestic partners, the filing with the domestic partner registry, in 3 
accordance with Title 22, section 2710, subsection 4, of a notice consent ing to the 4 
termination of a registered domestic partnership of the principal and the agent; or  5 
(2)  Upon service, in accordance with Title 22, section 2710, subsection 4, of a 6 
notice of intent to terminate the registered domestic partnership of the princip al 7 
and the agent; or  8 
E.  When the power of attorney terminates.  9 
3.  Agent's authority until termination.  Unless the power of attorney otherwise 10 
provides, an agent's authority is exercisable until the authority terminates under 11 
subsection 2, notwithstandin g a lapse of time since the execution of the power of 12 
attorney.  13 
4.  Termination of authority not effective without actual knowledge.  Termination 14 
of an agent's authority or of a power of attorney is not effective as to the agent or another 15 
person that, wit hout actual knowledge of the termination, acts in good faith under the 16 
power of attorney.  An act so performed, unless otherwise invalid or unenforceable, binds 17 
the principal and the principal's successors in interest.  18 
5.  Incapacity does not revoke or ter minate nondurable power of attorney 19 
without actual knowledge.  Incapacity of the principal of a power of attorney that is not 20 
durable does not revoke or terminate the power of attorney as to an agent or other person 21 
that, without actual knowledge of the in capacity, acts in good faith under the power of 22 
attorney.  An act so performed, unless otherwise invalid or unenforceable, binds the 23 
principal and the principal's successors in interest.  24 
6.  Previously executed power of attorney not revoked unless provided .  The 25 
execution of a power of attorney does not revoke a power of attorney previously executed 26 
by the principal unless the subsequent power of attorney provides that the previous power 27 
of attorney is revoked or that all other powers of attorney are revoke d. 28 
§5-811.  Coagents and successor agents  29 
1.  Coagents.  A principal may designate 2 or more persons to act as coagents.  30 
Unless the power of attorney otherwise provides, each coagent may exercise its authority 31 
independently.  32 
2.  Successor agents.  A princ ipal may designate one or more successor agents to act 33 
if an agent resigns, dies, becomes incapacitated, is not qualified to serve or declines to 34 
serve.  A principal may grant authority to designate one or more successor agents to an 35 
agent or other person designated by name, office or function.  Unless the power of 36 
attorney otherwise provides, a successor agent:  37 
A.  Has the same authority as that granted to the original agent; and  38 
B.  May not act until all predecessor agents have resigned, died, become 39 
incapacitated, are no longer qualified to serve or have declined to serve.  40 
 
 Page 265 - 128LR0452(01) -1 
 3.  Not liable for actions of other agent.  Except as otherwise provided in the power 1 
of attorney and subsection 4, an agent that does not participate in or conceal a breach of 2 
fiduciar y duty committed by another agent, including a predecessor agent, is not liable for 3 
the actions of the other agent.  4 
4.  Actual knowledge of breach or imminent breach; damages.  An agent that has 5 
actual knowledge of a breach or imminent breach of fiduciary duty by another agent shall 6 
notify the principal and, if the principal is incapacitated, take any action reasonably 7 
appropriate in the circumstances to safeguard the principal's interests.  An agent that fails 8 
to notify the principal or take action as requ ired by this subsection is liable for the 9 
reasonably foreseeable damages that could have been avoided if the agent had notified 10 
the principal or taken such action.  11 
§5-812.  Reimbursement and compensation of agent  12 
Unless the power of attorney otherwise prov ides, an agent is entitled to 13 
reimbursement of expenses reasonably incurred on behalf of the principal and to 14 
compensation that is reasonable under the circumstances.  The factors set forth in section 15 
3-721, subsection 2 should be considered as guides in d etermining the reasonableness of 16 
compensation under this section.  17 
§5-813.  Agent's acceptance  18 
Except as otherwise provided in the power of attorney, a person accepts appointment 19 
as an agent under a power of attorney by exercising authority or performing du ties as an 20 
agent or by any other assertion or conduct indicating acceptance.  21 
§5-814.  Agent's duties  22 
1.  Minimum mandatory duties.  Notwithstanding provisions in the power of 23 
attorney, an agent that has accepted appointment shall:  24 
A.  Act in accordance wit h the principal's reasonable expectations to the extent 25 
actually known by the agent and otherwise act as a fiduciary under the standards of 26 
care applicable to trustees as described under Title 18 -B, sections 802 to 807 and 27 
Title 18 -B, chapter 9;  28 
B.  Act in  good faith; and  29 
C.  Act only within the scope of authority granted in the power of attorney.  30 
2.  Default duties.  Except as otherwise provided in the power of attorney, an agent 31 
that has accepted appointment shall:  32 
A.  Act loyally for the principal's bene fit; 33 
B.  Act so as not to create a conflict of interest that impairs the agent's ability to act 34 
impartially;  35 
C.  Act with the care, competence and diligence ordinarily exercised by agents in 36 
similar circumstances;  37 
 
 Page 266 - 128LR0452(01) -1 
 D.  Keep a record of all receipts, disbur sements and transactions made on behalf of 1 
the principal;  2 
E.  Cooperate with a person that has authority to make health care decisions for the 3 
principal to carry out such decisions; and  4 
F.  Attempt to preserve the principal's estate plan, to the extent act ually known by the 5 
agent, based on all relevant factors, including:  6 
(1)  The value and nature of the principal's property;  7 
(2)  The principal's foreseeable obligations and need for maintenance;  8 
(3)  Minimization of taxes, including income, estate, inherit ance, generation - 9 
skipping transfer and gift taxes; and  10 
(4)  Eligibility for a benefit, a program or assistance under a statute, rule or 11 
regulation.  12 
3.  Failure to preserve estate plan; good faith.  An agent that acts in good faith is 13 
not liable to any ben eficiary of the principal's estate plan for failure to preserve the plan.  14 
4.  Agent also benefits.  An agent that acts with care, competence and diligence for 15 
the sole interest of the principal is not liable solely because the agent also benefits from 16 
the act or has an individual or conflicting interest in relation to the property or affairs of 17 
the principal.  18 
5.  Special skills or expertise.  If an agent is selected by the principal because of 19 
special skills or expertise possessed by the agent or in relianc e on the agent's 20 
representation that the agent has special skills or expertise, the special skills or expertise 21 
must be considered in determining whether the agent has acted with care, competence and 22 
diligence under the circumstances.  23 
6.  Value of property  declines.  Absent a breach of duty to the principal, an agent is 24 
not liable if the value of the principal's property declines.  25 
7.  Delegation of authority.  An agent that exercises authority to delegate to another 26 
person the authority granted by the princ ipal or that engages another person on behalf of 27 
the principal is not liable for an act, error of judgment or default of that person if the 28 
agent exercises care, competence and diligence in selecting and monitoring the person.  29 
8.  Disclosure upon request.  Except as otherwise provided in the power of attorney, 30 
an agent is not required to disclose receipts, disbursements or transactions conducted on 31 
behalf of the principal unless ordered by a court or requested by the principal, a guardian, 32 
a conservator, an other fiduciary acting for the principal, a governmental agency having 33 
authority to protect the welfare of the principal or, upon the death of the principal, by the 34 
personal representative or successor in interest of the principal's estate.  If so requeste d, 35 
within 30 days the agent shall comply with the request or provide a writing or other 36 
record substantiating why additional time is needed and shall comply with the request 37 
within an additional 30 days.  38 
 
 Page 267 - 128LR0452(01) -1 
 §5-815.  Exoneration of agent  1 
A provision in a power  of attorney relieving an agent of liability for breach of duty is 2 
binding on the principal and the principal's successors in interest except to the extent the 3 
provision:  4 
1.  Dishonesty, improper motive, reckless indifference.  Relieves the agent of 5 
liabil ity for breach of duty committed dishonestly, with an improper motive or with 6 
reckless indifference to the purposes of the power of attorney; or  7 
2.  Abuse of relationship.  Was inserted as a result of an abuse of a confidential or 8 
fiduciary relationship wi th the principal.  9 
§5-816.  Judicial relief  10 
1.  Petition.  The following persons may petition the Probate Court or the Superior 11 
Court for the county in which either the principal or the agent resides to construe a power 12 
of attorney or review the agent's con duct and grant appropriate relief:  13 
A.  The principal or the agent;  14 
B.  A guardian, conservator or other fiduciary acting for the principal;  15 
C.  A person authorized to make health care decisions for the principal;  16 
D.  The principal's spouse, registered dome stic partner, parent or descendant;  17 
E.  An individual who would qualify as a presumptive heir of the principal;  18 
F.  A person named as a beneficiary to receive any property, benefit or contractual 19 
right on the principal's death or as a beneficiary of a trus t created by or for the 20 
principal that has a financial interest in the principal's estate;  21 
G.  A governmental agency having regulatory authority to protect the welfare of the 22 
principal;  23 
H.  The principal's caregiver or another person that demonstrates suff icient interest in 24 
the principal's welfare; and  25 
I.  A person asked to accept the power of attorney.  26 
2.  Motion by principal to dismiss; lack of capacity.  Upon motion by the principal, 27 
the court shall dismiss a petition filed under this section, unless the  court finds that the 28 
principal lacks capacity to revoke the agent's authority or the power of attorney.  29 
§5-817.  Agent's liability  30 
An agent that violates this Part is liable to the principal or the principal's successors in 31 
interest for the amount require d to: 32 
1.  Restore property.  Restore the value of the principal's property to what it would 33 
have been had the violation not occurred; and  34 
 
 Page 268 - 128LR0452(01) -1 
 2.  Reimburse fees and costs.  Reimburse the principal or the principal's successors 1 
in interest for the attorney's fe es and costs paid on the agent's behalf.  2 
§5-818.  Agent's resignation; notice  3 
Unless the power of attorney provides a different method for an agent's resignation, 4 
an agent may resign by giving notice to the principal and, if the principal is incapacitated:  5 
1.  Conservator, guardian, coagent, successor agent.  To the conservator or 6 
guardian, if one has been appointed for the principal, and a coagent or successor agent; or  7 
2.  Caregiver, interested person, governmental agency.  If there is no person 8 
describe d in subsection 1, to:  9 
A.  The principal's caregiver;  10 
B.  Another person reasonably believed by the agent to have sufficient interest in the 11 
principal's welfare; or  12 
C.  A governmental agency having authority to protect the welfare of the principal.  13 
§5-819.  Acceptance of and reliance upon acknowledged power of attorney  14 
1.  Acknowledged.  For purposes of this section and section 5 -820, "acknowledged" 15 
means purportedly verified before a notary public or other individual authorized to take 16 
acknowledgments.  17 
2.  Signature not genuine.  A person that in good faith accepts an acknowledged 18 
power of attorney without actual knowledge that the signature is not genuine may rely 19 
upon the presumption under section 5 -805 that the signature is genuine.  20 
3.  Void, invalid or  terminated; exceeding or improper authority.  A person that 21 
in good faith accepts an acknowledged power of attorney without actual knowledge that 22 
the power of attorney is void, invalid or terminated, that the purported agent's authority is 23 
void, invalid o r terminated or that the agent is exceeding or improperly exercising the 24 
agent's authority may rely upon the power of attorney as if the power of attorney were 25 
genuine, valid and still in effect, the agent's authority were genuine, valid and still in 26 
effec t and the agent had not exceeded and had properly exercised the authority.  27 
4.  Request and rely upon.  A person that is asked to accept an acknowledged power 28 
of attorney may request, and rely upon, without further investigation:  29 
A.  An agent's certificatio n under penalty of perjury of any factual matter concerning 30 
the principal, agent or power of attorney;  31 
B.  An English translation of the power of attorney if the power of attorney contains, 32 
in whole or in part, language other than English; and  33 
C.  An opini on of counsel as to any matter of law concerning the power of attorney if 34 
the person making the request provides in a writing or other record the reason for the 35 
request.  36 
 
 Page 269 - 128LR0452(01) -1 
 5.  Expense of translation or opinion of counsel.  An English translation or an 1 
opini on of counsel requested under this section must be provided at the principal's 2 
expense unless the request is made more than 7 business days after the power of attorney 3 
is presented for acceptance.  4 
6.  Employee without actual knowledge.  For purposes of thi s section and section 5 
5-820, a person that conducts activities through employees is without actual knowledge 6 
of a fact relating to a power of attorney, a principal or an agent if the employee 7 
conducting the transaction involving the power of attorney is wi thout actual knowledge of 8 
the fact.  9 
§5-820.  Liability for refusal to accept acknowledged power of attorney  10 
1.  Request within 7 days; accept within 5 days of receipt.  Except as otherwise 11 
provided in subsection 2:  12 
A.  A person shall either accept an ackno wledged power of attorney or request a 13 
certification, a translation or an opinion of counsel under section 5 -819, subsection 4 14 
no later than 7 business days after presentation of the power of attorney for 15 
acceptance;  16 
B.  If a person requests a certificatio n, a translation or an opinion of counsel under 17 
section 5 -819, subsection 4, the person shall accept the power of attorney no later 18 
than 5 business days after receipt of the certification, translation or opinion of 19 
counsel; and  20 
C.  A person may not require  an additional or different form of power of attorney for 21 
authority granted in the power of attorney presented.  22 
2.  Acceptance not required.  A person is not required to accept an acknowledged 23 
power of attorney if:  24 
A.  The person is not otherwise required to engage in a transaction with the principal 25 
in the same circumstances;  26 
B.  Engaging in a transaction with the agent or the principal in the same 27 
circumstances would be inconsistent with federal law;  28 
C.  The person has actual knowledge of the termination of the agent's authority or of 29 
the power of attorney before exercise of the power;  30 
D.  A request for a certification, a translation or an opinion of counsel under section 31 
5-819, subsection 4 is refused;  32 
E.  The person in good faith believes that the power is not valid or that the agent does 33 
not have the authority to perform the act requested, whether or not a certification, a 34 
translation or an opinion of counsel under section 5 -819, subsection 4 has been 35 
requested or provided; or  36 
F.  The person has a good f aith belief that the principal may be subject to physical or 37 
financial abuse, neglect, exploitation or abandonment by the agent or a person acting 38 
for or with the agent and the person makes, or has actual knowledge that another 39 
 
 Page 270 - 128LR0452(01) -1 
 person has made, a report to  the Department of Health and Human Services regarding 1 
such beliefs.  2 
3.  Consequences of refusal.  A person that refuses in violation of this section to 3 
accept an acknowledged power of attorney is subject to:  4 
A.  A court order mandating acceptance of the p ower of attorney; and  5 
B.  Liability for reasonable attorney's fees and costs incurred in any action or 6 
proceeding that confirms the validity of the power of attorney or mandates 7 
acceptance of the power of attorney.  8 
§5-821.  Principles of law and equity  9 
Unless displaced by a provision of this Part, the principles of law and equity 10 
supplement this Part.  11 
§5-822.  Laws applicable to financial institutions and entities  12 
This Part does not supersede any other law applicable to financial institutions or other 13 
entities, and the other law controls if inconsistent with this Part.  14 
§5-823.  Remedies under other law  15 
The remedies under this Part are not exclusive and do not abrogate any right or 16 
remedy under the law of this State other than this Part.  17

AUTHORITY  19 
§5-831.  Authority that requires specific grant; grant of general authority  20 
1.  Specific grant of authority required.  An agent under a power of attorney may 21 
do the following on behalf of the principal or with the principal's property only if the 22 
power of a ttorney expressly grants the agent the authority and exercise of the authority is 23 
not otherwise prohibited by another agreement or instrument to which the authority or 24 
property is subject:  25 
A.  Create, amend, revoke or terminate an inter vivos trust;  26 
B.  Make a gift;  27 
C.  Create or change rights of survivorship;  28 
D.  Create or change a beneficiary designation;  29 
E.  Delegate authority granted under the power of attorney;  30 
F.  Waive the principal's right to be a beneficiary of a joint and survivor annuity, 31 
includ ing a survivor benefit under a retirement plan;  32 
G.  Exercise fiduciary powers that the principal has authority to delegate; and  33 
H.  Disclaim property, including a power of appointment.  34 
 
 Page 271 - 128LR0452(01) -1 
 2.  Limitation on creating interest in principal's property.  Notwiths tanding a 1 
grant of authority to do an act described in subsection 1, unless the power of attorney 2 
otherwise provides, an agent that is not an ancestor, spouse, registered domestic partner 3 
or descendant of the principal may not exercise authority under a po wer of attorney to 4 
create in the agent, or in an individual to whom the agent owes a legal obligation of 5 
support, an interest in the principal’s property, whether by gift, right of survivorship, 6 
beneficiary designation, disclaimer or otherwise.  7 
3.  General  authority.  Subject to subsections 1, 2, 4 and 5, if a power of attorney 8 
grants to an agent authority to do all acts that a principal could do, the agent has the 9 
general authority described in sections 5 -834 to 5 -846. 10 
4.  Authority to make a gift.  Unless  the power of attorney otherwise provides, a 11 
grant of authority to make a gift is subject to section 5 -847. 12 
5.  Overlapping subjects.  Subject to subsections 1, 2 and 4, if the subjects over 13 
which authority is granted in a power of attorney are similar or overlap, the broadest 14 
authority controls.  15 
6.  Authority with respect to principal's property.  Authority granted in a power of 16 
attorney is exercisable with respect to property that the principal has when the power of 17 
attorney is executed or acquires later,  whether or not the property is located in this State 18 
and whether or not the authority is exercised or the power of attorney is executed in this 19 
State.  20 
7.  Act pursuant to power of attorney.  An act performed by an agent pursuant to a 21 
power of attorney has  the same effect and inures to the benefit of and binds the principal 22 
and the principal's successors in interest as if the principal had performed the act.  23 
§5-832.  Incorporation of authority  24 
1.  Reference to subject.  An agent has authority described in t his subpart if the 25 
power of attorney refers to general authority with respect to the descriptive term for the 26 
subjects stated in sections 5 -834 to 5 -847 or cites the section in which the authority is 27 
described.  28 
2.  Reference to section number.  A reference  in a power of attorney to general 29 
authority with respect to the descriptive term for a subject in sections 5 -834 to 5 -847 or a 30 
citation to a section of sections 5 -834 to 5 -847 incorporates the entire section as if it were 31 
set out in full in the power of a ttorney.  32 
3.  Modify incorporated authority.  A principal may modify authority incorporated 33 
by reference.  34 
§5-833.  Construction of authority generally  35 
Except as otherwise provided in the power of attorney, by executing a power of 36 
attorney that incorporates by reference a subject described in sections 5 -834 to 5 -847 or 37 
that grants to an agent authority to do all acts that a principal could do pursuant to section 38 
5-831, subsection 3, a principal authorizes the agent, with respect to that subject, to:  39 
 
 Page 272 - 128LR0452(01) -1 
 1.  Money  or another thing of value.  Demand, receive and obtain, by litigation or 1 
otherwise, money or another thing of value to which the principal is, may become or 2 
claims to be entitled and conserve, invest, disburse or use anything so received or 3 
obtained for t he purposes intended;  4 
2.  Contracts.  Contract in any manner with any person, on terms agreeable to the 5 
agent, to accomplish a purpose of a transaction and perform, rescind, cancel, terminate, 6 
reform, restate, release or modify the contract or another cont ract made by or on behalf of 7 
the principal;  8 
3.  Instrument or communication.  Execute, acknowledge, seal, deliver, file or 9 
record any instrument or communication the agent considers desirable to accomplish a 10 
purpose of a transaction, including creating at any time a schedule listing some or all of 11 
the principal's property and attaching it to the power of attorney;  12 
4.  Claim in favor of or against principal; intervene.  Initiate, participate in, submit 13 
to alternative dispute resolution, settle, oppose or pro pose or accept a compromise with 14 
respect to a claim existing in favor of or against the principal or intervene in litigation 15 
relating to the claim;  16 
5.  Assistance of court or governmental agency.  Seek on the principal's behalf the 17 
assistance of a court or  other governmental agency to carry out an act authorized in the 18 
power of attorney;  19 
6.  Advisors.  Engage, compensate and discharge an attorney, accountant, 20 
discretionary investment manager, expert witness or other advisor;  21 
7.  Record, report or other docu ment.  Prepare, execute and file a record, report or 22 
other document to safeguard or promote the principal's interest under a statute, rule or 23 
regulation;  24 
8.  Communication with government or instrumentality.  Communicate with any 25 
representative or employee  of a government or governmental subdivision, agency or 26 
instrumentality on behalf of the principal;  27 
9.  Access communications.  Access communications intended for and communicate 28 
on behalf of the principal, whether by mail, electronic transmission, telepho ne or other 29 
means; and  30 
10.  Any lawful act.  Do any lawful act with respect to the subject and all property 31 
related to the subject.  32

§5-847.  Gifts  24

529, as  amended.  28 
2.  Consistent with principal's objectives.  An agent may make a gift of the 29 
principal's property only as the agent determines is consistent with the principal's 30 
objectives if known by the agent and, if unknown, as the agent determines is consist ent 31 
with the principal's objectives based on all relevant factors, including:  32 
A.  The value and nature of the principal's property;  33 
B.  The principal's foreseeable obligations and need for maintenance;  34 
C.  Minimization of taxes, including income, estate, i nheritance, generation -skipping 35 
transfer and gift taxes;  36 
 
 Page 284 - 128LR0452(01) -1 
 D.  Eligibility for a benefit, a program or assistance under a statute, rule or regulation; 1 
and 2 
E.  The principal's personal history of making or joining in making gifts.  3

§5-861.  Uniformity of application and construction  19 
In applying and construing this Part, consideration must be given to the need to 20 
promote uniformity of the law with respect to its subject matter among the states that 21 
enact it.  22 
§5-862.  Relation to Electronic Signatures in Global and National Commerce Act  23 
This Part modifies, limits and supersedes the federal Elect ronic Signatures in Global 24 
and National Commerce Act, 15 United States Code, Section 7001 et seq., but does not 25 
modify, limit or supersede 15 United States Code, Section 7001(c) or authorize electronic 26 
delivery of any of the notices described in 15 United States Code, Section 7003(b).  27

Maine Uniform Probate Code Comment (§5 -102) 11 
This section modifies  the Uniform Probate Code definition of " incapacitated person " 12 
by inserting  "informed" before "decisions."  Lack of capacity to make an "informed" 13 
decision is a statutory condition for involuntary treatment in a psychiatric hospital.  14 
"Informed" consent to tre atment is a term used in other health care contexts.  This change 15 
to the uniform language promotes consistency across Maine statutes related to capacity to 16 
decide or consent.  17 
Also in that definition, this section inserts  "reasonably available" before 18 
"tech nological assistance."  If technological assistance exists to address functional 19 
deficits, a guardianship or conservatorship is , arguably,  not "least restrictive."  According 20 
to the Uniform Probate Code language, if the respondent cannot afford technologic al 21 
assistance and if the assistance is not otherwise available, the respondent is precluded 22 
from getting either technological assistance or the protection that guardianship or 23 
conservatorship would provide.  24 
"Best interest of the minor" is not defined  in the Uniform Probate Code.  This section  25 
retains a definition of "best interest of the minor"  using currently existing criteria in Title 26 
19-A to promote uniformity across Maine statutes.  27 
The Uniform Probate Code does not include definitions of "de facto guard ian" and 28 
"demonstrated lack of consistent participation," which were both added to former Title 29 
18-A by Public Law 2005, chapter 371, which provided rights to adults who were caring 30 
for minors, but not under court appointment.  This section does not retain  those 31 
definitions. The Uniform Probate Code treatment of individuals  "other than a parent or 32 
guardian having care or custody of a minor" provides those individuals notice of 33 
guardianship proceedings, opportunity to object and potential guardianship appoin tment.  34 
Maine Uniform Probate Code Comment (§5 -103) 35 
This section is based on section 5 -104 of the Uniform Probate Code.   36 
 
 Page 287 - 128LR0452(01) -1 
 The Uniform Probate Code is adopted with a single change to allow transfer of funds 1 
under this provision to a married minor.  This is c onsistent with other statutes treating 2 
married minors as adults, such as Title 22, section 1503, which gives married minors 3 
authority to give consent for health care services.  With the exception of an increase over 4 
the amount in the former Title 18 -A of the permitted transfer amount from $5,000 to 5 
$10,000, this does not constitute a substantive change to Maine law.  6 
Maine Uniform Probate Code Comment (§5 -104) 7 
This section is based on section 5 -105 of the Uniform Probate Code.   8 
This section  adopts the Unifo rm Probate Code with 2 exceptions.  First, this section  9 
uses a 12 -month effective period for a power of attorney rather than the 6 -month period 10 
in the Uniform Probate Code.  Second, this section  provides for an automatic extension 11 
for parents serving in th e National Guard or Reserves of the United States Armed Forces .  12 
In adopting  the Uniform Probate Code , this section removes the requirement under 13 
former Title 18 -A that a delegation by a court -appointed guardian through a power of 14 
attorney be filed with th e court.  15 
Also, Public Law 2015, chapter 467 added a new subsection 3 to address a power of 16 
attorney executed by parents for temporary care of a minor, addressing concerns about 17 
organizations providing agents to provide care for the minor pursuant to the po wer of 18 
attorney.  19 
Maine Uniform Probate Code Comment (§5 -105) 20 
This section is based on section 5 -106 of the Uniform Probate Code.   21 
This section  adopts the Uniform Probate Code language concerning jurisdiction.  22 
This does not change the Probate Court's role  as the exclusive court in Maine with 23 
jurisdiction over guardianship and protective proceedings for minors and adults, except as 24 
that jurisdiction may be reserved specifically to another court.  The Uniform Adult 25 
Guardianship and Protective Proceedings Jur isdiction Act is Part 5 of this Article.  26

 Maine Uniform Probate Code Comment (§5 -110) 1 
This section is based on sectio n 5-112 of the Uniform Probate Code.   2 
This section adds to Maine law explicit authority to appoint contingent coguardians 3 
or successor guardians or conservators.  The section preserves the court's discretion t o 4 
appoint counsel for the ward or  indigent par ents or guardians or to "make any order that 5 
may be appropriate" as provided under the former Title 18 -A, section 5-212.  The section 6 
confirms Maine law  as interpreted by the Maine Supreme Judicial Court in In re 7 
Guardianship of David C. , 2010 ME 136, ¶¶ 6 -7 and In re Guardianship of Jeremiah T. , 8 
2009 ME 74, ¶¶ 24 -28. 9

Maine Uniform Probate Code Comment (§5 -112) 14 
This section is based on section 5 -114 of the Uniform Probate Code.   15 
This section removes the authority under former Title 18 -A, section 5 -309, subsection 16 
(b) and section 5 -405, subsection (a) for a ward or protected person to waive notice if that 17

counsel, the guardian ad litem or the visitor.  19 
Maine Uniform Probate Code Comment (§5 -113) 20 
This section is based on section 5 -115 of the Uniform Probate Code.   21 
This section does not include  the specific requirements of former Title 18 -A, sections 22 
1-112, 5 -303 and 5 -407 addressing appointment and duties of guardians ad litem in 23 
guardianship and conservatorship proceedings.  This section consolidates the appointment 24 
sections and retains  the court 's discretion and a duty to tailor the role of the guardian ad 25 
litem to the circumstances.  26 
Maine Uniform Probate Code Comment (§5 -114) 27 
This section is  based on section 5 -116 of the Uniform Probate Code.   28 
This section expands former Title 18 -A by allowing an individual not otherwise 29 
entitled to notice to receive notice in a guardianship or a conservatorship proceeding, as 30 
long as the individual has prov ided a statement showing the individual's interest and an 31 
address to which notice should be sent.  32

 Maine Uniform Probate Code Comment (§ 5-201) 1 
Title 22, section 4038 -C permits District Courts in child protective proceedings to 2 
appoint a permanency guardian.   This section  departs from the Uniform Probate Code to 3 
recognize that authority and to ensure that the Probate Court does not appoint a guardian 4 
without leave of the District Court if the District Court has appointed a permanency 5 
guardian.  6 
Maine Uniform P robate Code Comment (§ 5-202) 7 
The Uniform Probate Code provisions permitting parental appointment of a so -called 8 
standby guardian are new to Maine law.  9 
Maine Uniform Probate Code Comment (§ 5-204) 10 
This section  does not adopt the temporary and emergency guard ianship language of 11 
the Uniform Probate Code.  The existing process in Maine, including authority to issue 12 
orders for transitional arrangements, accommodates prompt disposition and appropriate 13 
protections for participants in the context of Maine's part -time probate courts.  This 14 
section  retains the "clear and convincing evidence" burden of proof.  This section  also 15 
retains additional protections, previously codified in the last 3 paragraphs of former  Title 16 
18-A, section 5 -204, subsection (d), which are now contained in  section 5-204, 17 
subsections 6, 7 and 8, concerning legal representation for indigent parents, concerning 18 
cost-effective participation of child support enforcement agents in guardianship 19 
proceedings and specifying any parental rights retained if  a limited guardian is appointed.  20 
Maine Uniform Probate Code Comment (§ 5-205) 21 
This section expands the list of people entitled to notice of a guardianship petition but 22 
otherwise does not constitute a substantive change to Maine law.  23 
Maine Uniform Probate C ode Comment (§ 5-206) 24 
This section adds as a specific criterion for limiting the powers of a guardian  that the 25 
limitation must be  in the interest of developing self -reliance of a ward, consistent with the 26 
adult guardianship statute.  This section does not i nclude  the provision  under previous 27 
Maine law prohibiting the appointment of  a guardian who intends to remove the minor 28 
from the State for purposes of adoption, leaving the decision as to the minor's best interest 29 
in the discretion of the court.  30 
Maine Unif orm Probate Code Comment (§ 5-207) 31 
This section expands the duties of a guardian under previous Maine law, requiring the 32 
guardian to become and remain acquainted with a ward and to inform the court of a 33 
change in the ward's address, but this section does no t otherwise constitute a substantive 34 
change to Maine law.  35 
 
 Page 290 - 128LR0452(01) -1

traditional in Maine that the marriage of a minor ward terminates a guardianship.  10

See Maine Uniform Probate Code C omment section 5-204. 15

Maine Uniform Probate Code Comment (§ 5-312) 3 
This section adopts the Uniform Probate Code in part, but retains the role under 4 
former Title 18 -A, section 5 -310-A of the visitor and guardian ad litem in cases of 5 
emergency guardianships.  Given the nature of the probate courts in Maine, it is not 6 
pract ical to require the assignment of a lawyer immediately upon the receipt of a pet ition 7 
for an emergency guardian  or to adopt the shortened time limits contained in the Uniform 8 
Probate Code.  Partly for that reason, this section  continues to require the fili ng, with the 9 
petition for emergency guardianship, of an affidavit  setting forth the factual basis for the 10 
emergency and the powers requested, as in former Title 18 -A, section 5 -310-A.  The role 11 
of the guardian ad litem and visitor will continue to ensure t hat the respondent' s interests 12 
are represented  without limiting the court's authority to appoint a lawyer for the 13 
respondent at a later time on a case -by-case basis.  14 
This section carries forward from the former Title 18 -A, section 5 -310-A a 15 
heightened stan dard of harm as a basis for an ex parte appointment.  16 
Instead of adopting the shorter time limits contained in the Uniform Probate Code, 17 
this section integrates provisions of the former Title 18 -A, section 5 -310-A providing that 18 
emergency appointment of an  emergency guardian  be followed by a visit with a guardian 19 
ad litem or visitor.  20

ARTICLE 6  18 
NONPROBATE TRANSFERS  ON DEATH  19 
PART 1  20 
PROVISIONS RELATING TO EFFECT OF DEATH  21 
§6-101.  Nonprobate transfers on death  22 
1.  Nonprobat e transfer on death nontestamentary.  A provision for a nonprobate 23 
transfer on death in an insurance policy, contract of employment, bond, mortgage, 24 
promissory note, certificated or uncertificated security, account agreement, custodial 25 
agreement, deposit a greement, compensation plan, pension plan, individual retirement 26 
plan, employee benefit plan, trust, conveyance, deed of gift, marital property agreement 27 
or other written instrument of a similar nature is nontestamentary.  Also nontestamentary 28 
is a written  provision that:  29 
A.  Money or other benefits due to, controlled by or owned by a decedent before 30 
death must be paid after the decedent's death to a person whom the decedent 31 
designates either in the instrument or in a separate writing, including a will, exe cuted 32 
either before or at the same time as the instrument or later;  33 
 
 Page 298 - 128LR0452(01) -1 
 B.  Money due or to become due under the instrument ceases to be payable in the 1 
event of death of the promisee or the promisor before payment or demand; or  2 
C.  Any property controlled by o r owned by the decedent before death that is the 3 
subject of the instrument passes to a person the decedent designates either in the 4 
instrument or in a separate writing, including a will, executed either before or at the 5 
same time as the instrument or later . 6 
2.  Rights of creditors.  Nothing in this section limits the rights of creditors under 7 
other laws of this State.  8 
§6-102.  Liability of nonprobate transferees for creditor claims and statutory 9 
allowances  10 
1.  "Nonprobate transfer" defined.  As used in this  section, "nonprobate transfer" 11 
means a valid transfer effective at death, other than a transfer of a survivorship interest in 12 
a joint tenancy of real estate, by a transferor whose last domicile was in this State, to the 13 
extent that the transferor immediat ely before death had power, acting alone, to prevent 14 
the transfer by revocation or withdrawal and instead to use the property for the benefit of 15 
the transferor or apply the property to discharge claims against the transferor's probate 16 
estate.  17 
2.  Liability  of nonprobate transferee.  Except as otherwise provided by statute, a 18 
transferee of a nonprobate transfer is subject to liability to any probate estate of the 19 
decedent for allowed claims against the decedent's probate estate and statutory 20 
allowances to th e decedent's spouse and children to the extent the estate is insufficient to 21 
satisfy those claims and allowances.  The liability of a nonprobate transferee may not 22 
exceed the value of nonprobate transfers received or controlled by that transferee.  23 
3.  Priority of liability.  Nonprobate transferees are liable for the insufficiency 24 
described in subsection 2 in the following order of priority:  25 
A.  A transferee designated in the decedent's will or any other governing instrument, 26 
as provided in the instrument;  27 
B.  The trustee of a trust serving as the principal nonprobate instrument in the 28 
decedent's estate plan as shown by its designation as devisee of the decedent's 29 
residuary estate or by other facts or circumstances, to the extent of the value of the 30 
nonprobat e transfer received or controlled; and  31 
C.  Other nonprobate transferees, in proportion to the values received.  32 
4.  Interests of beneficiaries to satisfy liability.  Unless otherwise provided by the 33 
trust instrument, interests of beneficiaries in all trusts  incurring liabilities under this 34 
section abate as necessary to satisfy the liability, as if all of the trust instruments were a 35 
single will and the interests were devises under it.  36 
5.  Instrument direct apportionment; conflicts.  A provision made in one 37 
instrument may direct the apportionment of the liability among the nonprobate transferees 38 
taking under that instrument or any other governing instrument.  If a provision in one 39 
instrument conflicts with a provision in another, the later one prevails.  40 
 
 Page 299 - 128LR0452(01) -1 
 6.  Liability enforceable in this State.  Upon due notice to a nonprobate transferee, 1 
the liability imposed by this section is enforceable in proceedings in this State, whether or 2 
not the transferee is located in this State.  3 
7.  Written demand for proceeding.  A proceeding under this section may not be 4 
commenced unless the personal representative of the decedent's estate has received a 5 
written demand for the proceeding from the surviving spouse or a child, to the extent that 6 
statutory allowances are affected, or a creditor.  If the personal representative declines or 7 
fails to commence a proceeding after demand, a person making demand may commence 8 
the proceeding in the name of the decedent's estate at the expense of the person making 9 
the demand and not of the estat e.  A personal representative who declines in good faith to 10 
commence a requested proceeding incurs no personal liability for declining.  11 
8.  Deadline for proceedings.  A proceeding under this section must be commenced 12 
within one year after the decedent's de ath, but a proceeding on behalf of a creditor whose 13 
claim was allowed after proceedings challenging disallowance of the claim may be 14 
commenced within 60 days after final allowance of the claim.  15 
9.  Liability of obligor, trustee.   Unless a written notice as serting that a decedent's 16 
probate estate is nonexistent or insufficient to pay allowed claims and statutory 17 
allowances has been received from the decedent's personal representative, the following 18 
provisions apply.  19 
A.  Payment or delivery of assets by a fin ancial institution, register or other obligor to 20 
a nonprobate transferee in accordance with the terms of the governing instrument 21 
controlling the transfer releases the obligor from all claims for amounts paid or assets 22 
delivered.  23 
B.  A trustee receiving or  controlling a nonprobate transfer is released from liability 24 
under this section with respect to any assets distributed to the trust's beneficiaries.  25 
Each beneficiary to the extent of the distribution received becomes liable for the 26 
amount of the trustee' s liability attributable to assets received by the beneficiary.  27 
PART 2  28 
MULTIPLE -PARTY ACCOUNTS  29 
SUBPART 1  30 
DEFINITIONS AND GENE RAL PROVISIONS  31 
§6-201.  Definitions  32 
As used in this Part, unless the context otherwise indicates, the following terms have 33 
the foll owing meanings.  34 
1.  Account.  "Account" means a contract of deposit between a depositor and a 35 
financial institution and includes a checking account, savings account, certificate of 36 
deposit and share account.  37 
 
 Page 300 - 128LR0452(01) -1 
 2.  Agent.  "Agent" means a person authorized to  make account transactions for a 1 
party.  2 
3.  Beneficiary.  "Beneficiary" means a person named as one to whom sums on 3 
deposit in an account are payable on request after death of all parties or for whom a party 4 
is named as trustee.  5 
4.  Financial institution.  "Financial institution" means an organization authorized to 6 
do business under state or federal laws relating to financial institutions and includes a 7 
bank, trust company, savings bank, building and loan association, savings and loan 8 
company or association  and credit union.  9 
5.  Multiple -party account.  "Multiple -party account" means an account payable on 10 
request to one or more of 2 or more parties, whether or not a right of survivorship is 11 
mentioned.  12 
6.  Party.  "Party" means a person who, by the terms of a n account, has a present 13 
right, subject to request, to payment from the account other than as a beneficiary or agent.  14 
7.  Payment.  "Payment," as it relates to payment of sums on deposit, includes 15 
withdrawal, payment to a party or 3rd person pursuant to a check or other request and a 16 
pledge of sums on deposit by a party or a setoff, reduction or other disposition of all or 17 
part of an account pursuant to a pledge.  18 
8.  POD designation.  "POD designation" means the designation of:  19 
A.  A beneficiary in an accou nt payable on request to one party during the party's 20 
lifetime and on the party's death to one or more beneficiaries, or to one or more 21 
parties during their lifetimes and on death of all of them to one or more beneficiaries; 22 
or  23 
B.  A beneficiary in an acc ount in the name of one or more parties as trustee for one 24 
or more beneficiaries if the relationship is established by the terms of the account and 25 
there is no subject of the trust other than the sums on deposit in the account, whether 26 
or not payment to th e beneficiary is mentioned.  27 
9.  Receive.  "Receive," as it relates to notice to a financial institution, means receipt 28 
in the office or branch office of the financial institution in which the account is 29 
established or, if the terms of the account require n otice at a particular place, in the place 30 
required.  31 
10.  Request.  "Request" means a request for payment complying with all terms of 32 
the account, including special requirements concerning necessary signatures and 33 
regulations of the financial institution.  If terms of the account condition payment on 34 
advance notice, a request for payment is treated as immediately effective and a notice of 35 
intent to withdraw is treated as a request for payment.  36 
11.  Sums on deposit.  "Sums on deposit" means the balance payabl e on an account, 37 
including interest and dividends earned, whether or not included in the current balance, 38 
 
 Page 301 - 128LR0452(01) -1 
 and any deposit life insurance proceeds added to the account by reason of death of a 1 
party.  2 
12.  Terms of the account.  "Terms of the account" include s the deposit agreement 3 
and other terms and conditions, including the form, of the contract of deposit.  4 
§6-202.  Limitation on scope of Part  5 
This Part does not apply to:  6 
1.  Business purpose.  An account established for a partnership, joint venture or 7 
other organization for a business purpose;  8 
2.  Controlled by agent or trustee.  An account controlled by one or more persons 9 
as an agent or trustee for a corporation, unincorporated association or charitable or civic 10 
organization; or  11 
3.  Other relationship.  A fiduciary or trust account in which the relationship is 12 
established other than by the terms of the account.  13 
§6-203.  Types of account; existing accounts  14 
1.  Single -party or multiple -party accounts.   An account may be for a single party 15 
or multiple partie s.  A multiple -party account may be with or without a right of 16 
survivorship between the parties.  Subject to section 6 -212, subsection 3, either a single - 17 
party account or a multiple -party account may have a POD designation, an agency 18 
designation or both.  19 
2.  Accounts governed by this Part.  An account established before, on or after the 20 
effective date of this Part, whether in the form prescribed in section 6 -204 or in any other 21 
form, is either a single -party account or a multiple -party account, with or with out right of 22 
survivorship and with or without a POD designation or an agency designation, within the 23 
meaning of this Part and is governed by this Part.  24 
§6-204.  Forms  25 
1.  Form.  A contract of deposit that contains provisions in substantially the 26 
following form establishes the type of account provided, and the account is governed by 27 
the provisions of this Part applicable to an account of that type.  28
