 2.  Depositor's intent.  A contract of deposit that does not contain pr ovisions in 1 
substantially the form provided in subsection 1 is governed by the provisions of this Part 2 
applicable to the type of account that most nearly conforms to the depositor's intent.  3 
§6-205.  Designation of agent  4 
1.  Designation of agent by all part ies.  By a writing signed by all parties, the 5 
parties may designate as agent of all parties on an account a person other than a party.  6 
2.  Disability or incapacity.  Unless the terms of an agency designation provide that 7 
the authority of the agent terminat es on disability or incapacity of a party, the agent's 8 
authority survives disability and incapacity.  The agent may act for a disabled or 9 
incapacitated party until the authority of the agent is terminated.  10 
3.  Death.  Death of the sole party or last surviv ing party terminates the authority of 11 
an agent.  12 
§6-206.  Applicability of Part  13 
The provisions of subpart 2 concerning beneficial ownership as between parties or as 14 
between parties and beneficiaries apply only to controversies between those persons and 15 
their creditors and other successors and do not apply to the right of those persons to 16 
payment as determined by the terms of the account.  Subpart 3 governs the liability and 17 
set-off rights of financial institutions that make payments pursuant to subpart 3.  18 
SUBPART 2  19 
OWNERSHIP AS BETWEEN  PARTIES AND OTHERS  20 
§6-211.  Ownership during lifetime  21 
1.  "Net contribution" defined.  As used in this section, "net contribution" of a party 22 
means the sum of all deposits to an account made by or for the party, less all paymen ts 23 
from the account made to or for the party that have not been paid to or applied to the use 24 
of another party and a proportionate share of any charges deducted from the account, plus 25 
a proportionate share of any interest or dividends earned, whether or no t included in the 26 
current balance.  "Net contribution" includes deposit life insurance proceeds added to the 27 
account by reason of death of the party whose net contribution is in question.  28 
2.  Interest based on net contribution of each party.  During the li fetime of all 29 
parties, an account belongs to the parties in proportion to the net contribution of each to 30 
the sums on deposit, unless there is clear and convincing evidence of a different intent.  31 
As between parties married to each other, in the absence of  proof otherwise the net 32 
contribution of each is presumed to be an equal amount.  33 
3.  Beneficiary; no right to sums.  A beneficiary in an account having a POD 34 
designation has no right to sums on deposit during the lifetime of any party.  35 
4.  Agent; no benefi cial right to sums.  An agent in an account with an agency 36 
designation has no beneficial right to sums on deposit.  37 
 
 Page 304 - 128LR0452(01) -1 
 §6-212.  Rights at death  1 
1.  Multiple -party account.  Except as otherwise provided in this Part, on death of a 2 
party sums on deposit in a mul tiple-party account belong to the surviving party or parties.  3 
If 2 or more parties survive and one is the surviving spouse of the decedent, the amount to 4 
which the decedent, immediately before death, was beneficially entitled under section 5 
6-211 belongs t o the surviving spouse.  If 2 or more parties survive and none is the 6 
surviving spouse of the decedent, the amount to which the decedent, immediately before 7 
death, was beneficially entitled under section 6 -211 belongs to the surviving parties in 8 
equal shar es and augments the proportion to which each survivor, immediately before the 9 
decedent's death, was beneficially entitled under section 6 -211, and the right of 10 
survivorship continues between the surviving parties.  11 
2.  POD designation.  In an account with a  POD designation:  12 
A.  On death of one of 2 or more parties, the rights in sums on deposit are governed 13 
by subsection 1; and  14 
B.  On death of the sole party or the last survivor of 2 or more parties, sums on 15 
deposit belong to the surviving beneficiary or ben eficiaries.  If 2 or more 16 
beneficiaries survive, sums on deposit belong to them in equal and undivided shares, 17 
and there is no right of survivorship in the event of death of a beneficiary thereafter.  18 
If no beneficiary survives, sums on deposit belong to t he estate of the last surviving 19 
party.  20 
3.  No POD designation; no right of survivorship.  Sums on deposit in a single - 21 
party account without a POD designation, or in a multiple -party account that, by the 22 
terms of the account, is without right of survivorshi p, are not affected by death of a party, 23 
but the amount to which the decedent, immediately before death, was beneficially entitled 24 
under section 6 -211 is transferred as part of the decedent's estate.  A POD designation in 25 
a multiple -party account without r ight of survivorship is ineffective.  For purposes of this 26 
section, designation of an account as a tenancy in common establishes that the account is 27 
without right of survivorship.  28 
4.  Liability for unpaid requests for payment.  The ownership right of a sur viving 29 
party or beneficiary, or of the decedent's estate, in sums on deposit is subject to requests 30 
for payment made by a party before the party's death, whether paid by the financial 31 
institution before or after death or unpaid.  The surviving party or ben eficiary, or the 32 
decedent's estate, is liable to the payee of an unpaid request for payment.  The liability is 33 
limited to a proportionate share of the amount transferred under this section, to the extent 34 
necessary to discharge the request for payment.  35 
§6-213.  Alteration of rights  36 
1.  Rights determined by terms of account.  Rights at the death of a party under 37 
section 6 -212 are determined by the terms of the account at the death of the party.  A 38 
party may alter the terms of the account by a notice signed by  the party and given to the 39 
financial institution to change the terms of the account or to stop or vary payment under 40 
the terms of the account.  To be effective, the notice must be received by the financial 41 
institution during the party's lifetime.  42 
 
 Page 305 - 128LR0452(01) -1 
 2.  Righ t of survivorship not altered by will.  A right of survivorship arising from 1 
the express terms of the account, section 6 -212 or a POD designation may not be altered 2 
by a will.  3 
§6-214.  Accounts and transfers nontestamentary  4 
Except as provided in Article 2,  Part 2 or as a consequence of and to the extent 5 
directed by section 6 -102, a transfer resulting from the application of section 6 -212 is 6 
effective by reason of the terms of the account involved and this Part and is not 7 
testamentary or subject to Articles 1 to 4.  8 
SUBPART 3  9 
PROTECTION OF FINANC IAL INSTITUTIONS  10 
§6-221.  Authority of financial institution  11 
A financial institution may enter into a contract of deposit for a multiple -party 12 
account to the same extent as it may enter into a contract of deposit for a  single -party 13 
account, and may provide for a POD designation and an agency designation in either a 14 
single -party account or a multiple -party account.  A financial institution need not inquire 15 
as to the source of a deposit to an account or as to the proposed  application of a payment 16 
from an account.  17 
§6-222.  Payment on multiple -party account  18 
A financial institution, on request, may pay sums on deposit in a multiple -party 19 
account to:  20 
1.  One or more of the parties.  One or more of the parties, whether or not a nother 21 
party is disabled, incapacitated or deceased when payment is requested and whether or 22 
not the party making the request survives another party; or  23 
2.  Personal representative.  The personal representative, if any, or, if there is none, 24 
the heirs or d evisees of a deceased party if proof of death is presented to the financial 25 
institution showing that the deceased party was the survivor of all other persons named on 26 
the account either as a party or beneficiary, unless the account is without right of 27 
survivorship under section 6 -212. 28 
§6-223.  Payment on POD designation  29 
A financial institution, on request, may pay sums on deposit in an account with a 30 
POD designation to:  31 
1.  One or more of the parties.  One or more of the parties, whether or not another 32 
party is disabled, incapacitated or deceased when the payment is requested and whether 33 
or not a party survives another party;  34 
 
 Page 306 - 128LR0452(01) -1 
 2.  Beneficiaries.  The beneficiary or beneficiaries if proof of death is presented to 1 
the financial institution showing that the bene ficiary or beneficiaries survived all persons 2 
named as parties; or  3 
3.  Personal representative.  The personal representative, if any, or, if there is none, 4 
the heirs or devisees of a deceased party if proof of death is presented to the financial 5 
institutio n showing that the deceased party was the survivor of all other persons named on 6 
the account either as a party or beneficiary.  7 
§6-224.  Payment to designated agent  8 
A financial institution, on request of an agent under an agency designation for an 9 
account, may pay to the agent sums on deposit in the account, whether or not a party is 10 
disabled, incapacitated or deceased when the request is made or received and whether or 11 
not the authority of the agent terminates on the disability or incapacity of a party.  12 
§6-225.  Payment to minor  13 
If a financial institution is required or permitted to make payment pursuant to this 14 
Part to a minor designated as a beneficiary, payment may be made pursuant to the Maine 15 
Uniform Transfers to Minors Act.  16 
§6-226.  Discharge  17 
1.  Payme nts in accordance with terms of account.  Payment made pursuant to this 18 
Part in accordance with the terms of the account discharges the financial institution from 19 
all claims for amounts so paid, whether or not the payment is consistent with the 20 
beneficial ownership of the account as between parties, beneficiaries or their successors.  21 
Payment may be made whether or not a party, beneficiary or agent is disabled, 22 
incapacitated or deceased when payment is requested, received or made.  23 
2.  Payments after receipt  of notice.  Protection under this section does not extend 24 
to payments made after a financial institution has received written notice from a party, or 25 
from the personal representative, surviving spouse or heir or devisee of a deceased party, 26 
to the effect that payments in accordance with the terms of the account, including one 27 
having an agency designation, should not be permitted, and the financial institution has 28 
had a reasonable opportunity to act on the notice when the payment is made.  Unless the 29 
notice  is withdrawn by the person giving it, the successor of any deceased party must 30 
concur in a request for payment if the financial institution is to be protected under this 31 
section.  Unless a financial institution has been served with process in an action or  32 
proceeding, no other notice or other information shown to have been available to the 33 
financial institution affects its right to protection under this section.  34 
3.  Notice of dispute; refusal to make payments.  A financial institution that 35 
receives written notice pursuant to this section that a dispute exists as to the rights of the 36 
parties may refuse, without liability, to make payments in accordance with the terms of 37 
the account.  38 
4.  Rights of parties in disputes.  Protection of a financial institution und er this 39 
section does not affect the rights of parties in disputes between themselves or their 40 
 
 Page 307 - 128LR0452(01) -1 
 successors concerning the beneficial ownership of sums on deposit in accounts or 1 
payments made from accounts.  2 
§6-227.  Setoff  3 
Without qualifying any other statuto ry right to setoff or lien and subject to any 4 
contractual provision, if a party is indebted to a financial institution, the financial 5 
institution has a right to setoff against the account.  The amount of the account subject to 6 
setoff is the proportion to w hich the party is, or immediately before death was, 7 
beneficially entitled under section 6 -211 or, in the absence of proof of that proportion, an 8 
equal share with all parties.  9 
PART 3  10 
TRANSFER ON DEATH SE CURITY REGISTRATION  11 
§6-301.  Definitions  12 
As used in th is Part, unless the context otherwise indicates, the following terms have 13 
the following meanings.  14 
1.  Beneficiary form.  "Beneficiary form" means a registration of a security that 15 
indicates the present owner of the security and the intention of the owner r egarding the 16 
person who will become the owner of the security upon the death of the owner.  17 
2.  Register.  "Register" means to issue a certificate showing the ownership of a 18 
certificated security or, in the case of an uncertificated security, to initiate or  transfer an 19 
account showing ownership of securities.  20 
3.  Registering entity.  "Registering entity" means a person that originates or 21 
transfers a security title by registration and includes a broker maintaining security 22 
accounts for customers and a transfe r agent or other person acting for or as an issuer of 23 
securities.  24 
4.  Security.  "Security" means a share, participation or other interest in property, in a 25 
business or in an obligation of an enterprise or other issuer and includes a certificated 26 
security,  an uncertificated security and a security account.  27 
5.  Security account.  "Security account" means:  28 
A.  A reinvestment account associated with a security, a securities account with a 29 
broker, a cash balance in a brokerage account, cash, interest, earnings or dividends 30 
earned or declared on a security in an account, a reinvestment account or a brokerage 31 
account, whether or not credited to the account before the owner's death; or  32 
B.  A cash balance or other property held for or due to the owner of a security  as a 33 
replacement for or product of an account security, whether or not credited to the 34 
account before the owner's death.  35 
 
 Page 308 - 128LR0452(01) -1 
 §6-302.  Registration in beneficiary form; sole or joint tenancy ownership  1 
Only individuals whose registration of a security shows sol e ownership by one 2 
individual or multiple ownership by 2 or more individuals with right of survivorship, 3 
rather than as tenants in common, may obtain registration in beneficiary form.  Multiple 4 
owners of a security registered in beneficiary form hold as jo int tenants with right of 5 
survivorship and not as tenants in common.  6 
§6-303.  Registration in beneficiary form; applicable law  7 
A security may be registered in beneficiary form if the form is authorized by this Part 8 
or a similar statute of the state of orga nization of the issuer or registering entity, the 9 
location of the registering entity's principal office, the office of the registering entity's 10 
transfer agent or the registering entity's office making the registration or by this Part or a 11 
similar statute o f the law of the state listed as the owner's address at the time of 12 
registration.  A registration governed by the law of a jurisdiction in which this Part or 13 
similar legislation is not in force or was not in force when a registration in beneficiary 14 
form wa s made is nevertheless presumed to be valid and authorized as a matter of 15 
contract law.  16 
§6-304.  Origination of registration in beneficiary form  17 
A security, whether evidenced by certificate or account, is registered in beneficiary 18 
form when the registratio n includes a designation of a beneficiary to take the ownership 19 
at the death of the owner or the deaths of all multiple owners.  20 
§6-305.  Form of registration in beneficiary form  21 
Registration in beneficiary form may be shown by the words "transfer on death"  or 22 
the abbreviation "TOD," or by the words "pay on death" or the abbreviation "POD," after 23 
the name of the registered owner and before the name of a beneficiary.  24 
§6-306.  Effect of registration in beneficiary form  25 
The designation of a transfer on death, o r "TOD," beneficiary on a registration in 26 
beneficiary form has no effect on ownership until the owner's death.  A registration of a 27 
security in beneficiary form may be canceled or changed at any time by the sole owner or 28 
all then -surviving owners without t he consent of the beneficiary.  29 
§6-307.  Ownership on death of owner  30 
On death of a sole owner or the last to die of all multiple owners, ownership of 31 
securities registered in beneficiary form passes to the beneficiary or beneficiaries who 32 
survive all owners .  On proof of death of all owners and compliance with any applicable 33 
requirements of the registering entity, a security registered in beneficiary form may be 34 
reregistered in the name of the beneficiary or beneficiaries who survived the death of all 35 
owners .  Until division of the security after the death of all owners, multiple beneficiaries 36 
surviving the death of all owners hold their interests as tenants in common.  If no 37 
beneficiary survives the death of all owners, the security belongs to the estate of the 38 
deceased sole owner or the estate of the last to die of all multiple owners.  39 
 
 Page 309 - 128LR0452(01) -1 
 §6-308.  Protection of registering entity  1 
1.  Security registration in beneficiary form not required; protections.  A 2 
registering entity is not required to offer or to accept a request for security registration in 3 
beneficiary form.  If a registration in beneficiary form is offered by a registering entity, 4 
the owner requesting registration in beneficiary form assents to the protections given to 5 
the registering entity by this Par t. 6 
2.  Registration to be implemented on death.  By accepting a request for 7 
registration of a security in beneficiary form, the registering entity agrees that the 8 
registration will be implemented on death of the deceased owner as provided in this Part.  9 
3.  Registering entity discharged from all claims; exceptions.  A registering entity 10 
is discharged from all claims to a security by the estate, creditors, heirs or devisees of a 11 
deceased owner if the registering entity registers a transfer of the security in accordance 12 
with section 6 -307 and does so in good faith reliance on:  13 
A.  The registration;  14 
B.  This Part; and  15 
C.  Information provided to the registering entity by affidavit of the personal 16 
representative of the deceased owner, by the surviving beneficiary  or by the surviving 17 
beneficiary's representatives or other information available to the registering entity.  18 
The protections of this Part do not extend to a reregistration or payment made after a 19 
registering entity has received written notice from any clai mant to any interest in the 20 
security objecting to implementation of a registration in beneficiary form.  No other 21 
notice or other information available to the registering entity affects its right to protection 22 
under this Part.  23 
4.  Rights of beneficiaries i n disputes.  The protection provided by this Part to the 24 
registering entity of a security does not affect the rights of beneficiaries in disputes 25 
between themselves and other claimants to ownership of the security transferred or its 26 
value or proceeds.  27 
§6-309.  Nontestamentary transfer on death  28 
A transfer on death resulting from a registration in beneficiary form is effective by 29 
reason of the contract regarding the registration between the owner and the registering 30 
entity and this Part and is not testamentar y. 31 
§6-310.  Terms, conditions and forms for registration  32 
1.  Terms and conditions.  A registering entity offering to accept registrations in 33 
beneficiary form may establish the terms and conditions under which it will receive 34 
requests:  35 
A.  For registrations  in beneficiary form; and  36 
 
 Page 310 - 128LR0452(01) -1 
 B.  For implementation of registrations in beneficiary form, including requests for 1 
cancellation of previously registered transfer on death, or "TOD," beneficiary 2 
designations and requests for reregistration to effect a change of beneficiary.  3 
The terms and conditions so established may provide for proving death, avoiding or 4 
resolving any problems concerning fractional shares, designating primary and contingent 5 
beneficiaries and substituting a named beneficiary's descendants to tak e the place of the 6 
named beneficiary in the event of the beneficiary's death.  Substitution may be indicated 7 
by appending to the name of the primary beneficiary the letters LDPS, standing for 8 
"lineal descendants per stirpes." This designation substitutes a  deceased beneficiary's 9 
descendants who survive the owner for a beneficiary who fails to so survive, the 10 
descendants to be identified and to share in accordance with the law of the beneficiary's 11 
domicile at the owner's death governing inheritance by descen dants of an intestate.  Other 12 
forms of identifying beneficiaries who are to take on one or more contingencies, and rules 13 
for providing proofs and assurances needed to satisfy reasonable concerns by registering 14 
entities regarding conditions and identities r elevant to accurate implementation of 15 
registrations in beneficiary form, may be contained in a registering entity's terms and 16 
conditions.  17 
2.  Forms.  The following are illustrations of registrations in beneficiary form that a 18 
registering entity may authori ze: 19 
A.  Sole owner - sole beneficiary:  John S. Brown TOD (or POD) John S. Brown Jr.;  20 
B.  Multiple owners - sole beneficiary:  John S. Brown Mary B. Brown JT TEN TOD 21 
John S. Brown Jr.; and  22 
C.  Multiple owners - primary and secondary (substituted) beneficia ries:  John S. 23 
Brown Mary B. Brown JT TEN TOD John S. Brown Jr. SUB BENE Peter Q. Brown 24 
or John S. Brown Mary B. Brown JT TEN TOD John S. Brown Jr. LDPS.  25 
§6-311.  Application of Part  26 
This Part applies to registrations of securities in beneficiary form made  before, on or 27 
after June 30, 1998 by decedents dying on or after June 30, 1998.  28 
Maine Uniform Probate Code Comment  (§6-101) 29 
This section does not constitute a substantive change to Maine law.  Maine has 30 
retained subsection (b) from former Title 18 -A, section 6 -201, which was a nonuniform 31 
provision.  32 
Maine Uniform Probate Code Comment  (§6-102) 33 
There is no counterpart to this section in former Title 18 -A, but the concepts for the 34 
most part were previously included in various sections of Maine law, including t he Maine 35 
Uniform Trust Code.  The section serves a useful function of addressing these issues in a 36 
comprehensive way and establishing an order of priority in the procedure for enforcing 37 
claims against various nonprobate assets.  One significant change is t o shorten the time 38 
period for bringing a claim under this section from 2 years after the decedent's date of 39 
 
 Page 311 - 128LR0452(01) -1 
 death to one year.  Th e section does not supersede existing law that insulates death 1 
benefits in life insurance contracts, retirement plans or indiv idual retirement account s 2 
from creditors' claims.  3 
Maine Uniform Probate Code Comment  (§6-201) 4 
Maine adopts the Uniform Probate Code  wording to coordinate definitions and 5 
consolidate the application of payable on death, or " POD ," accounts and so -called Tott en 6 
Trusts into the comprehensive framework of POD accounts through appropriate 7 
definitions of " beneficiary," " party"  and "POD designation."  The term "joint account" 8 
used throughout former Title 18 -A, section 6 -201 is replaced with "multiple -party 9 
account ," and other accounts previously designated under former Maine law as multiple - 10 
party accounts are addressed through definitions of "POD designation" and " beneficiary" 11 
as well as through other provisions of the Maine Uniform Probate Code . 12 
Maine Uniform Proba te Code Comment  (§6-202) 13 
This section  does not constitute a substantive change to Maine law.  14 
Maine Uniform Probate Code Comment  (§6-203) 15 
There is no counterpart to this section in former Title 18 -A.  This section  coordinates 16 
with the adoption of forms unde r the Maine Uniform Probate Code, section 6-204 and 17 
sets out clearly the options when an account is established.  18 
Maine Uniform Probate Code Comment  (§6-204) 19 
There is no counterpart to this section in former Title 18 -A.  The design  of this form 20 
encourage s the depositor and financial institution to consider the rights of a party to the 21 
account during a party's lifetime and the distribution of the account after a party's death.  22 
Since the form is not required to make the terms of the multiple -party account eff ective, it 23 
offers flexibility and a helpful alternative for depositors.  24 
Maine Uniform Probate Code Comment  (§6-205) 25 
There is no counterpart to this section in former Title 18 -A.  This section allows 26 
financial institutions to offer an option to depositors w ho seek the convenience of an 27 
agency relationship but intend the proceeds of an account to pass according to the 28 
depositor's will or to the depositor's heirs after death.  While not supplanting the 29 
comprehensive Maine Uniform Power of Attorney Act, this se ction offers a limited 30 
agency role for specific financial accounts.  31 
Maine  Uniform  Probate Code Comment  (§6-206) 32 
This section  does not constitute a substantive change to Maine law.  33 
Maine  Uniform  Probate Code Comment  (§6-211) 34 
 
 Page 312 - 128LR0452(01) -1 
 In the absence of proof otherwis e, subsection 2  creates a presumption, as between 1 
parties married to each other, that the net contribution of each  party  is an equal amount.   2 
Maine  Uniform  Probate Code Comment  (§6-212) 3 
Maine law is revised to delete the right to rebut the presumption tha t amounts held in 4 
a joint account pass to the surviving joint tenant.  Prior Maine law permitted the personal 5 
representative of an estate to claim proceeds passed to the estate if there was "clear and 6 
convincing evidence of a different intention at the tim e the account [was] created."  7 
This section includes the presumption that the deceased spouse's interest in a 8 
multiple -party account passes to the surviving spouse.  In most cases, any other party to a 9 
multiple -party account with spouses is a child of the spouses and the intent is to pass the 10 
interest after death to that child but not to increase the child's lifetime interest.   11 
The substance of subsection 4  is new to Maine law and clarifies that a surviving 12 
party's interest in a multiple -party account can be reduced by outstanding checks or other 13 
withdrawals by the deceased party that were made prior to death.  Such reductions might 14 
also include repayment of any automatic deposit, such as a Social Security payment , or 15 
automatic withdrawals for  the bills of a decedent.  16

ARTICLE 7  11 
TRUST ADMINISTRATION  12 
PART 1  13 
POWERS OF TRUSTEES  14 
§7-101.  Prohibitions and requirements applicable to trusts that are private 15 
foundation s 16 
1.  Prohibited acts.   In the administration of any trust that is a private foundation, as 17 
defined in Section 509 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986, a charitable trust, as 18 
defined in Section 4947(a)(1) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986, or a split -interest 19 
trust, as defined in Section 4947(a)(2) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986, the 20 
following acts are prohibited:  21 
A.  Engaging in any act of self -dealing, as defined in Section 4941(d) of the Internal 22 
Revenue Code of 1986, that would give rise to an y liability for the tax imposed by 23 
Section 4941(a) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986;  24 
B.  Retaining any excess business holdings, as defined in Section 4943(c) of the 25 
Internal Revenue Code of 1986, that would give rise to any liability for the tax 26 
impos ed by Section 4943(a) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986;  27 
C.  Making any investments that would jeopardize the carrying out of any of the 28 
exempt purposes of the trust, within the meaning of Section 4944 of the Internal 29 
Revenue Code of 1986, so as to give  rise to any liability for the tax imposed by 30 
Section 4944(a) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986; and  31 
 
 Page 315 - 128LR0452(01) -1 
 D.  Making any taxable expenditures, as defined in Section 4945(d) of the Internal 1 
Revenue Code of 1986, that would give rise to any liability for the t ax imposed by 2 
Section 4945(a) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986.  3 
This section does not apply to split -interest trusts or to amounts of split -interest trusts that 4 
are not subject to the prohibitions applicable to private foundations by reason of the 5 
provisions of Section 4947 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986.  6 
2.  Required distributions.   In the administration of any trust that is a private 7 
foundation or a charitable trust, there must be distributed, for the purposes specified in the 8 
trust instrument, for each taxable year, amounts at least sufficient to avoid liability for the 9 
tax imposed by Section 4942(a) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986.  10 
3.  Exception, contrary to terms of trust.   Subsections 1 and 2 do not apply to any 11 
trust to the extent that a court of competent jurisdiction determines that the application 12 
would be contrary to the terms of the instrument governing the trust and that the trust 13 
instrument may not properly be changed to conform to subsections 1 and 2.  14 
4.  Attorney General's power s.  Nothing in this section impairs the rights and 15 
powers of the courts or the Attorney General of this State with respect to any trust.  16 
5.  Internal Revenue Code.   All references to sections of the Internal Revenue Code 17 
of 1986 are deemed to include futur e amendments to the referenced sections and 18 
corresponding provisions of future internal revenue laws.  19 
§7-102.  Trustees authorized to invest trust funds in affiliated investments; 20 
limitations  21 
1.  Authorization.   An association, corporation or financial ins titution authorized to 22 
exercise trust powers in this State while acting as a fiduciary is authorized to purchase for 23 
the fiduciary estate, directly from underwriters or distributors or in the secondary market, 24 
bonds or other securities underwritten or dist ributed by that association, corporation or 25 
financial institution or an affiliate or by a syndicate that includes that association, 26 
corporation or financial institution and securities of an investment company registered 27 
under the federal Investment Company  Act of 1940, 15 United States Code, Section 28 
80a-1 et seq., as amended, for which that association, corporation or financial institution 29 
or an affiliate acts as advisor, distributor, transfer agent, registrar, sponsor, manager, 30 
shareholder servicing agent or custodian.  A person acting as a cofiduciary with an 31 
association, corporation or financial institution or an affiliate is authorized to consent to 32 
the investment in such interests.  33 
2.  Limitations.   The authority granted pursuant to subsection 1 may not  be 34 
exercised:  35 
A.  If the investment is prohibited by the instrument, judgment, decree or order 36 
creating the fiduciary relationship; or  37 
B.  Unless, in the case of cofiduciaries, the association, corporation or financial 38 
institution or an affiliate procures  the consent of its cofiduciaries to the investment.  39 
 
 Page 316 - 128LR0452(01) -1 
 3.  Disclosures.   The disclosures required by this section must be provided by a 1 
statement or letter mailed to the last known address of each person to whom statements 2 
for the fiduciary estate are provid ed.  The disclosures may be provided separately or as 3 
part of other documents of the fiduciary estate.  If made part of other documents of the 4 
fiduciary estate, the disclosures must be printed clearly and conspicuously on those 5 
documents.  6 
A.  A trustee pur chasing bonds or securities pursuant to this section shall disclose in 7 
writing all capacities in which the trustee or an affiliate acts for the issuer of those 8 
bonds or securities and that the trustee or an affiliate may have an interest in the 9 
underwritin g or distribution of those bonds or securities.  10 
B.  If the securities purchased pursuant to subsection 1 are shares of an investment 11 
company subject to this section, the trustee shall disclose the services provided and 12 
the receipt of compensation for those  services before the initial purchase and 13 
annually.  14 
§7-103.  Qualification of foreign trustee  15 
A foreign corporate trustee is required to qualify as a foreign corporation doing 16 
business in this State if it maintains the principal place of administration of any trust 17 
within the State. A foreign cotrustee is not required to qualify in this State solely because 18 
its cotrustee maintains the principal place of administration in this State. Unless otherwise 19 
doing business in this State, local qualification by a for eign trustee, corporate or 20 
individual, is not required in order for the trustee to receive distribution from a local 21 
estate or to hold, invest in, manage or acquire property located in this State or maintain 22 
litigation. Nothing in this section affects a de termination of what other acts require 23 
qualification as doing business in this State.  24 
PART 2  25 
COMMON TRUST FUNDS  26 
§7-201.  Definitions; establishment of common trust funds  27 
1.  Definitions.  As used in this Part, unless the context otherwise indicates, the 28 
following terms have the following meanings.  29 
A.  "Common trust fund" means a trust or fund maintained by a bank or trust 30 
company exclusively for the collective investment or reinvestment of money 31 
contributed to the trust or fund by the bank or trust company,  or an affiliated bank or 32 
trust company, as a fiduciary, including a trustee of a trust or fund for the primary 33 
purpose of paying employee benefits of any kind.  34 
B.  "Fiduciary" includes a trustee, executor, administrator, guardian and custodian 35 
under a uni form transfers to minors act.  36 
2.  Common trust funds.  A bank or trust company qualified to act as fiduciary in 37 
this State may establish and operate common trust funds for the purpose of furnishing 38 
investments to itself as fiduciary or to itself and others  as cofiduciaries, and for the 39 
purposes of furnishing investments to affiliated banks, within the meaning of Section 40 
 
 Page 317 - 128LR0452(01) -1 
 1504 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986, acting for themselves and others as 1 
cofiduciaries, and the bank or trust company may, as the fid uciary or cofiduciary or 2 
acting for affiliated banks alone or with their cofiduciaries, invest funds lawfully held for 3 
investment in interests in common trust funds, if the investment is not prohibited by the 4 
instrument, judgment, decree or order creating the fiduciary relationship and if, in the 5 
case of cofiduciaries, the bank or trust company or affiliate procures the consent of its 6 
cofiduciaries to the investment.  A person acting as a cofiduciary with the bank or trust 7 
company or affiliate is authorized  to consent to the investment in the interests.  8 
§7-202.  Court accountings  9 
Unless ordered by decree of the Superior Court, the bank or trust company operating 10 
common trust funds, referred to in this section as "the accountant," is not required to 11 
render a court accounting with regard to the funds, but the accountant may by petition to 12 
the Superior Court or the probate court in the county where the accountant has its 13 
principal place of business secure approval of the accounting on such conditions as the 14 
court may establish. Whenever a petition for the allowance of such an account is 15 
presented, the court having jurisdiction shall assign a time and place for hearing and shall 16 
cause public notice to be given by publication 3 weeks successively in a newspaper 17 
published in the county whose court has jurisdiction. In addition, the court shall, except to 18 
the extent as the several instruments creating the trusts participating in the common trust 19 
fund provide otherwise, order personal notice upon all known beneficiarie s of the 20 
participating trust estates who have a place of residence known to the accountant. 21 
Personal notice to known beneficiaries having a place of residence known to the 22 
accountant must be made by a written notice deposited in the mails addressed to each  23 
known beneficiary at the known place of residence at least 14 days before the time of 24 
hearing, or by a written notice either in hand or left at the known place of residence 14 25 
days at least before the time of hearing. The method of service and the form of  the notice 26 
must be as the court orders. "Place of residence known to the accountant" as used in this 27 
section includes only places of residence actually known to the accountant and does not 28 
include residences that could be discovered upon investigation but  do not in the due 29 
course of business come to the actual knowledge of the accountant. The allowance of an 30 
account is conclusive as to all matters shown in the account upon all persons then or 31 
thereafter interested in the funds invested in the common trust funds.  32 
§7-203.  Application of Part  33 
This Part applies to fiduciary relationships in existence on September 1, 1951 or  34 
established after that date.  35 
PART 3  36 
BANK AND TRUST COMPA NY NOMINEES  37 
§7-301.  Registration in name of nominees  38 
A state or national bank or  trust company, when acting in this State as a fiduciary or 39 
cofiduciary with others, may with the consent of its cofiduciary or cofiduciaries, if any, 40 
who are authorized to give consent, cause an investment held in that capacity to be 41 
 
 Page 318 - 128LR0452(01) -1 
 registered and held i n the name of a nominee or nominees of the bank or trust company. 1 
The bank or trust company is liable for the acts of a nominee with respect to a registered 2 
investment. "Fiduciary" as used in this Part includes, but is not limited to, personal 3 
representati ves, guardians, conservators, trustees, agents and custodians.  4 
§7-302.  Separate records  5 
The records of a bank or trust company must at all times show the ownership of 6 
investments held in the name of nominees; such investments must be in the possession 7 
and control of the bank or trust company and must be kept separate and apart from the 8 
assets of the bank or trust company.  9 
§7-303.  Applicability of provisions  10 
This Part governs fiduciaries and cofiduciaries acting under wills, agreements, court 11 
orders and ot her instruments existing on January 1, 1981 or made after that date. Nothing 12 
contained in this Part may be construed as authorizing a departure from or variation of the 13 
express words or limitations set forth in a will, agreement, court order or other instr ument 14 
creating or defining the fiduciary's duties and powers.  15 
PART 4  16 
UNIFORM PRINCIPAL AN D INCOME ACT OF 1997  17 
SUBPART 1  18 
DEFINITIONS AND FIDU CIARY DUTIES  19 
§7-401.  Short title  20 
This Part may be cited as the "Uniform Principal and Income Act of 1997."  21 
§7-402.  Definitions  22 
As used in this Part, unless the context otherwise indicates, the following terms have 23 
the following meanings.  24 
1.  Accounting period.   "Accounting period" means a calendar year unless another 25 
12-month period is selected by a fiduciary.  "Accou nting period" includes a portion of a 26 
calendar year or other 12 -month period that begins when an income interest begins or 27 
ends when an income interest ends.  28 
2.  Beneficiary.   "Beneficiary" includes, in the case of a decedent's estate, an heir and 29 
devisee and, in the case of a trust, an income beneficiary and a remainder beneficiary.  30 
3.  Fiduciary.   "Fiduciary" means a personal representative or a trustee.  "Fiduciary" 31 
includes an executor, administrator, successor personal representative, special 32 
administr ator and a person performing substantially the same function.  33 
 
 Page 319 - 128LR0452(01) -1 
 4.  Income.   "Income" means money or property that a fiduciary receives as current 1 
return from a principal asset.  "Income" includes a portion of receipts from a sale, 2 
exchange or liquidation of  a principal asset, to the extent provided in subpart 4.  3 
5.  Income beneficiary.   "Income beneficiary" means a person to whom net income 4 
of a trust is or may be payable.  5 
6.  Income interest.   "Income interest" means the right of an income beneficiary to 6 
receive all or part of net income, whether the terms of the trust require it to be distributed 7 
or authorize it to be distributed in the trustee's discretion.  8 
7.  Mandatory income interest.   "Mandatory income interest" means the right of an 9 
income beneficiary  to receive net income that the terms of the trust require the fiduciary 10 
to distribute.  11 
8.  Net income.   "Net income" means the total receipts allocated to income during an 12 
accounting period minus the disbursements made from income during the period, plus or 13 
minus transfers under this Part to or from income during the period.  14 
9.  Person.   "Person" means an individual; corporation; business trust; estate; trust; 15 
partnership; limited liability company; association; joint venture; government; 16 
governmental subd ivision, agency or instrumentality; public corporation; or any other 17 
legal or commercial entity.  18 
10.  Principal.   "Principal" means property held in trust for distribution to a 19 
remainder beneficiary when the trust terminates.  20 
11.  Remainder beneficiary.   "Remainder beneficiary" means a person entitled to 21 
receive principal when an income interest ends.  22 
12.  Terms of a trust.   "Terms of a trust" means the manifestation of the intent of a 23 
settlor or decedent with respect to the trust, expressed in a manner tha t admits of its proof 24 
in a judicial proceeding, whether by written or spoken words or by conduct.  25 
13.  Trustee.   "Trustee" includes an original, additional or successor trustee, whether 26 
or not appointed or confirmed by a court.  27 
§7-403.  Fiduciary duties; g eneral principles  28 
1.  Allocating receipts and disbursements.   In allocating receipts and disbursements 29 
to or between principal and income and with respect to any matter within the scope of 30 
subparts 2 and 3, a fiduciary:  31 
A.  Shall administer a trust or esta te in accordance with the terms of the trust or the 32 
will, even if there is a different provision in this Part;  33 
B.  May administer a trust or estate by the exercise of a discretionary power of 34 
administration given to the fiduciary by the terms of the trust or the will, even if the 35 
exercise of the power produces a result different from a result required or permitted 36 
by this Part;  37 
 
 Page 320 - 128LR0452(01) -1 
 C.  Shall administer a trust or estate in accordance with this Part if the terms of the 1 
trust or the will do not contain a differen t provision or do not give the fiduciary a 2 
discretionary power of administration; and  3 
D.  Shall add a receipt or charge a disbursement to principal to the extent that the 4 
terms of the trust and this Part do not provide a method for allocating the receipt o r 5 
disbursement to or between principal and income.  6 
2.  Fair and reasonable administration.   In exercising the power to adjust under 7 
section 7 -404, subsection 1 or a discretionary power of administration regarding a matter 8 
within the scope of this Part, whe ther granted by the terms of a trust, a will or this Part, a 9 
fiduciary shall administer a trust or estate impartially, based on what is fair and 10 
reasonable to all of the beneficiaries, except to the extent that the terms of the trust or the 11 
will clearly ma nifest an intention that the fiduciary favor or that the fiduciary may favor 12 
one or more of the beneficiaries.  A determination in accordance with this Part is 13 
presumed to be fair and reasonable to all of the beneficiaries.  14 
§7-404.  Trustee's power to adju st 15 
1.  Power to adjust between principal and income.   A trustee may adjust between 16 
principal and income by allocating an amount of income to principal or an amount of 17 
principal to income to the extent the trustee considers appropriate if the terms of the t rust 18 
describe the amount that may or must be distributed to a beneficiary by referring to the 19 
trust's income and the trustee determines, after applying the provisions of section 7 -403, 20 
subsection 1, that the trustee is unable to comply with section 7 -403, subsection 2.  21 
2.  Factors.   In deciding whether and to what extent to exercise the power conferred 22 
by subsection 1, a trustee shall consider all factors relevant to the trust and its 23 
beneficiaries, including the following factors to the extent they are rel evant:  24 
A.  The nature, purpose and expected duration of the trust;  25 
B.  The intent of the settlor;  26 
C.  The identity and circumstances of the beneficiaries and, to the extent reasonably 27 
known to the trustee, the needs of the beneficiaries for present and fut ure 28 
distributions authorized or required by the terms of the trust;  29 
D.  The needs for liquidity, regularity of income and preservation and appreciation of 30 
capital;  31 
E.  The assets held in the trust; the extent to which they consist of financial assets, 32 
interests in closely held enterprises, tangible and intangible personal property or real 33 
property; the extent to which an asset is used by a beneficiary; and whether an asset 34 
was purchased by the trustee or received from the settlor;  35 
F.  The net amount allocat ed to income under the other sections of this Part and the 36 
increase or decrease in the value of the principal assets, which the trustee may 37 
estimate as to assets for which market values are not readily available;  38 
G.  Whether and to what extent the terms of  the trust give the trustee the power to 39 
invade principal or accumulate income or prohibit the trustee from invading principal 40 
 
 Page 321 - 128LR0452(01) -1 
 or accumulating income, and the extent to which the trustee has exercised a power 1 
from time to time to invade principal or accumu late income;  2 
H.  The actual and anticipated effect of economic conditions on principal and income 3 
and effects of inflation and deflation; and  4 
I.  The anticipated tax consequences of an adjustment.  5 
3.  Adjustments not permitted.   A trustee may not make an a djustment under this 6 
section if any of the following applies:  7 
A.  The adjustment would diminish the income interest in a trust that requires all of 8 
the income to be paid at least annually to a spouse and for which an estate tax or gift 9 
tax marital deductio n would be allowed, in whole or in part, if the trustee did not 10 
have the power to make the adjustment;  11 
B.  The adjustment would reduce the actuarial value of the income interest in a trust 12 
to which a person transfers property with the intent to qualify for  a gift tax exclusion;  13 
C.  The adjustment would change the amount payable to a beneficiary as a fixed 14 
annuity or a fixed fraction of the value of the trust assets;  15 
D.  The adjustment is from any amount that is permanently set aside for charitable 16 
purposes under a will or the terms of a trust, unless both income and principal are so 17 
set aside;  18 
E.  The trustee's possession or exercise of the power to make an adjustment would 19 
cause an individual to be treated as the owner of all or part of the trust for income  tax 20 
purposes and the individual would not be treated as the owner if the trustee did not 21 
possess the power to make an adjustment;  22 
F.  The trustee's possession or exercise of the power to make an adjustment would 23 
cause all or part of the trust assets to be  included for estate tax purposes in the estate 24 
of an individual who has the power to remove a trustee or appoint a trustee, or both, 25 
and the assets would not be included in the estate of the individual if the trustee did 26 
not possess the power to make an a djustment;  27 
G.  The trustee is a beneficiary of the trust; or  28 
H.  The trust has been converted to a unitrust under section 7 -405. 29 
4.  Cotrustees.   If subsection 3, paragraph E, F or G applies to a trustee and there is 30 
more than one trustee, a cotrustee to w hom the provision does not apply may make the 31 
adjustment unless the exercise of the power by the remaining trustee or trustees is 32 
prohibited by the terms of the trust.  Terms of the trust requiring that if there are 2 or 33 
more trustees serving they must act  by agreement or by any majority or percentage 34 
consensus may not be construed to prohibit the remaining trustee or trustees from 35 
possessing or exercising the power to make the adjustment.  36 
5.  Release of power to adjust.   A trustee may release the entire po wer conferred by 37 
subsection 1 or may release only the power to adjust from income to principal or the 38 
power to adjust from principal to income if the trustee is uncertain about whether 39 
possessing or exercising the power will cause a result described in sub section 3, 40 
paragraphs A to F or if the trustee determines that possessing or exercising the power will 41 
 
 Page 322 - 128LR0452(01) -1 
 or may deprive the trust of a tax benefit or impose a tax burden not described in 1 
subsection 3.  The release of the power to adjust may be permanent or f or a specified 2 
period, including a period measured by the life of an individual.  3 
6.  Terms of trust deny power of adjustment.   Terms of a trust that limit the power 4 
of a trustee to make an adjustment between principal and income do not affect the 5 
applicati on of this section unless it is clear from the terms of the trust that the terms are 6 
intended to deny the trustee the power of adjustment conferred by subsection 1.  7 
§7-405.  Power to convert to unitrust  8 
1.  Convert to unitrust; requirements.   Unless expres sly prohibited by the terms of 9 
the trust, a trustee may release the power to adjust under section 7 -404 and convert a trust 10 
into a unitrust as described in this section if all of the following apply:  11 
A.  The trustee determines that the conversion will impr ove the ability of the trustee 12 
to carry out the intent of the settlor and the purposes of the trust;  13 
B.  The trustee gives written notice of the trustee's intention to release the power to 14 
adjust and to convert the trust into a unitrust and of how the unit rust will operate, 15 
including what initial decisions the trustee will make under this section, to the 16 
following beneficiaries:  17 
(1)  All beneficiaries who are currently eligible to receive income from the trust; 18 
and 19 
(2) All beneficiaries who would receive, i f no power of appointment were 20 
exercised, a distribution of principal if the trust were to terminate immediately 21 
prior to the giving of notice;  22 
C.  There is at least one beneficiary eligible to receive income and at least one 23 
beneficiary who would receive principal as described in paragraph B; and  24 
D.  No beneficiary objects to the conversion to a unitrust in a writing delivered to the 25 
trustee within 60 days of the mailing of the notice required under paragraph B.  26 
2.  Petition to convert.   If a beneficiary t imely objects to the conversion to a unitrust 27 
under subsection 1 or if the requirements of subsection 1, paragraph C are not met, the 28 
trustee may petition the court to approve the conversion to a unitrust.  A beneficiary may 29 
request a trustee to convert to  a unitrust and, if the trustee does not convert, the 30 
beneficiary may petition the court to order the conversion.  Upon receipt of a petition by 31 
the trustee or a beneficiary, the court shall approve the conversion or direct the requested 32 
conversion if the court concludes that the conversion will better enable the trustee to carry 33 
out the intent of the settlor and the purposes of the trust.  34 
3.  Factors.   In deciding whether to exercise the power conferred by subsection 1, a 35 
trustee shall consider the followi ng factors to the extent they are relevant:  36 
A.  The nature, purpose and expected duration of the trust;  37 
B.  The identity and circumstances of the beneficiaries and, to the extent reasonably 38 
known to the trustee, the needs of the beneficiaries for present a nd future 39 
distributions authorized or required by the terms of the trust;  40 
 
 Page 323 - 128LR0452(01) -1 
 C.  The needs for liquidity, regularity of income and preservation and appreciation of 1 
capital;  2 
D.  The assets held in the trust; the extent to which they consist of financial assets , 3 
interests in closely held enterprises, tangible and intangible personal property or real 4 
property; and the extent to which an asset is used by a beneficiary;  5 
E.  Whether and to what extent the terms of the trust give the trustee the power to 6 
invade princ ipal or accumulate income or prohibit the trustee from invading principal 7 
or accumulating income, and the extent to which the trustee has exercised a power 8 
from time to time to invade principal or accumulate income;  9 
F.  The actual and anticipated effect of  economic conditions on principal and income 10 
and effects of inflation and deflation; and  11 
G.  The anticipated tax consequences of the conversion.  12 
4.  After conversion; requirements.   After a trust is converted to a unitrust, all of 13 
the following apply:  14 
A.  The trustee shall follow an investment policy seeking a total return for the 15 
investments held by the trust, whether the return is to be derived from appreciation of 16 
capital, from earnings and distributions from capital or from both;  17 
B.  The trustee shall m ake regular distributions in accordance with the terms of the 18 
trust construed in accordance with the provisions of this section; and  19 
C.  "Income" in the terms of the trust means an annual distribution, known as the 20 
"unitrust distribution," equal to 4%, kno wn as the "payout percentage," of the net fair 21 
market value of the trust's assets, whether such assets would be considered income or 22 
principal under other provisions of this Part, averaged over the lesser of the 3 23 
preceding years and the period during whic h the trust has been in existence.  24 
5.  Trustee's determination.   The trustee of a unitrust subject to this section may in 25 
the trustee's discretion from time to time determine all of the following:  26 
A.  The effective date of a conversion to a unitrust;  27 
B.  The provisions for prorating a unitrust distribution for a short year in which a 28 
beneficiary's right to payment commences or ceases;  29 
C.  The frequency of unitrust distributions during the year;  30 
D.  The effect of other payments from or contributions to the t rust on the trust's 31 
valuation;  32 
E.  Whether to value the trust's assets annually or more frequently;  33 
F.  What valuation dates to use;  34 
G.  How frequently to value nonliquid assets and whether to estimate their value;  35 
H.  Whether to omit from the calculation of the unitrust distribution trust property 36 
occupied or possessed by a beneficiary; and  37 
I.  Any other matters necessary for the proper functioning of the unitrust.  38 
 
 Page 324 - 128LR0452(01) -1 
 6.  After conversion; allocation provisions.   After a trust is converted to a unitrust, 1 
the following allocation provisions apply to the trust:  2 
A.  Expenses that would be deducted from income if the trust were not a unitrust may 3 
not be deducted from the unitrust distribution; and  4 
B.  Unless otherwise provided by the terms of the trust, the unitru st distribution must 5 
be paid from net income, as net income would be determined if the trust were not a 6 
unitrust.  To the extent net income is insufficient, the unitrust distribution must be 7 
paid from net realized short -term capital gains.  To the extent n et income and net 8 
realized short -term capital gains are insufficient, the unitrust distribution must be paid 9 
from net realized long -term capital gains.  To the extent net income and net realized 10 
short -term and long -term capital gains are insufficient, the unitrust distribution must 11 
be paid from the principal of the trust.  12 
7.  Petition for changes.   The trustee of a unitrust subject to this section or, if the 13 
trustee declines to do so, a beneficiary may petition the court to do any of the following:  14 
A.  Select a payout percentage other than 4%;  15 
B.  Provide for a distribution of net income, as would be determined if the trust were 16 
not a unitrust, in excess of the unitrust distribution if such distribution is necessary to 17 
preserve a tax benefit;  18 
C.  Average the  valuation of the trust's net assets over a period other than 3 years; or  19 
D.  Reconvert from a unitrust.  Upon a reconversion, the power to adjust under 20 
section 7 -404 is revived.  21 
8.  Conversion does not affect certain trust provisions.   A conversion to a u nitrust 22 
does not affect a provision in the terms of the trust directing or authorizing the trustee to 23 
distribute principal or authorizing a beneficiary to withdraw a portion or all of the 24 
principal.  25 
9.  Conversion not permitted.   A trustee may not convert a trust into a unitrust if 26 
any of the following applies:  27 
A.  Payment of the unitrust distribution would change the amount payable to a 28 
beneficiary as a fixed annuity or a fixed fraction of the value of the trust assets;  29 
B.  The unitrust distribution would be made from any amount that is permanently set 30 
aside for charitable purposes under a will or the terms of the trust unless both income 31 
and principal are so set aside;  32 
C.  The trustee's possession or exercise of the power to convert would cause an 33 
individu al to be treated as the owner of all or part of the trust for income tax 34 
purposes, and the individual would not be treated as the owner if the trustee did not 35 
possess the power to convert;  36 
D.  The trustee's possession or exercise of the power to convert wo uld cause all or 37 
part of the trust assets to be included for estate tax purposes in the estate of an 38 
individual who has the power to remove a trustee or appoint a trustee, or both, and 39 
 
 Page 325 - 128LR0452(01) -1 
 the assets would not be included in the estate of the individual if the  trustee did not 1 
possess the power to convert;  2 
E.  The conversion would result in the disallowance of an estate tax or gift tax marital 3 
deduction that would be allowed if the trustee did not have the power to convert; or  4 
F.  The trustee is a beneficiary of  the trust.  5 
10.  Conversion by cotrustee.   If subsection 9, paragraph C, D or F applies to a 6 
trustee and there is more than one trustee, a cotrustee to whom the provision does not 7 
apply may convert the trust unless the exercise of the power by the remainin g trustee or 8 
trustees is prohibited by the terms of the trust.  Terms of the trust requiring that if there 9 
are 2 or more trustees serving they must act by agreement or by any majority or 10 
percentage consensus may not be construed to prohibit the remaining t rustee or trustees 11 
from exercising the power to convert.  If subsection 9, paragraph C, D or F applies to all 12 
the trustees, the trustees may petition the court to direct a conversion.  13 
11.  Release of power to convert.   A trustee may release the power confe rred by 14 
subsection 1 to convert to a unitrust if the trustee is uncertain about whether possessing or 15 
exercising the power will cause a result described in subsection 9, paragraph C, D or E or 16 
if the trustee determines that possessing or exercising the pow er will or may deprive the 17 
trust of a tax benefit or impose a tax burden not described in subsection 9.  The release of 18 
the power to convert to a unitrust may be permanent or for a specified period, including a 19 
period measured by the life of an individual.  20 
§7-406.  Judicial review of discretionary powers  21 
1.  Court determination of abuse of fiduciary's discretion.   A court may not 22 
change a fiduciary's decision to exercise or not to exercise a discretionary power 23 
conferred by this Part unless it determines th at the decision was an abuse of the 24 
fiduciary's discretion.  A court may not determine that a fiduciary abused the fiduciary's 25 
discretion merely because the court would have exercised the discretion in a different 26 
manner or would not have exercised the dis cretion.  27 
2.  Abuse of discretion; remedy.   If a court determines that a fiduciary has abused 28 
the fiduciary's discretion in exercising a discretionary power conferred by this Part, the 29 
remedy is to restore the income and remainder beneficiaries to the posit ions they would 30 
have occupied if the fiduciary had not abused the fiduciary's discretion, according to the 31 
provisions of this subsection:  32 
A.  To the extent that the abuse of discretion has resulted in no distribution to a 33 
beneficiary or a distribution that  is too small, the court shall require the fiduciary to 34 
distribute from the trust to the beneficiary an amount that the court determines will 35 
restore the beneficiary, in whole or in part, to the beneficiary's appropriate position;  36 
B.  To the extent that th e abuse of discretion has resulted in a distribution to a 37 
beneficiary that is too large, the court shall restore the beneficiaries or the trust, or 38 
both, in whole or in part, to their appropriate positions by requiring the fiduciary to 39 
withhold an amount f rom one or more future distributions to the beneficiary who 40 
received the distribution that was too large or requiring that beneficiary or that 41 
 
 Page 326 - 128LR0452(01) -1 
 beneficiary's estate to return some or all of the distribution to the trust, 1 
notwithstanding a spendthrift or sim ilar provision;  2 
C.  If the abuse of discretion concerns the power to convert a trust into a unitrust, the 3 
court shall require the trustee either to convert the trust to a unitrust or to reconvert 4 
from a unitrust; and  5 
D.  To the extent that the court is una ble, after applying paragraphs A, B and C, to 6 
restore the beneficiaries or the trust, or both, to the positions they would have 7 
occupied if the fiduciary had not abused the fiduciary's discretion, the court may 8 
require the fiduciary to pay an appropriate a mount from the fiduciary's own funds to 9 
one or more of the beneficiaries or the trust, or both.  10 
3.  Proposed exercise or nonexercise of discretion; court determination.   Upon a 11 
petition by the fiduciary, a court having jurisdiction over the trust or estate  shall 12 
determine whether a proposed exercise or nonexercise by the fiduciary of a discretionary 13 
power conferred by this Part will result in an abuse of the fiduciary's discretion.  If the 14 
petition describes the proposed exercise or nonexercise of the power  and contains 15 
sufficient information to inform the beneficiaries of the reasons for the proposal, the facts 16 
upon which the fiduciary relies and an explanation of how the income and remainder 17 
beneficiaries will be affected by the proposed exercise or nonexe rcise of the power, a 18 
beneficiary who challenges the proposed exercise or nonexercise has the burden of 19 
establishing that it will result in an abuse of discretion.  20 
SUBPART 2  21 
DECEDENT'S ESTATE OR  TERMINATING INCOME I NTEREST  22 
§7-421.  Determination and distri bution of net income  23 
After a decedent dies, in the case of an estate, or after an income interest in a trust 24 
ends, the provisions of this section apply.  25 
1.  Determination of net income and net principal.  A fiduciary of an estate or of a 26 
terminating income  interest shall determine the amount of net income and net principal 27 
receipts received from property specifically given to a beneficiary under the provisions of 28 
subparts 3 to 5 that apply to trustees and the provisions of subsection 5.  The fiduciary 29 
shall  distribute the net income and net principal receipts to the beneficiary who is to 30 
receive the specific property.  31 
2.  Requirements for determinations.  A fiduciary shall determine the remaining 32 
net income of a decedent's estate or a terminating income inte rest under the provisions of 33 
subparts 3 to 5 that apply to trustees and by:  34 
A.  Including in net income all income from property used to discharge liabilities;  35 
B.  Paying from income or principal, in the fiduciary's discretion, fees of attorneys, 36 
accountan ts and fiduciaries; court costs and other expenses of administration; and 37 
interest on death taxes; but the fiduciary may pay those expenses from income of 38 
property passing to a trust for which the fiduciary claims an estate tax marital or 39 
 
 Page 327 - 128LR0452(01) -1 
 charitable deduct ion only to the extent that the payment of those expenses from 1 
income will not cause the reduction or loss of the deduction; and  2 
C.  Paying from principal all other disbursements made or incurred in connection 3 
with the settlement of a decedent's estate or the winding up of a terminating income 4 
interest, including debts, funeral expenses, disposition of remains, exempt property 5 
and allowances distributable pursuant to Article 2, Part 4 and death taxes and related 6 
penalties that are apportioned to the estate or terminating income interest by the will, 7 
the terms of the trust or applicable law.  8 
3.  Distribution to beneficiary.  A fiduciary shall distribute to a beneficiary who 9 
receives a pecuniary amount outright the interest or any other amount provided by the 10 
will, the terms of the trust or applicable law from net income determined under 11 
subsection 2 or from principal to the extent that net income is insufficient.  If a 12 
beneficiary is to receive a pecuniary amount outright from a trust after an income interest 13 
ends and no interest or other amount is provided for by the terms of the trust or applicable 14 
law, the fiduciary shall distribute the interest or other amount to which the beneficiary 15 
would be entitled under applicable law if the pecuniary amount were requi red to be paid 16 
under a will under section 3 -904. 17 
4.  Distribution to other beneficiary.  A fiduciary shall distribute the net income 18 
remaining after distributions required by subsection 3 in the manner described in section 19 
7-422 to all other beneficiaries,  including a beneficiary who receives a pecuniary amount 20 
in trust, even if the beneficiary holds an unqualified power to withdraw assets from the 21 
trust or other presently exercisable general power of appointment over the trust.  22 
5.  Reduction of principal o r income receipts not permitted.  A fiduciary may not 23 
reduce principal or income receipts from property described in subsection 1 because of a 24 
payment described in section 7 -461 or 7 -462 to the extent that the will, the terms of the 25 
trust or applicable law  requires the fiduciary to make the payment from assets other than 26 
the property or to the extent that the fiduciary recovers or expects to recover the payment 27 
from a 3rd party.  The net income and principal receipts from the property are determined 28 
by incl uding all of the amounts the fiduciary receives or pays with respect to the property, 29 
whether those amounts accrued or became due before, on or after the date of a decedent's 30 
death or an income interest's terminating event, and by making a reasonable provi sion for 31 
amounts that the fiduciary believes the estate or terminating income interest may become 32 
obligated to pay after the property is distributed.  33 
§7-422.  Distribution to residuary and remainder beneficiaries  34 
1.  Distribution based on fractional intere st.  Each beneficiary described in section 35 
7-421, subsection 4 is entitled to receive a portion of the net income equal to the 36 
beneficiary's fractional interest in undistributed principal assets, using values as of the 37 
distribution date.  If a fiduciary ma kes more than one distribution of assets to 38 
beneficiaries to whom this section applies, each beneficiary, including one who does not 39 
receive part of the distribution, is entitled, as of each distribution date, to the net income 40 
the fiduciary has received a fter the date of death or terminating event or earlier 41 
distribution date but has not distributed as of the current distribution date.  42 
 
 Page 328 - 128LR0452(01) -1 
 2.  Determination of share.  In determining a beneficiary's share of net income, the 1 
provisions of this subsection apply:  2 
A.  The beneficiary is entitled to receive a portion of the net income equal to the 3 
beneficiary's fractional interest in the undistributed principal assets immediately 4 
before the distribution date, including assets that later may be sold to meet principal 5 
obligations;  6 
B.  The beneficiary's fractional interest in the undistributed principal assets must be 7 
calculated without regard to property specifically given to a beneficiary and property 8 
required to pay pecuniary amounts not in trust;  9 
C.  The beneficiary' s fractional interest in the undistributed principal assets must be 10 
calculated on the basis of the aggregate value of those assets as of the distribution 11 
date without reducing the value by any unpaid principal obligation; and  12 
D.  The distribution date for purposes of this section may be the date as of which the 13 
fiduciary calculates the value of the assets if that date is reasonably near the date on 14 
which assets are actually distributed.  15 
3.  Records required if not all distributed.  If a fiduciary does not d istribute all of 16 
the collected but undistributed net income to each person as of a distribution date, the 17 
fiduciary shall maintain appropriate records showing the interest of each beneficiary in 18 
that net income.  19 
4.  Application of provisions.  A fiduciary may apply the provisions of this section, 20 
to the extent that the fiduciary considers it appropriate, to net gain or loss realized after 21 
the date of death or terminating event or earlier distribution date from the disposition of a 22 
principal asset if this se ction applies to the income from the asset.  23 
SUBPART 3  24 
APPORTIONMENT AT BEG INNING AND END OF IN COME INTEREST  25 
§7-431.  When right to income begins and ends  26 
1.  Beginning of income interest.  An income beneficiary is entitled to net income 27 
from the date on wh ich the income interest begins.  An income interest begins on the date 28 
specified in the terms of the trust or, if no date is specified, on the date an asset becomes 29 
subject to a trust or successive income interest.  30 
2.  Asset subject to trust.  An asset bec omes subject to a trust:  31 
A.  On the date it is transferred to the trust in the case of an asset that is transferred to 32 
a trust during the transferor's life;  33 
B.  On the date of a testator's death in the case of an asset that becomes subject to a 34 
trust by re ason of a will, even if there is an intervening period of administration of the 35 
testator's estate; or  36 
C.  On the date of an individual's death in the case of an asset that is transferred to a 37 
fiduciary by a 3rd party because of the individual's death.  38 
 
 Page 329 - 128LR0452(01) -1 
 3.  Successive income interest.  An asset becomes subject to a successive income 1 
interest on the day after the preceding income interest ends, as determined under 2 
subsection 4, even if there is an intervening period of administration to wind up the 3 
preceding i ncome interest.  4 
4.  Ending of income interest.  An income interest ends on the day before an income 5 
beneficiary dies or another terminating event occurs or on the last day of a period during 6 
which there is no beneficiary to whom a trustee may distribute in come.  7 
§7-432.  Apportionment of receipts and disbursements when decedent dies or 8 
income interest begins  9 
1.  Application to principal.  A trustee shall allocate an income receipt or 10 
disbursement other than one to which section 7 -421, subsection 1 applies to  principal if 11 
its due date occurs before a decedent dies in the case of an estate or before an income 12 
interest begins in the case of a trust or successive income interest.  13 
2.  Application to income.  A trustee shall allocate an income receipt or 14 
disburseme nt to income if its due date occurs on or after the date on which a decedent 15 
dies or an income interest begins and it is a periodic due date.  An income receipt or 16 
disbursement must be treated as accruing from day to day if its due date is not periodic or 17 
it has no due date.  The portion of the receipt or disbursement accruing before the date on 18 
which a decedent dies or an income interest begins must be allocated to principal and the 19 
balance must be allocated to income.  20 
3.  Due date.  An item of income or a n obligation is due on the date the payor is 21 
required to make a payment.  If a payment date is not stated, there is no due date for the 22 
purposes of this Part.  Distributions to shareholders or other owners from an entity to 23 
which section 7 -441 applies are deemed to be due on the date fixed by the entity for 24 
determining who is entitled to receive the distribution or, if no date is fixed, on the 25 
declaration date for the distribution.  A due date is periodic for receipts or disbursements 26 
that must be paid at r egular intervals under a lease or an obligation to pay interest or if an 27 
entity customarily makes distributions at regular intervals.  28 
§7-433.  Apportionment when income interest ends  29 
1.  Undistributed income.  As used in this section, "undistributed income " means net 30 
income received before the date on which an income interest ends.  "Undistributed 31 
income" does not include an item of income or expense that is due or accrued or net 32 
income that has been added or is required to be added to principal under the t erms of the 33 
trust.  34 
2.  End of mandatory income interest.  When a mandatory income interest ends, the 35 
trustee shall pay to a mandatory income beneficiary who survives that date, or the estate 36 
of a deceased mandatory income beneficiary whose death causes the  interest to end, the 37 
beneficiary's share of the undistributed income that is not disposed of under the terms of 38 
the trust unless the beneficiary has an unqualified power to revoke more than 5% of the 39 
trust immediately before the income interest ends.  In the latter case, the undistributed 40 
income from the portion of the trust that may be revoked must be added to principal.  41 
 
 Page 330 - 128LR0452(01) -1 
 3.  Prorate final payment.  When a trustee's obligation to pay a fixed annuity or a 1 
fixed fraction of the value of the trust's assets en ds, the trustee shall prorate the final 2 
payment to the extent required by applicable law to accomplish a purpose of the trust or 3 
its settlor relating to income, gift, estate or other tax requirements.  4 
SUBPART 4  5 
ALLOCATION OF RECEIP TS DURING ADMINISTRA TION OF TRUST  6 
§7-441.  Character of receipts  7 
1.  Entity.  As used in this section, "entity" means a corporation, partnership, limited 8 
liability company, regulated investment company, real estate investment trust, common 9 
trust fund or any other organization in w hich a trustee has an interest other than a trust or 10 
estate to which section 7 -442 applies, a business or activity to which section 7 -443 11 
applies or an asset -backed security to which section 7 -455 applies.  12 
2.  Allocation to income; received from entity.  Except as otherwise provided in 13 
this section, a trustee shall allocate to income money received from an entity.  14 
3.  Allocation to principal; received from entity.  A trustee shall allocate the 15 
following receipts from an entity to principal:  16 
A.  Property oth er than money;  17 
B.  Money received in one distribution or a series of related distributions in exchange 18 
for part or all of a trust's interest in the entity;  19 
C.  Money received in total or partial liquidation of the entity; and  20 
D.  Money received from an ent ity that is a regulated investment company or a real 21 
estate investment trust if the money distributed is a capital gain dividend for federal 22 
income tax purposes.  23 
4.  Money received in partial liquidation.  Money is received in partial liquidation:  24 
A.  To the extent that the entity, at or near the time of a distribution, indicates that it 25 
is a distribution in partial liquidation; or  26 
B.  If the total amount of money and property received in a distribution or series of 27 
related distributions is greater than 20%  of the entity's gross assets, as shown by the 28 
entity's year -end financial statements immediately preceding the initial receipt.  29 
5.  Money not received in partial liquidation.  Money is not received in partial 30 
liquidation, nor may it be taken into account under subsection 4, paragraph B, to the 31 
extent that it does not exceed the amount of income tax that a trustee or beneficiary must 32 
pay on taxable income of the entity that distributes the money.  33 
6.  Statement about source or character of distribution.  A trustee may rely upon a 34 
statement made by an entity about the source or character of a distribution if the 35 
statement is made at or near the time of distribution by the entity's board of directors or 36 
other person or group of persons authorized to exercise po wers to pay money or transfer 37 
property comparable to those of a corporation's board of directors.  38 
 
 Page 331 - 128LR0452(01) -1 
 §7-442.  Distribution from trust or estate  1 
A trustee shall allocate to income an amount received as a distribution of income 2 
from a trust or an estate in whic h the trust has an interest other than a purchased interest, 3 
and shall allocate to principal an amount received as a distribution of principal from such 4 
a trust or estate.  If a trustee purchases an interest in a trust that is an investment entity, or 5 
a decedent or donor transfers an interest in such a trust to a trustee, section 7 -441 or 7 -455 6 
applies to a receipt from the trust.  7 
§7-443.  Business and other activities conducted by trustee  8 
1.  Separate accounting for business or other activity.  If a truste e who conducts a 9 
business or other activity determines that it is in the best interest of all the beneficiaries to 10
