account separately for the business or activity instead of accounting for it as part of the 11 
trust's general accounting records, the trustee m ay maintain separate accounting records 12 
for its transactions, whether or not its assets are segregated from other trust assets.  13 
2.  Net receipts used for business or other activity.  A trustee who accounts 14 
separately for a business or other activity may de termine the extent to which its net cash 15 
receipts must be retained for working capital, the acquisition or replacement of fixed 16 
assets and other reasonably foreseeable needs of the business or activity, and the extent to 17 
which the remaining net cash receip ts are accounted for as principal or income in the 18 
trust's general accounting records.  If a trustee sells assets of the business or other 19 
activity, other than in the ordinary course of the business or activity, the trustee shall 20 
account for the net amount  received as principal in the trust's general accounting records 21 
to the extent the trustee determines that the amount received is no longer required in the 22 
conduct of the business.  23 
3.  Separate accounting records activities.  Activities for which a trustee  may 24 
maintain separate accounting records include:  25 
A.  Retail, manufacturing, service and other traditional business activities;  26 
B.  Farming;  27 
C.  Raising and selling livestock and other animals;  28 
D.  Management of rental properties;  29 
E.  Extraction of minera ls and other natural resources;  30 
F.  Timber operations; and  31 
G.  Activities to which section 7 -454 applies.  32 
§7-444.  Principal receipts  33 
A trustee shall allocate to principal:  34 
1.  Assets received.  To the extent not allocated to income under this Part, assets  35 
received from a transferor during the transferor's lifetime, a decedent's estate, a trust with 36 
a terminating income interest or a payor under a contract naming the trust or its trustee as 37 
beneficiary;  38 
 
 Page 332 - 128LR0452(01) -1 
 2.  Received from sale, exchange, liquidation or chang e in form of asset.  Money 1 
or other property received from the sale, exchange, liquidation or change in form of a 2 
principal asset, including realized profit, subject to this subpart;  3 
3.  Reimbursements because of disbursements.  Amounts recovered from 3rd 4 
parties to reimburse the trust because of disbursements described in section 7 -462, 5 
subsection 1, paragraph G or for other reasons to the extent not based on the loss of 6 
income;  7 
4.  Proceeds of property taken by eminent domain.  Proceeds of property taken by 8 
eminent domain, but a separate award made for the loss of income with respect to an 9 
accounting period during which a current income beneficiary had a mandatory income 10 
interest is income;  11 
5.  Net income without beneficiary.  Net income received in an acc ounting period 12 
during which there is no beneficiary to whom a trustee may or must distribute income; 13 
and 14 
6.  Other receipts.  Other receipts as provided in sections 7 -448 to 7 -455. 15 
§7-445.  Rental property  16 
To the extent that a trustee accounts for receipts  from rental property pursuant to this 17 
section, the trustee shall allocate to income an amount received as rent of real or personal 18 
property, including an amount received for cancellation or renewal of a lease.  An amount 19 
received as a refundable deposit, including a security deposit or a deposit that is to be 20 
applied as rent for future periods, must be added to principal and held subject to the terms 21 
of the lease and is not available for distribution to a beneficiary until the trustee's 22 
contractual obligat ions have been satisfied with respect to that amount.  23 
§7-446.  Obligation to pay money  24 
1.  Interest on obligation to pay money; allocate to income.  An amount received 25 
as interest, whether determined at a fixed, variable or floating rate, on an obligation to 26 
pay money to the trustee, including an amount received as consideration for prepaying 27 
principal, must be allocated to income without any provision for amortization of 28 
premium.  29 
2.  Amount received from sale, redemption or other disposition of obligation to 30 
pay money; allocate to principal.  A trustee shall allocate to principal an amount 31 
received from the sale, redemption or other disposition of an obligation to pay money to 32 
the trustee more than one year after it is purchased or acquired by the trustee, including 33 
an obligation whose purchase price or value when it is acquired is less than its value at 34 
maturity.  If the obligation matures within one year after it is purchased or acquired by 35 
the trustee, an amount received in excess of its purchase price or  its value when acquired 36 
by the trust must be allocated to income.  37 
3.  Not applicable.  This section does not apply to an obligation to which section 38 
7-449, 7 -450, 7 -451, 7 -452, 7 -454 or 7 -455 applies.  39 
 
 Page 333 - 128LR0452(01) -1 
 §7-447.  Insurance policies and similar contracts  1 
1.  Trust, trustee as beneficiary; allocate to principal.  Except as otherwise 2 
provided in subsection 2, a trustee shall allocate to principal the proceeds of a life 3 
insurance policy or other contract in which the trust or its trustee is named as beneficiary, 4 
including a contract that insures the trust or its trustee against loss for damage to, 5 
destruction of or loss of title to a trust asset.  The trustee shall allocate dividends on an 6 
insurance policy to income if the premiums on the policy are paid from inco me, and to 7 
principal if the premiums are paid from principal.  8 
2.  Loss of occupancy, use, income, business profits; allocate to income.  A trustee 9 
shall allocate to income proceeds of a contract that insures the trustee against loss of 10 
occupancy or other u se by an income beneficiary, loss of income or, subject to section 11 
7-443, loss of profits from a business.  12 
3.  Not applicable.  This section does not apply to a contract to which section 7 -449 13 
applies.  14 
§7-448.  Insubstantial allocations not required  15 
If a t rustee determines that an allocation between principal and income required by 16 
section 7 -449, 7 -450, 7 -451, 7 -452 or 7 -455 is insubstantial, the trustee may allocate the 17 
entire amount to principal unless one of the circumstances described in section 7 -404, 18 
subsection 3 applies to the allocation.  This power may be exercised by a cotrustee in the 19 
circumstances described in section 7 -404, subsection 4 and may be released for the 20 
reasons and in the manner described in section 7 -404, subsection 5.  An allocation  is 21 
presumed to be insubstantial if:  22 
1.  Increase or decrease of less than 10%.  The amount of the allocation would 23 
increase or decrease net income in an accounting period, as determined before the 24 
allocation, by less than 10%; or  25 
2.  Value of asset less t han 10%.   The value of the asset producing the receipt for 26 
which the allocation would be made is less than 10% of the total value of the trust's assets 27 
at the beginning of the accounting period.  28 
§7-449.  Deferred compensation, annuities and similar payment s 29 
1.  Definitions.  As used in this section, unless the context otherwise indicates, the 30 
following terms have the following meanings.  31 
A.  "Payment" means a payment that a trustee may receive over a fixed number of 32 
years or during the life of one or more in dividuals because of services rendered or 33 
property transferred to the payor in exchange for future payments.  "Payment" 34 
includes a payment made in money or property from the payor's general assets or 35 
from a separate fund created by the payor.  For the purp oses of subsections 4, 5, 6 36 
and 7, "payment" also includes any payment from any separate fund, regardless of the 37 
reason for the payment.  38 
 
 Page 334 - 128LR0452(01) -1 
 B.  "Separate fund" includes a private or commercial annuity, an individual 1 
retirement account and a pension, profit -sharing, stock -bonus or stock -ownership 2 
plan.  3 
2.  Payment is interest or dividend; allocate to income.  To the extent that a 4 
payment is characterized as interest, a dividend or a payment made in lieu of interest or a 5 
dividend, a trustee shall allocate the pa yment to income.  The trustee shall allocate to 6 
principal the balance of the payment and any other payment received in the same 7 
accounting period that is not characterized as interest, a dividend or an equivalent 8 
payment.  9 
3.  Payment not interest or divide nd; allocation based on if required.  If no part 10 
of a payment is characterized as interest, a dividend or an equivalent payment, and all or 11 
part of the payment is required to be made, a trustee shall allocate to income 10% of the 12 
part that is required to b e made during the accounting period and the balance to principal.  13 
If no part of a payment is required to be made or the payment received is the entire 14 
amount to which the trustee is entitled, the trustee shall allocate the entire payment to 15 
principal.  Fo r purposes of this subsection, a payment is not required to be made to the 16 
extent that it is made because the trustee exercises a right of withdrawal.  17 
4.  Payment qualifies for marital deduction.  Except as otherwise provided in 18 
subsection 5, subsections 6  and 7 apply and subsections 2 and 3 do not apply in 19 
determining the allocation of a payment made from a separate fund to a trust:  20 
A.  That qualifies for the marital deduction under the federal Internal Revenue Code, 21 
26 United States Code, Section 2056(b)( 7) (2010), as amended, and for which either 22 
such an election has been made for federal purposes or for which an election under 23 
the pertinent provisions of the laws of the State to qualify as Maine qualified 24 
terminable interest property has been made; or  25 
B.  That qualifies for the marital deduction under the federal Internal Revenue Code, 26 
26 United States Code, Section 2056(b)(5) (2010), as amended.  27 
5.  Series of payments qualify for marital deduction.  Subsections 4, 6 and 7 do not 28 
apply if and to the exten t that the series of payments would, without the application of 29 
subsection 4, qualify for the marital deduction under the federal Internal Revenue Code, 30 
26 United States Code, Section 2056(b)(7)(C) (2010), as amended.  31 
6.  Internal income of separate fund.  A trustee shall determine the internal income 32 
of each separate fund for the accounting period as if the separate fund were a trust subject 33 
to this Part.  Upon request of the surviving spouse, the trustee shall demand that the 34 
person administering the sepa rate fund distribute the internal income to the trust.  The 35 
trustee shall allocate a payment from the separate fund to income to the extent of the 36 
internal income of the separate fund and distribute that amount to the surviving spouse.  37 
The trustee shall a llocate the balance of the payment to principal.  Upon request of the 38 
surviving spouse, the trustee shall allocate principal to income to the extent the internal 39 
income of the separate fund exceeds payments made from the separate fund to the trust 40 
during t he accounting period.  41 
 
 Page 335 - 128LR0452(01) -1 
 7.  Value of separate fund.  If a trustee cannot determine the internal income of a 1 
separate fund but can determine the value of the separate fund, the internal income of the 2 
separate fund is deemed to equal 4% of the fund's value, ac cording to the most recent 3 
statement of value preceding the beginning of the accounting period.  If the trustee can 4 
determine neither the internal income of the separate fund nor the fund's value, the 5 
internal income of the fund is deemed to equal the prod uct of the interest rate and the 6 
present value of the expected future payments, as determined under the federal Internal 7 
Revenue Code, 26 United States Code, Section 7520 (2010), as amended, for the month 8 
preceding the accounting period for which the compu tation is made.  9 
8.  Not applicable.  This section does not apply to a payment to which section 7 -450 10 
applies.  11 
§7-450.  Liquidating asset  12 
1.  Liquidating asset.  As used in this section, "liquidating asset" means an asset 13 
whose value will diminish or termin ate because the asset is expected to produce receipts 14 
for a period of limited duration.  "Liquidating asset" includes a leasehold, patent, 15 
copyright, royalty right and right to receive payments during a period of more than one 16 
year under an arrangement tha t does not provide for the payment of interest on the unpaid 17 
balance.  "Liquidating asset" does not include a payment subject to section 7 -449, 18 
resources subject to section 7 -451, timber subject to section 7 -452, an activity subject to 19 
section 7 -454, an as set subject to section 7 -455 or any asset for which the trustee 20 
establishes a reserve for depreciation under section 7 -463. 21 
2.  Allocation.  A trustee shall allocate to income 10% of the receipts from a 22 
liquidating asset and the balance to principal.  23 
§7-451.  Minerals, water and other natural resources  24 
1.  Allocation of receipts.  To the extent that a trustee accounts for receipts from an 25 
interest in minerals or other natural resources pursuant to this section, the trustee shall 26 
allocate them as follows:  27 
A.  If received as nominal delay rental or nominal annual rent on a lease, a receipt 28 
must be allocated to income;  29 
B.  If received from a production payment, a receipt must be allocated to income if 30 
and to the extent that the agreement creating the production  payment provides a 31 
factor for interest or its equivalent.  The balance must be allocated to principal;  32 
C.  If an amount received as a royalty, shut -in-well payment, take -or-pay payment, 33 
bonus or delay rental is more than nominal, 90% must be allocated to principal and 34 
the balance to income; and  35 
D.  If an amount is received from a working interest or any other interest not provided 36 
for in paragraph A, B or C, 90% of the net amount received must be allocated to 37 
principal and the balance to income.  38 
 
 Page 336 - 128LR0452(01) -1 
 2.  Alloca tion from interest in water.  An amount received on account of an interest 1 
in water that is renewable must be allocated to income.  If the water is not renewable, 2 
90% of the amount must be allocated to principal and the balance to income.  3 
3.  Timing of ext ractions.  This Part applies whether or not a decedent or donor was 4 
extracting minerals, water or other natural resources before the interest became subject to 5 
the trust.  6 
4.  Pre-2002 ownership.  If a trust owns an interest in minerals, water or other 7 
natural resources on January 1, 2002, the trustee may allocate receipts from the interest as 8 
provided in this Part or in the manner used by the trustee before January 1, 2002.  If the 9 
trust acquires an interest in minerals, water or other natural resources aft er January 1, 10 
2002, the trustee shall allocate receipts from the interest as provided in this Part.  11 
§7-452.  Timber  12 
1.  Allocation of net receipts.  To the extent that a trustee accounts for receipts from 13 
the sale of timber and related products pursuant to  this section, the trustee shall allocate 14 
the net receipts:  15 
A.  To income to the extent the net receipts do not exceed the product of mean annual 16 
growth multiplied by the number of years since the last timber sale, or, if more 17 
recent, the date the timber b ecame a part of the trust, multiplied by the stumpage rates 18 
obtained, after netting against the stumpage rates obtained the expenses associated 19 
with the conduct of the sale;  20 
B.  To principal to the extent that the proceeds received exceed the amount 21 
determ ined in paragraph A;  22 
C.  To or between income and principal if the net receipts are from the lease of 23 
timberland or from a contract to cut timber from land owned by a trust, by 24 
determining the amount of timber removed from the land under the lease or contr act 25 
and applying the provisions of paragraphs A and B; or  26 
D.  To principal to the extent that advance payments, bonuses and other payments are 27 
not allocated pursuant to paragraph A, B or C.  28 
2.  Deduction for depletion.  In determining net receipts to be al located pursuant to 29 
subsection 1, a trustee may deduct and transfer to principal a reasonable amount for 30 
depletion.  31 
3.  Timing of timber harvests.  This section applies whether or not a decedent or 32 
transferor was harvesting timber from the property before it became subject to the trust.  33 
4.  Pre-2003 ownership.  If a trust owns an interest in timberland on January 1, 2003, 34 
the trustee may allocate net receipts from the sale of timber and related products as 35 
provided in this section or in the manner used by t he trustee before January 1, 2003.  If 36 
the trust acquires an interest in timberland after January 1, 2003, the trustee shall allocate 37 
net receipts from the sale of timber and related products as provided in this section.  38 
 
 Page 337 - 128LR0452(01) -1 
 5.  Mean annual growth.  For purpos es of this section, "mean annual growth" 1 
means, at the trustee's option, either:  2 
A.  The mean annual increment of growth of the timber involved as determined by a 3 
licensed professional forester; or  4 
B.  Forty -five hundredths of a cord per acre of woodland.  5 
§7-453.  Property not productive of income  6 
1.  Income to obtain marital deduction.  If a marital deduction is allowed for all or 7 
part of a trust whose assets consist substantially of property that does not provide the 8 
spouse with sufficient income from or use of the trust assets, and if the amounts that the 9 
trustee transfers from principal to income under section 7 -404 and distributes to the 10 
spouse from principal pursuant to the terms of the trust are insufficient to provide the 11 
spouse with the beneficial e njoyment required to obtain the marital deduction, the spouse 12 
may require the trustee to make property productive of income, convert property within a 13 
reasonable time or exercise the power conferred by section 7 -404, subsection 1.  The 14 
trustee may decide w hich action or combination of actions to take.  15 
2.  Proceeds otherwise are principal.  In cases not governed by subsection 1, 16 
proceeds from the sale or other disposition of an asset are principal without regard to the 17 
amount of income the asset produces dur ing any accounting period.  18 
§7-454.  Derivatives and options  19 
1.  Derivative.  As used in this section, "derivative" means a contract or financial 20 
instrument or a combination of contracts and financial instruments that gives a trust the 21 
right or obligation t o participate in some or all changes in the price of a tangible or 22 
intangible asset or group of assets, or changes in a rate, an index of prices or rates or other 23 
market indicator for an asset or a group of assets.  24 
2.  Allocation to principal.  To the exte nt that a trustee does not account under 25 
section 7 -443 for transactions in derivatives, the trustee shall allocate to principal receipts 26 
from and disbursements made in connection with those transactions.  27 
3.  Options to buy or sell property; paid from or al located to principal.  If a 28 
trustee grants an option to buy property from the trust, whether or not the trust owns the 29 
property when the option is granted, grants an option that permits another person to sell 30 
property to the trust or acquires an option to buy property for the trust or an option to sell 31 
an asset owned by the trust, and the trustee or other owner of the asset is required to 32 
deliver the asset if the option is exercised, an amount received for granting the option 33 
must be allocated to principal.   An amount paid to acquire the option must be paid from 34 
principal.  A gain or loss realized upon the exercise of an option, including an option 35 
granted to a settlor of the trust for services rendered, must be allocated to principal.  36 
§7-455.  Asset -backed securities  37 
1.  Asset -backed security.  As used in this section, "asset -backed security" means an 38 
asset whose value is based upon the right it gives the owner to receive distributions from 39 
 
 Page 338 - 128LR0452(01) -1 
 the proceeds of financial assets that provide collateral for the sec urity.  "Asset -backed 1 
security" includes an asset that gives the owner the right to receive from the collateral 2 
financial assets only the interest or other current return or only the proceeds other than 3 
interest or current return.  The term does not includ e an asset to which section 7 -441 or 4 
7-449 applies.  5 
2.  Payment from interest or current return; allocate to income.  If a trust 6 
receives a payment from interest or other current return and from other proceeds of the 7 
collateral financial assets, the truste e shall allocate to income the portion of the payment 8 
that the payor identifies as being from interest or other current return and shall allocate 9 
the balance of the payment to principal.  10 
3.  Payments for trust's interest; allocate to income and principal.  If a trust 11 
receives one or more payments in exchange for the trust's entire interest in an asset - 12 
backed security in one accounting period, the trustee shall allocate the payments to 13 
principal.  If a payment is one of a series of payments that will result in the liquidation of 14 
the trust's interest in the security over more than one accounting period, the trustee shall 15 
allocate 10% of the payment to income and the balance to principal.  16 
SUBPART 5  17 
ALLOCATION OF DISBUR SEMENTS DURING ADMIN ISTRATION OF 18 
TRUST  19 
§7-461.  Disbursements from income  20 
A trustee shall make the following disbursements from income to the extent that they 21 
are not disbursements to which section 7 -421, subsection 2, paragraph B or C applies:  22 
1.  Compensation.  One-half of the regular compensatio n of the trustee and of any 23 
person providing investment advisory or custodial services to the trustee;  24 
2.  Expenses; income and remainder interests.  One-half of all expenses for 25 
accountings, judicial proceedings or other matters that involve both the inco me and 26 
remainder interests;  27 
3.  Other ordinary expenses.  All of the ordinary expenses other than those specified 28 
in subsections 1 and 2 incurred in connection with the administration, management or 29 
preservation of trust property and the distribution of in come, including interest, ordinary 30 
repairs, regularly recurring taxes assessed against principal and expenses of a proceeding 31 
or other matter that concerns primarily the income interest; and  32 
4.  Recurring premiums.  Recurring premiums on insurance covering  the loss of a 33 
principal asset or the loss of income from or use of the asset.  34 
§7-462.  Disbursements from principal  35 
1.  Required disbursements.  A trustee shall make the following disbursements from 36 
principal:  37 
 
 Page 339 - 128LR0452(01) -1 
 A.  The remaining 1/2 of the disbursements de scribed in section 7 -461, subsections 1 1 
and 2;  2 
B.  All of the trustee's compensation calculated on principal as a fee for acceptance, 3 
distribution or termination and disbursements made to prepare property for sale;  4 
C.  Payments on the principal of a trust debt;  5 
D.  Expenses of a proceeding that concerns primarily principal, including a 6 
proceeding to construe the trust or to protect the trust or its property;  7 
E.  Premiums paid on a policy of insurance not described in section 7 -461, subsection 8 
4 of which the  trust is the owner and beneficiary;  9 
F.  Estate, inheritance and other transfer taxes, including penalties, apportioned to the 10 
trust; and  11 
G.  Disbursements related to environmental matters, including reclamation, assessing 12 
environmental conditions, remedyi ng and removing environmental contamination, 13 
monitoring remedial activities and the release of substances, preventing future 14 
releases of substances, collecting amounts from persons liable or potentially liable for 15 
the costs of those activities, penalties i mposed under environmental laws or 16 
regulations and other payments made to comply with those laws or regulations, 17 
statutory or common law claims by 3rd parties and defending claims based on 18 
environmental matters.  19 
2.  Encumbered principal asset; transfer to income.  If a principal asset is 20 
encumbered with an obligation that requires income from that asset to be paid directly to 21 
the creditor, the trustee shall transfer from principal to income an amount equal to the 22 
income paid to the creditor in reduction of the principal balance of the obligation.  23 
§7-463.  Transfers from income to principal for depreciation  24 
1.  Depreciation.  As used in this section, "depreciation" means a reduction in value 25 
due to wear, tear, decay, corrosion or gradual obsolescence of a fix ed asset having a 26 
useful life of more than one year.  27 
2.  Reasonable amount of net cash receipts.  A trustee may transfer to principal a 28 
reasonable amount of the net cash receipts from a principal asset that is subject to 29 
depreciation, but may not transfer for depreciation any amount:  30 
A.  Of that portion of real property used or available for use by a beneficiary as a 31 
residence or of tangible personal property held or made available for the personal use 32 
or enjoyment of a beneficiary;  33 
B.  During the administr ation of a decedent's estate; or  34 
C.  Under this section if the trustee is accounting under section 7 -443 for the business 35 
or activity in which the asset is used.  36 
3.  Separate fund not required.  An amount transferred to principal pursuant to 37 
subsection 2 n eed not be held as a separate fund.  38 
 
 Page 340 - 128LR0452(01) -1 
 §7-464.  Transfers from income to reimburse principal  1 
1.  Transfer to reimburse or provide reserve.  If a trustee makes or expects to 2 
make a principal disbursement described in this section, the trustee may transfer an 3 
appropriate amount from income to principal in one or more accounting periods to 4 
reimburse principal or to provide a reserve for future principal disbursements.  5 
2.  Applicable principal disbursement.  Principal disbursements to which 6 
subsection 1 applies in clude the following, but only to the extent that the trustee has not 7 
been and does not expect to be reimbursed by a 3rd party:  8 
A.  An amount chargeable to income but paid from principal because it is unusually 9 
large, including extraordinary repairs;  10 
B.  A capital improvement to a principal asset, whether in the form of changes to an 11 
existing asset or the construction of a new asset, including special assessments;  12 
C.  Disbursements made to prepare property for rental, including tenant allowances, 13 
leasehold i mprovements and broker's commissions;  14 
D.  Periodic payments on an obligation secured by a principal asset to the extent that 15 
the amount transferred from income to principal for depreciation is less than the 16 
periodic payments; and  17 
E.  Disbursements describe d in section 7 -462, subsection 1, paragraph G.  18 
3.  Successive income interest.  If the asset whose ownership gives rise to the 19 
disbursements becomes subject to a successive income interest after an income interest 20 
ends, a trustee may continue to transfer a mounts from income to principal as provided in 21 
subsection 1.  22 
§7-465.  Income taxes  23 
1.  Tax based on receipts allocated to income.  A tax required to be paid by a 24 
trustee based on receipts allocated to income must be paid from income.  25 
2.  Tax based on recei pts allocated to principal.  A tax required to be paid by a 26 
trustee based on receipts allocated to principal must be paid from principal, even if the tax 27 
is called an income tax by the taxing authority.  28 
3.  Tax on trust's share of entity's taxable income.  A tax required to be paid by a 29 
trustee on the trust's share of an entity's taxable income must be paid:  30 
A.  From income to the extent that receipts from the entity are allocated only to 31 
income;  32 
B.  From principal to the extent that receipts from the entit y are allocated only to 33 
principal;  34 
C.  Proportionately from principal and income to the extent that receipts from the 35 
entity are allocated to both income and principal; and  36 
D.  From principal to the extent that the tax exceeds the total receipts from the e ntity.  37 
 
 Page 341 - 128LR0452(01) -1 
 4.  Adjustments because of deduction for payments to beneficiary.  After 1 
applying subsections 1 to 3, the trustee shall adjust income or principal receipts to the 2 
extent that the trust's taxes are reduced because the trust receives a deduction for 3 
payments made to a beneficiary.  4 
§7-466.  Adjustments between principal and income because of taxes  5 
1.  Adjustments to offset shifting of interests or benefits.  A fiduciary may make 6 
adjustments between principal and income to offset the shifting of economic  interests or 7 
tax benefits between income beneficiaries and remainder beneficiaries that arise from:  8 
A.  Elections and decisions, other than those described in subsection 2, that the 9 
fiduciary makes from time to time regarding tax matters;  10 
B.  An income ta x or any other tax that is imposed upon the fiduciary or a beneficiary 11 
as a result of a transaction involving or a distribution from the estate or trust; or  12 
C.  The ownership by an estate or trust of an interest in an entity whose taxable 13 
income, whether o r not distributed, is includable in the taxable income of the estate, 14 
trust or a beneficiary.  15 
2.  Increase in estate tax, reduction in income taxes.  If the amount of an estate tax 16 
marital deduction or charitable contribution deduction is reduced because a  fiduciary 17 
deducts an amount paid from principal for income tax purposes instead of deducting it for 18 
estate tax purposes, and as a result estate taxes paid from principal are increased and 19 
income taxes paid by an estate, trust or beneficiary are decreased,  each estate, trust or 20 
beneficiary that benefits from the decrease in income tax shall reimburse the principal 21 
from which the increase in estate tax is paid.  The total reimbursement must equal the 22 
increase in the estate tax to the extent that the principa l used to pay the increase would 23 
have qualified for a marital deduction or charitable contribution deduction but for the 24 
payment.  The proportionate share of the reimbursement for each estate, trust or 25 
beneficiary whose income taxes are reduced must be the  same as its proportionate share 26 
of the total decrease in income tax.  An estate or trust shall reimburse principal from 27 
income.  28

MISCELLANEOUS PROVIS IONS  30 
§7-471.  Uniformity of application and construction  31 
In applying and construing this Part, co nsideration must be given to the need to 32 
promote uniformity of the law with respect to its subject matter among states that enact it.  33 
§7-472.  Application of Part to all trusts and estates  34 
This Part applies to every trust or decedent's estate, including th ose in existence on 35 
January 1, 2003, beginning with the first fiscal year of the trust or decedent's estate that 36 
begins on or after January 1, 2003, except as otherwise expressly provided in the will or 37 
terms of the trust or in this Part.  38 
 
 Page 342 - 128LR0452(01) -1 
 §7-473.  Transiti onal matters  1 
Section 7 -449 applies to a trust described in section 7 -449, subsection 4 on and after 2 
the following dates:  3 
1.  Trust not funded as of January 1, 2012.  If the trust is not funded as of January 4 
1, 2012, the date of the decedent's death;  5 
2.  Trust initially funded in 2012.  If the trust is initially funded in the calendar year 6 
beginning January 1, 2012, the date of the decedent's death; or  7 
3.  All other trusts.  If the trust is not described in subsection 1 or 2, January 1, 2012.  8 
ARTICLE 8  9 
MISCE LLANEOUS PROVISIONS  10 
PART 1  11 
RECEIVERSHIPS FOR MI SSING AND ABSENT PER SONS  12 
§8-101.  Estates of absentees; petition  13 
If a person entitled to or having an interest in property within the jurisdiction of the 14 
State has disappeared or absconded from the place withi n or outside the State where the 15 
person was last known to be, has no agent in the State and it is not known where the 16 
person is, or if a person, having a spouse or minor child dependent to any extent upon the 17 
person for support, has disappeared or absconde d without making sufficient provision for 18 
support and it is not known where the person is, or, if it is known that the person is 19 
outside the State, anyone who would under the law of the State be entitled to administer 20 
the estate of the absentee if the abse ntee were deceased may file a petition under oath in 21 
the court for the county where the property is situated.  The petition must state the name, 22 
age, occupation and last known residence or address of the absentee, the date and 23 
circumstances of the disappea rance and the names and residences of other persons, 24 
whether members of the absentee's family or otherwise, of whom inquiry may be made.  25 
The petition must also contain a schedule of the absentee's known property, real and 26 
personal, and its location within  the State and request that such property be taken 27 
possession of and a receiver appointed under this Part.  28 
§8-102.  Warrant  29 
Upon receipt of a petition under section 8 -101, the court may issue a warrant, which 30 
may run throughout the State, directed to the p ublic administrator in the county where the 31 
property or some of it is situated, commanding the public administrator to take possession 32 
of the property listed in the schedule and expeditiously make return of the warrant with a 33 
schedule of the property taken .  The public administrator shall cause any portion of the 34 
warrant relating to land to be recorded in the registry of deeds for the county where the 35 
land is located.  The public administrator is entitled to the fees allowed by the court for 36 
serving the war rant, but may not receive more than those established by law for similar 37 
 
 Page 343 - 128LR0452(01) -1 
 service upon a writ of attachment.  The fees and the costs of publishing and serving the 1 
notice must be paid by the petitioner.  If a receiver is appointed under section 8 -105, the 2 
fees must be repaid by the receiver to the petitioner and the receiver may be compensated 3 
for these fees under section 8 -112. 4 
§8-103.  Notice  5 
Upon the return of a warrant issued under section 8 -102, the court shall issue a notice 6 
reciting the substance of th e petition, warrant and return, which must be addressed to the 7 
absentee, to all persons who claim an interest in the absentee's property and to all whom it 8 
may concern, ordering them to appear at a time and place named and show cause why a 9 
receiver of the property should not be appointed to hold and dispose of the property listed 10 
in the schedule under this Part.  11 
§8-104.  Publication  12 
The return day may not be less than 30 days nor more than 60 days after the date of 13 
the notice.  The court shall order the not ice to be published once in each of 3 successive 14 
weeks in one or more newspapers within the county in which the petition was filed under 15 
section 8 -101 and a copy of the notice to be mailed to the last known address of the 16 
absentee.  The court may order add itional and alternative notice to be given within or 17 
outside the State.  18 
§8-105.  Hearing; appointment of receiver of property; bond  19 
The absentee or a person who claims an interest in any of the property may appear 20 
and show cause why the petition should not  be granted.  The court may, after hearing, 21 
dismiss the petition and order that the property in possession of the public administrator 22 
be returned to the person entitled to the property or it may appoint as receiver a person 23 
who, under the law of the State , is entitled to administer the estate of the absentee if the 24 
absentee were deceased or, if no eligible person is known or if all eligible persons decline 25 
to serve, the court may appoint the public administrator as receiver of the property in the 26 
possessio n of the public administrator and named in the schedule.  If a receiver is 27 
appointed, the court shall find and record the date of the absentee's disappearance or 28 
absconding and the receiver shall give bond to the State of Maine in a sum and under the 29 
condi tions ordered by the court.  30 
§8-106.  Possession by receiver  31 
After approval of a bond under section 8 -105, the court may order the public 32 
administrator to transfer and deliver to the receiver possession of the property under the 33 
warrant.  The receiver shall  file a schedule of the property received in the registry of 34 
probate.  35 
§8-107.  Collection of debts  36 
In addition to property transferred to the receiver under section 8 -106, the receiver 37 
shall take possession of any other property within the State that belon gs to the absentee 38 
and demand and collect all debts due the absentee from any person in the State and hold 39 
the same as if it had been transferred and delivered to the receiver by the public 40 
 
 Page 344 - 128LR0452(01) -1 
 administrator.  If the receiver takes any additional real estate, the receiver shall file a 1 
certificate describing the real estate with the register of deeds for the county where the 2 
real estate is located.  3 
§8-108.  Appointment of receiver for absentee's debts  4 
If an absentee has left no corporeal property within the Stat e, but there are debts or 5 
obligations due or owing the absentee from persons in the State, a petition may be filed as 6 
provided in section 8 -101, stating the nature and amount of the absentee's known debts 7 
and obligations and praying that a receiver may be appointed.  Upon receipt of the 8 
petition, the court may issue a notice as provided in section 8 -103 without issuing a 9 
warrant and may, upon the return of the notice and after a hearing, dismiss the petition or 10 
appoint a receiver and authorize and direct th e receiver to demand and collect the 11 
absentee's debts and obligations.  The receiver shall give bond as provided in section 12 
8-105 and shall hold the proceeds of the absentee's debts and obligations and all property 13 
received by the receiver and distribute t he same as provided in this Part.  14 
§8-109.  Perishable goods  15 
The court may make orders for the care, custody, leasing and investing of all property 16 
and its proceeds in the possession of the receiver.  If any of the property consists of live 17 
animals or is pe rishable or cannot be kept without great or disproportionate expense, the 18 
court may, after the return of the warrant, order the property to be sold at public or private 19 
sale.  Upon petition of the receiver, the court may order all or part of the property, 20 
including the absentee's rights in land, to be sold at public or private sale to supply money 21 
for payments authorized by this Part or for reinvestment approved by the court.  22 
§8-110.  Support of dependents  23 
The court may order the absentee's property or its proceeds acquired by mortgage, 24 
lease or sale to be applied in payment of expenses incurred or that may be incurred to 25 
support and maintain the absentee's spouse and dependent children and to discharge any 26 
debts and claims for spousal support proved against  the absentee.  27 
§8-111.  Arbitration of claims  28 
The court may authorize the receiver appointed under section 8 -108 to adjust by 29 
arbitration or compromise any demand in favor of or against the absentee's estate.  30 
§8-112.  Compensation; cessation of duties  31 
The receiver appointed under section 8 -108 may receive compensation and 32 
disbursements ordered by the court, to be paid out of the absentee's property or proceeds.  33 
If, within 8 years after the date of the disappearance or absconding found by the court 34 
under se ction 8 -105, the absentee appears or a personal representative, assignee in 35 
insolvency or trustee in bankruptcy of the absentee is appointed, the receiver shall 36 
account for, deliver and pay over the remainder of the absentee's property.  If the absentee 37 
does not appear and claim the absentee's property within 8 years, all of the absentee's 38 
right, title and interest in the property, real or personal, or the proceeds thereof, ceases, 39 
and no action may be brought by the absentee.  40 
 
 Page 345 - 128LR0452(01) -1 
 §8-113.  Termination of receiv ership  1 
If at the expiration of 8 years after the date of the disappearance or absconding found 2 
by the court under section 8 -105, the absentee's property has not been accounted for, 3 
delivered or paid over under section 8 -112, the court shall order distribut ion of the 4 
remainder to the persons to whom, and in the shares and proportions in which, the 5 
absentee's property would have been distributed if the absentee had died intestate within 6 
the State on the day 8 years after the date of the disappearance or absco nding.  The 7 
receiver shall deduct from the share of each distributee and pay to the State Tax Assessor 8 
the amount each distributee would have paid in an inheritance tax to the State if the 9 
distributee had received the property by inheritance from a decease d resident of the State.  10 
§8-114.  Limitations  11 
Notwithstanding sections 8 -112 and 8 -113, if a receiver is not appointed within 7 12 
years after the date of disappearance or absconding found by the court under section 13 
8-105, the time limited to accounting for, or fixed for distributing, the absentee's property 14 
or its proceeds, or for barring actions relative thereto, is one year after the date of the 15 
appointment of a receiver.  16 
PART 2  17 
PROCEDURES GOVERNING  BONDS  18 
§8-201.  Applicability to proceedings on other bonds  19 
Except as otherwise provided by law, and whenever the provisions of this Part are 20 
applicable, proceedings, judgment and execution on the bonds given to the State of Maine 21 
or the court by personal representatives, guardians, conservators, trustees, survivi ng 22 
partners, assignees of insolvent debtors and others must be conducted in the manner 23 
provided in this Part.  24 
§8-202.  Surety on bond may cite trust officers for accounting  25 
Whenever a surety on a bond has reason to believe that the trust officer has deplet ed 26 
or is wasting or mismanaging the estate, the surety may cite the trust officer before the 27 
court as provided in section 3 -110.  If upon hearing the court is satisfied that the estate 28 
held in trust by the trust officer has been depleted, wasted or mismana ged, the court may 29 
remove the trust officer and appoint a new trust officer.  30 
§8-203.  Agreement with sureties for joint control  31 
It is lawful for any party of whom a bond, undertaking or other obligation is required 32 
to agree with the surety or sureties for the deposit of any or all money and assets for 33 
which the party and the surety or sureties are or may be held responsible with a national 34 
bank, savings bank, safe -deposit company or trust company authorized by law to do 35 
business in this State or with anothe r depository approved by the court having jurisdiction 36 
over the trust or undertaking for which the bond is required if such deposit is otherwise 37 
proper and in a manner that prevents the withdrawal of the money or assets or any part 38 
thereof without the writ ten consent of the surety or sureties or an order of the court made 39 
 
 Page 346 - 128LR0452(01) -1 
 on such notice to the surety or sureties as the court may direct.  Such agreement does not 1 
in any manner release from or change the liability of the principal or sureties under the 2 
terms o f the bond.  3 
§8-204.  Approval of bond by judge  4 
Except as otherwise provided by sections 3 -603 to 3 -606, 4 -204, 4 -207, 5 -415, 5 -416, 5 
5-433 and 5 -434 and Title 18 -B, section 702, a bond required to be given to the State of 6 
Maine or the court or to be filed i n the probate office is insufficient until it has been 7 
examined by the court and approved by the court in writing.  8 
§8-205.  Insufficient sureties  9 
When the sureties in a bond under section 8 -204 are insufficient, the court, on 10 
petition of any person interes ted and with notice to the principal, may require a new bond 11 
with sureties approved by the court.  12 
§8-206.  Discharge of surety  13 
On application of any surety or principal of a bond under this Part, the court, after 14 
notice to all parties interested, may disch arge the surety or sureties from all liability for 15 
any subsequent breach but not for any prior breaches and may require a new bond of the 16 
principal with sureties approved by the court.  17 
§8-207.  New bonds or removal of principal  18 
In proceedings under section s 8-205 and 8 -206, if the principal does not give a new 19 
bond within the time ordered by the court, the principal must be removed and another 20 
appointed.  21 
§8-208.  Reduction of liability where signed by surety company  22 
If a surety company becomes surety on a b ond given to the State of Maine, the court 23 
may, upon petition of any party in interest and after notice to all interested parties, reduce 24 
the amount for which the principal and surety are liable for a subsequent violation of the 25 
conditions of the bond.  26 
§8-209.  Actions on bonds  27 
Actions or proceedings on probate bonds of any kind payable to the State of Maine or 28 
the court may be commenced by any person interested in the estate or other matter for 29 
which the bond was given, either in the probate court in which  the bond was filed or in 30 
the Superior Court of the county in which the bond was filed.  31 
§8-210.  Principal made party in action against surety  32 
If the principal of the bond resides in the State when an action is brought under 33 
section 8 -209, and is not made a party to the action, or if at the trial or on proceedings on 34 
a judgment against the sureties only the principal is in the State, the court, at the request 35 
 
 Page 347 - 128LR0452(01) -1 
 of any such surety, may postpone or continue the action long enough to summon or bring 1 
the principa l into court.  2 
§8-211.  Proceedings and judgment  3 
With approval of the court after a continuance is issued under section 8 -210, the 4 
surety may request a writ, in the form prescribed by the court, to arrest the principal, if 5 
liable to arrest, or to attach the  principal's estate and summon the principal to appear and 6 
answer as a defendant in the action.  If, 14 days after service of the writ, the principal 7 
fails to appear at the time appointed and judgment is rendered for the plaintiff, the 8 
judgment must be aga inst the principal and the other defendants as if the principal had 9 
been a party.  Any attachment made on the writ may be used to satisfy the judgment as if 10 
the attachment had been issued in the original action.  11 
§8-212.  Limitation of actions on bonds  12 
Exce pt in the case of personal representatives provided for under sections 3 -1005 and 13 
3-1007, and whenever applicable under section 8 -201, an action on a bond must be 14 
commenced within 6 years after the principal has been cited by the court to appear to 15 
settle the account or, if not cited, within 6 years from the time of the breach of the bond, 16 
unless the breach is fraudulently concealed by the principal or surety from the persons 17 
pecuniarily interested and who are parties to the action, in which case the action  must be 18 
commenced within 3 years from the time the breach is discovered.  19 
§8-213.  Judicial authorization of actions  20 
The court may expressly authorize or instruct a personal representative or other 21 
fiduciary, on the court's own initiative or on the complai nt of any interested person, to 22 
commence an action on the bond for the benefit of the estate.  Nothing in this section may 23 
be deemed to limit the power or duty of a successor fiduciary to bring proceedings the 24 
fiduciary is authorized to bring without expre ss court authorization under section 3 -606, 25 
subsection 1, paragraph D; section 5 -416, subsection 1, paragraph C; Title 18 -B, section 26 
702; or any other provision of law.  27 
§8-214.  Forfeiture for failure to account when ordered  28 
When it appears in an action on  a bond against a principal that the principal is unable 29 
to account for personal property of the estate that the principal has received, execution 30 
must be awarded against the principal for the full value of the unaccounted -for property, 31 
without any allowan ce for charges of administration or debts paid.  32 
§8-215.  Judgment in trust for all interested  33 
Every judgment and execution in an action on the bond must be recovered by the 34 
court in trust for all interested parties.  The judge shall order the delinquent fi duciary, if 35 
still in office, to account for the amount or to assign the amount to the fiduciary's 36 
successor to be collected and distributed or otherwise disposed of as assets.  37 
PART 3  38
