 EFFECTIVE DATE  1 
§8-301.  Time of taking effect; provisions for transition  2 
1.  Effective date.  This Code takes effect on January 1, 1981.  3 
2.  Applicability.  Except as provided elsewhere in this Code, on the effective date of 4 
this Code:  5 
A.  The Code applies to any wills of decedents who die after the effective date;  6 
B.  The Cod e applies to any proceedings in court pending on the effective date or 7 
commenced after the effective date regardless of the time of the death of the decedent 8 
except to the extent that in the opinion of the court the former procedure should be 9 
made applicab le in a particular case in the interest of justice or because of 10 
infeasibility of application of the procedure of this Code;  11 
C.  Every personal representative, including a person administering an estate of a 12 
minor or incompetent holding an appointment on t he effective date of January 1, 13 
1981, continues to hold the appointment but has only the powers conferred by this 14 
Code and is subject to the duties imposed with respect to any act occurring or done 15 
after the effective date, and a guardian appointed prior t o January 1, 1981 has the 16 
powers conferred by this Code on guardians and conservators, unless otherwise 17 
limited by the original order of appointment or subsequent court order under this 18 
Code;  19 
D.  An act done before the effective date in any proceeding and any accrued right is 20 
not impaired by this Code.  If a right is acquired, extinguished or barred upon the 21 
expiration of a prescribed period of time that has commenced to run by the provisions 22 
of any statute before the effective date, the provisions remain i n force with respect to 23 
that right;  24 
E.  Any rule of construction or presumption provided in this Code applies to 25 
instruments executed and multiple party accounts opened before the effective date 26 
unless there is a clear indication of a contrary intent; and  27 
F.  For an adoption decree entered before the effective date and not amended after the 28 
effective date, the child is the child of both the natural and adopting parents for 29 
purposes of intestate succession, notwithstanding section 2 -119, unless the decree 30 
provides otherwise.  31 
ARTICLE 9  32 
ADOPTION  33 
PART 1  34 
GENERAL PROVISIONS  35 
 
 Page 349 - 128LR0452(01) -1 
 §9-101.  Short title  1 
This Article may be known and cited as "the Adoption Act."  2 
§9-102.  Definitions  3 
As used in this Article, unless the context otherwise indicates, the following terms 4 
have th e following meanings.  5 
1.  Adoptee.  "Adoptee" means a person who will be or who has been adopted, 6 
regardless of whether the person is a child or an adult.  7 
2.  Adult.  "Adult" means a person who is 18 years of age or older.  8 
3.  Child.  "Child" means a perso n who is under 18 years of age.  9 
4.  Consent.  "Consent," used as a noun, means a voluntary agreement to an adoption 10 
by a specific petitioner that is executed by a parent or custodian of the adoptee.  11 
5.  Department.  "Department" means the Department of Hea lth and Human 12 
Services.  13 
6.  Genetic father.  "Genetic father" means the man whose sperm fertilized the egg 14 
of a child's genetic mother.  15 
7.  Genetic mother.  "Genetic mother" means the woman whose egg was fertilized 16 
by the sperm of a child's genetic father.  17 
8.  Genetic parent.  "Genetic parent" means a child's genetic father or genetic 18 
mother.  19 
9.  Licensed child -placing agency.  "Licensed child -placing agency" means an 20 
agency, person, group of persons, organization, association or society licensed to operate  21 
in this State pursuant to Title 22, chapter 1671.  22 
10.  Parent.  "Parent" means a person who, with respect to a child:  23 
A.  Has established a parent -child relationship with the child under Title 19 -A, 24 
chapter 61; or  25 
B.  When no person described in paragraph  A exists, is the legal guardian of the 26 
child.  27 
11.  Petitioner.  "Petitioner" means a person filing a petition to adopt an adult or a 28 
child, and includes both petitioners under a joint petition, except as otherwise provided in 29 
this Article.  30 
12.  Putative f ather.  "Putative father" means a man who is the alleged genetic father 31 
of a child but whose paternity has not been legally established.  32 
 
 Page 350 - 128LR0452(01) -1 
 13.  Surrender and release.  "Surrender and release," used as a noun, means a 1 
voluntary relinquishment of all parental rights to a child to the department or a licensed 2 
child -placing agency for the purpose of placement for adoption.  3 
§9-103.  Jurisdiction  4 
1.  Probate Court jurisdiction.  Subject to Title 4, section 152, subsection 5 -A, the 5 
Probate Court has exclusive jurisd iction over the following:  6 
A.  Petitions for adoption;  7 
B.  Consents and reviews of withholdings of consent by persons other than a parent;  8 
C.  Surrenders and releases;  9 
D.  Termination of parental rights proceedings brought pursuant to section 9 -204; 10 
E.  Proceedings to determine the rights of putative fathers of children whose 11 
adoptions or surrenders and releases are pending before the Probate Court; and  12 
F.  Reviews conducted pursuant to section 9 -205. 13 
2.  District Court jurisdiction.  The District Court has  jurisdiction to conduct 14 
hearings pursuant to section 9 -205.  The District Court has jurisdiction over any matter 15 
described in subsection 1 if the proceeding concerns a child over whom the District Court 16 
has exclusive jurisdiction pursuant to Title 4, sect ion 152, subsection 5 -A. 17 
§9-104.  Venue; transfer  18 
1.  Venue if adoptee placed by agency or department.  If an adoptee is placed by a 19 
licensed child -placing agency or the department, the petition for adoption must be filed in 20 
the court in the county where:  21 
A.  The petitioner resides;  22 
B.  The adoptee resides or was born; or  23 
C.  An office of the agency that placed the adoptee for adoption is located.  24 
2.  Venue if agency or department not involved in placement.  If an adoptee is not 25 
placed by a licensed child -placing agency or the department, the petition for adoption 26 
must be filed in the county where the adoptee resides or where the petitioners reside.  27 
3.  Transfer.  If, in the interests of justice or for the convenience of the parties, the 28 
court finds that the  matter should be heard in another probate court, the court may 29 
transfer, stay or dismiss the proceeding, subject to any further conditions imposed by the 30 
court.  31 
§9-105.  Rights of adopted persons  32 
Except as otherwise provided by law, an adopted person has all the same rights, 33 
including inheritance rights, that a child born to the adoptive parents would have.  An 34 
adoptee also retains the right to inherit from the adoptee's genetic parents if the adoption 35 
decree so provides, as specified in section 2 -119, sub section 6.  36 
 
 Page 351 - 128LR0452(01) -1 
 §9-106.  Legal representation  1 
1.  Attorney for genetic parents.  The genetic parents are entitled to an attorney for 2 
any hearing held pursuant to this Article.  If the genetic mother or the genetic or putative 3 
father wants an attorney but is una ble to afford one, the genetic mother or the genetic or 4 
putative father may request the court to appoint an attorney.  If the court finds either or 5 
both of them indigent, the court shall appoint and pay the reasonable costs and expenses 6 
of the attorney of the indigent party.  The attorney may not be the attorney for the 7 
adoptive parents.  8 
2.  Attorney for minor indigent genetic parent.  When the adoptee is unrelated to 9 
the petitioner, the court shall appoint an attorney who is not the attorney for the adopti ve 10 
parents to represent a minor indigent genetic parent at every stage of the proceedings 11 
unless the minor indigent genetic parent refuses representation or the court determines 12 
that representation is unnecessary.  13 
§9-107.  Indian Child Welfare Act of 1978  14 
The federal Indian Child Welfare Act of 1978, United States Code, Title 25, Section 15 
1901 et seq. governs all proceedings under this Article that pertain to an Indian child as 16 
defined in that Act.  17 
§9-108.  Application of prior laws  18 
The laws in effect on Dec ember 31, 2018 apply to proceedings for which any of the 19 
following occurred before January 1, 2019:  20 
1.  Consent.  The filing of a consent;  21 
2.  Surrender and release.  The filing of a surrender and release;  22 
3.  Waiver of notice.  The filing of a waiver of n otice by a father or putative father 23 
under former Title 19, section 532 -C; 24 
4.  Order terminating parental rights.  The issuance of an order terminating 25 
parental rights; or  26 
5.  Adoption petition.  The filing of a petition for adoption.  27 
PART 2  28 
ESTABLISHMENT OF PATERNAL RIGHTS A ND TERMINATION OF 29 
PARENTAL RIGHTS  30 
§9-201.  Establishment of paternity  31 
1.  Affidavit of paternity.  When the genetic mother of a child born out of wedlock 32 
wishes to consent to the adoption of the child or to execute a surrender and relea se for the 33 
purpose of adoption of the child and the putative father has not consented to the adoption 34 
of the child or joined in a surrender and release for the purpose of adoption of the child or 35 
waived his right to notice, the genetic mother must file an affidavit of paternity with the 36 
 
 Page 352 - 128LR0452(01) -1 
 court so that the court may determine how to give notice of the proceedings to the 1 
putative father.  2 
2.  Notice of intent to consent or execute surrender and release.  If a court finds 3 
from the affidavit of the genetic mother  submitted pursuant to subsection 1 that the 4 
putative father's whereabouts are known, the court shall order that notice of the mother's 5 
intent to consent to adoption or to execute a surrender and release, or the mother's actual 6 
consent or surrender and rel ease, for the purpose of adoption of the child, be served upon 7 
the putative father.  If the court finds that the putative father's whereabouts are unknown, 8 
the court shall order notice by publication in accordance with the Maine Rules of Probate 9 
Procedure.   If the genetic mother does not know or refuses to tell the court who the 10 
genetic father is, the court may order publication in accordance with the Maine Rules of 11 
Probate Procedure in a newspaper of general circulation in the area where the petition is 12 
filed, where the genetic mother became pregnant or where the putative father is most 13 
likely to be located.  The notice must specify the names of the genetic mother and the 14 
child.  15 
3.  Waiver of notice.  A putative father or a legal father who is not the genet ic father 16 
may waive his right to notice under this section in a document acknowledged before a 17 
notary public or a judge.  The notary public may not be an attorney who represents either 18 
the mother or any person who is likely to become the legal guardian, cu stodian or parent 19 
of the child.  20 
A.  The waiver of notice must indicate that the putative father or legal father 21 
understands that the waiver of notice operates as a consent to adoption or a surrender 22 
and release for the purposes of adoption for any adoption  of the child and that by 23 
signing the waiver of notice the putative father or legal father voluntarily gives up 24 
any rights to the child.  25 
B.  The waiver of notice may state that the putative father or legal father neither 26 
admits nor denies paternity.  27 
C.  The legal father shall attach to the waiver of notice an affidavit stating that, 28 
although he is the legal father, he is not the genetic father.  29 
4.  Petition by putative father for parental rights.  If, after notice under this 30 
section, the putative father wis hes to establish parental rights to the child, he must, within 31 
20 days after notice has been given or within a longer period of time as ordered by the 32 
court, petition the court to grant to him parental rights.  The petition must include an 33 
allegation that the putative father is in fact the genetic father of the child.  34 
5.  Hearing date.  Upon receipt of a petition under subsection 4, the court shall fix a 35 
date for a hearing to determine the putative father's parental rights to the child.  36 
6.  Appointment of a ttorneys.  The court shall appoint an attorney who is not the 37 
attorney for the putative father, the genetic mother or the potential transferee agency or a 38 
potential adoptive parent to represent the child and to protect the child's interests in the 39 
proceedi ngs under this section.  40 
 
 Page 353 - 128LR0452(01) -1 
 7.  Notice of hearing.  Notice of a hearing under this section must be given to the 1 
putative father, the genetic mother, the attorney for the child and any other parties the 2 
court determines appropriate.  Notice need not be given to  a putative father or a legal 3 
father who is not the genetic father and who has waived his right to notice as provided in 4 
subsection 3.  5 
8.  Studies and reports.  Upon order of the court, the department or licensed child - 6 
placing agency shall furnish studies and reports relevant to the proceedings under this 7 
section.  8 
9.  Findings; putative father declared parent.  If, after a hearing under this section, 9 
the court finds that the putative father is the genetic father, that he is willing and able to 10 
protect the c hild from jeopardy and has not abandoned the child, that he is willing and 11 
able to take responsibility for the child and that it is in the best interests of the child, the 12 
court shall declare the putative father the child's parent with all the attendant ri ghts and 13 
responsibilities.  14 
10.  Findings; putative father.  If the court finds that the putative father has not 15 
petitioned or appeared within the period required by this section or has not met the 16 
requirements of subsection 9, the court shall rule that the  putative father has no parental 17 
rights and that only the genetic mother of the child need consent to adoption or a 18 
surrender and release.  19 
§9-202.  Surrender and release; consent  20 
1.  Surrender and release or consent; presence of judge.  With the approval o f the 21 
court of any county within the State and after a determination by the court that a 22 
surrender and release or a consent is in the best interest of the child, the parents or 23 
surviving parent of a child may at any time after the child's birth:  24 
A.  Surren der and release all parental rights to the child and the custody and control 25 
of the child to a licensed child -placing agency or the department to enable the 26 
licensed child -placing agency or the department to have the child adopted by a 27 
suitable person; or  28 
B.  Consent to have the child adopted by a specified petitioner.  29 
The parents or the surviving parent must execute the surrender and release or the consent 30 
in the presence of the judge.  The adoptee, if 14 years of age or older, must execute the 31 
consent in the presence of the judge.  The waiver of notice by the legal father who is not 32 
the genetic father or putative father is governed by section 9 -201, subsection 3.  33 
2.  Approval of surrender and release or consent.  The court may approve a 34 
surrender and relea se or a consent only if:  35 
A.  A licensed child -placing agency or the department certifies to the court that 36 
counseling was provided or was offered and refused.  This requirement does not 37 
apply if:  38 
(1)  One of the petitioners is a blood relative; or  39 
(2)  The  adoptee is an adult;  40 
 
 Page 354 - 128LR0452(01) -1 
 B.  The court has explained the individual's parental rights and responsibilities, the 1 
effects of the surrender and release or the consent, that in all but specific situations 2 
the individual has the right to revoke the surrender and r elease or consent within 3 3 
days and the existence of the adoption registry and the services available under Title 4 
22, section 2706 -A.  The individual does not have the right to revoke the consent 5 
when the individual is a consenting party and also a petitio ner; 6 
C.  The court determines that the surrender and release or the consent has been duly 7 
executed and was given freely after the parent was informed of the parent's rights; 8 
and 9 
D.  Except when a consenting party is also a petitioner, at least 3 days have elapsed 10 
since the parents or parent executed the surrender and release or the consent and the 11 
parents or parent did not withdraw or revoke the surrender and release or consent 12 
before the judge or, if the judge was not available, before the register.  13 
3.  Original; copies.  The original surrender and release or consent must be filed in 14 
the court where the surrender and release or the consent is executed.  An attested copy of 15 
the surrender and release or consent must be filed in the court in which the petition  is 16 
filed.  The court in which the surrender and release or the consent is executed shall 17 
provide an attested copy to each surrendering or consenting party and an attested copy to 18 
the transferring agency.  The copy given to the surrendering or consenting p arty must 19 
contain a statement explaining the importance of keeping the court informed of a current 20 
name and address.  21 
4.  Valid after 3 days; exception.  A surrender and release or a consent is not valid 22 
until 3 days after it has been executed, except that consent by a parent petitioning to adopt 23 
that parent's own child with that parent's spouse is valid upon signature.  24 
5.  Consent acknowledged.  Consent may be acknowledged before a notary public 25 
who is not an attorney for the adopting parents or a partner, associate or employee of an 26 
attorney for the adopting parents when consent is given by:  27 
A.  The department or a licensed child -placing agency; or  28 
B.  A public agency or a duly licensed private agency to which parental rights have 29 
been transferred under the  law of another state or country.  30 
6.  Final and irrevocable; exceptions.  Except as provided in subsection 7 and 31 
section 9 -205, subsection 2, a surrender and release or a consent is final and irrevocable 32 
when duly executed.  33 
7.  Consent; limitations.  A con sent is final only for the adoption consented to, and if 34 
that petition for adoption is withdrawn or dismissed or if the adoption is not finalized 35 
within 18 months of the execution of the consent, a review must be held pursuant to 36 
section 9 -205. 37 
8.  Surrend er and release or consent from another state.  The court shall accept a 38 
surrender and release or a consent by a court of comparable jurisdiction in another state if 39 
the court receives an affidavit from a member of that state's bar or a certificate from tha t 40 
court of comparable jurisdiction stating that:  41 
 
 Page 355 - 128LR0452(01) -1 
 A.  The party executing the surrender and release or the consent followed the 1 
procedure required to make a surrender and release or a consent valid in the state in 2 
which it was executed; and  3 
B.  The court of  comparable jurisdiction advised the person executing the surrender 4 
and release or the consent of the consequences of the surrender and release or the 5 
consent under the laws of the state in which the surrender and release or the consent 6 
was executed.  7 
The c ourt shall accept a waiver of notice by a putative father or a legal father who is not 8 
the genetic father that meets the requirements of section 9 -201, subsection 3.  9 
§9-203.  Duties and responsibilities subsequent to surrender and release  10 
Without notice to  the parent or parents, the surrender and release authorized pursuant 11 
to section 9 -202 may be transferred together with all rights under section 9 -202 from the 12 
transferee agency to the department or from the department as original transferee to any 13 
license d child -placing agency.  If the licensed child -placing agency or the department is 14 
unable to find a suitable adoptive home for a child surrendered and released by a parent 15 
or parents, the licensed child -placing agency or the department to whom custody and 16 
control of that child have been surrendered and released or transferred shall request a 17 
review pursuant to section 9 -205. 18 
§9-204.  Termination of parental rights  19 
1.  Petition for termination; Probate Court or District Court.  A petition for 20 
termination of parental rights may be brought in the Probate Court in which a petition for 21 
adoption is properly filed as part of that petition for adoption except when the District 22 
Court has exclusive jurisdiction over the child pursuant to Title 4, section 152, subsecti on 23 
5-A. 24 
2.  Title 22, chapter 1071, subchapter 6 applies.  Except as otherwise provided by 25 
this section, a termination of parental rights petition is subject to the provisions of Title 26 
22, chapter 1071, subchapter 6.  27 
3.  Guardian ad litem for child.  The c ourt may appoint a guardian ad litem for a 28 
child who is the subject of a petition for termination of parental rights under subsection 1.  29 
The appointment must be made as soon as possible after the petition for termination of 30 
parental rights is initiated.  31 
A.  The court shall pay reasonable costs and expenses for the guardian ad litem.  32 
B.  In general, the guardian ad litem shall act in pursuit of the best interests of the 33 
child.  The guardian ad litem must be given access to all reports and records relevant 34 
to the case and investigate to ascertain the facts.  The investigation must include, 35 
when possible and appropriate:  36 
(1)  Reviewing records of psychiatric, psychological or physical examinations of 37 
the child, parents or other persons having or seeking care o r custody of the child;  38 
(2)  Review of relevant school records and other pertinent materials;  39 
 
 Page 356 - 128LR0452(01) -1 
 (3)  Interviewing the child with or without other persons present; and  1 
(4)  Interviews with parents, guardians, teachers and other persons who have been 2 
involved in caring for or treating the child.  3 
The guardian ad litem may subpoena, examine and cross -examine witnesses and shall 4 
make recommendations to the court.  5 
§9-205.  Review  6 
1.  Judicial review required; 18 months.  The court shall conduct a judicial review 7 
if: 8 
A.  A child is not adopted within 18 months of the execution of a surrender and 9 
release;  10 
B.  The adoption is not finalized within 18 months of the consent to an adoption by a 11 
parent or parents; or  12 
C.  A petition for adoption is not finalized within 18 mo nths.  13 
2.  Determination whether adoption viable plan; review; plan; District Court.  If, 14 
after judicial review under subsection 1, the court determines that adoption is still a viable 15 
plan for the child, the court shall schedule another judicial review wit hin 2 years.  If the 16 
court determines that adoption is no longer a viable plan, the court shall attempt to notify 17 
the genetic parents, who must be given an opportunity to present an acceptable plan for 18 
the child.  If either or both parents are able and wil ling to assume physical custody of the 19 
child, the court shall declare the surrender and release or the consent void.  20 
If the genetic parents are not notified or are unable or unwilling to assume physical 21 
custody of the child or if the court determines that placement of the child with the genetic 22 
parents would constitute jeopardy as defined by Title 22, section 4002, subsection 6, the 23 
case must be transferred to the District Court for a hearing pursuant to Title 22, section 24 
4038 -A. 25 
PART 3  26 
ADOPTION PROCEDURES  27 
§9-301.  Petition for adoption and change of name; filing fee  28 
A husband and wife jointly or an unmarried person, resident or nonresident of the 29 
State, may petition the court to adopt a person, regardless of age, and to change that 30 
person's name.  The fee f or filing the petition is $65 plus:  31 
1.  National criminal history record check fee.  The fee for a national criminal 32 
history record check for noncriminal justice purposes set by the Federal Bureau of 33 
Investigation for each prospective adoptive parent who i s not the genetic parent of the 34 
child; and  35 
2.  State criminal history record check fee.  The fee for a state criminal history 36 
record check for noncriminal justice purposes established pursuant to Title 25, section 37 
 
 Page 357 - 128LR0452(01) -1 
 1541, subsection 6 for each prospective ad optive parent who is not the genetic parent of 1 
the child.  2 
§9-302.  Consent for adoption  3 
1.  Written consent.  Before an adoption is granted, written consent to the adoption 4 
must be given by:  5 
A.  The adoptee, if the adoptee is 14 years of age or older;  6 
B.  Each of the adoptee's living parents, except as provided in subsection 2;  7 
C.  A person or agency having legal custody or guardianship of the adoptee if the 8 
adoptee is a child or to whom the child has been surrendered and released, except that 9 
the person's or agency's lack of consent, if adjudged unreasonable by a court, may be 10 
overruled by the court.  In order for the court to find that the person or agency acted 11 
unreasonably in withholding consent, the petitioner must prove, by a preponderance 12 
of the evide nce, that the person or agency acted unreasonably.  The court may hold a 13 
pretrial conference to determine who will proceed.  The court may determine that 14 
even though the burden of proof is on the petitioner, the person or agency should 15 
proceed if the perso n or agency has important facts necessary to the petitioner in 16 
presenting the petitioner's case.  The court shall consider the following:  17 
(1)  Whether the person or agency determined the needs and interests of the child;  18 
(2)  Whether the person or agency d etermined the ability of the petitioner and 19 
other prospective families to meet the child's needs;  20 
(3)  Whether the person or agency made the decision consistent with the facts;  21 
(4)  Whether the harm of removing the child from the child's current placement 22 
outweighs any inadequacies of that placement; and  23 
(5)  All other factors that have a bearing on a determination of the reasonableness 24 
of the person's or agency's decision in withholding consent; and  25 
D.  A guardian appointed by the court, if the adoptee is a child, when the child has no 26 
living parent, guardian or legal custodian who may consent.  27 
A petition for adoption must be pending before a consent is executed.  28 
2.  Consent not required.  Consent to adoption is not required of:  29 
A.  A putative father or a l egal father who is not the genetic father if he:  30 
(1)  Received notice and failed to respond to the notice within the prescribed time 31 
period;  32 
(2)  Waived his right to notice under section 9 -201, subsection 3;  33 
(3)  Failed to meet the standards of section 9 -201, subsection 9; or  34 
(4)  Holds no parental rights regarding the adoptee under the laws of the foreign 35 
country in which the adoptee was born;  36 
 
 Page 358 - 128LR0452(01) -1 
 B.  A parent whose parental rights have been terminated under Title 22, chapter 1071, 1 
subchapter 6;  2 
C.  A parent w ho has executed a surrender and release pursuant to section 9 -202; 3 
D.  A parent whose parental rights have been voluntarily or judicially terminated and 4 
transferred to a public agency or a duly licensed private agency pursuant to the laws 5 
of another state or country; or  6 
E.  A parent of an adoptee who is 18 years of age or older.  7 
3.  Consent by department; notice.  When the department consents to the adoption 8 
of a child in its custody, the department shall immediately notify:  9 
A.  The District Court in which the action under Title 22, chapter 1071 is pending; 10 
and 11 
B.  The guardian ad litem for the child.  12 
§9-303.  Petition  13 
1.  Sworn; contents.  A petition for adoption must be sworn to by the petitioner and 14 
must include:  15 
A.  The full name, age and place of reside nce of the petitioner and, if married, the 16 
place and date of marriage;  17 
B.  The date and place of birth of the adoptee, if known;  18 
C.  The birth name of the adoptee, any other names by which the adoptee has been 19 
known and the adoptee's proposed new name, if any; 20 
D.  The residence of the adoptee at the time of the filing of the petition;  21 
E.  A statement of the petitioner's intention to establish a parent -child relationship 22 
between the petitioner and the adoptee and a statement that the petitioner is a fit and 23 
proper person able to care and provide for the adoptee's welfare;  24 
F.  The names and addresses of all persons or agencies known to the petitioner that 25 
affect the custody of, visitation with or access to the adoptee;  26 
G.  The relationship, if any, of the peti tioner to the adoptee;  27 
H.  The names and addresses of the department and the licensed child -placing 28 
agency, if any;  29 
I.  The names and addresses of all persons known to the petitioner at the time of filing 30 
from whom consent to the adoption is required; and  31 
J.  If the petition is for the adoption of a minor child, a statement that the petitioner 32 
acknowledges that after the adoption is finalized, the transfer of the long -term care 33 
and custody of the adoptee without a court order is prohibited under Title 17 -A, 34 
section 553, subsection 1, paragraphs C and D.  35 
 
 Page 359 - 128LR0452(01) -1 
 2.  Information to be shared and updated.  A petitioner shall indicate to the court 1 
what information the petitioner is willing to share with the genetic parents and under what 2 
circumstances and shall provide a mechanism for updating that information.  3 
3.  Caption.  The caption of a petition for adoption may be styled "In the Matter of 4 
the Adoption Petition of (name of adoptee)."  The petitioner must also be designated in 5 
the caption.  6 
§9-304.  Investigation; gua rdian ad litem; registry  7 
1.  Background check; study and report.  Upon the filing of a petition for adoption 8 
of a minor child, the court shall request a background check and shall direct the 9 
department or a licensed child -placing agency to conduct a study and make a report to the 10 
court.  11 
A.  The study must include an investigation of the conditions and antecedents of the 12 
child to determine whether the child is a proper subject for adoption and whether the 13 
proposed home is suitable for the child.  The departm ent or licensed child -placing 14 
agency shall submit the report to the court within 60 days.  15 
(1)  If the court has a report that provides sufficient, current information, the 16 
court may waive the requirement of a study and report.  17 
(2)  If the petitioner is a b lood relative of the child, the court may waive the 18 
requirement of a study and report.  19 
B.  The court shall request a background check for each prospective adoptive parent 20 
who is not the genetic parent of the child.  The background check must include a 21 
screening for child abuse cases in the records of the department and criminal history 22 
record information obtained from the Maine Criminal Justice Information System and 23 
the Federal Bureau of Investigation.  24 
(1)  The criminal history record information obtained from the Maine Criminal 25 
Justice Information System must include a record of public criminal history 26 
record information as defined in Title 16, section 703, subsection 8.  27 
(2)  The criminal history record information obtained from the Federal Bureau of 28 
Inves tigation must include other state and national criminal history record 29 
information.  30 
(3)  Each prospective parent who is not the genetic parent of the child shall 31

3.  Child's background.  This subsection governs the collection and disclosure of 21 
information about the background of a child subject to a petition for adoption under 22 
subsection 1.  23 
A.  The department, the licensed child -placing agency or any other person who acts 24 
to place or assist in placing a child for adoption shall obtain medical and genetic 25 
information about the genetic parents and the child.  Specifically, the department, the 26 
licensed child -placing agency or any other person who acts to place or assist in 27 
placing the child for adoption shall attempt to obtain:  28 
(1)  A current medical, psychological and developmental history of the child, 29 
including an account of the child's prenata l care and medical condition at birth, 30 
results of newborn screening, any drug or medication taken by the child's genetic 31 
mother during pregnancy, any subsequent medical, psychological or psychiatric 32 
examination and diagnosis, any physical, sexual or emotio nal abuse suffered by 33 
the child and a record of any immunizations and health care received since birth; 34 
and 35 
(2)  Relevant information concerning the medical, psychological and social 36 
history of the genetic parents, including any known disease or hereditary  37 
disposition to disease, the history of use of drugs and alcohol, the health of the 38 
genetic mother during her pregnancy and the health of the genetic parents at the 39 
time of the child's birth.  40 
B.  Prior to the child being placed for adoption, the department , the licensed child - 41 
placing agency or any other person who acts to place or assist in placing the child for 42 
 
 Page 362 - 128LR0452(01) -1 
 adoption shall provide the information described in paragraph A to the prospective 1 
adoptive parents.  2 
C.  If the department, the licensed child -placing agency or any other person who acts 3 
to place or assists in placing the child for adoption has specific, articulable reasons to 4 
question the truth or accuracy of any of the information obtained, those reasons must 5 
be disclosed in writing to the prospect ive adoptive parents.  6 
D.  The prospective adoptive parents must be informed in writing if any of the 7 
information described in this subsection cannot be obtained, either because the 8 
records are unavailable or because the genetic parents are unable or unwill ing to 9 
consent to its disclosure or to be interviewed.  10 
E.  If, after a child is placed for adoption and either before or after the adoption is 11 
final, the child suffers a serious medical or mental illness for which the specific 12 
medical, psychological or soc ial history of the genetic parents or the child may be 13 
useful in diagnosis or treatment, the prospective adoptive or adoptive parents may 14 
request that the department, the licensed child -placing agency or any other person 15 
who placed or assisted to place the  child attempt to obtain additional information.  16 
The department, licensed child -placing agency or other person shall attempt to obtain 17 
the information promptly and shall disclose any information collected to the 18 
prospective adoptive or adoptive parents as  soon as reasonably possible.  The 19 
department, licensed child -placing agency or other person may charge a fee to the 20 
prospective adoptive or adoptive parents to cover the cost of obtaining and providing 21 
the additional information.  Fees collected by the de partment must be dedicated to 22 
defray the costs of obtaining and providing the additional information.  Fees may be 23 
reduced or waived for low -income prospective adoptive or adoptive parents.  24 
F.  The department, the licensed child -placing agency or any other  person who acts to 25 
place or assist in placing the child for adoption shall file the information collected 26 
with the court and, if it appears that the adoption will be granted and this information 27 
has not previously been made available to the adoptive paren ts pursuant to Title 22, 28 
section 4008, subsection 3, paragraph G or Title 22, section 8205, the court shall 29 
make the information available to the adoptive parents, prior to issuing the decree 30 
pursuant to subsection 8, with protection for the identity of pe rsons other than the 31 
child.  32 
G.  If the child to be placed for adoption is from a foreign country that has 33 
jurisdiction over the child and the prospective adoptive parents are United States 34 
citizens, compliance with federal and international adoption laws i s deemed to be in 35 
compliance with this subsection.  36 
4.  Rebuttable presumption; sexual offenses.  There is a rebuttable presumption 37 
that the petitioner would create a situation of jeopardy for the child if the adoption were 38 
granted and that the adoption is not in the best interest of the child if the court finds that 39 
the petitioner for the adoption of a minor child:  40 
A.  Has been convicted of an offense listed in Title 19 -A, section 1653, subsection 41 
6-A, paragraph A in which the victim was a minor at the time  of the offense and the 42 
petitioner was at least 5 years older than the minor at the time of the offense, except 43 
that, if the offense was gross sexual assault under Title 17 -A, section 253, subsection 44 
 
 Page 363 - 128LR0452(01) -1 
 1, paragraph B or C, or an offense in another jurisdicti on that involves conduct that is 1 
substantially similar to that contained in Title 17 -A, section 253, subsection 1, 2 
paragraph B or C, and the minor victim submitted as a result of compulsion, the 3 
presumption applies regardless of the ages of the petitioner and the minor victim at 4 
the time of the offense; or  5 
B.  Has been adjudicated in an action under Title 22, chapter 1071 of sexually 6 
abusing a person who was a minor at the time of the abuse.  7 
The petitioner may present evidence to rebut the presumption.  8 
5.  Probationary period.  The court may require that a minor child subject to a 9 
petition for adoption under this section live for one year in the home of the petitioner 10 
before the petition is granted and that the child, during all or part of this probationary 11 
period, be under the supervision of the department or a licensed adoption agency.  12 
6.  Guardian ad litem.  The court may appoint a guardian ad litem for a minor child 13 
subject to a petition for adoption under this section at any time during the proceedings.  14 
7.  Adoption registry and services.  Before the adoption of a minor child is decreed, 15 
the court shall ensure that the petitioners are informed of the existence of the adoption 16 
registry and the services available under Title 22, section 2706 -A. 17 
8.  Declarat ion; name change.  If the court is satisfied with the identity and relations 18 
of the parties to a petition for adoption under this section, with the ability of the petitioner 19 
to bring up and educate the child properly, considering the condition of the child 's genetic 20 
parents, and with the fitness and propriety of the adoption, the court shall make a decree 21 
setting forth the facts and declaring that from that date the child is the child of the 22 
petitioner and that the child's name is changed, without requiring  public notice of that 23 
change.  24 
9.  Certified copy of birth certificate; certificate of adoption.  A certified copy of 25 
the birth certificate of the child proposed for adoption must be presented with the petition 26 
for adoption if the certified copy can be obt ained or made available by filing a delayed 27 
birth registration.  After the adoption has been decreed, the register shall file a certificate 28 
of adoption with the State Registrar of Vital Statistics on a form prescribed and furnished 29 
by the state registrar.  30 
10.  Transfer of long -term care or custody without court order.  Before the 31 
adoption is decreed under subsection 8, the court shall ensure that the petitioners are 32 
informed that the transfer of the long -term care and custody of the child without a court 33 
order is prohibited under Title 17 -A, section 553, subsection 1, paragraphs C and D.  34 
§9-305.  Evidence; procedure  35 
The court may proceed as follows in considering a petition for adoption.  36 
1.  Adoptee interview.  The court may interview any adoptee, and shall interview an 37 
adoptee who is 12 years of age or older, outside the presence of the prospective adoptive 38 
parents, to determine the adoptee's attitudes and desires about the adoption and other 39 
relevant issues.  40 
 
 Page 364 - 128LR0452(01) -1 
 2.  Inspection of records; disclosure.  The court  may conduct an inspection in 1 
camera of records of relevant child protective proceedings and may disclose only that 2 
information necessary for the determination of any issue before the court.  Any disclosure 3 
of information must be done pursuant to Title 22,  section 4008, subsection 3.  4 
3.  Recording; expenses.  The parties may request a recording of the proceedings.  5 
The requesting party shall pay the expense of the recording.  6 
§9-306.  Allowable payments; expenses  7 
1.  Allowable payments by or on behalf of pet itioner.  Except when one of the 8 
petitioners is a blood relative of the adoptee or the adoptee is an adult, only the following 9 
expenses may be paid by or on behalf of a petitioner in any proceeding under this Article:  10 
A.  The actual cost of legal services related to the surrender and release or the consent 11 
and to the adoption process;  12 
B.  Prenatal and postnatal counseling expenses for the genetic mother;  13 
C.  Prenatal, birthing and other related medical expenses for the genetic mother;  14 
D.  Necessary transpor tation expenses to obtain the services listed in paragraphs A, B 15 
and C;  16 
E.  Foster care expenses for the child;  17 
F.  Necessary living expenses for the genetic mother and the child;  18 
G.  For the genetic father, legal and counseling expenses related to the sur render and 19 
release, the consent and the adoption process; and  20 
H.  Fees to a licensed child -placing agency providing services in connection with the 21 
pending adoption.  22 
2.  Full accounting of disbursements by petitioner.  Prior to the dispositional 23 
hearing pu rsuant to section 9 -308, the petitioner shall file a full accounting of all 24 
disbursements of anything of value made or agreed to be made by or on behalf of the 25 
petitioner in connection with the adoption.  The accounting report must be signed under 26 
penalty of perjury and must be submitted to the court on or before the date the final 27 
decree is granted.  The accounting report must be itemized and show the services related 28 
to the adoption or to the placement of the adoptee for adoption that were received by the  29 
adoptee's genetic parents, by the adoptee or on behalf of the petitioner.  The accounting 30 
must include the dates of each payment and the names and addresses of each attorney, 31 
physician, hospital, licensed child -placing agency or other person or organizati on who 32 
received funds or anything of value from the petitioner in connection with the adoption or 33 
the placement of the adoptee with the petitioner or participated in any way in the handling 34 
of the funds, either directly or indirectly.  This subsection does  not apply when one of the 35 
petitioners is a blood relative or the adoptee is an adult.  36 
3.  Payments not contingent; other expenses and payments prohibited.  Payment 37 
for expenses allowable under subsection 1 may not be contingent upon any future 38 
decision a genetic parent might make pertaining to the child.  Other expenses or payments 39 
to genetic parents are not authorized.  40

 §9-307.  Adoption not granted  1 
If the court determines that it is unable to finalize an adoption to which genetic 2 
parents have consented, t he court shall notify the genetic parents that the court has not 3 
granted the adoption and shall conduct a review pursuant to section 9 -205. 4 
§9-308.  Final decree; dispositional hearing  5 
1.  Final decree of adoption; requirements.  The court shall grant a fi nal decree of 6 
adoption if the petitioner who filed the petition has been heard or has waived hearing and 7 
the court is satisfied from the hearing or record that:  8 
A.  All necessary consents, relinquishments or terminations of parental rights have 9 
been duly e xecuted and filed with the court;  10 
B.  An adoption study, when required by section 9 -304, has been filed with the court;  11 
C.  A list of all disbursements as required by section 9 -306 has been filed with the 12 
court;  13 
D.  The petitioner is a suitable adopting pa rent and desires to establish a parent -child 14 
relationship with the adoptee;  15 
E.  The best interests of the adoptee, described in subsection 2, are served by the 16 
adoption;  17 
F.  The petitioner has acknowledged that the petitioner understands that the transfer 18 
of the long -term care and custody of an adoptee who is a minor child without a court 19 
order is prohibited under Title 17 -A, section 553, subsection 1, paragraphs C and D; 20 
and 21 
G.  All requirements of this Article have been met.  22 
2.  Best interests of adoptee.   In determining the best interests of an adoptee, the 23 
court shall consider and evaluate the following factors to give the adoptee a permanent 24 
home at the earliest possible date:  25 
A.  The love, affection and other emotional ties existing between the adoptee  and the 26 
adopting person or persons, the genetic parent or genetic parents or the putative 27 
father;  28 
B.  The capacity and disposition of the adopting person or persons, the genetic parent 29 
or genetic parents or the putative father to educate and give the adop tee love, 30 
affection and guidance and to meet the needs of the adoptee.  An adoption may not be 31 
delayed or denied because the adoptive parent and the adoptee do not share the same 32 
race, color or national origin; and  33 
C.  The capacity and disposition of the a dopting person or persons, the genetic parent 34 
or genetic parents or the putative father to provide the adoptee with food, clothing 35 
and other material needs, education, permanence and medical care or other remedial 36 
care recognized and permitted in place of medical care under the laws of this State.  37 
3.  Findings; decree; confidentiality.  The court shall enter its findings in a written 38 
final decree that includes the new name of the adoptee.  The final decree must further 39 
 
 Page 366 - 128LR0452(01) -1 
 order that from the date of the decree  the adoptee is the child of the petitioner and must be 1 
accorded the status set forth in section 9 -105.  If the court determines that it is in the best 2 
interest of the adoptee, the court may require that the names of the adoptee and of the 3 
petitioner be ke pt confidential.  4 
4.  Notice to genetic parents.  Upon completion of an adoption proceeding, the 5 
genetic parents who consented to an adoption or who executed a surrender and release 6 
must be notified by the court of the completion by regular mail at their la st known 7 
address.  Notice under this subsection is not required to a genetic parent who is also a 8 
petitioner.  When the genetic parents' rights have been terminated pursuant to Title 22, 9 
section 4055, the notice must be given to the department and the depa rtment shall notify 10 
the genetic parents of the completion by regular mail at their last known address.  Actual 11 
receipt of the notice is not a precondition of completion and does not affect the rights or 12 
responsibilities of adoptees or adoptive parents.  13 
5.  Notice to grandparents.  The department shall notify the grandparents of a child 14 
when the child is placed for adoption if the department has received notice that the 15 
grandparents were granted reasonable rights of visitation or access under Title 19 -A, 16 
chapter 59 or Title 22, section 4005 -E. 17 
§9-309.  Appeals  18 
1.  Appeal; bond not required of child or next friend.  Any party may appeal from 19 
any order entered under this Article to the Supreme Judicial Court sitting as the Law 20 
Court, as in other civil actions, but a bond to prosecute an appeal is not required of a child 21 
or next friend and costs may not be awarded against either.  22 
2.  Appeal expedited.  An appeal from any order under this Article must be 23 
expedited.  24 
3.  Attorney, guardian ad litem continues.  An at torney or guardian ad litem 25 
appointed to represent a party in an adoption proceeding continues to represent the 26 
interests of that party in any appeal unless otherwise ordered by the court.  27 
§9-310.  Records confidential  28 
Notwithstanding any other provision o f law and except as provided in Title 22, 29 
section 2768, all court records relating to an adoption decreed on or after August 8, 1953 30 
are confidential.  The court shall keep records of those adoptions segregated from all 31 
other court records.  If a court det ermines that examination of records pertaining to a 32 
particular adoption is proper, the court may authorize that examination by specified 33 
persons, authorize the register to disclose to specified persons any information contained 34 
in the records by letter, ce rtificate or copy of the record or authorize a combination of 35 
both examination and disclosure.  36 
Any medical or genetic information in the court records relating to an adoption must 37 
be made available to the adopted child when the adopted child attains 18 yea rs of age and 38 
to the adopted child's descendants, adoptive parents or legal guardian on petition of the 39 
court.  40

 §9-311.  Interstate placements  1 
1.  Certificate of compliance; bring child to this State.  A person or agency who 2 
intends to bring a child to this  State from another state for the purpose of adoption must 3 
provide to the court the certification of compliance as required by the department 4 
pursuant to Title 22, chapter 1153 or 1154, as applicable.  5 
2.  Certificate of compliance; remove child from this S tate.  A person or agency 6 
who intends to remove a child from this State for the purpose of adoption in another state 7 
must obtain from the department certification of compliance with Title 22, chapter 1153 8 
or 1154, as applicable, prior to the removal of the  child from this State.  9 
3.  Department certification required.  The court may not grant a petition to adopt a 10 
child who has been brought to or will be removed from this State for the purpose of 11 
adoption without department certification of compliance with T itle 22, chapter 1153 or 12 
1154, as applicable.  13 
4.  Civil violation.  An agency or person who fails to comply with this section 14 
commits a civil violation for which a fine of not less than $100 and not more than $5,000 15 
may be adjudged.  16 
§9-312.  Foreign adopti ons 17 
If an adoption in a foreign country has been finalized and the adopting parents are 18 
seeking an adoption under the laws of this State to give recognition to the foreign 19 
adoption, a court may enter a decree of adoption based solely upon a judgment of 20 
adoption in a foreign country and may order a change of name if requested by the 21 
adopting parents.  The fee for filing the petition is $55.  22 
§9-313.  Advertisement  23 
1.  Definitions.  As used in this section, the following terms have the following 24 
meanings.  25 
A.  "Advertise" means to communicate by any public medium that originates within 26 
this State, including by newspaper, periodical, telephone book listing, outdoor 27 
advertising sign, radio or television, or by any computerized communication system, 28 
including by e -mail, website, Internet account or any similar medium of 29 
communication provided via the Internet.  30 
B.  "Internet account" means an account created within a bounded system established 31 
by an Internet -based service that requires a user to input or store access  information 32 
in an electronic device in order to view, create, use or edit the user's account 33 
information, profile, display, communications or stored data.  34 
2.  Advertising prohibited.  A person may not:  35 
A.  Advertise for the purpose of finding a child to a dopt or to otherwise take into 36 
permanent physical custody;  37 
 
 Page 368 - 128LR0452(01) -1 
 B.  Advertise that the person will find an adoptive home or any other permanent 1 
physical placement for a child or arrange for or assist in the adoption, adoptive 2 
placement or any other permanent ph ysical placement of a child;  3 
C.  Advertise that the person will place a child for adoption or in any other permanent 4 
physical placement; or  5 
D.  Advertise for the purpose of finding a person to adopt or otherwise take into 6 
permanent custody a particular chi ld. 7 
3.  Exceptions.  This section does not prohibit:  8 
A.  The department or a child -placing agency from advertising in accordance with 9 
rules adopted by the department; or  10 
B.  An attorney licensed to practice in this State from advertising the attorney's 11 
availability to practice or provide services relating to the adoption of children.  12 
4.  Violation.  A person who violates subsection 2 commits a civil violation for 13 
which a fine of not more than $5,000 may be adjudged.  14 
§9-314.  Immunity from liability for good  faith reporting; proceedings  15 
A person, including an agent of the department, who participates in good faith in 16 
reporting violations of this Article or participates in a related child protection 17 
investigation or proceeding is immune from any criminal or ci vil liability for reporting or 18 
participating in the investigation or proceeding.  For purposes of this section, "good faith" 19 
does not include instances when a false report is made and the person knows the report is 20 
false.  21 
§9-315.  Annulment of the adoption  decree  22 
1.  Annulment; reasons.  The court, on petition of 2 or more persons and after notice 23 
and hearing, may reverse and annul an adoption decree for one of the following reasons:  24 
A.  The court finds that the adoption was obtained as a result of fraud, d uress or 25 
illegal procedures; or  26 
B.  The court finds good cause shown consistent with the best interest of the child.  27 
2.  Notice.  Notice of a petition to annul must be given to the genetic parents, except 28 
those whose parental rights were terminated through  a proceeding pursuant to Title 22, 29 
section 4055, subsection 1, paragraph B, subparagraph (2), and to all parties to the 30 
adoption including the adoptive parents, an adoptee who is 14 years of age or older and 31 
the agency involved in the adoption.  32 
3.  Certif ied copy of annulment.  After the court annuls a decree of adoption, the 33 
register shall transmit immediately a certified copy of the annulment to the State 34 
Registrar of Vital Statistics.  35 
PART 4  36 
ADOPTION ASSISTANCE PROGRAM  37 
 
 Page 369 - 128LR0452(01) -1 
 §9-401.  Authorization; special ne eds children  1 
1.  Program.  There is established in the Department of Health and Human Services 2 
the Adoption Assistance Program, referred to in this Part as "the program."  3 
2.  Adoption assistance for special needs children.  Subject to rules and regulations  4 
adopted by the department and the federal Department of Health and Human Services, the 5 
department may provide through the program adoption assistance for special needs 6 
children in its care or custody or in the custody of a nonprofit private licensed child - 7 
placing agency in this State if those children are legally eligible for adoption and, when 8 
reasonable but unsuccessful efforts have been made to place them without adoption 9 
assistance, would not otherwise be adopted without the assistance of this program.  10 
3.  One-time adoption expenses.  The department shall, subject to rules and 11 
regulations adopted by the department and the federal Department of Health and Human 12 
Services, reimburse adoptive parents of a special needs child for one -time adoption 13 
expenses w hen reasonable but unsuccessful efforts have been made to place the child 14 
without such assistance.  15 
4.  "Special needs child" defined.  As used in this Part, "special needs child" means 16 
a child who:  17 
A.  Has a physical, mental or emotional handicap that make s placement difficult;  18 
B.  Has a medical condition that makes placement difficult;  19 
C.  Is a member of a sibling group that includes at least one member who is difficult 20 
to place;  21 
D.  Is difficult to place because of age or race;  22 
E.  Has been a victim of ph ysical, emotional or sexual abuse or neglect that places the 23 
child at risk for future emotional difficulties; or  24 
F.  Has in that child's family background factors such as severe mental illness, 25 
substance abuse, prostitution, genetic or medical conditions o r illnesses that place the 26 
child at risk for future problems.  27 
5.  Funds.  For the purposes of this section, the department is authorized to use funds 28 
that are appropriated for child welfare services and funds provided under the United 29 
States Social Securit y Act, Titles IV -B and IV -E. 30 
6.  Amount of adoption assistance.  The amount of adoption assistance under the 31 
program may vary depending upon the resources of the adoptive parents and the special 32 
needs of the child, as well as the availability of other reso urces, but may not exceed the 33 
total cost of caring for the child if the child were to remain in the care or custody of the 34 
department, without regard to the source of the funds.  35 
7.  Duration of assistance.  The duration of assistance under the program may 36 
continue until the cessation of legal parental responsibility or until the parents are no 37 
longer supporting the child, at which time the adoption assistance ceases.  However, if the 38 
child has need of educational benefits or has a physical, mental or emotio nal handicap, 39 
 
 Page 370 - 128LR0452(01) -1 
 adoption assistance may continue until the adoptee has attained 21 years of age if the 1 
adoptee, the parents and the department agree that the need for care and support exists.  2 
8.  Children from another state.  Children who are in the custody of a person or 3 
agency in another state who are brought to this State for the purpose of adoption are not 4 
eligible for adoption assistance through the program except for reimbursement of 5 
nonrecurring expenses if the child meets the requirements of the Unite d States Social 6 
Security Act, 42 United States Code, Section 673(c).  7 
§9-402.  Adoption assistance  8 
1.  Eligible applicants.  An application for the program may be submitted by the 9 
following persons:  10 
A.  A foster parent interested in adopting an eligible chi ld in the foster parent's care;  11 
B.  A person interested in adopting an eligible child; or  12 
C.  An adoptive parent who was not informed of the program or of facts relevant to a 13 
child's eligibility when adopting a child who was at the time of adoption eligibl e for 14 
participation in the program.  15 
2.  Standards for adoption apply.  All applicants for the program must meet 16 
department standards for adoption except for financial eligibility.  17 
3.  Assistance based on special needs.  Assistance under the program may be 18 
provided for special needs only and may be varied based on the special needs of the child.  19 
Assistance may be provided for a period of time based on the special needs of the child.  20 
§9-403.  Administration  21 
1.  Written agreement before final decree; exceptio ns; reduction in payments.  A 22 
written agreement between an applicant entering into the program and the department 23 
must precede the final decree of adoption, except that an application may be filed 24 
subsequent to the finalization of the adoption if there wer e facts relevant to the child's 25 
eligibility that were not presented at the time of the request for assistance or if the child 26 
was eligible for participation in the program at the time of placement and the adoptive 27 
parents were not informed of the program.  28 
Except as provided by section 9 -401, subsection 8, once an adoption assistance payment 29 
is agreed upon and the agreement signed by the prospective adoptive parents, the 30 
department may not reduce the adoption assistance payment amounts.  31 
2.  Annual determinat ion.  If assistance under the program continues for more than 32 
one year, the need for assistance must be annually redetermined.  Adoption assistance 33 
continues regardless of the state in which the adoptive parents reside, or the state to which 34 
the adoptive p arents move, as long as the adoptive parents continue to be eligible based 35 
on the annual redetermination of need.  36 
3.  Transfer to legal guardian; new agreement.  Upon the death of all adoptive 37 
parents, adoption assistance under the program may be transferr ed to the legal guardian as 38 
long as the child continues to be eligible for adoption assistance pursuant to the terms of 39 
 
 Page 371 - 128LR0452(01) -1 
 the most recent adoption assistance agreement with the adoptive parents.  The department 1 
shall enter into a new assistance agreement wit h the legal guardian.  2 
§9-404.  Rules  3 
The department shall adopt rules for the program consistent with this Part.  4 
PART B  5 
Sec. B -1.  33 MRSA c. 5,  as amended, is repealed.  6 
Sec. B -2.  33 MRSA c. 5 -A is enacted to read:  7 
CHAPTER 5 -A 8 
RULE AGAINST PERPETU ITIES  9 
§111.  Statutory rule against perpetuities  10 
1.  Validity of nonvested property interest.  A nonvested property interest is invalid 11 
unless:  12 
A.  When the interest is created, it is certain to vest or terminate no later than 21 years 13 
after the death of an indivi dual then alive; or  14 
B.  The interest either vests or terminates within 90 years after its creation.  15 
2.  Validity of general power of appointment subject to a condition precedent.  A 16 
general power of appointment not presently exercisable because of a condit ion precedent 17 
is invalid unless:  18 
A.  When the power is created, the condition precedent is certain to be satisfied or 19 
becomes impossible to satisfy no later than 21 years after the death of an individual 20 
then alive; or  21 
B.  The condition precedent either is  satisfied or becomes impossible to satisfy within 22 
90 years after its creation.  23 
3.  Validity of nongeneral or testamentary power of appointment.  A nongeneral 24 
power of appointment or a general testamentary power of appointment is invalid unless:  25 
A.  When t he power is created, it is certain to be irrevocably exercised or otherwise to 26 
terminate no later than 21 years after the death of an individual then alive; or  27 
B.  The power is irrevocably exercised or otherwise terminates within 90 years after 28 
its creatio n. 29 
4.  Possibility of post -death child disregarded.  In determining whether a nonvested 30 
property interest or a power of appointment is valid under subsection 1, paragraph A; 31 
subsection 2, paragraph A; or subsection 3, paragraph A, the possibility that a ch ild will 32 
be born to an individual after the individual's death is disregarded.  33 
 
 Page 372 - 128LR0452(01) -1 
 5.  Effect of certain "later of" -type language.   Language contained in a governing 1 
instrument that measures a period from the creation of a trust or other property 2 
arrangement i s inoperative to the extent it produces a period of time that exceeds 21 years 3 
after the death of the survivor of the specified lives in being if the language seeks:  4 
A.  To disallow the vesting or termination of any interest or trust beyond the later of:  5 
(1)  The expiration of a period of time not exceeding 21 years after the death of 6 
the survivor of specified lives in being at the creation of the trust or other 7 
property arrangement; and  8 
(2)  The expiration of a period of time that exceeds or might exceed 2 1 years after 9 
the death of the survivor of the specified lives in being at the creation of the trust 10 
or other property arrangement;  11 
B.  To postpone the vesting or termination of any interest or trust until the later of:  12 
(1)  The expiration of a period of t ime not exceeding 21 years after the death of 13 
the survivor of specified lives in being at the creation of the trust or other 14 
property arrangement; and  15 
(2)  The expiration of a period of time that exceeds or might exceed 21 years after 16 
the death of the surv ivor of the specified lives in being at the creation of the trust 17 
or other property arrangement; or  18 
C.  To operate in effect in any fashion similar to that described in paragraph A or B 19 
upon the later of:  20 
(1)  The expiration of a period of time not exceedi ng 21 years after the death of 21 
the survivor of specified lives in being at the creation of the trust or other 22 
property arrangement; and  23 
(2)  The expiration of a period of time that exceeds or might exceed 21 years after 24 
the death of the survivor of the spe cified lives in being at the creation of the trust 25 
or other property arrangement.  26 
§112.  When nonvested property interest or power of appointment created  27 
1.  General principles.  Except as provided in subsections 2 and 3 and in section 28 
115, subsection 1, t he time of creation of a nonvested property interest or a power of 29 
appointment is determined under general principles of property law.  30 
2.  Unqualified beneficial owner.  For purposes of this chapter, if there is an 31 
individual who alone can exercise a power  created by a governing instrument to become 32 
the unqualified beneficial owner of a nonvested property interest or a property interest 33 
subject to a power of appointment described in section 111, subsection 2 or 3, the 34 
nonvested property interest or power of  appointment is created when the power to 35 
become the unqualified beneficial owner terminates.  36 
3.  Arising out of transfer of property.  For purposes of this chapter, a nonvested 37 
property interest or a power of appointment arising out of a transfer of prope rty to a 38 
previously funded trust or other existing property arrangement is created when the 39 
 
 Page 373 - 128LR0452(01) -1 
 nonvested property interest or power of appointment in the original contribution was 1 
created.  2 
§113.  Reformation  3 
Upon the petition of an interested person, a court shall reform a disposition in the 4 
manner that most closely approximates the transferor's manifested plan of distribution 5 
and so that the reformed disposition is within the 90 years allowed by section 111, 6 
subsection 1, paragraph B; section 111, subsection 2, paragraph B; or section 111, 7 
subsection 3, paragraph B if:  8 
1.  Nonvested property interest or power of appointment.  A nonvested property 9 
interest or a power of appointment becomes invalid under section 111;  10 
2.  Class gift.  A class gift is not but migh t become invalid under section 111 and the 11 
time has arrived when the share of any class member is to take effect in possession or 12 
enjoyment; or  13 
3.  Certain nonvested property interest not validated.  A nonvested property 14 
interest that is not validated by s ection 111, subsection 1, paragraph A can vest but not 15 
within 90 years after its creation.  16 
§114.  Exclusions from statutory rule against perpetuities  17 
Section 111 does not apply to:  18 
1.  Nonvested property interest or power of appointment arising out of 19 
nond onative transfer; exceptions.   A nonvested property interest or a power of 20 
appointment arising out of a nondonative transfer, except a nonvested property interest or 21 
a power of appointment arising out of:  22 
A.  A premarital or postmarital agreement;  23 
B.  A separation or divorce settlement;  24 
C.  A spouse’s election;  25 
D.  An arrangement similar to those described in paragraphs A, B and C arising out 26 
of a prospective, existing or previous marital relationship between the parties;  27 
E.  A contract to make or not to re voke a will or trust;  28 
F.  A contract to exercise or not to exercise a power of appointment;  29 
G.  A transfer in satisfaction of a duty of support; or  30 
H.  A reciprocal transfer;  31 
2.  Fiduciary’s power.   A fiduciary's power relating to the administration or 32 
management of assets, including the power of a fiduciary to sell, lease or mortgage 33 
property, and the power of a fiduciary to determine principal and income;  34 
3.  Power to appoint fiduciary.  A power to appoint a fiduciary;  35 
 
 Page 374 - 128LR0452(01) -1 
 4.  Discretionary power of trustee t o distribute.  A discretionary power of a trustee 1 
to distribute principal before termination of a trust to a beneficiary having an indefeasibly 2 
vested interest in the income and principal;  3 
5.  Nonvested property interest held by charity, government or gove rnmental 4 
agency or subdivision.  A nonvested property interest held by a charity, government or 5 
governmental agency or subdivision if the nonvested property interest is preceded by an 6 
interest held by another charity, government or governmental agency or s ubdivision;  7 
6.  Not subject to rule or excluded by other statute.  A property interest, power of 8 
appointment or arrangement that was not subject to the common law rule against 9 
perpetuities or is excluded by another statute of this State; or  10 
7.  Trusts to w hich rule does not apply.  A trust in which the governing instrument 11 
provides that the rule against perpetuities does not apply to the trust and under which the 12 
trustee or other individual to whom the power is properly granted or delegated has the 13 
power un der the governing instrument, applicable statute or common law to sell, 14 
mortgage or lease property for any period of time beyond the period that is required for 15 
an interest created under the governing instrument to vest.  This subsection applies to all 16 
trusts created by will or inter vivos instrument executed or amended on or after 17 
September 18, 1999 and to all trusts created by exercise of power of appointment granted 18 
under instruments executed or amended on or after September 18, 1999.  19 
§115.  Application  20 
1.  Nonvested property interest or a power of appointment created prior to 21 
effective date of this chapter.  This subsection governs nonvested property interests and 22 
powers of appointment created prior to the effective date of this chapter.  23 
A.  Except as pr ovided in section 116, subsection 1, this chapter may not be 24 
construed to invalidate or modify the terms of any limitation that would have been 25 
valid prior to August 20, 1955.  26 
B.  This chapter applies only to inter vivos instruments taking effect after Aug ust 20, 27 
1955, to wills if the testator dies after August 20, 1955 and to appointments made 28 
after August 20, 1955, including appointments by inter vivos instruments or wills 29 
under powers created before August 20, 1955.  30 
C.  Section 114, subsection 7 applies to all trusts created by will or inter vivos 31 
instrument executed or amended on or after September 18, 1999 and to all trusts 32 
created by exercise of power of appointment granted under instruments executed or 33 
amended on or after September 18, 1999.  34 
D.   If a nonvested property interest or a power of appointment was created before the 35 
effective date of this chapter and is determined in a judicial proceeding, commenced 36 
on or after the effective date of this chapter, to violate this State's rule against 37 
perpetui ties as that rule existed before the effective date of this chapter, a court upon 38 
the petition of an interested person may reform the disposition in the manner that 39 
most closely approximates the transferor's manifested plan of distribution and so that 40 
the reformed disposition is within the limits of the rule against perpetuities applicable 41 
when the nonvested property interest or power of appointment was created.  42 
 
 Page 375 - 128LR0452(01) -1 
 2.  Nonvested property interest or a power of appointment created on or after 1 
effective date of this chapter.  Except as provided by subsection 1, paragraph D, this 2 
chapter applies to a nonvested property interest or a power of appointment that is created 3 
on or after the effective date of this chapter.  4 
3.  Creation by exercise of a power of appointme nt.  For purposes of this section, a 5 
nonvested property interest or a power of appointment created by the exercise of a power 6 
of appointment is created when the power is irrevocably exercised or when a revocable 7 
exercise becomes irrevocable.  8 
§116.  Conting ent interests  9 
1.  Specified contingency within 30 years.  Except as provided in subsection 2, a fee 10 
simple determinable in land or a fee simple in land subject to a right of entry for 11 
condition broken becomes a fee simple absolute if the specified continge ncy does not 12 
occur within 30 years from the date when the fee simple determinable or the fee simple 13 
subject to a right of entry becomes possessory.  If the specified contingency occurs within 14 
the 30 years, the succeeding interest, which may be an interest in a person other than the 15 
individual creating the interest or that individual's heirs, becomes possessory or the right 16 
of entry exercisable notwithstanding the rule against perpetuities.  17 
2.  Contingency within period.  If a fee simple determinable in land  or a fee simple 18 
in land subject to a right of entry for condition broken is so limited that the specified 19 
contingency must occur, if at all, within the period of the rule against perpetuities, the 20 
interests take effect as limited.  21 
3.  Not applicable to pu blic, charitable or religious purposes; grant to State or 22 
political subdivision.  This section does not apply:  23 
A.  If both the fee simple determinable and the succeeding interest or both the fee 24 
simple and the right of entry are for public, charitable or r eligious purposes; or  25 
B.  To a deed, gift or grant to the State or any political subdivision of the State.  26 
§117.  Application of provisions  27 
This chapter applies to both legal and equitable interests.  28 
§118.  Supersession  29 
This chapter supersedes the rule of the common law known as the rule against 30 
perpetuities and it replaces chapter 5.  31

Sec. C -108.  39-A MRSA §104, first ¶, as amended by PL 1995, c. 297, §1, is 14 
further amended to read:  15 
An employer who has secured the payment of compen sation in conformity with 16 
sections 401 to 407 is exempt from civil actions, either at common law or under sections 17 
901 to 908; Title 14, sections 8101 to 8118; and Title 18-A 18-C, section 2-804 2-807, 18 
involving personal injuries sustained by an employee a rising out of and in the course of 19 
employment, or for death resulting from those injuries.  An employer that uses a private 20 
employment agency for temporary help services is entitled to the same immunity from 21 
civil actions by employees of the temporary help  service as is granted with respect to the 22 
employer's own employees as long as the temporary help service has secured the payment 23 
of compensation in conformity with sections 401 to 407.  "Temporary help services" 24 
means a service where an agency assigns its  own employees to a 3rd party to work under 25 
the direction and control of the 3rd party to support or supplement the 3rd party's work 26 
force in work situations such as employee absences, temporary skill shortages, seasonal 27 
work load conditions and special as signments and projects.  These exemptions from 28 
liability apply to all employees, supervisors, officers and directors of the employer for 29 
any personal injuries arising out of and in the course of employment, or for death 30 
resulting from those injuries.  Thes e exemptions also apply to occupational diseases 31 
sustained by an employee or for death resulting from those diseases.  These exemptions 32 
do not apply to an illegally employed minor as described in section 408, subsection 2.  33 
SUMMARY  34 
This bill, which is being  submi tted pursuant to Resolve 2015 , chapter 73, section 1, 35 
recodifies and revises the Maine Revised Statutes, Title 18 -A and amends other laws 36 
affected by this recodifica tion and revision accordingly.  37 
Resolve 2013, chapters 5 and 82 directed the Probate a nd Trust Law Advisory 38 
Commission to review the existing Probate Code and the latest version of the Uniform 39 
Probate Code and develop legislative recommendations based on the review.  The 40 
Probate and Trust Law Advisory Commission submitted legislative recomm endations in a 41 
report to the Joint Standing Committee on Judiciary of the 127th Legislature on 42 
 
 Page 408 - 128LR0452(01) -1 
 December 6, 2014 and included revisions to the recommendations in a subsequent report 1 
submitted November 20, 2015.  The purpose of this bill is to adopt the Unif orm Probate 2 
Code as the Maine Uniform Probate Code, incorporating the changes recommended by 3 
the Probate and Trust Law Advisory Commission , and to reorganize the Probate Code to 4 
be more logical, while bringing the language into conformity with current draf ting 5 
standards, clarifying current law and eliminating inconsistencies within Title 18 -A. 6
